shall occur immediately following the consideration of the minutes for the next
preceding City Council meeting.
   B.   The terms of all officers elected to fill a vacancy shall commence
immediately upon the qualification of such elected officer for such office in
accordance with the law.
   C.   The terms of all appointive officers and employees shall commence upon
appointment and qualification for said office as provided by law, which
appointment shall be for a period of time ending at twelve o’clock (12:00)
midnight on the third Monday of the month of May next ensuing, or until a
successor of the appointee is duly appointed and qualified.
(1980 Code § 13-8) (Ord. 2612, 5-25-2021)
1-10-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Each head of a department and all officials or employees handling funds of the
City shall, at the beginning of each fiscal year, enter into a bond to the
City, conditioned on the faithful discharge of his or her duties according to
law. Each bond shall be in the principal sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) or in a principal amount equal to twice the amount of funds which
said official or employee will normally have in his or her possession,
whichever is the greater in amount.
(1980 Code § 13-2)
1-10-3: COMPENSATION:
   A.   Officers And Employees:
      1.   Mayor: The salary of the Mayor is hereby fixed at the sum of twelve
thousand dollars ($12,000.00) per year, payable in equal monthly installments.
In addition thereto, the Mayor shall receive for all Council and committee
meetings the same rate of compensation as the Alderpersons receive.
      2.   Alderpersons: Each Alderperson shall receive for his or her services
sixty five dollars ($65.00) for each regular meeting of the City Council and
for each claims committee meeting and for each special meeting and adjourned
meeting attended, and forty five dollars ($45.00) each for all other committee
meetings attended, payable monthly.
(Ord. 2273, 8-12-2007)
      3.   City Clerk: The salary of the City Clerk is hereby fixed at the sum
of three thousand six hundred dollars ($3,600.00) per year, payable in equal
monthly installments.
(Ord. 2275, 10-29-2008)
      4.   City Treasurer: The salary of the City Treasurer is hereby fixed at
the sum of three thousand six hundred dollars ($3,600.00) per year, payable
monthly; provided, however, that the Treasurer shall receive an additional
fifty dollars ($50.00) for each annual report and accounting when made and
published according to law.
(Ord. 2462, 8-23-2016)
      5.   City Attorney: Retainer of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year
for full Council meeting or one hundred ninety dollars ($190.00) per hour.
(1980 Code § 14-5)
      6.   Building Official (see also section
2-1-7 of this Code): The salary of the Building Official of the City is hereby
established in the amount of twenty four dollars ($24.00) per hour.
(Ord. 1794, 9-5-1995)
      7.   Judges Of Election: All judges of election at City elections shall
each be paid the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day for their
services.
(1980 Code § 14-6)
      8.   Other Compensation: All other officers and employees whose salaries
or compensation is not fixed by ordinance shall receive such salaries or
compensation as the City Council, by resolution. shall from time to time
provide.
(1980 Code § 14-7)
   B.   Expenses: The officers and officials of the City shall be compensated
for the expense of office, including meals, lodging, travel and mileage, when
using a personal vehicle when attending to the business of the City, and shall
be compensated for mileage at such rate as is and may from time to time be
established for tax purposes by the Internal Revenue Service.
(1980 Code § 14-10)
   C.   Temporary Suspensions: Nothing in this Code shall create an absolute
right in any official or employee to receive his or her entire annual salary,
or other compensation, where it is necessary on the part of the City Council to
make a temporary suspension of the services of one or more officials or
employees because of the lack of City funds with which to pay for the suspended
services.
(1980 Code § 14-8)
   D.   Work-Related Accidents:
      1.   All employees of the City sustaining work-related accidents shall be
compensated during the incapacity of said employee on account of said accident,
if the incapacity is of the duration of eight (8) weeks or less, and if the
duration of the incapacity exceeds eight (8) weeks, for the first eight (8)
weeks of the incapacity, on the following basis: a) each employee shall, during
said period of time, receive from the City such sums which, together with all
workers' compensation payments for loss of time or wages during said period and
together with all temporary disability pension payments during said period,
shall equal the normal and regular basic compensation being received by the
employee; b) to be eligible for the payments, each employee shall furnish to
the City Collector the certificate in writing of a physician duly licensed to
practice medicine in the State of Illinois certifying that the employee is
unable to fulfill and perform his regular duties on account of a work- related
accident, and the employee shall also make in writing an application to the
City, in which application the employee shall agree to reimburse the City for
such sums received from workers' compensation and pension funds during said
period, which sums are compensations for the employee's loss of time, should
the City in the first instance pay the employee during his disability his full
and regular salary or compensation.
      2.   The intent of this subsection is to provide the injured employee
during said period of time with financial stability, and the further intent of
this subsection is that during said period of time, the total receipts of the
employee from all sources for loss of time shall equal but not exceed the
regular and normal compensation (overtime excluded) being received by the
employee at the time of the accident.
(1980 Code § 14-9)
1-10-4: CONSERVATORS OF THE PEACE:
The Mayor, members of the City Council, members of the Fire Department, as well
as every member of the Police Department are hereby declared to be conservators
of the peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to the conservators
of the peace by statute.
(1980 Code § 13-10)
1-10-5: LIMITATION ON POWER TO CONTRACT OR PURCHASE:
No committee of the City Council, nor any member of the City Council, nor any
other officer or employee of the City shall expend or contract for the
expenditure of any monies belonging to the City, or incur liability on the part
of the City, without the prior authority of the City Council so to do, or
unless authorized so to do by ordinance or resolution of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 2-24)
1-10-6: PERSONNEL POLICY ADOPTED:
The City Personnel Policy, and any amendments thereto, is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out at length herein. Three (3) copies are on file in the
Office of the City Clerk for public use and inspection.
(2019 Code)
ARTICLE A: CITY COLLECTOR
Section
1-10A-1: Office Created; Appointment
1-10A-2: Oath And Bond
1-10A-3: Duties
1-10A-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of City Collector, an executive office of
the City. The City Collector shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the
consent of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 5-6)
1-10A-2: OATH AND BOND:
The City Collector shall, before entering upon the duties of his office,
execute the oath required by law and shall also make, execute and give a bond
in the penal sum of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), with sureties to
be approved by the City Council for the faithful performance of the duties of
his office and for the full accounting for and payment of all monies received
by the Collector, according to the law and the ordinances of the City.
(1980 Code § 5-7)
1-10A-3: DUTIES:
   A.   General Duties: The City Collector shall collect all water bills, sewer
rentals, garbage bills, special assessments, and all other sums and monies due
the City, the collection of which is not specifically imposed upon the City
Clerk, City Treasurer, or other officials of the City government.
   B.   Annual Statement: As required by 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-125, between April 1
and 10 of each year, the City Collector shall file with the City Clerk a
statement of: 1) all the monies collected by him during the year; 2) the
particular warrant, special assessment, or account on which collected; 3) the
balance of money uncollected on all warrants in his possession; and 4) the
balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return on all warrants which
he returned to the City Clerk during the preceding fiscal year.
(1980 Code § 5-6)
   C.   Deposits And Records:
      1.   The City Collector shall deposit daily all monies collected by him
in such bank as the City Council from time to time may designate, and said
deposits shall be made in the name of the City Treasurer, for which the
Collector shall take duplicate deposit slips, one of which shall be filed with
his reports to the City Council.
      2.   The Collector shall annually, between August 1 and 15 of each year,
file with the City Clerk and with the City Treasurer a verified report of all
monies collected by him during the year, and of all accounts and monies due the
City and uncollected.
   D.   Additional Duties: The Collector shall also perform such other and
additional duties as the City Council or Mayor may from time to time designate
or prescribe.
(1980 Code § 5-8)
ARTICLE B: CITY ATTORNEY
Section
1-10B-1: Office Created; Appointment
1-10B-2: Powers And Duties
1-10B-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the Office of City Attorney, an executive office of the
City. The City Attorney shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the advice
and consent of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 5-3)
1-10B-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The City Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the City and shall
render advice on all legal questions affecting the City whenever requested to
do so by any City official.
(1980 Code § 5-3)
   B.   The City Attorney shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or
actions at law or equity to which the City may be a party, or in which it may
be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer of the City on
behalf of the City, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the
City, or upon the verified or sworn complaint of any other person when, in his
judgment, the public interest shall require the same to be prosecuted.
(1980 Code § 5-4)
   C.   The City Attorney shall not be required to prosecute any suit or action
arising under the ordinances of the City when, upon investigation of the same,
he shall become satisfied that the complaint was instituted maliciously or
vexatiously, and without probable cause; and he shall be authorized to
discontinue such suit or proceeding upon such terms as may be just and
equitable.
   D.   The City Attorney shall have the power to adjust all pending litigation
and to settle the same upon the authority of the Mayor and City Council.
(1980 Code § 5-5)
ARTICLE C: BUILDING OFFICIAL
Section
1-10C-1: Position Created; Appointment
1-10C-2: Duties
1-10C-3: Enforcement Powers
Cross-reference:
   Compensation, see section
1-10-3 and 2-1-7
   Generally, see section
12-3-1 
1-10C-1: POSITION CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the position of Building Official who shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with the consent of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 5-13)
1-10C-2: DUTIES:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the Building Official to see to the enforcement
of all ordinance provisions relating to buildings or zoning and to inspect all
buildings or structures being erected or altered as frequently as may be
necessary to ensure compliance with the City ordinances.
(1980 Code § 5-14)
   B.   The appointive official designated by the City to administer and
enforce the zoning ordinance of the City, whether he be called a Building
Officer, Building Inspector, Building Official, or whatever his title, shall
attend each meeting of the Plan Commission and each meeting of any Zoning
Commission.
(1980 Code, § 12-13)
1-10C-3: ENFORCEMENT POWERS:
   A.   Stop Work Order: The Building Official shall have the power to order
all work or construction or alteration or repair of buildings in the City
stopped when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any
ordinance relating thereto, or in violation of the zoning ordinance. Work shall
not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written
permission of the official; provided, that if the stop order is an oral one, it
shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour. Such written stop
order may be served by any police officer.
(1980 Code § 5-15)
   B.   Entry Powers: The Building Official shall have the power to make or
cause to be made entry into any building or premises where the work of
altering, repairing or constructing any building or structure is going on for
the purpose of making inspections at any reasonable hour.
(1980 Code § 5-16)
   C.   Penalty For Violating Stop Work Order: Any firm, person or corporation
who shall continue work in violation of a stop order of the Building Official
shall be punished as set forth in section
1-4-1- of this Code.
(1980 Code § 5-17)
ARTICLE D: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR
Section
1-10D-1: Position Created; Appointment; Building Official May Serve As
1-10D-2: Powers
1-10D-3: Inspections
1-10D-1: POSITION CREATED; APPOINTMENT; BUILDING OFFICIAL MAY SERVE AS:
There is hereby created the position of Electrical Inspector, who shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, and who may be
the same person as the Building Official. In the event of the failure to
appoint an Electrical Inspector, the Building Official shall act as and be the
Electrical Inspector.
(1980 Code § 40-10)
1-10D-2: POWERS:
The Electrical Inspector shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to
enter any building in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose
of making an inspection or test of the electrical equipment therein; and he
shall have the authority to enforce all the ordinance provisions relating to
electrical wiring and equipment. He shall have the power to cause the current
in any wire or conduit to be turned off whenever this is necessary in an
emergency for the protection of life and property. If necessary, he may seek a
court order requiring such inspection and the compliance with the provisions of
title 11, chapter 7 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 40-11)
1-10D-3: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The Electrical Inspector shall make all inspections necessary to see to
the enforcement of the City ordinances, and no electrical wiring shall be
covered until it has been inspected.
(1980 Code § 40-12)
   B.   The Electrical Inspector shall give a certificate of approval to the
owner or person in charge of the premises which he has inspected where he finds
that the electrical apparatus and wiring therein fully comply with the
ordinances of the City.
(1980 Code § 40-13)
CHAPTER 11: ETHICS
Section
1-11-1: State Regulations Adopted
1-11-2: Definitions
1-11-3: Interpretation
1-11-4: Prohibited Acts
1-11-5: Penalties
1-11-6: Amendments
1-11-7: Unconstitutionality Of Provisions
1-11-1: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The regulations of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/5-15 and 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/10-10 through 430/10-40 of the State Officials and
Employees Ethics Act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter
referred to as the "act" in this chapter), are hereby adopted by reference and
made applicable to the officers and employees of the City to the extent
required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
(2019 Code)
1-11-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the terms “officer” and “employee” shall be
defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
(2019 Code)
1-11-3: INTERPRETATION:
This chapter does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of City officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less
restrictive than this chapter, however, the provisions of this chapter shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/
70-5(a).
(2019 Code)
1-11-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Gifts:
      1.   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited
or accepted under the act by any officer or any employee of the City is hereby
prohibited.
      2.   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to
any officer or employee of the City under the act is hereby prohibited.
   B.   Political Activities: The participation in political activities
prohibited under the act by any officer or employee of the City is hereby
prohibited.
(2019 Code)
1-11-5: PENALTIES:
The penalties for violations of this chapter shall be the same as those
penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar
violations of the act.
(2019 Code)
1-11-6: AMENDMENTS:
Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date hereof
shall be incorporated into this chapter by reference and shall be applicable to
the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited
political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional
for adoption by the City shall not be incorporated into this chapter by
reference without formal action by the City.
(2019 Code)
1-11-7: UNCONSTITUTIONALITY OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this chapter shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
Supreme Court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This chapter shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the Corporate Authorities of the City if the act is found unconstitutional by
the Illinois Supreme Court.
   B.   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the act unconstitutional
but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not
address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act, as adopted by
this chapter, shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this
chapter relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed
repealed without further action by the Corporate Authorities of the City.
(2019 Code)
CHAPTER 12: ACCESS TO PUBLIC RECORDS
Section
1-12-1: FOIA Officers Designated; General Provisions
1-12-2: FOIA Officer Training
1-12-3: Written Request
1-12-4: Retrieval Of Request
1-12-5: Fees
1-12-6: Denial Of Request
1-12-7: Directories, Subdivision Diagram And Records Catalog
1-12-1: FOIA OFFICERS DESIGNATED; GENERAL PROVISIONS:
The Administrative Assistant of the City is hereby designated as the FOIA
Officer to whom all initial requests for access to the records the City are to
be referred. Such requests are to be made at the Office of the City at 201 N.
Brianna Dr., P.O. Box 338, Watseka, Illinois 60970, between the hours of eight
thirty o'clock (8:30) A.M. and four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M., Monday through
Friday. In the event that the Administrative Assistant is not available during
the times described above, the City Attorney is designated as the Deputy FOIA
Officer to whom such initial requests are to be made. Except in instances when
records are furnished immediately, the FOIA Officer, or his/her designees,
shall receive requests submitted to the City under the Freedom of Information
Act (5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.), ensure that the City responds to requests in a
timely fashion, and issue responses under the act. The FOIA Officer shall
develop a list of documents or categories of records that the City shall
immediately disclose upon request.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
1-12-2: FOIA OFFICER TRAINING:
The FOIA Officer and Deputy FOIA Officer shall, within six (6) months after
January 1, 2010, successfully complete an electronic training curriculum to be
developed by the Public Access Counselor of the State of Illinois and
thereafter successfully complete an annual training program. Whenever a new
Freedom of Information Officer is designated by the City, that person shall
successfully complete the electronic training curriculum within thirty (30)
days after assuming the position.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
1-12-3: WRITTEN REQUEST:
Upon receiving a request for a public record, the FOIA Officer shall:
   A.   Note the date the City receives the written request;
   B.   Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and make a
notation of that date on the written request;
   C.   Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including
all documents submitted with the request, until there has been compliance with
or denial of the request; and
   D.   Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of the
response, a record of written communications with the requester, and a copy of
other communications.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
1-12-4: RETRIEVAL OF REQUEST:
Any records which are the subject of a request under the Freedom of Information
Act shall be retrieved from such place as they are stored, by the FOIA Officer,
or by an employee of the City acting under the direction of the FOIA Officer.
In no event shall records be retrieved by the party requesting them or by any
person who is not employed by the City.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
1-12-5: FEES:
If copies of records are requested, the fees for such copies, whether certified
or not, shall be as determined from time to time by the FOIA Officer pursuant
to section 6(b) of the Freedom of Information Act (5 ILCS 140/6(b)). The City
shall maintain a written schedule of current fees in the City Office. The fees
so charged shall reflect the actual cost of copying the records and the cost of
certifying copies, if certification is requested.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
1-12-6: DENIAL OF REQUEST:
In the event that a request to inspect City records is denied by the FOIA
Officer, the denial may be appealed to the Public Access Counselor of the State
of Illinois.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
1-12-7: DIRECTORIES, SUBDIVISION DIAGRAM AND RECORDS CATALOG:
The City Clerk shall prepare: a) a City Information Directory; b) a block
diagram of the functional subdivisions of the City; c) a City Records
Directory; and d) a Records Catalogue, all of which shall be substantially in
the same form as the documents attached to ordinance 2325 and made a part
hereof as exhibits A, B, C, and D. This information shall also be posted on the
City's website, if any.
(Ord. 2325, 7-27-2010)
CHAPTER 13: OFFICIAL COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND OFFICIAL MAP
Section
1-13-1: Official Comprehensive Plan And Official Map Described
1-13-2: Copies On File And Available
1-13-3: Initiating And Amending Plans And Maps; Adoption
1-13-1: OFFICIAL COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND OFFICIAL MAP DESCRIBED:
An official comprehensive plan, or any amendment thereof or addition thereto,
proposed by the Plan Commission shall be effective in the City and contiguous
area herein prescribed only after its formal adoption by the City Council. Such
plan shall be advisory and in and of itself shall not be construed to regulate
or control the use of private property in any way, except as to such part
thereof as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the City Council.
At any time or times, before or after the adoption of the Official
Comprehensive Plan by the City Council, the Council may designate by ordinance
an Official Map, which map may consist of the whole area included within the
Official Comprehensive Plan or one or more separate geographical or functional
parts, and may include all or any part of the contiguous unincorporated area
within one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits of the City.
Such map or maps shall be made a part of the said ordinance, which ordinance
shall specifically state standard requirements of the City relating to size of
streets, alleys, public ways, parks, playgrounds, other public grounds, and
ways for public service facilities; the kind and quantity of materials which
shall be used in the construction of streets, and alleys; and the kind and
quality of materials for public service facilities as may be consistent with
Illinois Commerce Commission or industry standards, and shall contain the
standards required for drainage and sanitary sewers and collection and
treatment of sewage. The map shall be drawn to scale, shall be reasonably
accurate, and shall show north point, section lines and numbers, and streams.
(1980 Code § 12-5)
1-13-2: COPIES ON FILE AND AVAILABLE:
The Official Comprehensive Plan and the ordinance or ordinances, including the
Official Map, shall be placed on file with the City Clerk and shall be
available at all times during business hours for public inspection. Copies of
said plan, all ordinances implementing the same and including the Official Map,
shall be made available to all interested parties upon payment of such sum as
the City Council shall determine to be adequate to reimburse the General Fund
of the City for the cost of printing and distributing the same.
(1980 Code § 12-5)
1-13-3: INITIATING AND AMENDING PLANS AND MAPS; ADOPTION:
   A.   The City Council may initiate plans and maps by requesting the Plan
Commission to prepare an Official Comprehensive Plan and recommend the same, or
may originate an Official Comprehensive Plan, or a part thereof, or an
amendment thereto, and may refer same or suggested changes in an existing
Comprehensive Plan to the Plan Commission for its consideration and
recommendation thereon. No Comprehensive Plan or amendment thereto shall be
adopted that has not been submitted to the Plan Commission.
   B.   The City Council may adopt parts of a Comprehensive Plan recommended by
the Plan Commission without adopting the entire Comprehensive Plan as
recommended, or may modify or amend portions of a recommended Comprehensive
Plan without a re-reference of same to the Plan Commission, and may adopt such
Comprehensive Plan, as modified or amended. Such Comprehensive Plan, when
adopted, shall be the Official Comprehensive Plan, or part thereof of the City.
   C.   Upon submission by the City Council of any suggested Comprehensive
Plan, part thereof, or amendment to an existing Comprehensive Plan to the Plan
Commission for consideration and recommendation, the City Council may require a
report thereon from the Plan Commission with its recommendation within ninety
(90) days from the date of such submission, and if the Plan Commission shall
fail to make such report within such ninety (90) days, then the City Council
may proceed to consider such Comprehensive Plan, or part thereof, or amendment
to an existing Comprehensive Plan, for adoption, including arranging for and
holding of a public hearing thereon in accordance with the provisions
hereinafter contained in the same manner as if the Plan Commission had made its
recommendation.
   D.   An Official Comprehensive Plan, or any amendment thereof, shall not be
adopted by the City until notice and opportunity for public hearing have first
been afforded in the manner herein provided. Upon submission of a Comprehensive
Plan by the Plan Commission, or a proposed amendment to an existing....
   E.   Within ninety (90) days after the conclusion of the hearing, the City
Council, after consideration of the recommendation of the Plan Commission and
such information as shall have been derived from the hearing, shall either
adopt the Comprehensive Plan or amendment in whole or in part or reject the
entire Comprehensive Plan or amendment. If adopted, the City Council shall
enact an ordinance including a map or maps as hereinbefore provided. In
adopting an Official Comprehensive Plan, except as herein otherwise provided,
the City Council shall be subject to the same limitations as to subject matter
as apply to the Plan Commission. If at the expiration of such ninety (90) days,
the City Council has taken no formal action, the Comprehensive Plan or
amendment thereto may thereafter not be acted upon by the City Council without
again complying with the conditions of notice and hearing heretofore provided.
   F.   No Official Map, or amendment or addition thereto, shall be ground for
rejection of any plat of subdivision or resubdivision by the City Council, if
application for final approval of such subdivision or resubdivision is filed
with the City Council fifteen (15) days or more prior to the date on which the
ordinance approving the Official Map, or amendment or addition thereto, is
adopted.
   G.   The Comprehensive Plan, or amendment, shall become effective upon the
expiration of ten (10) days after the date of filing notice of the adoption of
such Comprehensive Plan, or amendment, with the County Recorder of Deeds.
Whenever used in this section, the words "plans" or "Comprehensive Plan" shall
be deemed to mean and include, where applicable, an Official Map or Maps.
(1980 Code § 12-6)
TITLE 2: BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter
PLAN COMMISSION   1
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS   2
LIBRARY AND LIBRARY BOARD OF DIRECTORS   3
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD   4
CHAPTER 1: PLAN COMMISSION
Section
2-1-1: Commission Created; Composition; Appointment
2-1-2: Terms Of Office
2-1-3: Organization
2-1-4: Powers And Duties
2-1-5: Public Improvements
2-1-6: Staff And Technical Advisors
2-1-7: Compensation
2-1-1: COMMISSION CREATED; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created a Plan Commission for the City which shall consist of
eight (8) members to include the following:
   A.   The Mayor shall be an ex officio member of the Plan Commission, with
power to vote.
   B.   Seven (7) other members, citizens of the City or residents of territory
contiguous to the City and not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond
the corporate limits, as is provided by statute, shall be appointed by the
Mayor, on the basis of their particular fitness for their duty on the Plan
Commission, subject to the approval of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 12-1)
2-1-2: TERMS OF OFFICE:
Ex officio members shall serve for the term of their elective office. Of the
seven (7) appointed citizens, each shall serve for a period of seven (7) years,
on a staggered term basis, with the term of one member expiring at the end of
each fiscal year. Vacancies shall be filled by appointments for unexpired terms
only.
(1980 Code § 12-2)
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Immediately following their appointment, the members of the Plan
Commission shall meet, organize and elect such officers as it may deem
necessary, and adopt and later change or alter, rules and regulations of
organization and procedure consistent with City ordinances and State laws. The
commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which shall be open
at all times to public inspection. The commission shall also file an annual
report with the Mayor and City Council setting forth its transactions and
recommendations.
(1980 Code § 12-3)
   B.   The Plan Commission shall hold at least one regular meeting of the
commission each month, at a time and place to be fixed or determined by the
commission.
(1980 Code § 12-12)
2-1-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Plan Commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To prepare and recommend to the City Council a comprehensive plan of
public improvements looking to the present and future development and growth of
the City. Such a plan, after its adoption by the City Council, will be known as
the Official Plan. Such plan shall include reasonable requirements in reference
to streets, alleys, and public grounds within the corporate limits and in
contiguous territory outside of and distant not more than one and one-half (11/
2) miles from such limits, and not included in any city or village, such
requirements to be effective whenever the lands shall be subdivided after the
adoption of the plan (see title 1, chapter 13 of this Code).
   B.   To prepare and recommend to the City Council, from time to time, such
changes in the plan or any part thereof as may be deemed necessary by the City
Council or by the Plan Commission.
   C.   To prepare and recommend to the City Council from time to time plans
and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the Official
Plan.
   D.   To give aid to the City officials charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the Official Plan, to further the
making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the
Official Plan.
   E.   To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities
for the general purpose of public understanding.
   F.   To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other
agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure
harmonious and integrated planning for the area.
   G.   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by statute.
   H.   To act as a Zoning Commission on all applications for special use under
title 12, chapter 3, article C of this Code and applications for amendment
under title 12, chapter 3, article D of this Code.
(1980 Code § 12-4)
2-1-5: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
The City Clerk shall furnish the Plan Commission, for its consideration, a copy
of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any
nature. The Plan Commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a report
necessary or advisable, for the consideration of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 12-10)
2-1-6: STAFF AND TECHNICAL ADVISORS:
The commission may, at the direction of the City Council, employ necessary help
whose salaries, wages, and other necessary expenses shall be provided for by
appropriation made by the City Council from public funds. If the Plan
Commission shall deem it advisable to secure technical advice or services, it
may be done upon authority from the City Council and appropriations by the City
Council therefor.
(1980 Code § 12-11)
2-1-7: COMPENSATION:
Each member of the Zoning Committee and Plan Commission and the enforcing
officer appointed to administer the zoning ordinance of the City (see also
subsection
1-10-36A of this Code) shall be paid the sum of fifty five dollars ($55.00) for
each meeting. The Building Inspector shall be paid twenty four dollars ($24.00)
per hour.
(1980 Code § 12-14)
CHAPTER 2: BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
Section
2-2-1: Board Created; Appointment
2-2-2: Terms Of Office
2-2-3: Qualifications
2-2-4: Oath And Bond
2-2-5: Removal From Office
2-2-6: Powers And Duties Generally
2-2-7: Appointments And Hires
2-2-8: Vacant Positions
2-2-9: Compensation
2-2-10: Advertising For Applicants
2-2-1: BOARD CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners which shall
consist of three (3) members. The members of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners are appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the
City Council. No such appointments shall be made by any Mayor within thirty
(30) days before the expiration of his term of office.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018; amd. Ord. 2687, 9-26-2023)
2-2-2: TERMS OF OFFICE:
The members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall serve three-
year terms and until their successors have been appointed and duly qualified.
The members shall serve staggered terms with not more than three (3) terms
commencing in any given year.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
2-2-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
Members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be residents of
Iroquois County and otherwise meet the qualifications of section 10-2.1-3 of
the Illinois Municipal Code.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
2-2-4: OATH AND BOND:
Each member of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall take an oath of
office and shall execute and deliver to the City a bond in the sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the performance of the duties of his office.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
2-2-5: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be subject to
removal from office in the same manner as other officers of the City.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
2-2-6: POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY:
Except as otherwise provided herein, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
shall have all powers, duties and authority concerning the hiring, appointment,
promotion, demotion, removal, suspension or discharge over full-time sworn
members of the Police and Fire Departments as provided in the provisions of the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners Act (65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.) and
shall have the power to make rules and regulations as long as they do not
conflict with the ordinances of the City.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
2-2-7: APPOINTMENTS AND HIRES:
   A.   Full-Time Sworn Police And Fire Department Members: Except as otherwise
provided in this Code, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall appoint
all full-time sworn officers of the Police and Fire Departments pursuant to the
provisions of Article 10, Division 2.1, of the Illinois Municipal Code. All
full-time sworn members of the Police Department must be certified by the
Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board before assuming active duty.
   B.   Lateral Hires Of Police Officers:
      1.   In addition to the original appointment list established pursuant to
the provisions of subsection A, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners are
also authorized to appoint full-time sworn members of the Police Department who
have previously served as full-time or part-time sworn officers of a regular
police department in any municipal, county, or State law enforcement agency,
provided they are certified by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards
Board and have been with their respective law enforcement agency for the past
three (3) years.
      2.   Applicants as lateral hires shall be ranked in order of their
relative excellence, experience and qualifications as determined by the Board
of Fire and Police Commissioners.
      3.   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is authorized to
establish the application process for lateral hires which shall include, but is
not limited to, the submission of a written application, oral interview(s), a
background investigation, a physical examination and a psychological
examination. However, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is authorized
to waive the physical and psychological examinations.
      4.   All lateral hires shall serve a one-year probationary period.
   C.   Officers: The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall elect a
chairman and vice chairman from its members to serve during the municipal
fiscal year. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may employ a Secretary
or may designate one of its own members to act as such. The Secretary shall
keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers
pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all
examinations held, and shall perform such other duties as the board shall
prescribe.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018; amd. Ord. 2642, 4-26-2022)
2-2-8: VACANT POSITIONS:
   A.   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners has the discretion to fill
any vacancy through either the original appointment list or through the lateral
hire application process. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is
authorized to select any of the four (4) highest ranking candidates on the
original appointment list or the most qualified lateral hire applicant.
   B.   All hires shall be at the patrol officer level, with seniority
commencing on the first working day as a member of the Police Department.
   C.   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall establish an
expiration date for the original appointment list and is authorized to prepare
a new original appointment list even if a vacancy exists. All applications for
lateral hires shall be retained by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
for two (2) years.
   D.   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is not required to appoint a
lateral hire if a vacancy exists.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
2-2-9: COMPENSATION:
Each member of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be compensated
for each meeting attended at the rate of fifty-five dollars ($55.00) per
meeting, said compensation to be paid by the City.
(1980 Code, § 12-8; amd. Ord. 2642, 4-26-2022)
2-2-10: ADVERTISING FOR APPLICANTS:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall periodically advertise for
entry level and lateral hire applicants.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
CHAPTER 3: LIBRARY AND LIBRARY BOARD OF DIRECTORS
Section
2-3-1: Library Established
2-3-2: Library Board Of Directors
2-3-3: Rules And Regulations; Violations
2-3-1: LIBRARY ESTABLISHED:
A public library and reading room shall be maintained in the City for the use
and benefit of the inhabitants of the City. The Library shall be governed by a
Board of Library Directors.
(1980 Code § 11-1)
2-3-2: LIBRARY BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
   A.   Composition; Appointment And Term: The board shall consist of nine (9)
directors to be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the consent of the City
Council. The term of the Library Directors shall be three (3) years, staggered
so that the terms expire each year.
(1980 Code §§ 11-1-1, 11-1-2)
   B.   Organization: The Library Directors shall select a President and
Secretary and shall meet at such time as the Library Board may determine.
(1980 Code § 11-3)
   C.   Duties And Functions:
      1.   The Library Board shall have charge of the operation of the City
Library and of the expenditure of all library funds.
      2.   Each year it shall file a report with the City Council containing,
among other things, an itemized statement of the expenses anticipated for the
coming year, and it shall also report in writing to the Council, with
reasonable detail, its receipts or revenues and its disbursements for the last
fiscal year.
      3.   The board shall perform such other duties and shall have such other
powers as is by law provided.
(1980 Code § 11-4)
2-3-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS; VIOLATIONS:
The Board of Library Directors shall have the power to make any reasonable
rules and regulations governing the use of the library facilities. Any person
violating any such rule shall be punished as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 11-5)
CHAPTER 4: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD
Section
2-4-1: Established
2-4-2: Officers
2-4-3: Powers And Responsibilities
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a foreign fire insurance board. The foreign fire
insurance board shall consist of not more than seven (7) and not less than thee
(3) trustees, as set forth in the bylaws of the foreign fire insurance board,
and each shall be a member of the fire department. The fire chief shall be a
trustee, who shall hold office by virtue of rank. The other trustees shall be
elected at large by the sworn members of the fire department at a meeting to be
held in June of an odd numbered year, but the terms of office shall be not less
than two (2) years and not more than four (4) years, as set forth in the bylaws
of the foreign fire insurance board. Vacancies on the board shall be filled in
the same manner as an original election at a meeting to be held no later than
sixty (60) days following the vacancy.
(Ord. 2606, 3-23-2021)
2-4-2: OFFICERS:
The trustees of the foreign fire insurance board shall elect from their
membership a chairman and a treasurer. The election of officers shall be held
annually at a meeting to be held in June. The treasurer of the foreign fire
insurance board shall give a sufficient bond to the City, to be approved by the
mayor, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his/her duties under the
Watseka City Code and the rules and regulations established by the board.
(Ord. 2606, 3-23-2021)
2-4-3: POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The foreign fire insurance board, and its officers, shall possess all powers
and responsibilities as set forth in 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 65 ILCS 5/11-10-2.
The foreign fire insurance board is authorized to make all needful rules and
regulations with respect to the board and management of money appropriated to
the board. The officers of the foreign fire insurance board shall develop and
maintain a listing of those items the board feels are appropriate expenditures
for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the fire department. All expenditures
of money shall be approved by a majority of the trustees of the foreign fire
insurance board then holding office.
(Ord. 2606, 3-23-2021)

CHAPTER 1: GENERAL FINANCE PROVISIONS
Section
3-1-1: Municipal And Fiscal Year
3-1-2: Surety Bonds
3-1-3: Deposit Of Funds; Depositories
3-1-4: Claims
3-1-5: Inventory
3-1-6: Annual Audit
3-1-7: Sale And Disposal Of City Property
3-1-8: Persons Indebted To The City of Watseka
3-1-1: MUNICIPAL AND FISCAL YEAR:
The municipal or fiscal year of the City shall commence on May 1 in each year
and end at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on the following April 30.
(1980 Code § 13-1)
3-1-2: SURETY BONDS:
Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the City is required as a prerequisite to
exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the issuance of any
license or permit or the exercise of any special privilege, the surety on such
bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in the State
of Illinois as a surety company, unless otherwise provided by ordinance.
(1980 Code § 13-3)
3-1-3: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS; DEPOSITORY:
A. Deposit Of Funds: The City Treasurer shall keep all funds and monies in his
custody belonging to the City in such places of deposit or investment as may be
designated by the City Council.
   B.   Depositories:
      1.   When a bank or other financial institution has been designated as a
depository, it shall continue as such until fourteen (14) days have elapsed
after a new depository is designated and has qualified by meeting the
requirements of this subsection.
      2.   When a new depository is designated, the City Council shall notify
the sureties of the Treasurer of that fact in writing at least seven (7) days
before the transfer of funds, if there is a transfer of funds. The Treasurer
shall be discharged from responsibility for all funds or monies that he
deposits in a designated bank or financial institution while the funds and
monies are so deposited.
      3.   a.   If Municipal funds or monies are deposited in a designated bank
or financial institution, but not in a wholly insured interest-bearing
investment account, the amount of such deposits shall not exceed seventy five
percent (75%) of the capital stock and surplus of said institution, and the
Treasurer shall be responsible for funds or monies deposited therein in excess
of this limitation.
         b.   No such bank or financial institution shall be qualified to
receive such Municipal funds or monies until it has furnished the City Council
with copies of the last two (2) sworn statements of resources and liabilities
which it is required to furnish to the auditor of public accounts or to the
comptroller of currency. Each bank or financial institution designated as a
depository for such funds or monies shall, while acting as the depository,
furnish the City Council with a copy of all statements of resources and
liabilities which it is required to furnish to the auditor of public accounts
or the comptroller of currency.
         c.   Investments in the name of the City in interest-bearing savings
accounts in banks, building and loan associations, or other financial
institutions, which are fully insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance
Corporation and which are made at the direction of the City Council, shall not
be considered in determining whether deposits in excess of seventy five percent
(75%) of the capital stock and surplus of the depository bank or financial
institution has been made.
(1980 Code § 4-12)
3-1-4: CLAIMS:
No bills, claims or expenditures of any kind or nature shall be paid and no
order drawn on the City Treasurer therefor, unless such bills or claims shall
have been regularly passed on and allowed by the City Council, specifying upon
what fund the order shall be drawn.
(1980 Code § 13-4)
3-1-5: INVENTORY:
Each head of each department shall, semi-annually, on May 1 and on November 1
of each year, submit to the City Council an inventory of the equipment,
supplies, materials, and invoices on hand.
(1980 Code § 13-5)
3-1-6: ANNUAL AUDIT:
The records and accounts of the City shall be fully audited at the end of each
fiscal year by some impartial accountant selected by the City Council for that
purpose, which audit shall be made in accordance with “The Illinois Municipal
Auditing Law (65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq.)”.
(1980 Code § 13-7)
3-1-7: SALE AND DISPOSAL OF CITY PROPERTY:
The head of each department of the City shall report to the appropriate
committee of the City Council any unused or surplus City property which may be
sold or disposed of. Such property then may be sold or disposed of as follows:
   A.   Where the committee in charge of such department shall then determine
the reasonable value of such unused or surplus property, and where the value of
such property is less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), the head of such
department is hereby authorized to sell and dispose of such property in a
reasonable manner with the approval of the committee and the Mayor.
   B.   Where the value of the property is two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) or less, the sale or disposition shall be approved by a motion of
the City Council by a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote.
   C.   Where the value of such property exceeds the amount of two thousand
five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), such property shall be sold or disposed of as
otherwise provided by law.
(1980 Code § 13-5.1)
3-1-8: PERSONS INDEBTED TO THE CITY OF WATSEKA:
   A.   No person or entity shall be issued any permit or license required
under this City Code, nor shall any permit or license be renewed, if at the
time of said application or renewal that person or entity, including any of
its, is in the arrears of any debt due and owing the City of Watseka.
   B.   No permit or license required under this City Code shall be issued or
renewed for any person or entity for or in relation to any real property
located in the City of Watseka if, at the time of said application or renewal,
there is arrearage of any debt due and owing the City of Watseka arising from
or in relation to that real property whether or not incurred by or owed by the
person or entity seeking a permit or license, or its renewal.
   C.   For purpose of this section, the word "debt" shall mean any amounts
assessed or to be remitted to the City of Watseka including, but not limited
to, fees, licenses, permits, fines, penalties, judgments, taxes, utility
charges, or for work performed by the City or its agents on real property,
whether or not memorialized in a lien. Unless a date is otherwise specified in
this City Code, amounts shall be deemed in arrears if they are not satisfied
within thirty (30) days following the invoice, billing, notice, assessment, or
accrual.
(Ord. 2629, 11-23-2021)
CHAPTER 2: CONTRACTS
ARTICLE A: PUBLIC CONTRACTS
Section
3-2A-1: Contractual Liabilities; Limitation
3-2A-2: Public Works Contracts
3-2A-3: Method Of Advertisement
3-2A-4: Contents Of Advertisement
3-2A-5: Receiving Bids
3-2A-6: Reservations
3-2A-7: Bid Bond
3-2A-8: Non-Responsive Bids
3-2A-9: Evaluation Factors
3-2A-10: Withdrawal Of Bids
3-2A-11: Execution Of Contract Documents
3-2A-12: Change Orders
3-2A-13: State And Federal Procurement Standards
3-2A-1: CONTRACTUAL LIABILITIES; LIMITATION:
Except as otherwise authorized by law, no contract shall be entered into, nor
any expense incurred, unless a prior appropriation has been made for such
contract or expense.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-2: PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTS:
No contract for any work or other public improvement, the expense of which will
exceed $25,000.00, shall be entered into or commenced unless by: (a) contract
let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for bids in the manner
prescribed herein; or (b) a vote of two-thirds of all aldermen then holding
office. Nothing herein shall require a contract to be awarded after advertising
for bids when: (i) the contract will be paid for in whole or in part by special
assessment or special taxation, (ii) the contract is for architectural,
engineering, or land surveying services, or (iii) advertising for bids is not
required by law.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-3: METHOD OF ADVERTISEMENT:
Bids shall be advertised at least ten (10) days before the due date for
responding to the call by any one or all of the following means: (a) by
publishing a call to bidders in a newspaper of general circulation in the City
of Watseka; (b) by publishing a call to bidders on the City of Watseka’s
website; or (c) by sending a call to bidders to all contractors that have
registered with the Building Official to receive such advertisements with
respect to the type of work to be performed provided not less than three (3)
contractors have registered therefor.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-4: CONTENTS OF ADVERTISEMENT:
A call to bidders shall contain such information as would allow a reasonable
person in the industry to understand the general nature and conditions of the
project, directions to obtain the contract documents, instructions for
submitting bids, and any other matters deemed pertinent by the City for
contractors to properly and efficiently respond to the call.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-5: RECEIVING BIDS:
All competitive bids must be sealed by the bidder and must be opened by a City
official or agent at a public bid opening at which the contents of the bids
shall be announced. Each bidder shall receive at least three (3) days’ notice
of the time and place of the bid opening.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-6: RESERVATIONS:
A call to bidders shall not create any legal obligation on behalf of the City
to evaluate any bid that is submitted, or to enter into any contract with a
contractor submitting a bid. At any time before the City awards a contract, it
may (a) cancel or modify a call to bidders or the contract documents in whole
or in part; (b) reject any or all bids submitted; (c) waive non-material
formalities and technicalities deemed appropriate; (d) postpone a bid opening;
(e) issue a call for new bids; and/or (f) award the contract for the project in
whole or in part, or to one or more contractors.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-7: BID BOND:
When required by the call to bidders, no bid submitted in relation to any
contract to be let shall be valid or considered unless the contractor submits
with its bid a cashier’s check, certified check or bid bond guaranteeing its
offer to contract with the City if awarded the same. The security shall be made
payable to the City, without condition, in an amount of not less than ten
percent (10%) of the aggregate bid amount. Any contractor who shall fail to
enter into a contract so awarded shall forfeit all or a portion of the bid
security up to the difference between its bid and the next lowest bid accepted
by the City, if any.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-8: NON-RESPONSIVE BIDS:
All bids will be examined for responsiveness. All bids deemed materially
unresponsive shall be rejected without further evaluation or inquiry. Non-
material or technical irregularities may be waived provided they do not put the
contractor in a competitive advantage to other contractors.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-9: EVALUATION FACTORS:
Bid evaluation guidelines may be included in the contract documents available
to a contractor to bid on a particular project. In the absence of specific bid
evaluation guidelines, the following shall apply:
   A.   All bids deemed responsive, or otherwise accepted for evaluation, shall
be evaluated and ranked according to the qualifications of the contractor,
financial stability, ability commence and complete the project in an
expeditious manner, and bid amount. The contractor most qualified for the
project will receive the highest ranking in that category and the contractor
submitting the lowest bid will receive the highest ranking in that category.
   B.   The City Engineer will examine and investigate the contractor’s past
performance history, expertise, capabilities, governmental standing with the
jurisdiction authority over any part of the project, financial resources,
employment, equipment and material availability, and outstanding projects that
may affect a contractor’s workmanship or ability to start or complete the
project in a timely manner. Any and all references listed by a contractor may
be contacted by the City. Material omissions or falsification of information
requested from the contractor will result in a disqualification from the
project and may disqualify a contractor from bidding on future projects.
   C.   Uncharacteristically low or high bids shall be examined for mistakes or
the contractor’s misunderstanding of the scope of the project. A contractor
submitting an uncharacteristically low or high bid may be contacted by the City
Engineer and questioned regarding the accuracy of the same. Neither the bid
amount nor the scope of the project may be altered in consequence of such an
inquiry, except to the extent an easily identifiable typographical or
mathematical error can be objectively implemented in such a manner that does
not affect the integrity of the bidding process. Negotiations are strictly
prohibited. Bids that are uncharacteristically low or high due to mistakes that
cannot be corrected will be rejected.
   D.   The aggregate bid score of all bids shall be transcribed in a bid
abstract. The bid abstract, score calculation sheets, information generated as
a part of the evaluation, and the recommendation of the City Engineer shall be
forwarded to the City Council for review and action.
   E.   Bid scores may be adjusted by the City Council upon review of the City
Engineer’s recommendation and evaluation records. Bid scores shall be adopted
by the City Council as presented or modified.
   F.   The bid receiving the highest aggregate bid score by the City Council
shall be considered the lowest responsible bidder, and may be awarded the
contract for the project, subject to the provision and execution of necessary
documents.
   G.   The City Engineer shall notify all contractors of the result of the bid
evaluation and award. All contractors except the two receiving the highest
aggregate bid score shall be relieved of any further responsibility for the
project, and any bid security submitted to honor the same shall be released.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-10: WITHDRAWAL OF BIDS:
Bids may be withdrawn prior to the expiration of the bidding period, but any
such withdrawal shall disqualify the contractor from the project. No bid shall
be withdrawn after the bid opening until the earlier of the consent of the City
or forty-five (45) days following the expiration of the bidding period, as may
be extended.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-11: EXECUTION OF CONTRACT DOCUMENTS:
The contractor determined to be the lowest responsible bidder shall execute and
deliver all contract documents no later than next regular City Council meeting
following the award, or fifteen (15) days after the award, whichever is last to
occur. Upon execution of the contract, the bid bond of the contractor awarded
the contract, and the contractor having the next highest aggregate bid score,
shall be released. In the event the lowest responsible bidder fails to execute
and deliver all contract documents in the time and manner prescribed, the City
may, but shall not be required to, award the contract to the next lowest
responsible bidder. If the City decides not to award the contract to the next
lowest responsible bidder, the bid security of the contractor that failed to
execute and deliver the contract documents will be forfeited in full.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-12: CHANGE ORDERS:
Any contract procured through competitive bidding that authorizes or
necessitates any increase in the contract price that is 50% or more than the
original contract price, then the portion of the contract that is covered by
the change order shall be resubmitted for bidding in the same manner as the
original contract.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
3-2A-13: STATE AND FEDERAL PROCUREMENT STANDARDS:
Nothing herein shall absolve the City from complying with such conditions as
may be imposed by the State of Illinois or the United States of America, or
their agencies, departments or officials, when the contract to be awarded by
the City is funded in whole or in part with state or federal monies, as the
case may be.
(Ord. 2569, 4-28-2020)
ARTICLE B: PUBLIC WORKS BY SPECIAL ASSESSMENT
Section
3-2B-1: Scope
3-2B-2: Preparation Of Plans
3-2B-3: Advertising For Bids
3-2B-4: Contractor’s Bond
3-2B-5: Failure Regarding Contract
3-2B-6: Conflict Of Interest
3-2B-7: Application Of Other Laws
3-2B-1: SCOPE:
All contracts for the making of any public improvements in the City, to be paid
for in whole or in part by special assessment or special taxation, shall be let
to the lowest responsible bidder therefor in the manner hereinafter prescribed,
and be approved by the Mayor and City Council.
(1980 Code § 33-2)
3-2B-2: PREPARATION OF PLANS:
Whenever any local or public improvement shall be ordered by the City Council,
which is to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment or special
taxation, it shall be the duty of the City engineer to prepare a plan or
profile of the proposed improvement and specifications for the construction of
the same, a copy of which shall be kept on file in his office and in the Office
of the City Clerk, and be open to the inspection of City officers and other
persons interested therein.
(1980 Code § 33-3)
3-2B-3: ADVERTISING FOR BIDS:
As soon as the special tax or special assessment for any such improvement shall
have been finally confirmed, as provided by law, and sooner if deemed expedient
by the Mayor and City Council, the City Clerk is authorized to advertise in one
or more newspapers of general circulation or printed or published in the City
for proposals to furnish materials and do said work according to the plans and
specifications aforesaid. The advertisement shall be published for at least
twenty one (21) days before the date fixed for opening the proposals, and shall
state the nature and extent of the improvement ordered, the place where
specifications thereof may be seen, and the time and place when and where the
bids will be opened. The right to reject any and all proposals so received
shall be reserved in the advertisement.
(1980 Code § 33-4)
3-2B-4: CONTRACTOR’S BOND:
Whenever any such work or material is let by contract to any person or
corporation, the City shall, in all cases, take a good and sufficient bond from
such person or corporation to insure the performance of the work in the time
and manner required in the contract, and to save and indemnify the City and
keep it harmless against all liabilities, judgments, costs and expenses which
may in any way accrue against the City in consequence of the granting of the
contract, or which may in any way result from the carelessness or neglect of
the person or corporation, or his or its agent, employees or workers, in any
respect whatever, and to insure and guarantee the payment of all labor and
material claims growing or arising out of the work.
(1980 Code § 33-5)
3-2B-5: FAILURE REGARDING CONTRACT:
Any bidder who shall fail to enter into any contract so awarded, or shall fail
to fulfill any contract entered into by him with the City, shall not be
permitted to bid again for any City work, unless the Council shall, for good
cause shown, remove his disability.
(1980 Code § 33-6)
3-2B-6: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
No member of the City Council or other City officer or employee shall be
interested, either directly or indirectly, in any contract with or work for the
City, or become surety for any contractor or other person upon any bond to
secure the performance of any contract with the City.
(1980 Code § 33-7)
3-2B-7: APPLICATION OF OTHER LAWS:
The provisions of article A of this chapter shall also apply to this article on
public works by special assessment, except wherein the provisions of this
article provide differently.
(1980 Code § 33-8)
CHAPTER 3: TAX RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES
Section
3-3-1: Definitions
3-3-2: Application Of Payments
3-3-3: Interest On Overdue Payments
3-3-4: Determinations Of Tax Liability
3-3-5: Appeals
3-3-6: Credits And Refunds
3-3-7: Records; Audit Procedure
3-3-8: Voluntary Disclosure
3-3-9: Lien Review
3-3-10: Penalties
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly
indicates otherwise:
CITY: The City of Watseka.
HEARING OFFICER: That person appointed as Hearing Officer under the City’s
system of administrative adjudication of nonvehicular regulation violations.
LOCAL TAX ADMINISTRATOR: That person charged with the administration or
collection of a locally imposed and administered tax, or his/her designee.
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX OR TAX: A tax imposed by the City that is
collected or administered by the City and not an agency or department of the
State of Illinois.
TAX ORDINANCE: Any ordinance adopted by the City that imposes a locally imposed
and administered tax.
TAXPAYER: Any person required to pay a locally imposed and administered tax,
which generally includes the person upon whom the legal incidence of such tax
is placed, and with respect to consumer taxes, the business or entity required
to collect and pay the tax.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-2: APPLICATION OF PAYMENTS:
Payments or remittances received for a tax period shall be applied in the
following order of priority: a) the interest due for the applicable period; b)
the tax due for the applicable period; and c) the penalty due for the
applicable period.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-3: INTEREST ON OVERDUE PAYMENTS:
Interest shall accrue on any untimely paid tax, underpaid tax or unpaid tax at
a rate of fifteen (15%) percent per annum.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-4: DETERMINATIONS OF TAX LIABILITY:
   A.   The Local Tax Administrator shall have the authority and duty to issue
determinations of tax liability to taxpayers.
   B.   The determination notice shall be issued and sent to the taxpayer by
certified mail, return receipt requested, no more than four (4) years after the
end of the calendar year in which the tax was due; however, if less than
seventy five percent (75%) of the tax was paid, a determination notice may be
issued and sent no more than six (6) years after the end of the calendar year
in which the tax was due; provided further, that if a fraudulent tax return was
filed, no period of time shall limit the issuance of a determination notice.
   C.   All determinations of tax liability shall include the following
information: 1) the reason for tax liability; 2) the amount of the tax
liability, interest, and penalties due, as well as the basis for such
calculation; 3) the procedure for appeals; and 4) information regarding the
right of the City to audit the taxpayer’s books and records for a particular
period, and its obligation to refund overpayments.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-5: APPEALS:
Any taxpayer may, within forty five (45) days of the date of receipt of a
determination of tax liability, file a written appeal of a determination of tax
liability, setting forth the basis therefor. For reasonable cause shown in
writing by the taxpayer, and full payment of the amount of the tax so
protested, plus accrued interest due, the Local Tax Administrator may extend
the forty five (45) day appeal period for an additional forty five (45) days.
The Hearing Officer shall conduct a hearing on the underlying determination and
issue a written decision as to his findings and conclusions. The formal rules
of evidence shall not apply at such hearing.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-6: CREDITS AND REFUNDS:
A taxpayer may, in writing, claim a credit or refund for the payment of taxes,
interest, or penalties paid in error for up to four (4) years after the end of
the calendar year in which the payment was made. Claims must include
information setting forth the taxpayer, applicable tax period, proof of
payment, and an explanation/calculation of any claimed error. The Local Tax
Administrator shall review each claim and issue a determination of tax
liability, and whether or not a credit or refund is justified, within thirty
(30) days of receipt of the claim.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-7: RECORDS; AUDIT PROCEDURE:
Every (prospective) taxpayer shall be subject to an audit by the Local Tax
Administrator, and each taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of the
its business and activities, including original source documents and books of
entry denoting the transactions which gave rise to or may give rise to any tax
liability, exemption, or deduction. All books shall be kept in the English
language and shall be subject to and available for inspection at the request of
the Local Tax Administrator.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-8: VOLUNTARY DISCLOSURE:
A taxpayer who has not received a written notice of an audit or determination
of a tax liability may seek disclosure of its tax liability by applying to the
Local Tax Administrator in writing for voluntary disclosure of the taxpayer’s
liability pertaining to a particular tax and agreeing to pay, within ninety
(90) days of the date of the application, the tax due, plus one percent (1%)
interest per month, for all periods that precede the filing or the application,
but not more than four (4) years prior thereto. The taxpayer shall be liable
for any underpaid taxes and accrued interest during the four-year time period
but, except for the taxes and interest due hereunder, the taxpayer shall not be
liable for any taxes imposed prior to the date of the application for voluntary
disclosure.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-9: LIEN REVIEW:
In January of each calendar year, the Local Tax Administrator shall cause all
liens filed against all taxpayers for unpaid taxes to be reviewed. Upon a
determination by the Local Tax Administrator that the lien is valid, the lien
shall remain in full force and effect. If the lien is determined to be
improper, the Local Tax Administrator shall: a) remove the lien at the City’s
expense; b) correct the taxpayer's credit record; and c) correct any public
disclosure of the improperly imposed lien.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
3-3-10: PENALTIES:
A penalty at a rate of five percent (5%) of a tax due and not timely paid or
remitted shall be assessed for late or unpaid tax payments; a penalty at a rate
of five percent (5%) of a tax required to be shown on a return shall be
assessed for late or underreported returns; and a penalty at a rate of twenty
five percent (25%) of the total tax due shall be assessed for taxes for which
no return is filed before the issuance of a notice of tax deficiency or tax
liability to the taxpayer. The Local Tax Administrator shall have the authority
to waive or abate any penalty if he/she determines that reasonable cause
existed for such deficiency.
(Ord. 2504, 5-22-2018)
CHAPTER 4: CITY TAXES
ARTICLE A: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS’ AND SERVICE OCCUPATION TAXES
Section
3-4A-1: Taxes Imposed; Rates
3-4A-2: Exemptions From Taxes
3-4A-3: Compliance With State Laws
3-4A-4: State Administration And Enforcement
3-4A-5: Cannabis Retailers’ Occupation Tax
3-4A-1: TAXES IMPOSED; RATES:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property
titled or registered with an agency of this State’s government, at retail in
the City at the rate of three-fourths percent (0.75%) of the gross receipts
from such sales made in the course of such business while this article is in
effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the City in the
business of making sales of service, at the rate of three- fourths percent
(0.75%) of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by
such service person as an incident to a sale of service.
(Ord. 1733, 9-30-1993)
3-4A-2: EXEMPTIONS FROM TAXES:
The home rule municipal retailers' occupational tax and the home rule municipal
service occupation tax shall not be applicable on the sales of food for human
consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other
than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been prepared for
immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs,
medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles
used by diabetics.
(Ord. 1733, 9-30-1993)
3-4A-3: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAWS:
The imposition of these home rule taxes are in accordance with the provisions
of sections
8-11-1 and
8-11-5, respectively, of the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended.
(Ord. 1733, 9-30-1993)
3-4A-4: STATE ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an
incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue
of the State of Illinois. The Department of Revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this article.
(Ord. 1733, 9-30-1993)
3-4A-5: CANNABIS RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of selling cannabis, other than cannabis purchased under the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, at retail in the City
at the rate of three percent (3%) of the gross receipts from these sales made
in the course of that business.
   B.   Tax Collections; Reimbursement: Each retailer shall collect and remit
to the Illinois Department of Revenue the tax imposed under this section. A
retailer may reimburse itself for its tax liability hereunder by separately
stating the tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in
combination, in a single amount, with any state tax the retailer is required to
collect.
   C.   Administration and Enforcement: The Illinois Department of Revenue
shall have full power and authority to administer and enforce the provisions of
this section. The tax imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as
an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department
of Revenue. Any tax required to be collected, and any tax collected by such
retailer and required to be remitted to the Illinois Department of Revenue,
shall constitute a debt owed by the retailer to the State.
(Ord. 2547, 9-24-2019)
ARTICLE B: MUNICIPAL USE TAX
Section
3-4B-1: Adoption Of Ordinance 1255
3-4B-1: ADOPTION OF ORDINANCE 1255:
Ordinance 1255, adopted November 18, 1974, imposing a Municipal tax of one
percent (1%) upon the privilege of using in the City any item of tangible
personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a
retailer, is incorporated herein by reference, as adopted and published.
(1980 Code § 47-3)
ARTICLE C: HOTEL OPERATORS’ OCCUPATION TAX
Section
3-4C-1: Definitions
3-4C-2: Tax Imposed; Rate; Exemptions
3-4C-3: Use Of Revenue
3-4C-4: Books And Records
3-4C-5: Certificate Of Registration Required By Business Owner
3-4C-6: Tax Return; Payment Of Tax
3-4C-7: Audits
3-4C-8: Violations
3-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following
words and terms shall have he meanings ascribed to them in this section:
HOTEL: Any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration,
obtain living quarters or sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term
includes, but is not limited to, inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging
houses, rooming houses and apartment houses, retreat centers, conference
centers and hunting lodges.
OCCUPANCY: The use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any
room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose, or the right to the use or possession
of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use
and possession of the room or rooms.
OPERATOR: Any person operating a hotel.
PERMANENT RESIDENT: Any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room
or rooms, regardless of whether or not it is the same room or rooms, in a hotel
for at least thirty (30) consecutive days.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock
company, joint adventure, public or private corporation, limited liability
company, or a receiver, executor, trustee, guardian or other representative
appointed by order of any court.
RENT OR RENTAL: The consideration received for occupancy, valued in money,
whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits
and property or services of any kind or nature.
ROOM OR ROOMS: Any living quarters or sleeping or housekeeping accommodations.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-2: TAX IMPOSED; RATE; EXEMPTIONS:
A tax is imposed upon persons engaged in the business of renting, leasing or
letting rooms in a hotel at the rate of five percent (5%) of the gross rental
receipts from such renting, leasing or letting, excluding, however, from gross
rental receipts, the proceeds of such renting, leasing or letting to permanent
residents of that hotel.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-3: USE OF REVENUE:
The revenue derived from this article may only be used to promote tourism and
conventions within the territorial boundaries of the City or to otherwise
attract nonresident overnight visitors to the City.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-4: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
   A.   Every operator shall keep separate books or records of his business as
an operator so as to show the rents and occupancies taxable under this article
separately from his transactions not taxable under this article. If any
operator fails to keep such separate books or records, he shall be liable to
tax at the rate designated in section
3-4C-2 of this article upon the entire proceeds from his hotel.
   B.   The City may adopt rules that establish requirements, including record
forms and formats, for records required to be kept and maintained by taxpayers.
   C.   For purposes of this section, “records” means all data maintained by
the taxpayer, including data on paper, microfilm, microfiche or any type of
machine-sensible data compilation.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-5: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED BY BUSINESS OWNER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of renting,
leasing or letting rooms in a hotel in the City without a certificate of
registration from the City.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-6: TAX RETURN; PAYMENT OF TAX:
   A.   Except as provided hereinafter in this section, on or before the last
day of each calendar month, every person engaged in the business of renting,
leasing or letting rooms in a hotel in the City during the preceding calendar
month shall file a return with the City, stating:
      1.   The name of the operator.
      2.   His residence address and the address of his principal place of
business and the address of the principal place of business (if that is a
different address) from which he engages in the business of renting, leasing or
letting rooms in a hotel in Watseka.
      3.   Total amount of rental receipts received by him during the preceding
calendar month from renting, leasing or letting rooms during such preceding
calendar month.
      4.   Total amount of rental receipts received by him during the preceding
