calendar month from renting, leasing or letting rooms to permanent residents
during such preceding calendar month.
      5.   Total amount of other exclusions from gross rental receipts allowed
by this article.
      6.   Gross rental receipts which were received by him during the
preceding calendar month and upon the basis of which the tax is imposed.
      7.   The amount of tax due.
   B.   The return must be signed by the owner, part owner or in the case of a
corporation, its president, vice president, secretary or treasurer and in the
case of an LLC, its manager, or in case of a trust, its trustee.
   C.   The person filing the return shall, at the time of filing, pay the City
the amount of tax imposed by this article.
   D.   If all payment is not made when due, or returns not filed when
required, the taxpayer shall be liable for:
      1.   An amount in the sum of double the tax due;
      2.   The costs of an audit by the City's accountant; and
      3.   Any and all attorney fees, court costs and related expenses incurred
in the collection of the taxes.
   E.   Any person who signs a false return shall be fined one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for each such occurrence.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-7: AUDITS:
Audits of hotels and motels are authorized under this article should the City
not receive timely returns and/or suspect that false returns have been filed.
All hotels and motels in Watseka shall allow an audit when requested by the
City. Failure to allow a timely audit will result in a fine of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00).
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
3-4C-8: VIOLATIONS:
Any person, firm or other organization who violates this article in excess of
two (2) times per calendar year may be prohibited from operating within the
City.
(Ord. 2082, 2-17-2003)
ARTICLE D: MOTOR FUEL TAX
Section
3-4D-1: Title
3-4D-2: Definitions
3-4D-3: Tax Imposed
3-4D-4: Exemptions
3-4D-5: Special Fuel Sold Or Used For Non-Highway Purposes
3-4D-6: Payment On Retail Purchase
3-4D-7: Tax Collections
3-4D-8: Registration; Return; Filing
3-4D-9: Commission On Tax Paid When Due
3-4D-10: Failure To Pay Or File; Penalties And Interest
3-4D-11: Recordkeeping
3-4D-12: Sales And Uses Presumed Taxable; Burden Of Proof
3-4D-13: Disposition Of Proceeds Of Tax
3-4D-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known and cited as the “Watseka Vehicle Fuel Tax
Ordinance.”
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them herein, except where to the context clearly
indicates a contrary meaning. Words used in the present tense shall include the
future; the singular number shall include the plural and the plural the
singular; and the word “shall” is mandatory and not directory.
CITY: The City of Watseka, Iroquois County, Illinois.
DIESEL FUEL: Any product intended for use or offered for sale as a fuel for
engines in which the fuel is injected into the combustion chamber and ignited
by pressure without electric spark.
DISTRIBUTOR: Any person who produces, refines, blends, compounds or
manufactures vehicle fuel in the city; or transports or has transported vehicle
fuel to any location in the city; or receives in the city vehicle fuel on which
the city vehicle fuel tax has not been paid; or sells vehicle fuel to a retail
dealer for resale in the city. The term shall include any person transports
vehicle fuel into the city or receives vehicle fuel in the city for his own use
and consumption, and not for sale or resale.
DYED DIESEL FUEL: Any special fuel, as defined herein, sold or used for non-
highway purposes containing only the dye Solvent Red 164 at a concentration
spectrally equivalent to at least 3.9 pounds of the solid dye standard Solvent
Red 26 per thousand barrels of special fuel. The dye must be added prior to
removal from a terminal rack.
GALLON: In addition to its ordinary meaning, its equivalent in a capacity of
measurement of substance in a gaseous state.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, limited liability company,
or a receiver, trustee, guardian, conservator, legal representative, or other
legally recognized entity.
RETAIL DEALER: Any person who is engaged in the business of selling vehicle
fuel in the city to a purchaser for the purchaser’s use or consumption, and not
for resale in any form.
SALE AT RETAIL: Any sale to a person for that person’s use or consumption and
not for resale to another.
SALE, RESALE OR PURCHASE: Any transfer of ownership or title tile or both, any
exchange or any barter, whether conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by
any means whatsoever for consideration.
SPECIAL FUEL: All volatile and inflammable liquids capable of being used for
the generation of power in an internal combustion engine. The term includes
diesel fuel as defined in herein.
TAX: The city’s vehicle fuel tax.
TERMINAL RACK: A mechanism for dispensing vehicle fuel or fuel from a refinery,
terminal, or bulk plant into a transport truck, railroad tank car, or other
means of transportation.
USE: The exercise of any right to or power over vehicle fuel incident to the
ownership thereof, including but not limited to the receipt of vehicle fuel by
any person into a fuel supply tank of a vehicle.
VEHICLE: Is the same as “motor vehicle” as defined in The Illinois Vehicle Code
(65 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.).
VEHICLE FUEL: Is the same as “motor fuel” as defined in the Motor Fuel Tax Law
(35 ILCS 505/1 et seq.) and includes all volatile and inflammable liquids
produced, blended or compounded for the purpose of, or which are suitable or
practicable for, operating motor vehicles. The term includes without limitation
gasoline, gasohol, diesel oil, motor benzol, motor benzene, propane gas fuel,
kerosene, and special fuel.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-3: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of purchasing or using, in the city,
vehicle fuel purchased at retail. The tax shall be at a rate of $0.05 per
gallon of vehicle fuel. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of
the tax shall be on the purchaser or user of the vehicle fuel, and nothing in
this section shall be construed to impose a tax upon the occupation of selling
or distributing vehicle fuel. It shall be a violation of this section for any
distributor or retail dealer to fail to add the tax to the retail price of the
vehicle fuel or to absorb the tax. The tax shall be in addition to any and all
other taxes. The tax shall apply only to vehicle fuel delivered on or after
July 1, 2021 and shall not apply to inventory at the retail dealer on that
date.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-4: EXEMPTIONS:
The tax imposed by this article shall not apply to the following sales or uses:
   A.   Sale by a distributor to another distributor holding a valid
registration certificate;
   B.   Sale by a distributor or retailer of vehicle fuel whose place of
business is outside the city;
   C.   Sale or use for purposes other than for propulsion or operation of a
motor vehicle;
   D.   Sale of use to the extent the tax imposed by this article would violate
the state or United States Constitution;
   E.   Sale to or use by the federal government or any state or local
governmental body;
   F.   Sale to or use by any air common carrier, certified by the carrier to
be used for consumption, shipment or storage in the conduct of its business as
an air common carrier, for a flight destined for a destination outside the
United States;
   G.   Sale to or use of dyed diesel fuel for non-highway purposes in
accordance with the provisions of Section
3-4D-5; and,
   H.   Sale to or use of vehicle fuel by a commercial common carrier provided
the vehicle fuel is delivered directly to a stationary bulk storage tank
located on the property of the common carrier in the city and used only by such
common carrier for commercial vehicles engaged in interstate or intrastate
commerce (not-for-hire, property only) and registered to the common carrier.
For each sale described in this subsection, a specific notation of the nature
of the exemption must be made on the invoice for these sales. The distributor
must retain the invoice number and date, name of carrier, bill of lading/
manifest number, name and address of purchaser, and invoiced gallons sold. A
legible and conspicuous notice stating “Non-taxable Use Only, Penalty For
Taxable Use” must appear on all shipping papers (including delivery tickets or
manifests and excluding material safety data sheets), bills of lading, and
invoices accompanying any sale of dyed diesel fuel.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-5: SPECIAL FUEL SOLD OR USED FOR NON-HIGHWAY PURPOSES:
   A.   Sales or uses of dyed diesel fuel to retail dealers or other persons
other than distributors for non-highway purposes shall be exempt from the tax
provided:
      1.   The special fuel is delivered from a vehicle designed for the
specific purpose of such sales and delivered directly to a stationary bulk
storage tank that displays the following notice: “Dyed Diesel Fuel, Non-taxable
Use Only”;
      2.   The fuel is delivered from a vehicle designed for the specific
purpose of such sales and delivered directly into the fuel supply tanks of non-
highway vehicles that are not required to be registered for highway use; or,
      3.   The fuel is dispensed from a dyed diesel fuel dispensing facility
that has withdrawal facilities that are not readily accessible to and are not
capable of dispensing dyed diesel fuel into the supply tank of a motor vehicle.
   B.   For purposes of this section, a dyed diesel fuel dispensing facility is
considered to have withdrawal facilities that are “not readily accessible to,
and not capable of dispensing dyed diesel fuel into, the fuel supply tank of a
motor vehicle” only when the dyed diesel fuel is delivered from:
      1.   A dispenser hose that is short enough that it will not reach the
fuel supply tank of a motor vehicle; or
      2.   A dispenser that is enclosed by a fence or other physical barrier so
that a vehicle cannot pull alongside the dispenser to permit fueling.
   C.   For each sale of dyed diesel fuel described in this section, a specific
notation of the nature of the exemption must be made on the invoice for these
sales. The distributor must retain the invoice number and date, name of
carrier, bill of lading/manifest number, name and address of purchaser, and
invoiced gallons sold. A legible and conspicuous notice stating “Dyed Diesel
Fuel, Non-taxable Use Only, Penalty For Taxable Use” must appear on all
shipping papers (including delivery tickets or manifests and excluding material
safety data sheets), bills of lading, and invoices accompanying any sale of
dyed diesel fuel.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-6: PAYMENT ON RETAIL PURCHASE:
Use in the city shall be deemed to occur only at the place in the city where
the vehicle fuel is transferred into the motor vehicle by which it is to be
consumed. To the extent that a person has paid the tax imposed in this article
on the retail purchase of vehicle fuel, the user shall be exempt from the
payment of and liability for the tax on the use of such vehicle fuel.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-7: TAX COLLECTIONS:
   A.   The tax shall be collected by each distributor who sells such vehicle
fuel to a retail dealer doing business in the city. Any distributor who shall
pay the tax to the city shall collect the tax from any retail dealer to whom
the distributor sells vehicle fuel. Any distributor who sells vehicle fuel
directly to a purchaser or user, for delivery in the city, and not for resale,
shall collect the tax from the purchaser or user.
   B.   A retail dealer shall collect the tax from the purchaser of the vehicle
fuel. If any retail dealer receives vehicle fuel upon which the tax has not
been collected by the distributor, then the retail dealer shall remit such tax
directly to the city by the last day of the month following the month in which
he received such vehicle fuel, and shall collect such tax from his purchasers.
   C.   If any purchaser or user receives vehicle fuel upon which the tax has
not been collected by the distributor or retail dealer, such purchaser or user
shall pay the tax directly to the city by the last day of the month following
the month in which such purchaser or user made the taxable purchase or use of
the vehicle fuel.
   D.   Any person who collects the tax shall do so as a trustee for and on
account of the city.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-8: REGISTRATION; RETURN; FILING:
Every distributor doing business in the city on June 1, 2021, shall register
with the City Treasurer by June 30, 2021. Every person becoming a distributor
after that date shall register with the City Treasurer within thirty (30) days
after the commencement of such business. Every distributor shall file each
month with the City Treasurer remittance return, containing a report of his
sales of vehicle fuel to retail dealers or users in the city occurring in the
prior calendar month. For example, the tax return for the month of January
shall be filed and the tax paid on or before the last day of the ensuing
February. The return shall be in a form prescribed and furnished by the City
Treasurer. If mailed, the return must be postmarked on or before the last day
of the month following the month for which the report is due. Each such return
shall be accompanied by a remittance of the appropriate amount of tax
applicable to the sales reported. Payment shall be made to the City Treasurer.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-9: COMMISSION ON TAX PAID WHEN DUE:
A distributor or retail dealer remitting the tax to the city shall be entitled
to a commission of one percent (1%) of the tax remitted, to compensate for the
cost of collection, filing returns, and supplying information to the city, but
in no event shall any commission be allowed on any tax not remitted when due.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-10: FAILURE TO PAY OR FILE; PENALTIES AND INTEREST:
   A.   Failure to pay or remit the tax or to file the remittance return as
required by this article shall be subject to the following penalties and
interest:
      1.   Any tax not paid or remitted when due shall bear interest at the
rate of two percent (2%) per month, or fraction thereof, until the tax is paid
or remitted; and,
      2.   In addition to any interest charged, any person who fails to pay or
to remit the tax, or remittance return, when due shall be subject to a late
penalty of ten percent (10%) of such tax.
   B.   Where the failure to pay or to remit the tax or to file the remittance
return in a timely manner is due to reasonable cause beyond the control of the
person charged with filing and paying the tax, the penalties described herein
may be waived by the City Treasurer.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-11: RECORDKEEPING:
Every distributor and every retail dealer required to collect and remit the tax
imposed in this article, and every purchaser or user, shall keep accurate and
complete books and records of his business of selling, purchases, and uses of
vehicle fuel, including the maintenance of all invoices and other source
documents, and whether or not exempt under this article. All books and records
shall be subject to inspection by the City Treasurer or duly authorized agents
or employees thereof, at all times during regular business hours.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-12: SALES AND USES PRESUMED TAXABLE; BURDEN OF PROOF:
It shall be presumed that all sales and uses of vehicle fuel in the city are
subject to tax under this article until the contrary is established. The burden
of proving that a sale or use is not taxable hereunder shall be upon the
distributor, retail dealer, purchaser or user so claiming.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
3-4D-13: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS OF TAX:
All proceeds from the imposition of the tax under this article, including
penalties, shall be paid into the treasury of the city and shall be credited to
and deposited in the Streets and Alleys Fund. Except as may be necessary to
reimburse the city for the costs of administering and collecting the tax, all
proceeds from the tax shall be used for the improvement, pavement, repairing or
maintaining public streets, alleys, curbs, and sidewalks.
(Ord. 2611, 5-25-2021)
ARTICLE E: ALCOHOL TAX
Section
3-4E-1: Title
3-4E-2: Definitions
3-4E-3: Tax Imposed
3-4E-4: Tax Collections
3-4E-5: Return; Filing
3-4E-6: Commission on Tax Paid when Due
3-4E-7: Failure to Pay or File; Penalties and Interest
3-4E-8: Recordkeeping
3-4E-9: Suspension/Revocation of Liquor License; Fine in Lieu
3-4E-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known and cited as the “Watseka Alcohol Tax Ordinance.”
The tax imposed under this article shall be known and cited as the “Watseka
Alcohol Tax.”
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them herein, except where to the context clearly
indicates a contrary meaning. Words used in the present tense shall include the
future; the singular number shall include the plural and the plural the
singular; and the word “shall” is mandatory and not directory.
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or
solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable
of being consumed as a beverage by a human being.
CITY: The City of Watseka, Iroquois County, Illinois.
LIQUOR ESTABLISHMENT: Any premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor, including any premises possessing or required to obtain a retail liquor
license under Title 4, Business and License Regulations, Chapter 2, Alcoholic
Beverages, of the Watseka City Code.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, limited liability company,
or a receiver, trustee, guardian, conservator, legal representative, or other
legally recognized entity.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-3: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of purchasing at retail alcoholic
liquor at a liquor establishment at a rate of six (6%) percent of the purchase
price therefor. The tax shall be imposed and shall be applicable to alcoholic
liquor purchased for on- and off-premises consumption, and whether in original
package quantities or not. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment
of the tax shall be on the purchaser of alcoholic liquor (the "consumer"), and
nothing in this section shall be construed to impose a tax upon the occupation
of selling, preparing or serving alcoholic liquor. The tax shall be in addition
to any and all other taxes. The tax shall apply only to the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor after August 1, 2023.(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021; amd. Ord. 2684, 6-
27-2023)
3-4E-4: TAX COLLECTIONS:
   A.   it shall be the duty of the owner, manager or operator of a liquor
establishment to collect the tax imposed by this article from the consumer and
to pay the tax to the city as required herein.
   B.   every person required to collect the tax imposed by this article shall
collect the tax from the consumer at the time he/she collects payment for the
sale of alcoholic liquor at retail. The amount due pursuant to the tax imposed
shall be stated separately on the receipt or other statement or memorandum of
the payment given to the consumer at the time of payment.
   C.   Any person who collects the tax shall do so as a trustee for and on
account of the city.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-5: RETURN; FILING:
The owner of each liquor establishment shall file with City Treasurer each
month a remittance return containing a report of retail sales of alcoholic
liquor in the prior calendar month. Each such return shall be accompanied by a
remittance of the appropriate amount of tax applicable to the sales period
reported. Payment shall be made to the City Treasurer. The return shall be in a
form prescribed and furnished by the City Treasurer. If mailed, the return must
be postmarked on or before the last day of the month following the month for
which the report is due.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-6: COMMISSION ON TAX PAID WHEN DUE:
The owner of each liquor establishment shall be entitled to a commission of one
percent (1%) of the tax remitted, to compensate for the cost of collection,
filing returns, and supplying information to the city, but in no event shall
any commission be allowed on any tax not remitted when due.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-7: FAILURE TO PAY OR FILE; PENALTIES AND INTEREST:
   A.   Failure to pay or remit the tax or to file the remittance return as
required by this article shall be subject to the following penalties and
interest:
      1.   Any tax not paid or remitted when due shall bear interest at the
rate of two percent (2%) per month, or fraction thereof, until the tax is paid
or remitted; and
      2.   In addition to any interest charged, any person who fails to pay or
to remit the tax, or remittance return, when due shall be subject to a late
penalty of ten percent (10%) of such tax.
   B.   Where the failure to pay or to remit the tax or to file the remittance
return in a timely manner is due to reasonable cause beyond the control of the
person charged with filing and paying the tax, the penalties described herein
may be waived by the City Treasurer.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-8: RECORDKEEPING:
Every person required to collect and remit the tax imposed in this article
shall keep accurate and complete books and records of its daily sales of
alcoholic liquor at retail, including actual tax receipts collected. All books
and records shall be maintained for a period of at least forty-eight (48)
months, and shall be subject to inspection by the City Treasurer or duly
authorized agents or employees thereof, at all times during regular business
hours.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
3-4E-9: SUSPENSION/REVOCATION OF LIQUOR LICENSE; FINE IN LIEU:
Notwithstanding and in addition to any interest or penalties that may be
imposed, any person found to have willfully evaded payment, collection and/or
remittance of the tax imposed, or willfully failed to keep accurate and
complete books and records required, by this article may have his/her/its
liquor license suspended or revoked, or a fine imposed in lieu thereof in
accordance with Section
4-2-21(C) of the Watseka City Code. Prior to such suspension/hearing/fine, a
hearing shall be held in accordance with the provisions of Section
4-2-21(B) of the Watseka City Code.
(Ord. 2621, 9-28-2021)
ARTICLE F: SIMPLIFIED MUNICIPAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX
Section
3-4F-1: Title
3-4F-2: Definitions
3-4F-3: Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Imposed
3-4F-4: Collection of Tax by Retailers
3-4F-5: Returns to Department
3-4F-6: Resellers
3-4F-7:Disposition of Tax Proceeds
3-4F-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known and cited as the "Watseka Simplified Municipal
Telecommunications Tax Ordinance." The tax imposed under this article shall be
known and cited as the “Watseka Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax.”
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
3-4F-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms have the following meanings:
ACT: The Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Act, 35 ILCS 636/5-1, et seq.
AMOUNT PAID: The amount charged to the taxpayer's service address in the City
regardless of where such amount is billed or paid.
CITY: The City of Watseka, Iroquois County, Illinois.
DEPARTMENT: The Illinois Department of Revenue.
GROSS CHARGE: The amount paid for the act or privilege of originating or
receiving telecommunications in the City and for all services and equipment
provided in connection therewith by a retailer, valued in money whether paid in
money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services and property of every
kind or nature, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the
cost of such telecommunications, the cost of the materials used, labor or
service costs or any other expense whatsoever. In case credit is extended, the
amount thereof shall be included only as and when paid. GROSS CHARGES for
private line service shall include charges imposed at each channel termination
point within the City and charges for that portion of the inter-office channels
provided within the City. Charges for that portion of the inter-office channel
connecting two (2) or more channel termination points, one or more of which is
located within the jurisdictional boundary of the City, shall be determined by
the retailer by multiplying an amount equal to the total charge for the inter-
office channel by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of channel
termination points that are located within the jurisdictional boundary of the
City and the denominator of which is the total number of channel termination
points connected by the inter-office channel. However, GROSS CHARGE shall not
include any of the following:
   1.   Any amounts added to a purchaser's bill because of a charge made
pursuant to:
      a.   The tax imposed by this article;
      b.   The tax imposed by the Telecommunications Excise Tax Act;
      c.   The tax imposed by Section 4251 of the Internal Revenue Code;
      d.   911 surcharges; or
      e.   Charges added to customers' bills pursuant to the provisions of
Section 9-221 or 9-222 of the Public Utilities Act, as amended, or any similar
charges added to customers' bills by retailers who are not subject to rate
regulation by the Illinois Commerce Commission for the purpose of recovering
any of the tax liabilities or other amounts specified in those provisions of
the Public Utilities Act.
   2.   Charges for a sent collect telecommunication received outside of the
City.
   3.   Charges for leased time on equipment or charges for the storage of data
or information for subsequent retrieval or the processing of data or
information intended to change its form or content. Such equipment includes,
but is not limited to, the use of calculators, computers, data processing
equipment, tabulating equipment or accounting equipment and also includes the
usage of computers under a time-sharing agreement.
   4.   Charges for customer equipment, including such equipment that is leased
or rented by the customer from any source, wherein such charges are
disaggregated and separately identified from other charges.
   5.   Charges to business enterprises certified as exempt under Section 9-
222.1 of the Public Utilities Act to the extent of such exemption and during
the period of time specified by the Department of Commerce and Economic
Opportunity.
   6.   Charges for telecommunications and all services and equipment provided
in connection therewith between a parent corporation and its wholly owned
subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries when the tax imposed under
this article has already been paid to a retailer and only to the extent that
the charges between the parent corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries or
between wholly owned subsidiaries represent expense allocation between the
corporations and not the generation of profit for the corporation rendering
such service.
   7.   Bad debts ("bad debt" means any portion of a debt that is related to a
sale at retail for which gross charges are not otherwise deductible or
excludable that has become worthless or uncollectible, as determined under
applicable federal income tax standards; if the portion of the debt deemed to
be bad is subsequently paid, the retailer shall report and pay the tax on that
portion during the reporting period in which the payment is made).
   8.   Charges paid by inserting coins in coin-operated telecommunication
devices.
   9.   Amounts paid by telecommunications retailers under the
Telecommunications Infrastructure Maintenance Fee Act.
   10.   Charges for nontaxable services or telecommunications if (i) those
charges are aggregated with other charges for telecommunications that are
taxable, (ii) those charges are not separately stated on the customer bill or
invoice, and (iii) the retailer can reasonably identify the nontaxable charges
on the retailer's books and records kept in the regular course of business. If
the nontaxable charges cannot reasonably be identified, the gross charge from
the sale of both taxable and nontaxable services or telecommunications billed
on a combined basis shall be attributed to the taxable services or
telecommunications. The burden of proving nontaxable charges shall be on the
retailer of the telecommunications.
INTERSTATE TELECOMMUNICATIONS: All telecommunications that either originate or
terminate outside this State.
INTRASTATE TELECOMMUNICATIONS: All telecommunications that originate and
terminate within this State.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, or
a receiver, trustee, guardian, or other representative appointed by order of
any court, the Federal and State governments, including State universities
created by statute, or any city, town, county, or other political subdivision
of this State.
PURCHASE AT RETAIL: The acquisition, consumption or use of telecommunications
through a sale at retail.
RETAILER: Every person engaged in the business of making sales at retail as
defined in this section. The Department may, in its discretion, upon
application, authorize the collection of the tax hereby imposed by any retailer
not maintaining a place of business within this State, who, to the satisfaction
of  the Department, furnishes adequate security to insure collection and
payment of the tax. Such retailer shall be issued, without charge, a permit to
collect such tax. When so authorized, it shall be the duty of such retailer to
collect the tax upon all of the gross charges for telecommunications in this
State in the same manner and subject to the same requirements as a retailer
maintaining a place of business within this State. The permit may be revoked by
the Department at its discretion.
RETAILER MAINTAINING A PLACE OF BUSINESS IN THIS STATE: Or any like term, means
and includes any retailer having or maintaining within this State, directly or
by a subsidiary, an office, distribution facilities, transmission facilities,
sales office, warehouse or other place of business, or any agent or other
representative operating within this State under the authority of the retailer
or its subsidiary, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or
other representative is located here permanently or temporarily, or whether
such retailer or subsidiary is licensed to do business in this State.
SALE AT RETAIL: The transmitting, supplying or furnishing of telecommunications
and all services and equipment provided in connection therewith for a
consideration, to persons other than the Federal and State governments, and
State universities created by statute and other than between a parent
corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned
subsidiaries for their use or consumption and not for resale.
SERVICE ADDRESS: The location of telecommunications equipment from which
telecommunications services are originated or at which telecommunications
services are received by a taxpayer. In the event this may not be a defined
location, as in the case of mobile phones, paging systems, and maritime
systems, service address means the customer's place of primary use as defined
in the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Conformity Act. For air-to-ground
systems and the like, "service address" shall mean the location of a taxpayer's
primary use of the telecommunications equipment as defined by telephone number,
authorization code, or location in Illinois where bills are sent.
TAXPAYER: A person who individually or through his or her agents, employees, or
permittees engages in the act or privilege of originating or receiving
telecommunications in the City and who incurs a tax liability as authorized by
this article.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS: In addition to the meaning ordinarily and popularly
ascribed to it, includes, without limitation, messages or information
transmitted through use of local, toll, and wide area telephone service,
private line services, channel services, telegraph services, teletypewriter,
computer exchange services, cellular mobile telecommunications service,
specialized mobile radio, stationary two-way radio, paging service, or any
other form of mobile and portable one-way or two-way communications, or any
other transmission of messages or information by electronic or similar means,
between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio,
satellite, or similar facilities. As used in this article, "private line" means
a dedicated non-traffic sensitive service for a single customer, that entitles
the customer to exclusive or priority use of a communications channel or group
of channels, from one or more specified locations to one or more other
specified locations. The definition of TELECOMMUNICATIONS shall not include
value added services in which computer processing applications are used to act
on the form, content, code, and protocol of the information for purposes other
than transmission. TELECOMMUNICATIONS shall not include purchases of
telecommunications by a telecommunications service provider for use as a
component part of the service provided by such provider to the ultimate retail
consumer who originates or terminates the taxable end-to-end communications.
Carrier access charges, right of access charges, charges for use of inter-
company facilities, and all telecommunications resold in the subsequent
provision of, used as a component of, or integrated into, end-to-end
telecommunications service shall be nontaxable as sales for resale; Prepaid
telephone calling arrangements shall not be considered TELECOMMUNICATIONS
subject to the tax imposed under this article. For purposes of this section,
"prepaid telephone calling arrangements" means that term as defined in Section
2-27 of the Retailers' Occupation Tax Act.
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
3-4F-3: SIMPLIFIED MUNICIPAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon any and all of the following acts or privileges:
   A.   The act or privilege of originating in the City or receiving in the
City intrastate telecommunications by a person at the rate of six (6%) percent
of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at retail from a
retailer. To prevent actual multi-municipal taxation of the act or privilege
that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon proof
that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another municipality on that event, shall
be allowed a credit against any tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by this
subsection to the extent of the amount of the tax properly due and paid in the
municipality that was not previously allowed as a credit against any other
municipal tax.
   B.   The act or privilege of originating in the City or receiving in the
City interstate telecommunications by a person at a rate of six (6%) percent of
the gross charge for such communications purchased at retail from a retailer.
To prevent actual multi-state or multimunicipal taxation of the act or
privilege that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon
proof that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another state or municipality in this
State on such event, shall be allowed a credit against any tax enacted pursuant
to or authorized by this subsection to the extent of the amount of such tax
properly due and paid in such other state or such tax properly due and paid in
a municipality in this State which was not previously allowed as a credit
against any other state or local tax in this State.
   C.   The tax imposed by this section is not imposed on such act or privilege
to the extent such act or privilege may not, under the Constitution and
statutes of the United States, be made the subject of taxation by the City.
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
3-4F-4: COLLECTION OF TAX BY RETAILERS:
   A.   The tax authorized by this article shall be collected from the taxpayer
by a retailer maintaining a place of business in this State and shall be
remitted by such retailer to the Department. Any tax required to be collected
pursuant to or as authorized by this article and any such tax collected by such
retailer and required to be remitted to the Department shall constitute a debt
owed by the retailer to the State. Retailers shall collect the tax from the
taxpayer by adding the tax to the gross charge for the act or privilege or
originating or receiving telecommunications when sold for use, in the manner
prescribed by the Department. The tax authorized by this article shall
constitute a debt of the taxpayer to the retailer until paid, and, if unpaid,
is recoverable at law in the same manner as the original charge for such sale
at retail. If the retailer fails to collect the tax from the taxpayer, then the
taxpayer shall be required to pay the tax directly to the Department in the
manner provided by the Department.
   B.   Whenever possible, the tax authorized by this article shall, when
collected, be stated as a distinct item separate and apart from the gross
charge for telecommunications.
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
3-4F-5: RETURNS TO DEPARTMENT:
On or before the last day of every month, the tax imposed under this article on
telecommunication retailers shall be returned with appropriate forms and
information as required by the Department pursuant to the Act and any
accompanying rules and regulations created by the Department to implement the
Act.
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
3-4F-6: RESELLERS:
   A.   If a person who originates or receives telecommunications claims to be
a reseller of such telecommunications, such person shall apply to the
Department for a resale number. Such applicant shall state the facts which will
show the Department why such applicant is not liable for the tax authorized by
this article on any of such purchases and shall furnish such additional
information as the Department may reasonably require.
   B.   Upon approval of the application, the Department shall assign a resale
number to the applicant and shall clarify such number to the applicant. The
Department may cancel any number which is obtained through misrepresentation,
or which is used to send or receive such telecommunication tax-free when such
actions in fact are not for resale, or which no longer applies because of the
person's having discontinued the making of resales.
   C.   Except as provided hereinabove in this section, the act or privilege of
originating or receiving telecommunications in this State shall not be made
tax-free on the ground of being a sale for resale unless the person has an
active resale number from the Department and furnishes that number to the
retailer in connection with certifying to the retailer that any sale to such
person is non-taxable because of being a sale for resale.
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
3-4F-7: DISPOSITION OF TAX PROCEEDS:
All proceeds from the imposition of the tax under this article, including
penalties, shall be paid into the treasury of the City and shall be credited to
and deposited in the Streets and Alleys Fund. All proceeds from the tax shall
be used for the improvement, pavement, repairing or maintaining public streets,
alleys, curbs, and sidewalks.
(Ord. 2635, 2-22-2022)
ARTICLE G: ELECTRIC UTILITY TAX
Section
3-4G-1: Title
3-4G-2: Definitions
3-4G-3: Tax Imposed
3-4G-4: Collection of Tax
3-4G-5: Tax Remittance and Return
3-4G-6: Resales
3-4G-7: Books and Records
3-4G-8: Failure to Pay or File; Penalties and Interest
3-4G-9: Disposition of Tax Proceeds
3-4G-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known and cited as the "Watseka Electric Utility Tax
Ordinance." The tax imposed under this article shall be known and cited as the
"Watseka Electric Utility Tax."
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms have the following meanings:
CITY: The City of Watseka, Iroquois County, Illinois.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, limited liability company,
municipal corporation, the State or any of its political subdivisions, any
State university created by statute, or a receiver, trustee, guardian or other
representative appointed by order of any court.
PERSON MAINTAINING A PLACE OF BUSINESS IN THIS STATE: Any person having or
maintaining within this State, directly or by a subsidiary or other affiliate,
an office, generation facility, distribution facility, transmission facility,
sales office or other place of business, or any employee, agent, or other
representative operating within this State under the authority of the person or
its subsidiary or other affiliate, irrespective of whether such place of
business or agent or other representative is located in this State permanently
or temporarily, or whether such person, subsidiary or other affiliate is
licensed or qualified to do business in this State.
PUBLIC UTILITY: The meaning ascribed to it in section 3-105 of the Public
Utilities Act and shall include alternative retail electric suppliers as
defined in section 16-102 of the Public Utilities Act.
PURCHASE AT RETAIL: Any acquisition of electricity by a purchaser for purposes
of use or consumption, and not for resale, but shall not include the use of
electricity by a public utility directly in the generation, production,
transmission, delivery or sale of electricity.
PURCHASER: Any person who uses or consumes, within the corporate limits of the
City, electricity acquired in a purchase at retail.
STATE: The State of Illinois.
TAX COLLECTOR: The person delivering electricity to the purchaser.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-3: TAX IMPOSED:
   A.   Effective June 1, 2022, a tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of
using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail and used or
consumed within the corporate limits of the City at the following rates,
calculated on a monthly basis for each purchaser:
      1.   For the first 2,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.610 cents per kilowatt hour;
      2.   For the next 48,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.400 cents per kilowatt hour;
      3.   For the next 50,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.360 cents per kilowatt hour;
      4.   For the next 400,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.350 cents per kilowatt hour;
      5.   For the next 500,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.340 cents per kilowatt hour;
      6.   For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.320 cents per kilowatt hour;
      7.   For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.315 cents per kilowatt hour;
      8.   For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.310 cents per kilowatt hour;
      9.   For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month;
0.305 cents per kilowatt hour;
      10.   For all electricity consumed in excess of 20,000,000 kilowatt-hours
in a month; 0.300 cents per kilowatt hour.
   B.   The tax imposed by this section is in addition to all taxes, fees and
other revenue measures imposed by the City, the State or any other political
subdivision of the State.
   C.   The tax shall not be imposed if and to the extent that the imposition
or collection would violate the constitution or statutes of the United States
or the State.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-4: COLLECTION OF TAX:
   A.   The tax authorized by article shall be collected from the purchaser by
the person maintaining a place of business in this State who delivers the
electricity to the purchaser. The tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser
to the person who delivers the electricity to the purchaser and if unpaid, is
recoverable in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the
electricity.
   B.   The tax required to be collected from the purchaser and any such tax
collected by a person delivering electricity shall constitute a debt owed to
the City by such person delivering the electricity, provided, that the person
delivering electricity shall be allowed credit for such tax related to
deliveries of electricity the charges for which are written off as
uncollectible, and provided further, that if such charges are thereafter
collected, the delivering supplier shall be obligated to remit such tax.
   C.   Persons delivering electricity shall collect the tax from the purchaser
by adding such tax to the gross charge for delivering the electricity. Persons
delivering electricity shall also be authorized to add to such gross charge an
amount equal to 3% of the tax to reimburse the person delivering electricity
for the expenses incurred in keeping records, billing customers, preparing and
filing returns, remitting the tax and supplying data to the City upon request.
   D.   If the person delivering electricity fails to collect the tax from the
purchaser, then the purchaser shall be required to pay the tax directly to the
City.
   E.   For purposes of this article, any partial payment of a billed amount
not specifically identified by the purchaser shall be deemed to be for the
delivery of electricity.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-5: TAX REMITTANCE AND RETURN:
   A.   Every tax collector shall on a monthly basis file a return in a form
prescribed by the City Clerk. The return and accompanying tax remittance shall
be due on or before the last day of the month following the month during which
the tax is collected.
   B.   If the person delivering electricity fails to collect the tax from the
purchaser, then the purchaser shall file a return in a form prescribed by the
City Clerk and pay the tax directly to the City on or before the last day of
the month following the month during which the electricity is used or consumed.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-6: RESALES:
   A.   Electricity that is delivered to a person in this City shall be
considered to be for use and consumption by that person unless the person
receiving the electricity has an active resale number issued by the City and
furnishes that number to the person who delivers the electricity and certifies
to that person that the sale is either entirely or partially nontaxable as a
sale for resale.
   B.   If a person who receives electricity in the City claims to be an
authorized reseller of electricity, that person shall apply to the City for a
resale number. The applicant shall state facts showing why it is not liable for
the tax imposed by this article on any purchases of electricity and shall
furnish such additional information as the City may reasonably require.
   C.   Upon approval of the application, the City shall assign a resale number
to the applicant and shall certify the number to the applicant.
   D.   The City may cancel the resale number of any person if the person fails
to pay any tax payable under this article for electricity used or consumed by
the person, or if the number:
      1.   Was obtained through misrepresentation; or
      2.   Is no longer necessary because the person has discontinued making
resales.
   E.   If a reseller has acquired electricity partly for use or consumption
and partly for resale, the reseller shall pay the tax imposed by this article
directly to the City pursuant to section 3-40-5 on the amount of electricity
that the reseller uses or consumes and shall collect the tax pursuant to
section 3-40 -4 and remit the tax pursuant to section 3-40 -5 on the amount of
electricity delivered by the reseller to a purchaser.
   F.   Any person who delivers electricity to a reseller having an active
resale number and complying with all other conditions of this section shall be
excused from collecting and remitting the tax on any portion of the electricity
delivered to the reseller, provided that the person reports to the City the
total amount of electricity delivered to the reseller, and such other
information that the City may reasonably require.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-7: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
Every tax collector, and every taxpayer required to pay the tax imposed by this
article shall keep accurate books and records of its business or activity,
including contemporaneous books and records denoting the transactions that gave
rise, or may have given rise, to any tax liability under this article. The
books and records shall be subject to and available for inspection at all times
during business hours of the day.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-8: FAILURE TO PAY OR FILE; PENALTIES AND INTEREST:
   A.   Failure to pay or remit the tax or to file the remittance return as
required by this article shall be subject to the following penalties and
interest:
      1.   Any tax not paid or remitted when due shall bear interest at the
rate of two percent (2%) per month, or fraction thereof, until the tax is paid
or remitted; and
      2.   In addition to any interest charged, any person who fails to pay or
to remit the tax, or remittance return, when due shall be subject to a late
penalty of ten percent (10%) of such tax.
   B.   Where the failure to pay or to remit the tax or to file the remittance
return in a timely manner is due to reasonable cause beyond the control of the
person charged with filing and paying the tax, the penalties described herein
may be waived by the City Treasurer.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
3-4G-9: DISPOSITION OF TAX PROCEEDS:
All proceeds from the imposition of the tax under this article, including
penalties, shall be paid into the treasury of the City and shall be credited to
and deposited in the Streets and Alleys Fund. All proceeds from the tax shall
be used for the improvement, pavement, repairing or maintaining public streets,
alleys, curbs, and sidewalks.
(Ord. 2641, 3-22-2022)
CHAPTER 5: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
Section
3-5-1: Compliance Required
3-5-2: Tax Imposed
3-5-3: Report And Payment Required
3-5-4: Inspection Of Books And Records
3-5-5: Penalty
3-5-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any corporation, company, or association not
incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois to engage in effecting
fire insurance in the City without fully complying with, or while in default or
in violation of, the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2605, 3-23-2021)
3-5-2: TAX IMPOSED:
All corporations, companies, and associations not incorporated under the laws
of the State of Illinois and engaged in the business of effecting fire
insurance in the City shall pay to the Treasurer of the Foreign Fire Insurance
Board of the City, for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the fire
department, a sum of money equal to two percent (2%) of the gross annual
receipts of premiums upon fire insurance policies effected, or agreed to be
effected, on property located in the City, by such corporation, company, or
association for each year ending as of July 1.
(Ord. 2605, 3-23-2021)
3-5-3: REPORT AND PAYMENT REQUIRED:
Every corporation, company, and association, and any person acting as agent for
or on behalf of such entity, effecting fire insurance in the City shall render
to the Treasurer of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board, on July 15 of each year,
a full and true account, verified under oath, of all premiums for fire
insurance received during each year ending as of July 1 next preceding the
issuance of said report. Such corporation, company, association, or agent
shall, at the time of rendering its report, pay the sum of money due under the
provisions of this chapter. The sum of money for which a company, corporation,
or association is chargeable under the provisions of this chapter may be
recovered of it, or from its agent, by an action in the name and for the use of
the City as for money had and received.
(Ord. 2605, 3-23-2021)
3-5-4: INSPECTION OF BOOKS AND RECORDS:
The City Clerk shall have the power to examine the books, records, and other
papers and documents of a designated agent, corporation, company, or
association for the purposes of verifying the correctness of the report of
amounts received for fire insurance.
(Ord. 2605, 3-23-2021)
3-5-5: PENALTY:
In addition to such other remedies as may be afforded by law, any corporation,
company, association, or agent of such entity, found in violation of any
provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than $250.00 nor more than
$750.00 for each violation. Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to
continue shall be deemed and constitute a separate offense. No corporation,
company, association, or agent of such entity, found in violation of the
provisions of this chapter shall effect fire insurance, or transact any
business related to effecting fire insurance, until such time as it/he/she
shall come into compliance with this chapter and pay all fines due and owing
for violations hereof.
(Ord. 2605, 3-23-2021)
CHAPTER 6: HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES REMOVAL COSTS
Section
3-6-1: Costs Established
3-6-2: Amendments To Charges
3-6-3: Other Charges Authorized
3-6-4: Waiver Of Charges
3-6-1: COSTS ESTABLISHED:
Charges for removal or remediation of a release or substantial threat of a
release of a “hazardous substance”, as defined in applicable United States
Environmental Protection Acts, State of Illinois Environmental Protection Acts,
natural gas, gas liquids, and liquefied natural gas, pesticides, natural gas
leaks caused by the improper or incorrect location of electrical or natural gas
service lines or by the negligent actions of any contractor performing labor or
services with the City, when rendered by the City Fire Department or any agency
in accordance with any mutual aid agreement to which the City is a party, shall
be as specified in exhibit A attached to ordinance 2412 and by this reference
incorporated herein.
(Ord. 2412, 2-25-2014)
3-6-2: AMENDMENTS TO CHARGES:
Pursuant to the authority of Illinois law, including, but not limited to, the
Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.), the City Council may, from
time to time, amend the charges for removal or remedial action when rendered by
the City Fire Department or any agency in accordance with any mutual aid
agreement to which the City is a party, identified in this chapter by duly and
properly adopting an amended exhibit A at a meeting convened pursuant to the
Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.), memorializing the amendatory exhibit
A, the effective date of the amendatory exhibit A, and recording in the minutes
of said meeting the roll call vote of the City Council approving the amendment.
(Ord. 2412, 2-25-2014)
3-6-3: OTHER CHARGES AUTHORIZED:
Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the assessment of fees or other charges
pursuant to any other City Council ordinance or resolution.
(Ord. 2412, 2-25-2014)
3-6-4: WAIVER OF CHARGES:
The City Council is hereby authorized to waive any or all of the fees due under
this chapter.
(Ord. 2412, 2-25-2014)
TITLE 4: BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS

CHAPTER 1: GENERAL LICENSE AND PERMIT REGULATIONS
Section
4-1-1: Persons Subject To License
4-1-2: Application For License Or Permit
4-1-3: Forms And Signatures
4-1-4: Investigation And Inspection Of Applicant
4-1-5: License And Permit Fees
4-1-6: Term Of License
4-1-7: Nontransferability Of License; Change Of Location
4-1-8: Posting License
4-1-9: Building And Premises Requirements
4-1-10: Nuisance Businesses Prohibited
4-1-11: Inspections And Analyses
4-1-12: Revocation Of License Or Permit
4-1-13: Penalties
4-1-1: PERSONS SUBJECT TO LICENSE:
Whenever in this Code a license is required for the maintenance, operation or
conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in
any activity or occupation, any person or corporation shall be subject to the
requirement if, by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he holds
himself forth as being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits
patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform
any part of such business or occupation in the City.
(1980 Code § 23-2)
4-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE OR PERMIT:
Applications for all licenses and permits required by ordinance shall be made
in writing to the City Clerk, in the absence of any other provision to the
contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or
license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee
to be paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as
may be needed for the proper guidance of the City officials in the issuing of
the permit or license.
(1980 Code § 23-1)
4-1-3: FORMS AND SIGNATURES:
   A.   Forms: Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor,
shall be prepared and kept on hand by the City Clerk.
(1980 Code § 23-3)
   B.   Signatures Required: Each license or permit issued shall bear the
signatures of the Mayor and the City Clerk, in the absence of any provision to
the contrary.
(1980 Code § 23-4)
4-1-4: INVESTIGATION AND INSPECTION OF APPLICANT:
Upon receipt of an application for a license or permit, where the ordinances of
the City require an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such
permit or license, the City Clerk shall refer the application to the proper
official or officials for making the investigation within forty eight (48)
hours of the time of such receipt. The official charged with the duty of making
the investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or
otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving the application or a copy
thereof.
(1980 Code § 23-5)
4-1-5: LICENSE AND PERMIT FEES:
   A.   In the absence of any provision to the contrary, all fees and charges
for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time the application
therefor is made to the City Clerk.
   B.   When an application for an annual license is made after the expiration
of six (6) months of the current license year, the license for the remainder of
the year shall be issued upon payment of one- half (½) of the annual fee;
provided, that the applicant has not previously held a license of the same type
and class for which application is made.
(1980 Code § 23-6)
4-1-6: TERM OF LICENSE:
All annual licenses shall terminate on April 30, where no provision to the
contrary is made.
(1980 Code § 23-7)
4-1-7: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE; CHANGE OF LOCATION:
No license shall be assignable or transferable, nor shall any person be
authorized to do business or act under such license but the person to whom it
is granted or his administrator or executor, or at any other place than that
specified therein, nor shall any license authorize any person to act under it
at more than one place; provided, that any licensee conducting any business or
occupation required to be licensed who shall change the location of such place
of business before the expiration of the license, upon written notice to the
City Clerk of the change in location, may continue the business at the new
location under the license previously issued unless otherwise restricted by
ordinance or law.
(1980 Code § 23-9)
4-1-8: POSTING LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the City
to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for the
business at all times.
(1980 Code § 23-12)
4-1-9: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no
permit for any thing or act, if the premises and building to be used for the
purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the City.
   B.   No license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or
the performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning
ordinance or any other ordinance of the City.
(1980 Code § 23-8)
4-1-10: NUISANCE BUSINESSES PROHIBITED:
No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to
a nuisance in fact.
(1980 Code § 23-10)
4-1-11: INSPECTIONS AND ANALYSES:
   A.   Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the
operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by
ordinance, or are reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance
provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the
licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit
thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the
City who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable
time that admission is requested.
   B.   Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably
necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance provisions or to detect
violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee whose business is
governed by such provision to give to any authorized officer or employee of the
City requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity for
such analysis upon request.
   C.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the Mayor may
revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the
City who refuses to permit any officer or employee who is authorized to make
such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection, or take an adequate
sample of the commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while
in the performance of his duty in making the inspection. Provided, that no
license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the
licensee or person in charge of the premises, in the name of the City, stating
that the inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to make the
inspection or obtain the sample.
(1980 Code § 23-13)
4-1-12: REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
Any license or permit may be revoked by the Mayor at any time during the life
of the license or permit for any violation by the licensee or permittee of the
ordinance provisions relating to the license or permit, the subject matter of
the license or permit, or the premises occupied. Such revocation may be in
addition to any fine imposed.
(1980 Code § 23-11)
4-1-13: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined as set fort in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Upon the conviction of a licensee of any such violation,
the Mayor, in his discretion, may forfeit and cancel the license of the
licensee.
(1980 Code § 23-14; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
Section
4-2-1: Definitions
4-2-2: Administrative Officials
4-2-3: Licenses And Compliance Required
4-2-4: Ineligibility For License; Location Description Required
4-2-5: Application For License
4-2-5-1: Applications For Supplemental Licenses
4-2-6: Selection Of Licensees
4-2-7: Classification Of Licenses
4-2-8: Number Of Licenses
4-2-9: License Fees
4-2-10: Privilege Granted By License
4-2-11: Termination Of License
4-2-12: Conditions On Certain Licenses
4-2-13: Sanitary Conditions
4-2-14: Closing Hours
4-2-15: Change Of Location
4-2-16: Sales To Certain Persons Prohibited
4-2-17: Underage Persons
4-2-18: Additional Prohibitions
4-2-19: Inspections; Entry Powers
4-2-20: Complaints By Residents
4-2-21: Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Fine In Lieu
4-2-22: Appeals
4-2-23: Violations; Penalties
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Except as herein otherwise defined, the terms herein used shall have the same
definitions and meanings as under the statutes of the State of Illinois
relating to dram shops.
(1980 Code § 22-2)
4-2-2: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIALS:
   A.   Liquor Control Commissioner:
      1.   Mayor Serve As: The Mayor shall constitute and be the Liquor Control
Commissioner of the City.
(1980 Code § 22-24)
      2.   Powers: The Mayor, as Liquor Control Commissioner, shall have the
following powers:
         a.   To grant and/or suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or
revoke for cause all local licenses issued to persons or premises within his
jurisdiction.
         b.   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at
any time upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the
provisions of the statutes or any rules or regulations adopted by the Liquor
Control Commissioner or by the State Commission have been or are being violated
and, at such time, to examine the premises of the licensee in connection
therewith.
         c.   To receive complaint from any citizen within his jurisdiction
that any of the provisions of the statutes or any rules or regulations adopted
pursuant hereto have been or are being violated, and to act upon such
complaints in the manner hereinafter provided.
         d.   To levy fines in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
         e.   To have such other powers relating to liquor control as may be or
may hereafter be given by ordinance or law.
(1980 Code § 22-19)
   B.   Liquor Committee: The Mayor shall appoint three (3) Alderpersons who,
together with the Mayor, shall constitute the Liquor Committee of the City
Council. The Liquor Committee shall advise and assist the Liquor Control
Commissioner in the administration of the provisions of this chapter. Whenever
in this Code reference is made to a Liquor Control Committee or a Committee on
Liquor Licenses, it shall be deemed to refer to the Liquor Committee.
(1980 Code § 22-25)
4-2-3: LICENSES AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale at retail, or
outside of one’s personal residence to permit the consumption of, any alcoholic
liquor in the City:
   A.   Without a State of Illinois liquor license;
   B.   Without a Watseka liquor license;
   C.   At a location, place, or premises other than as described in the liquor
license; or
   D.   In violation of the terms of the liquor license.
(Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017)
4-2-4: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE; LOCATION DESCRIPTION REQUIRED:
A. No license shall be issued to any person who does not own the premises for
which a license is sought or does not have a valid lease thereon for the full
period for which the license is to be issued, who is not of good character and
reputation in the City, who is in any manner disqualified from obtaining a
State retail liquor dealer's license under the law of this State now in force
relating to alcoholic liquors or the nature of whose business or proposed
business is such, in the opinion of the Liquor Committee, and that the sale of
liquor in connection therewith will not be for the public good and convenience.
The license shall describe the location of the place of business to be operated
by the licensee, and the location shall be changed only by written permission
of the Mayor and the approval of the Liquor Committee, if the new location is a
proper one under the laws of the State.
(1980 Code § 22-5)
   B.   No license shall be issued to any person who is delinquent in the
payment of any obligation due the City for any charge, cost, fine, expense,
license fee, water bill, sewer bill, or any other fee imposed under this Code.
In the event any such obligation is delinquent on the effective date of the
license, or becomes delinquent after the effective date of the license, then
the license shall be subject to suspension or revocation under the provisions
of section
4-2-21 of this chapter.
   C.   No license shall be issued to any corporation in its own right, or to
any corporation any of whose principal officers, directors, or shareholders
owning more than a five percent (5%) interest therein are delinquent in the
payment of any obligation due the City for any charge, cost, fine, expense,
license fee, water bill, sewer bill, or any other fee imposed under this Code.
In the event any such obligation is delinquent on the effective date of the
license, or becomes delinquent after the effective date of the license, then
the license shall be subject to suspension or revocation under the provisions
of section
4-2-21 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2287, 4-28-2009)
4-2-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for City liquor licenses shall be made to the Mayor in writing,
signed by the applicant if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof
if a corporation, verified under oath, and shall include:
   A.   Such information as will allow the Mayor to investigate and determine
that no grounds exist for the denial thereof pursuant to sections 6-2, 6-11, 6-
12, or 6-25 of the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (the “act”), as amended from time
to time (235 ILCS 5/6-2, 5/6-11, 5/6-12 or 5/6-25);
   B.   Proof of dram shop liability insurance having the limits prescribed by
section 6-21 of the act (235 ILCS 5/6-21); and
   C.   Such other information or documentation as may be required to qualify
for such license.
(Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017)
4-2-5-1: APPLICATIONS FOR SUPPLEMENTAL LICENSES:
   A.   Class I License: Any applicant desirous of supplementing its on-
premises license with a Class I license shall submit to the Mayor the following
information in addition to that information required by the underlying license:
      1.   Proof that:
         a.   Outdoor operations will not disturb the lawful use and quiet
enjoyment of nearby properties;
         b.   The Class I premises will be operated in strict accordance with
applicable Health, Building, Fire, and Life Safety Codes;
         c.   Adequate safeguards are in place for security, crowd control,
lighting control, and protection of minors;
         d.   The licensee has previously maintained adequate control and
supervision of the licensed premises and has consistently operated the licensed
premises in substantial compliance with this chapter; and
         e.   That the Class I premises can be made to comply with the
conditions and limitations of the Class I license;
      2.   Information identifying the date and hours the Class I premises will
be in use, the purpose of the event, and the number of attendees expected; and
      3.   An executed contract with a private security company that will be
providing security for the event.
   B.   Class O License: Any applicant desirous of supplementing its on-
premises license with a Class O license shall submit to the Mayor the following
information in addition to that information required by the underlying license:
      1.   Proof that:
         a.   Outdoor operations will not disturb the lawful use and quiet
enjoyment of nearby properties;
         b.   The Class O premises will be operated in strict accordance with
applicable Health, Building, Fire, and Life Safety Codes;
         c.   Adequate safeguards are in place for security, crowd control,
lighting control, and protection of minors;
         d.   The licensee has previously maintained adequate control and
supervision of the licensed premises and has consistently operated the licensed
premises in substantial compliance with this chapter; and
         e.   That the Class O premises can be made to comply with the
conditions and limitations of the Class O license; and
      2.   A scaled site plan showing the location for outside service of
alcoholic liquor in relation to the permanent structure on the premises,
fences, emergency exits, and any other fixed objects within that location, and
a detailed description of materials to be used as fencing and emergency exits.
Such matters shall be reviewed and approved by the Building Official; provided,
that they demonstrate that the fencing is satisfactory, in both height and
design, taking into account such factors as the location of the premises, the
primary nature of the business, the proximity and nature of surrounding
business, the zoning of adjacent properties, the safety of the patrons and
public, the degree of permanency of the Class O premises, the number of
employees permanently stationed in the area or otherwise charged with
supervision over the area, and if recorded or live music or entertainment is to
be provided.
   C.   Class S License: Any applicant desirous of supplementing its Class A,
Class C, or Class D license with a Class S license shall submit to the Mayor
the following information in addition to that information required by the
underlying license:
      1.   An approved sidewalk café permit issued by the Building Official.
         a.   An applicant for a sidewalk café permit shall submit the
following information to the Building Official with its request for a sidewalk
café permit:
            (1)   The name of the individual, partnership, corporation, or
association applying for the permit;
            (2)   The residence and phone numbers of the applicant or partners
or, if a corporation or association, the residence and phone numbers of the
principal officers;
            (3)   The name of the business and the location for which the
permit is requested;
            (4)   A nonrefundable permit application processing fee in the
amount of fifty dollars ($50.00);
            (5)   A refundable, assuming the permit is not granted, permit fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of sidewalk
space used; and
            (6)   A scaled site plan of the proposed sidewalk café, including
the location of the licensed premises, location of access points to the
sidewalk café, locations of tables and seating, locations of fences, and the
location of the curb cut and adjacent street or roadway. Measurements of the
size of the sidewalk café, its proximity to the licensed premises, and
proximity to any adjacent roadway shall be shown on the site plan.
         b.   The Building Official's decision to grant or deny the sidewalk
café permit shall be governed by the following standards:
            (1)   The sidewalk café shall be operated on a sidewalk adjacent to
the licensed premises, and no part thereof shall protrude past the building
lines of the licensed premises;
            (2)   No sidewalk café shall be located next to another premises
licensed for a sidewalk café;
            (3)   No sidewalk café shall be located adjacent to a designated
bus stop;
            (4)   No sidewalk café shall be located within fifteen feet (15')
of any street corner or twenty five feet (25') of a street corner if the
intersection is not controlled by a traffic control device at each direction of
travel, as measured from the intersection of the curb line;
            (5)   The sidewalk on which the sidewalk café is to be located must
have a minimum width of twelve feet (12');
            (6)   No sidewalk café shall reduce the paved pedestrianway to less
than five feet (5');
            (7)   The sidewalk café, with the exception of the entranceway
thereto which shall be no larger than six feet (6') in width, shall be
separated from the sidewalk and pedestrian traffic by a wrought iron fence or
other approved divider of at least three feet (3') but no greater than four
feet (4') in height on all sides;
            (8)   The sidewalk café shall be situated on the sidewalk nearest
the licensed premises and shall leave that portion of the sidewalk closest to
the street unobstructed; and
            (9)   Tables and seats proposed should be heavy enough to withstand
significant wind gusts.
      2.   A bond issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in
the State of Illinois in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with
the City’s name as obligee, conditioned for the faithful performance of the
provisions of this Code; and
      3.   Proof of commercial public liability insurance in the amount of
three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per person, five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence, and twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) in property damage, and the City shall be named an additional
insured on a primary and noncontributory basis with respect to claims. The
applicant shall also provide a waiver of subrogation on their liability policy
in favor of the City. Liability coverage should be written by a carrier
licensed to do business in Illinois and have an AM Bests rating of A-VII or
better. Coverages shall be written on an occurrence basis. Claims-made coverage
is not acceptable. The applicant shall, upon the request of the City, furnish
said insurance policy or certificates evidencing coverage, which policies or
certificates shall provide that the insurance coverage shall not be reduced,
canceled, or allowed to expire without at least thirty (30) days' written
notice to the City. Failure to provide evidence of insurance in no way will be
deemed a waiver of the insurance requirements.
(Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017)
4-2-6: SELECTION OF LICENSEES:
In case applications for any class of retail liquor dealers’ licenses are
received from qualified applicants with respect to proper premises in greater
number than the number allowed by this chapter, the Mayor shall, from the moral
character and standing of the applicants, their financial integrity and
business reputation, the character of the respective business to be run, with
the assistance of the Liquor Committee, determine which of the applicants are
more likely to conduct the business more consistent with the public good and
convenience and make his choice accordingly.
(1980 Code § 22-18)
4-2-7: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES:
Liquor licenses shall be and are hereby divided into the following classes:
   A.   Class A, Premises, Beer And Wine: A Class A license shall authorize the
retail sale of beer and wine only, for consumption on-premises.
   B.   Class A-1, Mixed: A Class A-1 license shall authorize the retail sale
of beer and wine only, for consumption on-premises and the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor in packaged quantities for consumption off-premises.
(Ord., 3-27-2018; amd. Ord. 2541, 5-28-2019)
   C.   Class B, Package: A Class B license shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for consumption off-premises. Class B licenses shall be
divided into two (2) subclasses: a Class B-1 license, which shall authorize the
retail sale of any alcoholic liquor in package quantities; and a Class B-
2 license, which shall authorize the sale of beer and wine only, in package
quantities.
   D.   Class C, General Premises: A Class C license shall authorize the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on-premises and the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor in packaged quantities for consumption off-premises.
   E.   Class D, Club: A Class D license shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for consumption on-premises. A Class D club license shall only
be issued to clubs or fraternal orders of restricted membership having a
charter from a state or national organization or operating under and by the
authority or society that is statewide or national in scope.
   F.   Class E, Banquet Hall: A Class E license shall authorize the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on-premises, being a banquet hall. A
“banquet hall” shall mean a business or facility the whole or part of which is
rented and food and beverage are offered to persons attending an organized
function. A Class E license shall not authorize the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor at times other than that of an organized function.
   G.   Class, F Nonprofit Special Event: A Class F license shall authorize the
retail sale of beer and wine only, for consumption on-premises at special
events sponsored by not-for-profit organizations or entities. A Class F license
shall designate the location and dates of validity.
   H.   Class G, For Profit Special Event Supplemental: A Class G license shall
supplement a Class A license, Class C license, Class D License, or Class E
License, and shall authorize the retail sale of beer and wine only, for
consumption on-premises. A Class F license shall designate a location other
than the underlying licensed premises and the dates of validity.
