   I.   Class H, Artistic Special Event: A Class H license shall authorize the
consumption of beer and wine only, on the licensed premises, but not the retail
sale, delivery, or distribution of any alcoholic liquor by the holder. A Class
H license shall designate the location, dates, and times of validity, which
shall correspond to the dates and times the licensed premises is being used for
instruction related to an artistic/culinary experience or event involving
customer/patron participation. The consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be
limited to those brought to the licensed premises by customers/patrons
participating in an artistic or culinary experience event.
   J.   Class I, Invitation Only Special Event Supplemental: A Class I license
shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption outside of
the Class I premises, but on the same lot as, a permanent structure otherwise
being a licensed premises, on the date and time identified in the Class I
license, which shall correspond to the date and time the licensed premises is
being used for an invitation-only event. No more than four (4) Class I licenses
shall be issued to the same underlying liquor licensee in a calendar year.
   K.   Class O, Outdoor Supplemental: A Class O license shall authorize the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption outside of the Class O
premises, but on the same lot as, a permanent structure otherwise being a
licensed premises, and only in conjunction with the sale of food for outdoor
dining (full kitchen).
   L.   Class S, Sidewalk Café Supplemental: A Class S license shall supplement
the Class A license, Class C license, or Class D license, and shall authorize
the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption in a sidewalk café adjacent
to a permanent structure otherwise being a licensed premises, and only in
conjunction with the sale of food for outdoor dining (full kitchen). A Class S
license shall only be valid from May-October of the calendar year.
   M.   Class SE, Special Event: A Class SE license shall authorize the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on-premises in conjunction with a
special event for a period not to exceed three (3) consecutive days. The type
of alcoholic beverages to be served, the place of service, and the hours of
service, shall be established by the Liquor Control Commissioner and identified
in the license; provided, however, no special event liquor license shall be
issued for an event at a residence or on a residential lot, nor shall more than
three (3) special event liquor licenses be issued to the same licensee or
licensed premises within the same license year.
   N.   Class SG, Single Glass: A Class SG license shall authorize the retail
sale or complimentary distribution of the beer, wine and champagne, by single
glass only, for consumption on the licensed premises only, when the principal
business on the licensed premises is a spa, beauty salon or barber shop, or at
an art gallery, art studio, or other place of business while instructing an
artistic/culinary experience event involving customer/patron participation. The
sale, service and consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be limited to those
supplied by the licensee to customers/patrons of the principal business use
while receiving such services or while participating in an artistic or culinary
experience event.
(Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017; amd. Ord., 3-27-2018; Ord. 2517, 7-30-2018; Ord. 2541,
5-28-2019; Ord. 2677, 2-28-2023)
4-2-8: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The number of licenses available for each class herein described are limited as
follows:
Class A   5
Class A-1 7
Class B-1 9
Class B-2 9
Class C   12
Class D   1
Class E   1
Class F   No limit
Class G   No limit
Class H   No limit
Class I   No limit
Class O   Same as underlying class
Class S   Same as underlying class
Class SE  No limit
Class SG  1
 
(Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017; amd. Ord., 3-27-2018; Ord. 2517, 7-30-2018; Ord. 2541,
5-28-2019; Ord. 2603A, 3-23-2021; Ord. 2677, 2-28-2023)
4-2-9: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Fees Established: The annual fees and special event fees for licenses
under this chapter shall be as follows:
Class A   $250.00
Class A-1 1,200.00
Class B-1 450.00
Class B-2 200.00
Class C   1,200.00
Class D   800.00
Class E   600.00
Class F   15.00 per event
Class G   50.00 per day
Class H   15.00 per day
Class I   30.00 per day
Class O   75.00
Class S   75.00
Class SE  50.00 per day
Class SG  350.00
 
   B.   Payment And Disposition Of Fees: All fees shall be paid to the Mayor or
the City Clerk at the time application is made, and shall be forthwith turned
over to the City Treasurer. In the event the license applied for is denied, the
fee shall be returned to the applicant; but if the license is granted, then the
fee shall be deposited in the General Corporate Fund or in such other funds as
shall have been designated by the City Council.
(1980 Code § 22-10; amd. Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017; Ord., 3-27-2018; amd. Ord. 2517,
7-30-2018; amd. Ord. 2541, 5-28-2019; Ord. 2677, 2-28-2023)
4-2-10: PRIVILEGE GRANTED BY LICENSE:
A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year
after issuance, unless sooner revoked as is in this chapter provided, and shall
not constitute property nor shall it be the subject to attachment, garnishment
or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or
involuntarily, nor subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license
shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall
cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that the executor or the
administrator of the estate of any deceased licensee and the trustee of any
insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic
beverages, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic beverages under
the order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the
deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent or
such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license but not
longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such
licensee.
(1980 Code § 22-14)
4-2-11: TERMINATION OF LICENSE:
Each license issued under this chapter shall terminate at twelve o'clock (12:
00) midnight April 30 following its issuance, unless sooner revoked.
(1980 Code § 22-15)
4-2-12: CONDITIONS ON CERTAIN LICENSES:
The following conditions and limitations are placed on the following licenses:
   A.   Class H License:
      1.   A Class H license shall permit the consumption of beer and wine
only, during the principal business hours, no earlier than nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. and no later than eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Monday through Saturday
of each week, and no earlier than eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and no later than
eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday of each week.
      2.   A Class H license holder shall clear the premises of all customers/
patrons at or prior to eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. unless such patrons
are engaged in legal commercial activity that does not involve the consumption
of alcoholic liquor.
      3.   No video gaming or video gaming terminals shall be permitted or
allowed in or on a Class H licensed premises.
      4.   No food shall be prepared in or on a Class H licensed premises
except in conjunction with a culinary experience event through which customers/
patrons participate by preparing food for their own consumption.
      5.   No advertisement, sign, or any other external indicia of the Class H
licensee, the Class H licensed premises, or the primary business use shall
contain an express or implicit reference to alcoholic liquor.
      6.   No person or premises holding or having a liquor license of any
other class shall be permitted to simultaneously hold, or have applicable to
it, a Class H license.
   B.   Class I License:
      1.   Class I premises shall be closed no later than the time identified
on the Class I license.
      2.   Live or recorded entertainment, music, or any other natural or
amplified sound shall be permitted in a Class I premises; provided, however,
the sound level of any entertainment, music, or any other sound shall not
exceed sixty (60) decibels at any time, as measured at any property line.
      3.   No smoking shall be permitted in or within five feet (5') of a Class
I premises.
      4.   No sales of alcoholic liquor shall be made to any person on
adjoining properties, streets, sidewalks, or alleys.
      5.   Access to the Class I premises shall be through the permanent
structure constituting the licensed premises, except for emergency exits
required by this Code or the Fire Department.
      6.   The Class I premises shall be secured on all sides (excepting a
portion abutting the structure constituting the licensed premises) with
temporary plastic or wooden fencing, at least four feet (4') high, erected on
the Class I premises.
      7.   All temporary fencing erected around the Class I premises shall be
removed no later than twenty four (24) hours after the event licensed.
      8.   No customer, employee, or other person shall remove alcoholic liquor
from the Class I premises, except for persons carrying the same directly
between the Class I premises and the licensed premises.
      9.   The Class I license holder shall provide, at its own cost and
expense, one security guard from a professional security company per forty (40)
persons in attendance at an event to be held on a Class I premises.
   C.   Class O License:
      1.   Class O premises shall be closed no later than then nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M., Sunday through Thursday, and no later than eleven o'clock (11:00)
P.M. on Friday and Saturday.
      2.   Live or recorded entertainment, music, or any other natural or
amplified sound shall be permitted in a Class O premises; provided, however,
the sound level of any entertainment, music or other sound shall not exceed
sixty (60) decibels at any time, as measured at any property line.
      3.   No smoking shall be permitted in or within five feet (5') of a Class
O premises.
      4.   No sales of alcoholic liquor shall be made to any person on
adjoining properties, streets, sidewalks, or alleys.
      5.   Access to the Class O premises shall be through the permanent
structure constituting the licensed premises, except for emergency exits
required by this Code or the Fire Department.
      6.   The Class O premises shall be secure and inaccessible to customers
or the public when not in operation.
      7.   No customer, employee, or other person shall remove alcoholic liquor
from the Class O premises, except for persons carrying the same directly
between the Class O premises and the licensed premises.
   D.   Class S License:
      1.   Sidewalk cafes shall be closed no later than then nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M., Sunday through Thursday, and no later than eleven o'clock (11:00)
P.M. on Friday and Saturday.
      2.   No live entertainment or amplified sound or music shall be permitted
in a sidewalk café.
      3.   No smoking shall be permitted in or within five feet (5') of a
sidewalk café.
      4.   No sales of alcoholic liquor shall be made to any person on
adjoining properties, streets, sidewalks, or alleys.
      5.   Any sidewalk café being operated on the side of the building located
on a corner lot shall be accessible from a side door of the licensed premises
only.
      6.   No customer, employee, or other person shall remove alcoholic liquor
from the area designated as a sidewalk café, except for persons carrying
alcoholic liquor directly between the sidewalk café and the licensed premises.
The licensee shall be responsible to see that no person is served or consumes
alcoholic liquor in the sidewalk café unless seated in the seated area
provided, in accordance with site plans approved for the sidewalk café permit.
      7.   Licensees shall be responsible for the cleanliness of the sidewalk
within fifty feet (50') of the approved location.
      8.   Licensees shall stack tables and chairs together and secure them
with a lock at the end of each day's operation.
      9.   Licensees shall sweep and remove any garbage or debris from the
sidewalk café at the end of each day's operation and shall also hose the area
of the sidewalk upon which the sidewalk café is located.
      10.   Sweeping or placement of garbage, debris, or other materials into
streets, storm sewers or any adjacent paved pedestrianway is prohibited.
   E.   Class SG License:
      1.   A Class SG licensee shall permit the sale, delivery or consumption
of beer, wine and champagne during the principal business' hours, but in no
event earlier than nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and no later than eleven o'clock
(11 :00) P.M. on Monday through Saturday of each week, and no earlier than
eleven o'clock (11 :00) A.M. and no later than eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on
Sunday of each week.
      2.   A class SG license holder shall clear the premises of all customers/
patrons at or prior to eleven thirty (11:30) P.M. unless such patrons are
engaged in legal commercial activity that does not involve the sale, delivery
or consumption of alcoholic liquor.
      3.   No video gaming or video gaming terminal shall be permitted or
allowed in or on a Class SG licensed premises.
      4.   No food shall be prepared in or on a Class SG licensed premises
except in conjunction with a culinary experience event through which customers/
patrons participate by preparing food for their own consumption.
      5.   No advertisement, sign or any other external indicia of the Class SG
licensee, the Class SG Licensed premises, or the primary business use, shall
contain an express or implicit reference to alcoholic beverages being sold,
delivered, or available for consumption.
      6.   No person or premises holding or having a liquor license of any
other class shall be permitted to simultaneously hold or have applicable to it
a Class SG license.
(Ord. 2481, 9-26-2017; amd. Ord. 2677, 2-28-2023)
4-2-13: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages or for the storage
of such beverages for such sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with the ordinances regulating
the condition of premises used for the storage of food or sale of food for
human consumption.
(1980 Code § 22-13)
4-2-14: CLOSING HOURS:
No holder of any license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall sell
any alcoholic liquor between the hours of one o’clock (1:00) A.M. and six
o’clock (6:00) A.M. on any day. During such closed hours, it shall be unlawful
to sell or consume, or permit the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors on
any licensed premises.
(1980 Code § 22-11) (Ord. 2620, 9-28-2021)
4-2-15: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A retail liquor dealer’s license shall permit the sale of alcoholic beverages
only on the premises described in the application and license. Such location
may be changed only upon the written permit to make such change, issued by the
Liquor Control Commissioner. No change of location shall be permitted, unless
the proposed new location is a proper one for the sale of alcoholic liquor
under the laws of this State and the ordinances of the City.
(1980 Code § 22-12)
4-2-16: SALES TO CERTAIN PERSONS PROHIBITED:
No licensee shall sell, give, or deliver any alcoholic beverages to any minor,
or to any intoxicated person, except as provided in 235 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-16.1.
(1980 Code § 22-16)
4-2-17: UNDERAGE PERSONS:
   A.   Definition: Whenever the term MINOR is used in this section, it shall
mean a person under the age of twenty one (21) years, unless the State Statutes
shall, with relation to the age of persons who may or may not be served
intoxicating liquors, prescribe a different age, in which event, a person
described as a MINOR in this chapter shall be a person under the age prescribed
by statute.
   B.   Purchase By, Accepting Gift, Possession Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for a minor to purchase or obtain any alcoholic
liquor in any tavern or other place in the City where alcoholic liquor is sold.
(1980 Code § 22-17)
      2.   Any person to whom the sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is
prohibited because of age shall not purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic
liquor or have alcoholic liquor in his possession.
(1980 Code § 22-17; amd. 2019 Code)
      3.   No person shall purchase, accept delivery or have possession of
alcoholic liquor in violation of this section.
      4.   The consumption of alcoholic liquor by any minor is forbidden.
(1980 Code §§ 22-5, 22-17)
   C.   ID Requirements; False ID:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for a minor to misrepresent his or her age for
the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor in any tavern or other
place in the City where alcoholic liquor is sold.
(1980 Code § 22-17; amd. 2019 Code)
      2.   In every tavern or other place in the City where alcoholic liquor is
sold, there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place, a printed
card which shall be supplied by the City Clerk and which shall read
substantially as follows:
   WARNING TO MINORS
      You are subject to a fine up to Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) under Title
4, Chapter 2 of the Watseka City Code if you purchase alcoholic liquor, or
misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic
liquor.
(1980 Code § 22-17)
      3.   If a licensee or his agents or employees believe or have reason to
believe that a sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of
the age of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or
delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification,
containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his
official duties.
      4.   No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification
card; use the identification card of another; carry or use a false or forged
identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false
information.
(1980 Code §§ 22-5, 22-17)
   D.   Sales For, Delivery To, Gifting Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to sell, give, or deliver alcoholic liquor to
any minor.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is an adult to purchase or
buy any alcoholic liquor for the purpose of reselling the same to a minor or
for the purpose of giving or delivering the same to any such minor.
      3.   The sale of intoxicating liquor to any minor, the gift of
intoxicating liquor to any minor, and the purchase of intoxicating liquor by,
for or in behalf of any minor person within the City is hereby prohibited.
(1980 Code § 22-17)
   E.   Presence On Premises:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a Class C retail liquor
dealer’s license, or his or her agent or employee, to suffer or permit any
minor to be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to or
situated in the room or place where such licensed premises is located; provided
that this subsection E1 shall not apply to any minor who is accompanied by his
or her parent or guardian, or spouse of legal age, or any licensed premises for
which a “restaurant” subclass license has been issued; and provided, that this
subsection E1 shall not apply to any licensed recreational center to or in
which center alcoholic liquor is not served or sold.
(1980 Code § 22-17; amd. 2019 Code)
      2.   In this subsection, a “licensed recreational center” shall mean an
area standing apart from the immediate bar area, in which various forms of
entertainment are provided for the public. Such recreational areas shall
include regulation size or sanctioned bowling alleys, three (3) or more
regulation size billiard or pool tables, or such forms of entertainment as from
time to time shall be approved by the City Council. The annual license fee for
each recreational center shall be ten dollars ($10.00). All applications for
licensed recreational centers shall be made in accordance with the general
provisions of the title on licenses, and when approved by the Mayor and Liquor
Committee, the license shall be issued by the City Clerk.
      3.   At every tavern or other place in the City where the principal
business is the sale of alcoholic liquor, there shall be displayed at all times
in a prominent place near every entrance and placed so as to be clearly visible
to all entrants, a sign which shall be provided by the City Clerk and which
shall read substantially as follows:
   MINORS NOT PERMITTED
   Under Title 4, chapter 2 of the City Code of the City of Watseka, minors are
not permitted on these premises, except when accompanied by parent, guardian,
or spouse of legal age. All entrants must have legal proof of age.
      4.   In addition to all other fines and penalties, the Mayor may suspend
or revoke the retail liquor dealer’s license for any violation of the
provisions of this subsection.
(1980 Code § 22-17)
   F.   Employment:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any minor to sell any alcoholic liquor in
any Class B licensed retail establishment; except, that minors eighteen (18)
years old and older may sell alcoholic liquor in any Class B establishment in
which the minor is employed, on the condition that an employee of the
establishment is present on the premises in a supervisory capacity and is not
less than the age of twenty one (21) years.
(Ord. 2441, 5-26-2015)
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any minor to draw, pour, mix or serve any
alcoholic liquor in any licensed retail premises; except, that minors over the
age of eighteen (18) years may serve alcoholic liquor at Class A or C subclass
“restaurant establishments”; provided, however, that this exception shall apply
only on the conditions that:
(1980 Code § 22-17)
         a.   A person over the age of twenty one (21) years shall be present
in a supervisory capacity; and
(1980 Code § 22-17; amd. 2019 Code)
         b.   Such service shall be solely in the capacity of waiting tables in
a dining area and not in a lounge area or a bar room.
   G.   Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian: It shall be unlawful for any
parent or guardian to permit any minor child of whom he or she may be the
parent or guardian to violate any of the provisions of this section.
(1980 Code § 22-17)
   H.   Penalties:
      1.   Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of this section
shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each conviction thereof.
      2.   Any adult convicted of violating any of the provisions of this
section shall be penalized pursuant to subsection
4-2-23B of this chapter.
(1980 Code §§ 22-5, 22-17)
4-2-18: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS:
A. Consumption In Public (see also section
7-8-1 of this Code): No person shall carry, possess, or consume any alcoholic
liquor on any street, sidewalk, alley, or any other public way within the
limits of the City, unless the alcoholic liquor is in its original container
with the seal unbroken.
(Ord. 2247, 11-13-2007)
   B.   Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any license holder to permit any
person to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe in any building,
tent, or other structure used for any of the purposes for which a license is
issued under this chapter. In the event of a violation of this subsection, the
license shall be subject to suspension or revocation under the provisions of
subsection
4-2-21A of this chapter.
(Ord. 2287, 4-28-2009)
4-2-19: INSPECTIONS; ENTRY POWERS:
By acceptance of a liquor license under this chapter, each licensee shall be
deemed to consent to entry on the licensed premises by the Liquor Control
Commissioner, his agents, or any law enforcement officer to determine whether
any of the provisions of the statutes or any rules or regulations adopted by
the Liquor Control Commissioner or by the State Commission have been or are
being violated, and at such time to examine the premises of the licensee in
connection therewith. Refusal to permit such entry by the licensee or
employees, or agents of the licensee, shall be a violation of this chapter and
subject to the penalties herein prescribed.
(1980 Code § 22-19(a))
4-2-20: COMPLAINTS BY RESIDENTS:
Any five (5) residents of the City shall have the right to file a complaint in
writing with the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, stating that any licensee
of the City has been or is violating the provisions of this chapter, which
complaint shall be signed and sworn to by the parties complaining. The
complaint shall state the particular provision of this chapter believed to have
been violated and the facts, in detail, upon which the belief is based. If the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner is satisfied that the complaint substantially
charges a violation and that from the facts as alleged, there is reasonable
cause of such belief, he shall set the matter for hearing and shall serve
notice upon the licensee of the time and place of such hearing and of the
particular charge in the complaint.
(1980 Code § 22-22)
4-2-21: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FINE IN LIEU:
   A.   Grounds: In case any rioting, brawling, fighting, display of deadly
weapons, lewd misconduct, violation of the laws of this State, or violation of
any of the ordinances of the City, or of this chapter takes place within, upon,
or adjacent to the premises licensed, the Mayor, with the consent of the Liquor
Control Committee, may revoke the license of said licensee, or he may suspend
the license for such period as shall be agreed upon by the Mayor and the Liquor
Control Committee. During the time the license shall be suspended, the
licensee, his agents, servants, and employees, shall make no sale of any
alcoholic beverages at retail in or upon the premises described in the license.
In case of revocation or suspension for cause, the licensee shall not be
entitled to a refund of any license fees.
(1980 Code § 22-20)
   B.   Hearing: No license shall be revoked or suspended, except after a
public hearing by the Liquor Control Commissioner, with a three-day written
notice to the licensee, affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and
defend. Such notice, if practicable, shall be served personally upon the
licensee, but if the licensee has left the City or cannot be found, a seven-day
notice sent through the United States mail, postage prepaid, and addressed to
the licensee at his last known address, may be used in place of personal
service. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall reduce all evidence to
writing and shall maintain an official record of the proceedings. The Local
Liquor Control Commissioner shall, within five (5) days after the hearing, if
he determines after such hearing that the license shall be revoked or
suspended, state the reason or reasons for such determination in a written
order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a copy of such order, within
the five (5) days, upon the licensee.
(1980 Code § 22-21)
   C.   Fine In Lieu Of Suspension Or Revocation: In addition to suspension,
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner may levy a fine on the licensee for such
violations. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for a first violation within a twelve-month period, one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve-month period, and
two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or subsequent
violation within a twelve-month period. Each day on which a violation continues
shall constitute a separate violation. Not more than fifteen thousand dollars
($15,000.00) in fines under this subsection may be imposed against any licensee
during the period of his license. Proceeds from such fines shall be paid into
the Municipal Treasury.
(1980 Code § 22-21)
4-2-22: APPEALS:
Pursuant to 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-9, it is hereby resolved and
ordained by the City Council that, as provided for home rule municipalities,
the appeal from an order or action of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner
shall be limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings of such
Local Liquor Control Commissioner. On appeal, a certified official record of
the proceedings taken and prepared by a certified court reporter shall be filed
by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner within five (5) days after notice of
the filing of such appeal.
(1980 Code § 22-27)
4-2-23: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Responsibility For Violations: Every act or omission of whatever nature
constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by any
manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to
be the act of such employer or licensee, and the employer or licensee shall be
punishable in the same manner as if said act or omission had been done or
omitted by him personally.
(1980 Code § 22-23)
   B.   Penalties: Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the
provisions of this chapter, for which violation no specific penalty has been
provided, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 22-28; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 3: VIDEO GAMING
Section
4-3-1: Licenses Required
4-3-2: Applications For Licenses
4-3-3: License Fees
4-3-4: Expiration Of Licenses
4-3-5: Display Of License
4-3-6: Revocation Of License
4-3-1: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   The owner of a “video gaming terminal”, as defined in 230 ILCS Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/5 shall obtain a license for such device issued by the
City.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to install, keep, maintain, or use,
or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use, upon his or her
premises, any video gaming terminal unless a valid license issued under this
chapter for the video gaming terminal is in effect.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver video gaming terminals
within the City for use by any other person for gain or profit from the
operation thereof unless a license therefor has been issued by the City, and
the license fee has been paid for the then current year.
(Ord. 2378, 8-28-2012)
4-3-2: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
Applications for the licenses required by this chapter shall be filed with the
City Clerk and shall contain the following information:
   A.   The name, address, and date of birth of the owner of the video gaming
terminal and of the owner of the establishment where the video gaming terminal
is to be located. If the owner of the video gaming terminal is a corporation or
an LLC, the application must be signed by the president of the corporation or
the manager of the LLC, who shall provide all of the information required by
this section as to such person.
   B.   Prior convictions of the owner of the video gaming terminal and the
owner of the establishment, if any.
   C.   The place where the video gaming terminal is to be displayed or
operated and the business conducted at that location.
   D.   A description of the video gaming terminal to be covered by the
license.
   E.   Evidence that a license has been issued by the Illinois Gaming Board to
the owner of the video gaming terminal and the owner of the establishment.
(Ord. 2378, 8-28-2012)
4-3-3: LICENSE FEES:
The annual fee for each license required by this chapter shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00). The fee shall be nonrefundable and shall not be prorated.
(Ord. 2486, 9-26-2017)
4-3-4: EXPIRATION OF LICENSES:
Each license issued under this chapter shall terminate at twelve o'clock (12:
00) midnight on April 30 following its issuance, unless sooner revoked.
(Ord. 2378, 8-28-2012)
4-3-5: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
The license required by this chapter shall be prominently displayed next to the
video gaming terminal.
(Ord. 2378, 8-28-2012)
4-3-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   The Mayor, upon receiving information that a violation of the
provisions of this chapter or of the Video Gaming Act (230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.)
by an owner or licensee of a video gaming terminal may have occurred, shall
notify such owner or licensee of any charge of a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter or of the Video Gaming Act in connection with the
operation of any video gaming terminal.
   B.   Upon five (5) days notice of a hearing to the owner or licensee, which
hearing shall be before the Mayor with the opportunity of such owner or
licensee to be heard, the Mayor may order the revocation of the license upon a
finding that a violation of the provisions of this chapter or of the Video
Gaming Act has occurred, and the license shall thereupon be terminated.
(Ord. 2378, 8-28-2012)
CHAPTER 4: AMUSEMENTS
Section
4-4-1: Scope
4-4-2: License Required; Exemptions
4-4-3: Applications For Licenses; Fees
4-4-4: Order And Conduct
4-4-5: Interference With Aisles And Passageways
4-4-6: Exit Signs And Lights
4-4-7: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
4-4-8: Slot Machines And Coin-Operated Machines
4-4-9: Medicine Shows
4-4-10: Exemptions From Provisions
4-4-11: Penalty
4-4-1: SCOPE:
The provisions of this chapter, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to
all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the City,
whether specifically licensed in this title or not. (1980 Code § 23-30)
4-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the
public and for admittance to which a fee is charged without having first
secured a license therefor; provided, that the provisions of this section shall
not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by any
other ordinance of the City.
(1980 Code § 23-31)
4-4-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; FEES:
Applications for licenses shall be made to the City Clerk and shall comply with
all of the general provisions of this title relating to applications. For such
licenses, the following fees shall be paid:
 
Menageries                       $ 5.00 per day
Carnivals and circuses           20.00 per day
Exhibitions of inanimate objects 5.00 per day
Other amusements                 10.00 per day
 
4-4-4: ORDER AND CONDUCT:
   A.   Order Preserved: It shall be the duty of every proprietor or lessee of
any theater or public hall, and of every person giving or conducting any show
or amusement within the City, to preserve good order in and about his place of
exhibition or amusement, and if necessary for that purpose, he shall employ at
his own expense a sufficient number of auxiliary police officers. The Chief of
Police, upon the failure of the licensee to furnish a auxiliary police officer
for maintaining good order, may close the show, entertainment, or amusement
until the licensee makes adequate provisions for maintaining good order.
(1980 Code § 23-35)
   B.   Conduct Of Audience:
      1.   The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly
and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such
amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other
risks.
(1980 Code § 23-37)
   C.   Riots: It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of
any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or
disturbance.
(1980 Code § 23-38)
4-4-5: INTERFERENCE WITH AISLES AND PASSAGEWAYS:
No chairs, stools or seats of any description shall be placed or permitted to
remain in the aisles or passageways in any theater, hall or other public
building when the same is occupied by the public or any audience. It shall be
the duty of the Chief of Police and all members of the police force to see that
this section is strictly observed; and in case of any violation hereof, to
proceed forthwith to clear any obstructed aisle or passageway, and to arrest
the offender or offenders.
(1980 Code § 23-36; amd. 2019 Code)
4-4-6: EXIT SIGNS AND LIGHTS:
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building, hall
or other enclosure used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred
(100) persons or more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures, and
other entertainment is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a
sign on which the word “Exit” shall appear in letters at least six inches (6")
high over every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress
therefrom, and a light shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over
such sign, which light shall be kept burning during the entire period that the
hall is open to the public and until the audience has left the hall.
(1980 Code § 23-41)
4-4-7: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Street Shows: No permit shall be granted or given for any carnival,
exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any public street or
sidewalk or in any place that the only main accommodation for the public or the
audience will be in a public place, except on the order of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 23-32)
   B.   Indecent, Immoral Entertainments: No person, firm or corporation,
whether licensed or not, shall give, produce, present, conduct or offer, either
publicly or privately, with or without charging an admission fee, any indecent,
immoral, lewd or impure play, exhibition, entertainment, performance,
apparatus, or production, or any play, exhibition, entertainment, performance,
apparatus or production suggestive of anything indecent, immoral, lewd or
impure, within the City.
(1980 Code § 23-33; amd. 2019 Code)
   C.   Smoking:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or
pipe in any building, tent, or other structure used for any of the purposes for
which a license is issued under this chapter.
(1980 Code § 23-39)
      2.   It shall be the duty of the owner of the premises, or of the
occupant in charge, to provide and place printed signs on which the words “No
Smoking” shall appear in letters at least four inches (4") high, in conspicuous
places on the premises.
(1980 Code § 23-40)
4-4-8: SLOT MACHINES AND COIN-OPERATED MACHINES:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to maintain or expose for public
use any coin-operated machine or any slot machine, operated with a slug or
coin, for the use or operation of which a fee is charged, without having first
obtained a license therefor.
   B.   License Fee: The annual fee for such licenses shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per gaming/video machine.
   C.   Definition: As used in this section, the term SLOT MACHINE shall mean
and include any device not a gambling device, operated by means of slugs or
coins, which show pictures, numbers or symbols, singly or in combinations, as a
result of operation, and shall include coin-operated pool tables.
   D.   Interpretation: A coin-operated machine shall include machines operated
by the insertion of paper currency, but shall not include coin-operated
machines otherwise licensed in this Code.
(1980 Code § 23-42)
4-4-9: MEDICINE SHOWS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to give or conduct any medicine
show or performance in connection with or for the purpose of attracting
prospective buyers of, or crowds for the purpose of lectures on or
demonstrations of any tonic, medicine, remedy specific for human ailments,
without having first secured a license therefor.
   B.   Application For License: Applications for such licenses shall state
thereon the name, nature and contents of the article to be promoted or offered
for sale. Such applications shall be referred to the Chief of Police.
   C.   Review Of Applications; Restrictions On Issuance: No license shall be
issued where the tonic, medicine, or remedy is harmful for use without the
advice of a physician or consists in whole or part of harmful habit-forming
drugs or narcotics.
(1980 Code § 23-43)
4-4-10: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall not require the taking out of a license or the payment of
license fees by citizens or residents of the City for the production of
theatricals, musical entertainments, cantatas, lectures, church or band fairs,
balls or like entertainments, where such entertainments shall be under the
auspices of local organizations or persons, wholly or in the greater part
consisting of local talent, and for the benefit of religious, charitable or
educational organizations, or where the proceeds of such entertainment shall go
to the general funds for the maintenance of local organizations, churches,
schools, bands, lodges, hospitals or for like purposes, such entertainments
being produced only for a period not exceeding one week in any one month by any
one organization.
(1980 Code § 23-34)
4-4-11: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, each person, firm or corporation
violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined as set
forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 23-190; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 5: RAFFLES
Section
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Raffle Licensing Commissioner
4-5-3: License Required
4-5-4: Qualifications Of Licensee; Ineligibility For License
4-5-5: Application For License; Fee
4-5-6: Contents Of License
4-5-7: Term Of License
4-5-8: Display Of License
4-5-9: Conduct Of Raffles
4-5-10: Inspections
4-5-11: Raffles Manager
4-5-12: Records And Reports
4-5-13: Issuance, Suspension And Revocation Of License
4-5-14: Responsibility For Violations
4-5-15: Penalties
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
FRATERNAL ORGANIZATION: An organization of persons having a common interest,
the primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and
to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the
burdens of government by caring for those that otherwise would be cared for by
government.
LICENSEE: Any person or club holding a license under the provisions of this
chapter.
NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of the raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
RAFFLE: A form of “lottery”, as defined in section 28-2(b) of the Illinois
Criminal Code of 2012, as amended (720 ILCS 5/28-2(b), conducted by an
organization licensed under this chapter, in which:
   A.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
presented and differentiated by a number, or by any combination of numbers, or
by some other medium, one or more of which chance is to be designated the
winning chance.
   B.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by other
method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of
persons conducting or connected with the lottery; except, that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
RAFFLE does not include a savings promotion raffle authorized under section 5g
of the Illinois Banking Act, section 7008 of the Savings Bank Act, section 42.7
of the Illinois Credit Union Act, section 5136B of the National Bank Act (12
USC 25a) or section 4 of the Home Owners’ Loan Act (12 USC 1463).
RAFFLES AND POKER RUNS ACT: The Act of the General Assembly of Illinois
entitled "Raffles and Poker Runs Act", which was approved August 5, 1980, as
amended, and cited as 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/0.01 et. seq.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-2: RAFFLE LICENSING COMMISSIONER:
The Mayor of the City or his designee shall be the Raffle Licensing
Commissioner.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
There is hereby authorized the issuance of licenses for the purpose of
conducting raffles in the City in conformance with the “Raffles and Poker Runs
Act” of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-4: QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEE; INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
   A.   A license pursuant to this chapter shall be issued only to a bona fide
fraternal organization that operates without profit to their members and has
been in existence continuously for a period of at least five (5) years
immediately before making application for a license and which has had, during
that entire five-year period, a bona fide membership, engaged in carrying out
their objects, and as further defined in the Illinois Raffles and Poker Runs
Act (230 ILCS 15/12b).
   B.   The following persons or entities are ineligible for any license under
this chapter:
      1.   Any person whose felony conviction will impair the person’s ability
to engage in the licensed position;
      2.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or promoter;
      3.   Any person who is not of good moral character;
      4.   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection B1,
B2 or B3 of this section has a proprietary, legal or equitable interest in, or
which the person is active or employed;
      5.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or
B3 of this section is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or
not.
      6.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or
B3 of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a
RAFFLE, as defined in this chapter.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
   C.   Applicant Convictions.
    
      1.   The licensing authority shall not require applicants to report the
following information and shall not consider the following criminal history
records in connection with an application for licensure:
         a.   Juvenile adjudications of delinquent minors as defined in section
5-105 of the Juvenile Court Act of 1987, subject to the restrictions set forth
in section 5-130 of the Juvenile Court Act of 1987.
         b.   Law enforcement records, court records, and conviction records of
an individual who was 17 years old at the time of the offense and before
January 1, 2014, unless the nature of the offense required the individual to be
tried as an adult.
         c.   Records of arrest not followed by a conviction.
         d.   Convictions overturned by a higher court.
         e.   Convictions or arrests that have been sealed or expunged.
      2.   The licensing authority, upon a finding that an applicant for a
license was previously convicted of a felony shall consider any evidence of
rehabilitation and mitigating factors contained in the applicant’s record,
including any of the following factors and evidence, to determine if the
conviction will impair the ability of the applicant to engage in the position
for which a license is sought:
         a.   The lack of direct relation of the offense for which the
applicant was previously convicted to the duties, functions, and
responsibilities of the position for which a license is sought;
         b.   Whether five (5) years since a felony conviction or three (3)
years since release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is later,
have passed without a subsequent conviction;
         c.   If the applicant was previously licensed or employed in this
State or other states or jurisdictions, then the lack of prior misconduct
arising from or related to the licensed position or position of employment;
         d.   The age of the person at the time of the criminal offense;
         e.   Successful completion of sentence and, for applicants serving a
term of parole or probation, a progress report provided by the applicant’s
probation or parole officer that documents the applicant’s compliance with
conditions of supervision;
         f.   Evidence of the applicant’s present fitness and professional
character;
         g.   Evidence of rehabilitation or rehabilitative effort during or
after incarceration, or during or after a term of supervision, including, but
not limited to, a certificate of good conduct under section 5-5.5-25 of the
Unified Code of Corrections or a certificate of relief from disabilities under
section 5-5.5-10 of the Unified Code of Corrections; and
         h.   Any other mitigating factors that contribute to the person’s
potential and current ability to perform the duties and responsibilities of the
position for which a license or employment is sought.
      3.   If the licensing authority refuses to issue a license to an
applicant, then the applicant shall be notified of the denial in writing with
the following included in the notice of denial:
         a.   A statement about the decision to refuse to issue a license;
         b.   A list of the convictions that the licensing authority determined
will impair the applicant’s ability to engage in the position for which a
license is sought;
         c.   A list of convictions that formed the sole or partial basis for
the refusal to issue a license; and
         d.   A summary of the appeal process or the earliest the applicant may
reapply for a license, whichever is applicable.
      4.   No later than May 1 of each year, the licensing authority must
prepare, publicly announce, and publish a report of summary statistical
information relating to new and renewal license applications during the
preceding calendar year. Each report shall show, at a minimum:
         a.   The number of applicants for a new or renewal license within the
previous calendar year;
         b.   The number of applicants for a new or renewal license within the
previous calendar year who had any criminal conviction;
         c.   The number of applicants for a new or renewal license in the
previous calendar year who were granted a license;
         d.   The number of applicants for a new or renewal license with a
criminal conviction who were granted a license within the previous calendar
year;
         e.   The number of applicants for a new or renewal license within the
previous calendar year who were denied a license; and
         f.   The number of applicants for a new or renewal license with a
criminal conviction who were denied a license in the previous calendar year in
whole or in part because of a prior conviction.
(230 ILCS 15/3.1)
4-5-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
   A.   Any applicant for a license shall apply for the license in writing and
file the application with the City Clerk. The filing fee for each license shall
be five dollars ($5.00) and shall be paid at the time of filing the
application. Any funds received as a result of the application shall be
deposited in the General Fund of the City.
   B.   The application for license shall specify the location in which raffle
chances will be sold or issued, the time and determination of winning chances
and location or locations at which winning chances will be determined, the
nature and number of ....... The application for license must be completed in
its entirety and must include a sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit
character of the prospective license organization, signed by the presiding
officer and the secretary of the organization, and must include authorization
to conduct a background check including credit information and criminal
history.
   C.   The application shall also contain a written agreement signed by the
applicant or authorized officer of the applicant, hereby holding the City, its
officers, Alderpersons, employees, attorneys and all other agents harmless from
any claim or cause of action (whether State or Federal) for injury or damages
arising out of, or in any way related to, the subject raffle or to any property
(real and/or personal) conveyed by the applicant pursuant to the subject
raffle.
   D.   The Raffle Commissioner shall review the applications and shall act
upon the application within thirty (30) days of receipt. Any additional
information which may be required and requested shall extend the time for
answering to thirty (30) days from the response to said request.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-6: CONTENTS OF LICENSE:
A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall state the
name and address of the licensee, a description of the premises for which the
license is granted and the dates of its issuance and expiration.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-7: TERM OF LICENSE:
Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for not more than one
year and for the number of raffles specified in the application and license.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-8: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Upon issuance, the license shall be displayed at the site where the winning
chances will be determined.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-9: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct the game.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of a raffle.
   D.   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance
or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under
this chapter and Illinois Raffles and Poker Runs Act.
   E.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on
the license, and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the license for a raffle.
   F.   A person under the age of eighteen (18) may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances only with permission of a parent or guardian.
A person under the age of eighteen (18) may be within the area where winning
chances in a raffle are being determined only when accompanied by his parent or
guardian.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-10: INSPECTIONS:
Licensees shall make all premises named in the license issued pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter available for inspection by the local Raffle
Commissioner, Alderperson of the City, duly appointed police officers of the
City and other officers designated by the Mayor to conduct inspections and
observations pursuant to this chapter.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-11: RAFFLES MANAGER:
All operations of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of
a single raffles manager designated by the organization.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-12: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning games are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, description of the
purchased item of service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount
and date of payment.
   B.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo receipts,
if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant
to a license therefor being issued by the Department of Revenue of the State of
Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have
separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same
person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
   C.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report promptly
after the conclusion of each raffle to its membership, and to the Raffle
Licensing Commissioner, its gross receipts, expenses and net proceed from
raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this
section.
   D.   Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and the organization shall make available their records relating to the
operation of raffles for public inspection at a reasonable time and place.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-13: ISSUANCE, SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   The Raffle Licensing Commissioner may issue, revoke, or suspend any
license in accordance with the provisions of this chapter or on the basis or
provisions of any State of Illinois law pertaining to raffles.
   B.   Any raffle license may be suspended or revoked for any violation of
this chapter, or any other City ordinance, or any violation of the Illinois
Raffles and Poker Runs Act, or any other applicable State Statutes.
   C.   When any licensee shall have its license revoked for any cause, no
license shall be granted for a period of one year thereafter.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-14: RESPONSIBILITY FOR VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager, or
other agent of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
employer or licensee, and said employer or licensee shall be punishable in the
same manner as if said act or omission had been done or omitted by him
personally.
   B.   Any person or organization who is licensed by the City for the purposes
of selling raffle chances shall be deemed to be licensed within the City for
the purposes of selling or offering for sale any raffle chance.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
4-5-15: PENALTIES:
Any person or organization that is convicted of violating any of the provisions
of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00). Each day
any person or organization violates or continues to violate any provisions of
this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. Suspension or revocation of a
license may be in addition to the imposition of a fine or other such penalty
for the conviction of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, and
suspension or revocation shall be no defense to a prosecution for such
violations.
(Ord. 2439, 4-28-2015)
CHAPTER 6: PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
Section
4-6-1: Definitions
4-6-2: Permit Required
4-6-3: Application For Permit
4-6-4: Permit And Badge Fees
4-6-5: Review Of Application; Issuance Or Denial Of Permit
4-6-6: Contents And Expiration Of Permit
4-6-7: Canvassers Exempt From Permit Requirements
4-6-8: Uninvited Soliciting, Peddling Or Canvassing
4-6-9: Permitted Hours
4-6-10: Handbills And Flyers
4-6-11: Street Solicitations Prohibited
4-6-12: Suspension Or Revocation Of Permit
4-6-13: Appeals
4-6-14: Claims Of Exemptions
4-6-15: Penalty
4-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases, and their derivations, when used in
this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
CANVASSER: Any person who attempts to make personal contact with another
(except on premises where that person is employed or resides) for the primary
purpose of: a) attempting to enlist support for or against a particular
religion, philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, or candidate, even if
incidental to the purpose, the canvasser accepts contributions for or against
such cause; and/or b) distributes a handbill, flyer, pamphlet, or any other
type of literature advertising a noncommercial event, service or ideal.
CANVASSER shall also include any person who seeks charitable contributions for
a patriotic, philanthropic, religious, social, health, welfare, benevolent,
educational, civic, cultural or fraternal cause or ideology.
CANVASSING ACTIVITIES: The actions of a canvasser.
CITY: The City of Watseka.
CITY CLERK: The City Clerk of the City of Watseka or his/her assigns.
CONTRIBUTIONS: Mean and include alms, money, subscriptions, property, or any
other types of donations.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The City Council of the City of Watseka.
PEDDLER: Any person who, not having been invited by another, carries or
transports goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature and
offers the same for sale (except on premises where that person is employed or
resides). A PEDDLER shall also include any person who solicits orders and, as a
separate transaction, makes a subsequent delivery to a purchaser.
PEDDLING ACTIVITIES: The actions of a peddler.
PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, association, club, society or other
organization.
SOLICITING ACTIVITIES: The actions of a solicitor.
SOLICITOR: Any person who, not having been invited by another (except on
premises where that person is employed or resides), takes or attempts to take
orders for the sale of goods, merchandise, wares, or other personal property of
any nature for future delivery, or for services performed in the future. A
SOLICITOR shall also include any person who distributes handbills and flyers
advertising a commercial event or service.
STREET: Any public street, highway or other thoroughfare primarily intended for
use by motor vehicles. STREET shall mean the entire area between a curb cut,
including, but not limited to, any and all medians and crosswalks.
STREET SOLICITATION: The act of soliciting, peddling or canvassing in and on a
City street or highway.
(2019 Code)
4-6-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling or solicitation
activities within the City without first obtaining a permit issued by the City
Clerk.
(2019 Code)
4-6-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person who desires to engage in peddling or solicitation activities shall
file with the City Clerk an application in writing, on a form to be furnished
by the City Clerk, which shall consist of the following information:
   A.   Name, address, age and telephone number of the applicant, which shall
be confirmed through the applicant’s driver’s license or State identification
card, articles of incorporation, or other legally recognized form of
identification;
   B.   A brief description of the business or activity;
   C.   If acting as an employee of an employer, the name, address and
telephone number of the employer; or if acting as an agent, the name, address
and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with
credentials in written form establishing the relationship and the authority of
the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case may be;
   D.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of or
pleaded guilty to a felony or misdemeanor, the nature of the offense, and the
date of the conviction or plea;
   E.   A statement as to whether the applicant has had a permit denied,
suspended or revoked for noncompliance with this chapter in the past; and
   F.   Proof of possession of any license or permit which, under Federal,
State or local law, the applicant is required to have in order to conduct the
proposed business, or which, under any such law, would exempt the applicant
from the permit requirements of this chapter.
(2019 Code)
4-6-4: PERMIT AND BADGE FEES:
At the time the application is filed with the City Clerk, the applicant shall
pay a fee to cover the cost of processing the application and investigating the
facts stated therein. The permit fee shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for each
solicitor and peddler.
(2019 Code)
4-6-5: REVIEW OF APPLICATION; ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT:
   A.   Review Of Application; Issuance Of Permit: Upon receipt of an
application, the City Clerk shall review the application to determine if all of
the information required by this chapter is present. If the application has
listed all of the information necessary, and there exists no reason to deny the
permit for the reasons set forth in subsection F2 of this section, the City
Clerk shall issue the permit to the applicant.
   B.   Contents Of Permit: Any permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall
contain the name and address of the permittee, the name of any employer or
principal, the class of permit issued, the date of issuance and the date of
expiration.
   C.   Time Limit For Review; Temporary Permit: The City Clerk shall make a
good faith effort to complete an application review and advise an applicant of
his/her decision within seventy two (72) hours of receipt of the application,
excepting weekends and holidays. An applicant may obtain his/her permit from
City Hall once advised that a decision to grant the permit has been issued by
the City Clerk.
   D.   Notice Of Issuance Or Denial: The City Clerk shall notify the applicant
of his/her decision to grant or deny a permit by the telephone number listed on
the application. The City Clerk shall advise the applicant of the basis for the
denial.
   E.   Incomplete Application: If an application is incomplete, the City Clerk
shall allow the applicant an opportunity to provide the information necessary
for his/her review.
   F.   Denial Of Permit:
      1.   In the case of a denial, the City Clerk shall issue a written
decision advising the applicant why the permit was denied. The written decision
shall be mailed to the applicant via U.S. mail at the address contained on the
application. The written decision shall be postmarked no later than three (3)
business days subsequent to the expiration of the seventy two (72) hour review
period or the oral advisement of a denial of a permit, whichever is later.
      2.   The City Clerk may refuse to issue a permit for any of the following
reasons:
         a.   The location and time of solicitation or peddling referenced on
the application is otherwise prohibited by this chapter;
         b.   An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information
on the application;
         c.   The applicant has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a felony
or misdemeanor involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled substances,
crimes of dishonesty (e.g., theft, fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, etc.), or
any violent acts against persons or property within the five (5) years
preceding the date of application;
         d.   The applicant's failure to provide proof of authority to act on
behalf of an employer or principal; or
         e.   The applicant’s denial of a permit issued under this chapter
within the immediate past year, unless the applicant can and does show that the
basis for the previous denial no longer exists.
      3.   The City Clerk's denial and the reasons for disapproval shall be
noted on the application.
      4.   A denial of a permit may be appealed in the manner provided in
section
4-6-15 of this chapter.
   G.   Record Of Permits: A record of all permits issued and denied pursuant
to this chapter shall be maintained by the City Clerk for a period of two (2)
years.
(2019 Code)
4-6-6: CONTENTS AND EXPIRATION OF PERMIT:
All permits shall list the number of days and dates upon which a solicitor or
peddler is authorized to conduct his/her activities. The permit shall expire on
the date requested by the solicitor or peddler. Provided, however, no permit
shall be valid for more than one year after the date of issuance. No person
shall engage in soliciting/peddling activities without a valid permit.
(2019 Code)
4-6-7: CANVASSERS EXEMPT FROM PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
Canvassers shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this chapter.
Canvassers shall be subject to all other time, place and manner restrictions
provided in this chapter.
(2019 Code)
4-6-8: UNINVITED SOLICITING, PEDDLING OR CANVASSING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser to enter
upon any private premises in the City which has posted at the entry to the
premises or at the entry to the principal building on the premises a sign
bearing the words “No Peddlers” or “No Solicitors”, or words of similar import.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser to remain
on any private premises once requested to leave by an occupant. Once requested
to leave, a solicitor, peddler or canvasser must do so immediately and
peacefully.
(2019 Code)
4-6-9: PERMITTED HOURS:
Permitted hours for canvassing activities, peddling activities, and soliciting
activities are Monday through Saturday between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and Sunday between the hours of twelve
o'clock (12:00) noon and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. No person shall engage in
canvassing activities, peddling activities, and soliciting activities other
than during permitted hours.
(2019 Code)
4-6-10: HANDBILLS AND FLYERS:
It shall be unlawful to leave a handbill or flyer upon any premises which is
not securely attached thereto or placed in such a manner to prevent litter.
Provided, however, it shall be unlawful to damage any property in an attempt to
securely attach any handbill or flyer to a premises.
(2019 Code)
4-6-11: STREET SOLICITATIONS PROHIBITED:
Street solicitation is not permitted in or on any street or highway in the
City.
(2019 Code)
4-6-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   Any permit may be suspended or revoked for the following reasons:
      1.   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in an
application;
      2.   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by the permittee in
the course of conducting solicitation or peddling activities;
      3.   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities contrary to the
provisions contained in the permit or this chapter;
      4.   A conviction of any crime which would otherwise be a basis for
denying a permit application; or
      5.   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities in such a manner so
as to create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace, or endanger
the health, safety or welfare of the public.
   B.   Any permit issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the
City Clerk after notice and a hearing for any basis identified in subsection A
of this section. Notice and a hearing prior to a suspension or revocation shall
not be given if the City Clerk determines that an immediate suspension or
revocation is necessary. In such cases, a post-deprivation hearing will be
provided.
   C.   The City Clerk shall provide notice to the permittee via U.S. mail
setting forth the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall consist of
the charges for which the permit's suspension or revocation is being
considered. The notice shall contain the date(s) on which any charge is alleged
to have occurred along with the name(s) of any witness(es) that will testify at
the hearing. Any written or tangible evidence of the occurrence shall be
identified in the notice.
   D.   A hearing pursuant to this section shall occur no earlier than seven
(7) days nor later than fourteen (14) days from the date the notice of hearing
is postmarked.
   E.   The permittee shall be responsible for obtaining a court reporter in
order to preserve the record for appeal.
   F.   After the hearing, the City Clerk shall orally advise the permittee of
his/her decision to suspend or revoke a permit under this chapter. After the
decision has been orally related to the permittee, the City Clerk shall issue a
written decision setting forth his/her decision and the basis for the ruling.
The written decision shall be mailed to the permittee via U.S. mail at the
address contained in the application. The written decision shall be postmarked
no later than three (3) business days subsequent to the hearing.
(2019 Code)
4-6-13: APPEALS:
   A.   Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the City Clerk to
deny, suspend or revoke a permit shall have the right to appeal such action to
the Corporate Authorities within fourteen (14) days from the date on which the
City Clerk’s decision has been mailed to the applicant/permittee. This date
shall be determined by the date on which the written decision was postmarked.
In the event the City Clerk fails to issue a written decision, the appellant
shall have seventeen (17) days from the date on which he/she was orally
informed of the City Clerk's decision to deny, suspend or revoke a permit to
appeal that decision.
   B.   An appeal shall be perfected by filing a written statement with the
City Clerk setting forth the grounds for the appeal. If a written decision was
provided to the appellant from the City Clerk, a copy of that decision shall be
attached to the appellant’s written statement. After the receipt of said
appeal, the City Clerk shall schedule the appeal for the next regularly
scheduled meeting of the Corporate Authorities. Provided, however, if the
appeal is received within ninety six (96) hours of a regularly scheduled
meeting, the appeal shall be heard at the following regularly scheduled
meeting.
   C.   A hearing shall be set no later than thirty (30) days from the date on
which an appeal is received.
   D.   Notice of the time and place of the appeal hearing shall be given to
the appellant via U.S. mail at the address provided on the person's
application.
   E.   An appellant shall be given notice of the hearing at least seventy two
(72) hours before the hearing.
   F.   A decision to affirm or reverse the decision of the City Clerk
concerning the suspension or revocation of a permit shall be limited to the
record generated at the hearing in front of the City Clerk.
   G.   The decision of the Corporate Authorities shall be final and binding on
all parties concerned.
   H.   A decision to affirm or reverse a decision of the City Clerk shall be
made by a majority vote of the Corporate Authorities present at the meeting.
(2019 Code)
4-6-14: CLAIMS OF EXEMPTIONS:
Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the application of this chapter
shall cite to the City Clerk the legal authority under which the exemption is
claimed and shall present to the City Clerk proof of qualification for the
exemption.
(2019 Code)
4-6-15: PENALTY:
Any person found to have violated any provision of this chapter shall be fined
as set fort in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(2019 Code)
CHAPTER 7: JEWELRY STORES AND PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS
Section
4-7-1: Definitions
4-7-2: Record Of Transactions
4-7-3: Descriptions, Photographs Of Articles
4-7-4: Issuance Of Signed Receipt
4-7-5: Waiting Period
4-7-6: Report Of Lost Or Stolen Articles To Police
4-7-7: Return Of Stolen Property
4-7-8: Inspections
4-7-9: Exemptions From Provisions
4-7-10: Penalty
4-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
INDIVIDUALLY IDENTIFIABLE ARTICLES: Articles that are individually identifiable
by a serial number; or other applied numbers, letters, characters or markings;
or other unique features that serve to distinguish it from any other similar
article and can be used to establish ownership of the article.
JEWELRY STORE: A business where every owner, operator or employee is engaged in
the purchase, sale, trade or barter of jewelry, including, but not limited to,
jewelry and/or precious metals and stones, whether the dealer operates from a
fixed storefront business, or is conducting business on a temporary, short-term
basis from a nonfixed location.
PRECIOUS METALS: Articles consisting primarily of the elements gold (chemical
symbol Au), silver (chemical symbol Ag), platinum (chemical symbol Pt) or
palladium (chemical symbol Pd), but not including articles merely plated with
these metals or articles similar in color to these metals but not actually
consisting of them.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-2: RECORD OF TRANSACTIONS:
Every jewelry store shall collect the below listed information for each and
every transaction conducted during each day they were open for business by the
end of that business day and must fax or otherwise provide the Police
Department with the below listed information by the end of that same business
day:
   A.   The name, current address, and date of birth of the seller;
   B.   A digital photographic or scanned image of a photo ID card of the
seller, sufficiently clear to allow the information on the ID to be read. The
photo ID must be a currently valid (not expired) card issued by a government
entity of a state or of the United States, and must include the seller’s first
and last name, current address, date of birth, and physical description; and
   C.   The date and time of the transaction.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-3: DESCRIPTIONS, PHOTOGRAPHS OF ARTICLES:
   A.   Individual Descriptions: Each individually identifiable item of jewelry
and/or precious metals and stones brought into a jewelry store by a seller for
sale, barter, or trade, during a single transaction, shall be itemized
separately. The jewelry store shall not lump such articles together (e.g.,
“five gold monogrammed rings”), but must instead provide a complete and
thorough description of each item to include the following:
      1.   Type of article;
      2.   Brand name/make/manufacturer (if applicable);
      3.   Color/finish; and
      4.   Any other identifying marks, writing, engraving, etc.
   B.   Photograph: A digital photograph(s) shall be taken of each individually
identifiable article, sufficiently detailed to allow reasonable identification
of the article. The digital photograph(s) shall capture any identifying
numbers, marks, writing, engraving, etc., or any other distinguishing
characteristics of each item.
   C.   Nonindividually Identifiable Articles: Articles that cannot be
distinguished from any other similar articles may be described in groups of
similar types of articles, but only within the same transaction made by the
same seller. The jewelry store shall provide reasonable descriptions of the
number and types of items within each group to enable the Police Department to
determine if they may have been stolen during a particular crime.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-4: ISSUANCE OF SIGNED RECEIPT:
Every jewelry store operator shall, at the time of receiving any item of
jewelry and/or precious metals and stones, deliver to the person selling,
delivering, bartering, or trading any such property a receipt signed by him/her
containing an accurate account and description, in the English language, of all
jewelry and/or precious metals and stones, goods, articles or other things so
sold, delivered, bartered, or traded.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-5: WAITING PERIOD:
No jewelry and/or precious metals and stones received by a jewelry store shall
be permitted to be resold, transferred, bartered, exchanged, or otherwise
disposed of for a period of seventy two (72) hours after the delivery of the
signed receipt and the delivery of the record of transactions to the City
Police Department as provided herein.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-6: REPORT OF LOST OR STOLEN ARTICLES TO POLICE:
Every jewelry store who shall receive or be in possession of any goods,
articles or things under circumstances which would lead a reasonable person to
conclude that they have been lost or stolen, or which have been alleged or
supposed to have been lost or stolen, shall immediately notify the City Police
Department of such receipt and forthwith, on demand, exhibit the same to any
member of the Police Department.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-7: RETURN OF STOLEN PROPERTY:
When any person is found to be the owner of stolen property which has been
obtained by a jewelry store, such property shall be returned to the owner
thereof without the payment of the money paid by the jewelry store therefor or
any costs or charges of any kind which the jewelry store may have placed upon
the same.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-8: INSPECTIONS:
The Police Chief, or any officer designated by him, shall have general
supervision over all jewelry stores, and shall also have the power to inspect
their respective places of business and all articles or things kept therein
whenever he shall deem it necessary to do so to effectuate the purposes of this
chapter.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-9: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
