This chapter shall not apply to charitable organizations that accept donated
goods for resale, nor shall it apply to persons selling jewelry and/or precious
metals and stones belonging to them or family members, on a temporary basis,
from their own residential property in the form of a “garage sale” or “yard
sale”.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
4-7-10: PENALTY:
Any violation of this chapter may be punished as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(Ord. 2416, 5-27-2014)
CHAPTER 8: GARAGE AND YARD SALES
Section
4-8-1: State Certificate Or Local Permit Required
4-8-2: Posting Permit
4-8-3: Number Of Sales And Days Of Sales
4-8-4: Removal Of Permit And Advertisements
4-8-5: Record Of Permits
4-8-6: Inclement Weather; Reissuance Of Permit
4-8-7: Penalty
4-8-1: STATE CERTIFICATE OR LOCAL PERMIT REQUIRED:
Any person, firm, corporation, or other entity within the City shall conduct
sales commonly referred to and known as garage sales, porch sales, basement
sales, yard sales and similar types of sales, and not holding a valid
certificate of registration issued pursuant to the provision of 35 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 120/2a (retailers’ occupation tax certificate) must first
obtain a permit therefor by applying to the City Clerk not less than five (5)
days prior to the commencement of such sale.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
4-8-2: POSTING PERMIT:
The permit referred to in section
4-8-1 of this chapter must be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises
permitted for such sale, visible from the street, no more than three (3) days
prior to the date of the sale.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
4-8-3: NUMBER OF SALES AND DAYS OF SALES:
   A.   No person shall conduct a garage sale, yard sale, basement sale, or
personal property sale, as defined in section
4-8-1 of this chapter, more than twice during any consecutive twelve-month
period from the same residential address.
   B.   Any such sale or holding for sale shall be limited to any two (2)
consecutive calendar days only.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
4-8-4: REMOVAL OF PERMIT AND ADVERTISEMENTS:
The permit and any signs, notices, or any other document advertising such sale
posted anywhere within the City must be promptly removed within four (4) hours
after the sale is completed.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
4-8-5: RECORD OF PERMITS:
The City Clerk shall keep a log or record of all permits issued hereunder,
indicating thereon the name of the permittee, the address of the sale premises,
and the date or dates of sale.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
4-8-6: INCLEMENT WEATHER; REISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
In the event that a permit has been issued and inclement weather occurs over a
substantial portion of those days permitted for the sale, such permittee, upon
due proof of same and within ten (10) days from the last day of the sale
permitted, may make a renewed application to the City Clerk for reissuance of
such defeated permit, and upon such proof and issuance, there shall be no
charge for the reissuance of the renewed permit.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
4-8-7: PENALTY:
Any person who sells or endeavors to sell any merchandise at such sale in
violation of the terms of this chapter shall be subject to section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(Ord. 2327, 7-27-2010)
CHAPTER 9: TOBACCO AND RELATED PRODUCTS
Section
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: License Required
4-9-3: Application For License
4-9-4: Acts Prohibited
4-9-5: Purpose And Possession By Certain Persons Prohibited
4-9-6: Vending Machines
4-9-7: Responsibility For Agent And Employees
4-9-8: Penalty
4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the following meanings:
ADULT-ONLY FACILITY: A facility or restricted area (whether open-air or
enclosed) where the operator ensures or has a reasonable basis to believe (such
as by checking identification as required under State law, or by checking the
identification of any person appearing to be under the age of 30) that no
person under legal age is present. A facility or restricted area need not be
permanently restricted to persons under 21 years of age to constitute an adult-
only facility, provided that the operator ensures or has a reasonable basis to
believe that no person under twenty one (21) years of age is present during the
event or time period in question.
AGE RESTRICTED AREA: A signed designated area in a retail establishment to
which persons under twenty one (21) years of age are not permitted access
unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT: A product or device not consisting of or
containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine,
whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting,
sniffing, or by any other means. ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT does not include:
cigarettes as defined in section 1 of the Cigarette Tax Act and tobacco
products as defined in section 10-5 of the Tobacco Products Tax Act of 1995;
TOBACCO PRODUCT and ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE as defined in this section; or any
product approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as
a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence product, or for other
medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely for that approved
purpose.
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE: Any device that employs a battery or other mechanism to
heat a solution or substance to produce a vapor or aerosol intended for
inhalation; any cartridge or container of a solution or substance intended to
be used with or in the device or to refill the device; or any solution or
substance, whether or not it contains nicotine intended for use in the device.
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE includes, but is not limited to, any electronic nicotine
delivery system, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe,
electronic hookah, vape pen, or similar product or device, and any components
or parts that can be used to build the product or device. ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE
does not include: cigarettes as defined in section 1 of the Cigarette Tax Act
and tobacco products as defined in section 10-5 of the Tobacco Products Tax Act
of 1995; TOBACCO PRODUCT and ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT as defined in this
section; any product approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration
for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence product, or
for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely for that
approved purpose; any asthma inhaler prescribed by a physician for that
condition and is being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose; or
any therapeutic product approved for use under the Compassionate Use of Medical
Cannabis Pilot Program Act.
LINE OF SIGHT: Visible to a cashier or other employee.
LUNCH WAGON: A mobile vehicle designed and constructed to transport food and
from which food is sold to the general public.
NICOTINE: Any form of the chemical nicotine, including any salt or complex,
regardless of whether the chemical is naturally or synthetically derived.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, or association who
establishes for operation by another, or leases or distributes for the purpose
of operation for another, any device or machine for the vending of tobacco
products, electronic cigarettes, alternative nicotine products, tobacco
accessories or smoking herbs whether or not such establishment for operation,
leasing or distribution be for a fixed charge or rental, or on the basis of the
division of the income obtained from said machine.
OWNER: An operator who has acquired possession and control of a vending machine
by purchase, lease or otherwise.
SMOKELESS TOBACCO: Any tobacco products that are suitable for dipping or
chewing.
SMOKING HERBS: All substances of plant origin and their derivatives, including
but not limited to broom, calea, California poppy, damiana, hops, ginseng,
lobelia, jimson weed and other members of the Datura genus, passion flower and
wild lettuce, which are processed or sold primarily for use as smoking
materials.
TOBACCO ACCESSORIES: Cigarette papers, pipes, holders of smoking materials of
all types, cigarette rolling machines, and other items, designed primarily for
the smoking or ingestion of tobacco products or of substances made illegal
under any statute or of substances whose sale, gift, barter, or exchange is
made unlawful hereunder.
TOBACCO DEALER: Any person, at wholesale or retail, selling, offering for sale,
furnishing or offering to furnish, tobacco products, electronic cigarettes,
alternative nicotine products, tobacco accessories or smoking herbs. TOBACCO
DEALER include operators of vending machines.
TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any product containing or made from tobacco that is intended
for human consumption, whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed, dissolved,
inhaled, snorted, sniffed, or ingested by any other means, including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco,
snuff, snus, and any other smokeless tobacco product which contains tobacco
that is finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf and intended to be placed in the
oral cavity. TOBACCO PRODUCT includes any component, part, or accessory of a
tobacco product, whether or not sold separately. TOBACCO PRODUCT does not
include: an electronic cigarette and alternative nicotine product as defined in
this section; or any product that has been approved by the United States Food
and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco
dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and
sold solely for that approved purpose.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, at retail, to give away,
deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or
delivering tobacco products, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine
products, tobacco accessories or smoking herbs within the City without having
first obtained a tobacco dealer’s license therefor pursuant to this chapter.
The annual fee for a tobacco license shall be forty dollars ($40.00). Such
license shall be in addition to any other license required by this Code.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a tobacco dealer license shall be made in writing to the City
Collector. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the location
to be used, time period covered and the fee to be paid, and each applicant
shall obtain such additional information as may be needed for the proper
guidance of the City officials in issuing the said license. All licenses issued
shall be annual licenses, terminating on the last day of the fiscal year of the
City.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-4: ACTS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall sell or offer for sale, at retail, to give away,
deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or
delivering tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, alternative nicotine
products, tobacco accessories or smoking herbs within the City without having
first obtained a tobacco dealer’s license.
   B.   No person, including any tobacco dealer, shall sell, offer for sale,
give away or deliver any tobacco product, electronic cigarette, alternative
nicotine product, tobacco accessory or smoking herb to any person under the age
of twenty one (21) years.
   C.   No tobacco dealer or any officer, associate, member, representative,
agent or employee of such licensee under sixteen (16) years of age may sell any
tobacco product, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product, tobacco
accessory or smoking herb in a licensed premises. This subsection does not
apply to a sales clerk in a family-owned business which can prove that the
sales clerk is in fact a son or daughter of the owner.
   D.   Before selling, offering for sale, giving, or furnishing a tobacco
product, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product, tobacco accessory
or smoking herb to another person, the person selling, offering for sale,
giving, or furnishing the tobacco product, electronic cigarette, alternative
nicotine product, smoking accessory or smoking herb shall verify that the
person is at least twenty one (21) years of age by examining from any person
that appears to be under thirty (30) years of age a government-issued
photographic identification that establishes the person to be twenty one (21)
years of age or older.
   E.   The sale or distribution by any person of a tobacco product, including
but not limited to a single or loose cigarette, that is not contained within a
sealed container, pack, or package as provided by the manufacturer, which
container, pack, or package bears the health warning required by federal law,
is prohibited.
   F.   All single packs of tobacco products, electronic cigarettes,
alternative nicotine products, tobacco accessories and smoking herbs must be
sold from behind the counter or in an age restricted area or in a sealed
display case. Any other tobacco products must be sold in line of sight. The
restrictions described in this subsection do not apply to a retail tobacco
store that derives at least ninety percent (90%) of its revenue from tobacco
and tobacco related products; does not permit persons under the age of twenty
one (21) to enter the premises unless accompanied by a parent or legal
guardian; and posts a sign on the main entrance way stating that persons under
the age of twenty one (21) are prohibited from entering unless accompanied by a
parent or legal guardian. This subsection does not prohibit the sale of tobacco
products, electronic cigarettes, alternative nicotine products, tobacco
accessories and smoking herbs from vending machines if the location of the
vending machines are otherwise in compliance with the provision of this
chapter.
   G.   No person shall sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver any tobacco
product or alterative nicotine product within one hundred feet (100') of any
school, child care facility or other building used for education or
recreational programs for persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
   H.   No person shall distribute without charge samples of any tobacco
product, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product, tobacco accessory
or smoking herbs to any other person, regardless of age. This subsection does
not apply to the distribution of a tobacco product, electronic cigarette,
alternative nicotine product, tobacco accessory or smoking herb sample in any
adult-only facility.
   I.   No person, including shall sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver
any tobacco product, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product,
tobacco accessory or smoking herb without posting at or near every display of
such products, or upon every vending machine which offers those products for
sale, a sign stating the following:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE
PRODUCTS, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES, AND SMOKING HERBS TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY ONE
(21) YEARS OF AGE OR THE MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE TO PROCURE SUCH A SALE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW.
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background; the
letters to be at least one inch high. Such signs shall be posted in a
conspicuous place upon the premises or vending machine as the case may be.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-5: PURCHASE AND POSSESSION BY CERTAIN PERSONS PROHIBITED:
Unless otherwise expressly permitted by State law, no person under twenty one
(21) years of age shall buy, purchase, or possess any tobacco product,
electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product, tobacco accessory or
smoking herb.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-6: VENDING MACHINES:
No tobacco product, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product, tobacco
accessory or smoking herb may be sold through a vending machine except if such
tobacco product, electronic cigarette, alternative nicotine product, tobacco
accessory or smoking herb is not placed together with any non-tobacco product,
other than matches, and only if the vending machine is in any of the following
locations: places to which persons under twenty one (21) years of age are not
permitted access at any time; or places where alcoholic beverages are sold and
consumed on the premises and vending machine operation is under the direct
supervision of the owner or manager.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-7: RESPONSIBILITY FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager, or other
agent or employee of any vendor; and such vendor shall be deemed and held to be
the act of such vendor; such vendor shall be punishable in the same manner as
if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the vendor personally.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
4-9-8: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person found in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall
be fined not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day a violation
continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
   B.   Any tobacco dealer licensee found in violation of the provisions of
this chapter shall, in addition to any fine that may be imposed, be subject to
license suspension and/or revocation proceedings.
   C.   Violations of this chapter may be administered in accordance with the
provisions of Chapter 1-4A.
(Ord. 2545, 7-30-2019)
CHAPTER 10: JUNK DEALERS AND MOTOR VEHICLE WRECKING YARDS
Section
4-10-1: Licenses Required
4-10-2: License Fees
4-10-3: Stolen Goods
4-10-4: Penalty
4-10-1: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   Junk Dealers: It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business
of a junk dealer or to keep any junk shop, store or place for the purchase or
sale of junk, rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper or
empty bottles without having obtained a license therefor.
(1980 Code § 23-50)
   B.   Motor Vehicle Wrecking Yards: It shall be unlawful to operate or carry
on any motor vehicle wrecking store or yard, where motor vehicles are wrecked
and dismantled for the purpose of salvaging and selling such parts thereof as
may still be usable, and of disposing of as junk other portions thereof,
without having obtained a license therefor.
(1980 Code § 23-51)
4-10-2: LICENSE FEES:
The fee to be paid for such licenses, as an annual license and tax, shall be
the sum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and an additional fee of ten
dollars ($10.00) shall be paid for each vehicle used in the City in the conduct
of the business; provided, that a junk dealer not maintaining a store or yard
in the City shall pay only ten dollars ($10.00) per vehicle used.
(1980 Code § 23-52)
4-10-3: STOLEN GOODS:
Every keeper of a junk shop, who shall receive or be in possession of any
goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen, shall,
upon demand, produce such articles or things to any member of the Police
Department for examination.
(1980 Code § 23-53)
4-10-4: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 23-55; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 11: ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS
Section
4-11-1: Definition
4-11-2: Registration Required; Application
4-11-3: Registration Fee And Year
4-11-4: Regulations
4-11-5: Out Of Town Contractors
4-11-6: Penalty
4-11-1: DEFINITION:
The term ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR, as used in this chapter, is defined as any
person engaged in the business of installing or altering, by contract,
electrical equipment for the utilization of electricity for light, heat, or
power. The term ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR shall not include the installing or
altering of: a) radio apparatus, or equipment for wireless reception of sounds
and signals; or b) apparatus, conductors or other equipment installed for or by
public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction
of the Illinois Commerce Commission, for use in their operation as public
utilities. Nor shall the term include the employees employed by an electrical
contractor to do or supervise his work.
(1980 Code § 40-2)
4-11-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of electrical
contractor without having first obtained a certificate of registration
therefor. Applications for such certificates shall be made to the City Clerk,
and a list of all contractors registered shall be given by the Clerk to the
Electrical Inspector. The application for such certificate shall be verified,
and before the certificate may issue, it must appear to the Clerk, from the
application and from other information furnished the Clerk, that the applicant
has had at least five (5) years’ experience as a journeyman electrician
installing, altering and servicing electrical equipment. Each applicant shall
furnish the names and addresses of former employers, period of time employed,
and in what capacity, or show that he has previously been registered as an
electrical contractor, giving the date and place of such registration.
(1980 Code § 40-1)
4-11-3: REGISTRATION FEE AND YEAR:
The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor shall be twenty five
dollars ($25.00). The register year shall correspond with the license year.
(1980 Code § 40-3)
4-11-4: REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this
chapter to install any electrical appliances, wiring or fixtures without strict
compliance with the ordinances relating to such fixtures (see title 11, chapter
7 of this Code). And it shall be unlawful for any such person, firm or
corporation to do any such work without having first obtained the permits as
may be required by law.
(1980 Code § 40-4)
4-11-5: OUT OF TOWN CONTRACTORS:
Any electrical contractor who is registered as such in any other city or
village in this State shall not be required to be registered in the City, but
every out-of-town person, firm or corporation doing business in the City as an
electrical contractor shall, while doing business in the City, carry on his
person a valid certificate of registration issued by such other city or
village.
(1980 Code § 40-5)
4-11-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 40-7)
CHAPTER 12: CABLE AND VIDEO PROVIDERS
Section
4-12-1: Definitions
4-12-2: Authorization Required
4-12-3: Customer Service Obligations
4-12-4: Facilities In Public Ways
4-12-5: Service Provider Fee
4-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly
indicates otherwise:
APPLICABLE LAW: Any Federal, State, County or local law, statute, ordinance,
rule, regulation, order and decree of any court or administrative body or
tribunal, order or determination of any governmental authority that in any
manner affects or governs cable operators, cable systems, or cable services
including, but not limited to: the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as
amended by the Cable Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 and the
Telecommunications Act of 1996; the Cable and Video Competition Law of 2007
(220 ILCS 5/21-100 et seq.); the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law (220
ILCS 5/22-501 et seq.); the Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.);
the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.); and applicable
ordinances of the City of Watseka, whether or not codified and made a part of
the City of Watseka Code.
CABLE ACT OR ACT: The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended by
the Cable Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 and the
Telecommunications Act of 1996, 47 USC section 521 et seq., as the same may be
amended from time to time.
CABLE OPERATOR OR HOLDER: Any person or group of persons who provides cable
service over a cable system and directly or through one or more affiliates owns
a significant interest in such cable system; or who otherwise controls or is
responsible for, through any arrangement, the management and operation of a
cable system, and includes those entities that have received authorization to
offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401.
CABLE SERVICE OR SERVICE: The one-way transmission to subscribers of video
programming or other programming service and subscriber interaction, if any,
which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other
programming service. The term includes the provision of cable service or video
service to subscribers by, and the interaction of subscribers with, the person
or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video
service from the Commission pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-
401.
CABLE SYSTEM OR SYSTEM: Has the meaning set forth in 47 USC section 522 of the
Cable Act, and means a holder's facilities, consisting of a set of closed
transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control
equipment, that is designed to provide cable service which includes video
programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within the City, but
such term does not include: a) a facility that serves only to re-transmit the
television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; b) a facility
that serves subscribers without using any public right-of-way; c) a facility of
a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of
title II of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended; except, that such a
facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of section
621(c) of the Cable Act) to the extent such facility is used in the
transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of
such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services; d) an open video
system that complies with section 653 of the Cable Act; or e) any facilities of
any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility systems.
COMMISSION: The Illinois Commerce Commission.
CUSTOMER OR SUBSCRIBER: A person who lawfully receives and pays for cable
service with the cable operator's express permission.
FCC: The Federal Communications Commission or successor governmental entity
thereto.
GROSS REVENUES:
   A.   All consideration of any kind or nature, including, without limitation,
cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by the holder for
the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable service or video
service within the holder’s cable service or video service area within the
City.
   B.   GROSS REVENUES shall include the following:
   1.   Recurring charges for cable or video service;
      2.   Event-based charges for cable service or video service, including,
but not limited to, pay- per-view and video-on-demand charges;
      3.   Rental of set top boxes and other cable service or video service
equipment;
      4.    Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video
service, including, but not limited to, activation, installation, and repair
charges;
      5.   Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or
video service, including, but not limited to, service order and service
termination charges;
      6.   Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and
other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments;
      7.   A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or its
affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation
of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the
City. The allocation shall be based on the number of subscribers in the City
divided by the total number of subscribers in relation to the relevant regional
or national compensation arrangement;
      8.   Compensation received by the holder that is derived from the
operation of the holder’s network to provide cable service or video service
with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the holder’s network,
such as a “home shopping” or similar channel, subject to subsection A9 of this
definition;
      9.   In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or
integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the
portion of the holder’s revenue attributable to the other services,
capabilities, or applications shall be included in the gross revenue unless the
holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from
its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business; and
      10.   The service provider fee permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-801(b).
   C.   GROSS REVENUES do not include any of the following:
      1.   Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt,
subject to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi);
      2.   Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the
amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the State-issued
authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is
attributable to cable service or video service;
      3.   Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or
functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues
received from services not classified as cable service or video service,
including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication
services, information services, or the provision of directory or Internet
advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and
electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder to
noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the holder’s books and
records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable
laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders;
      4.   The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which the
purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the purchaser’s
subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will
resell the service within the City and pay the fee permitted by 220 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service;
      5.   Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers
or the transaction by a municipality, the State of Illinois, or any other
governmental entity and collected by the holder of the State-issued
authorization and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales
and use taxes;
      6.   Security deposits collected from subscribers; and
      7.   Amounts paid by subscribers to “home shopping” or similar vendors
for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the
cable service or video service.
   D.   Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the revenue of an
affiliate of a holder shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to
the extent the treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate rather than
the holder has the effect of evading the payment of the fee permitted by 220
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b) which would otherwise be paid by the
cable service or video service.
OTHER PROGRAMMING SERVICE: Information that a cable operator makes available to
all subscribers generally.
PERSON: Any natural person or any association, firm, partnership, joint
venture, corporation, or other legally recognized entity, whether for-profit or
not-for-profit, but shall not mean the City.
PUBLIC, EDUCATIONAL OR GOVERNMENTAL ACCESS FACILITIES OR PEG:
   A.   Channel capacity designated for public, educational, or governmental
use; and
   B.   Facilities and equipment for the use of such channel capacity.
PUBLIC WAY: The surface of, and the space above and below, any street, alley,
other land or waterway, dedicated or commonly used for pedestrian or vehicular
traffic or other similar purposes, including, but not limited to, public
utility easements and other easements dedicated for compatible uses, now or
hereafter held by the City, to the extent that the City has the right and
authority to authorize, regulate, or permit the location of facilities other
than those of the City. PUBLIC WAY shall not include any real or personal
property of the City that is not specifically described in this definition and
shall not include City buildings, fixtures, and other structures and
improvements, regardless of whether they are situated in the public way.
VIDEO SERVICE, VIDEO PROGRAMMING OR PROGRAMMING: Video programming and
subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of
such video programming services, and which is provided through wireline
facilities located at least in part in the public right-of- way without regard
to delivery technology, including Internet protocol technology. This definition
does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service
provider defined in 47 USC section 332(d) or any video programming provided
solely as part of, and via, service that enables users to access content,
information, electronic mail, or other services offered over the public
Internet.
(Ord. 2503, 5-22-2018)
4-12-2: AUTHORIZATION REQUIRED:
No person may construct or operate a cable system within the City without first
having obtained a franchise authorizing the same, unless that person has
obtained a State-issued authorization pursuant to the Cable and Video
Competition Law of 2007.
(Ord. 2503, 5-22-2018)
4-12-3: CUSTOMER SERVICE OBLIGATIONS:
   A.   State Regulations Adopted:
      1.   The Cable and Video Customer Protection Law, 220 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/22-501 et seq., as amended, is hereby adopted by reference.
      2.   A material breach of subsection A1 of this section shall be
punishable by a fine in the amount of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each day of a material breach, and shall not exceed twenty five thousand
dollars ($25,000.00) for each occurrence of a material breach per customer.
   B.   Enforcement: The City shall enforce all customer service and privacy
protection standards of the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law, and
process complaints received from residents of the City.
   C.   Customer Credits: The schedule of customer credits for violations shall
be as provided in 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22-501(s), and applied on
the statement issued to the customer for the next billing cycle following a
violation. The cable operator is responsible for providing the credits, and the
customer shall be under no obligation to request such credit.
(Ord. 2503, 5-22-2018)
4-12-4: FACILITIES IN PUBLIC WAYS:
The installation, construction, maintenance and operation of facilities in the
public way shall be subject to and governed by title 9, chapter 4 of this Code.
(Ord. 2503, 5-22-2018)
4-12-5: SERVICE PROVIDER FEE:
   A.   Fee Imposed: A fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable or
video service in the City at a rate of five percent (5%) of the holder's gross
revenues therefrom.
   B.   Holder’s Liability; Payment Date: A holder shall be liable for and pay
the service provider fee to the City on a quarterly basis, forty five (45) days
after the close of each calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee shall be
considered paid on the date it is properly postmarked. Each payment shall
include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. The
holder's liability for the fee shall commence on the first day of the calendar
month following thirty (30) days after its receipt of the ordinance adopting
this chapter.
   C.   Accounting Principles: All determinations and calculations relative to
the service provider fee shall be computed in accordance with generally
accepted accounting principles.
   D.   Responsibility For Taxes And Other Charges: Nothing herein shall be
construed to exempt a holder from any other tax or charge that is or may later
be imposed by the City.
   E.   Audit Required: Each holder providing cable or video service in the
City shall be subject to audit of its books and records in the manner
applicable to those cable operators governed by a franchise agreement. If none,
audits shall be subject to and governed by the provisions of section
11-42-11.05 of the Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-42-11.05), and shall otherwise
be conducted in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards. The
City’s acceptance of amounts remitted shall not be construed as an accord that
the amounts paid are correct. Any additional amount deemed owing after an audit
shall be paid by the holder to the City within thirty (30) days after the City
submission of an invoice for the sum.
   F.   Late Payments: All fees due and payments which are past due shall be
governed by title 3, chapter 3 of this Code.
(Ord. 2503, 5-22-2018)
CHAPTER 13: YARD WASTE PERMITS
Section
4-13-1: Permit Required
4-13-2: Permit Fee
4-13-3: Foreign Waste
4-13-4: Exceptions
4-13-5: Rules
4-13-6: Penalty
4-13-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Unless otherwise excepted, no person, firm, corporation, and/or other entity
shall deposit organic yard waste into the City yard waste disposal facility
after May 1, 2019 in the absence of a valid and current yard waste disposal
permit issued by the City Clerk. Such permits shall be renewed annually, and
shall be valid from May 1 of each calendar year through April 30 of the
following calendar year.
(Ord. 2536, 3-26-2019)
4-13-2: PERMIT FEE:
   A.   The annual permit fee for those persons, firms, corporations, or other
entities in the business of tree removal, tree trimming, tree surgery, or other
business involving the cutting, pruning, and/or removal of tree branches within
the limits of the City shall be two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
   B.   The annual permit fee for those persons, firms, corporations, or other
entities in the business of grounds maintenance, landscaping, lawn cutting,
leaf raking, or other business that accumulates yard waste in the course of its
services within the limits of the City at any time shall be six hundred dollars
($600.00).
(Ord. 2536, 3-26-2019)
4-13-3: FOREIGN WASTE:
No organic yard waste from locations outside of the City shall be deposited in
the City yard waste disposal facility.
(Ord. 2536, 3-26-2019)
4-13-4: EXCEPTIONS:
No permit shall be required for any person, firm, corporation, and/or other
entity to deposit organic yard waste into the City yard waste disposal facility
that is not engaged in a business identified in section
4-14-2 provided such yard waste is generated from his/its own real property
located within the City.
(Ord. 2536, 3-26-2019)
4-13-5: RULES:
All persons, firms, corporations, or other entities depositing organic yard
waste into the City yard waste disposal facility shall abide by and follow such
rules as may be posted for the use thereof, and failure to do so may result in
the suspension/revocation of privileges and/or permits.
(Ord. 2536, 3-26-2019)
4-13-6: PENALTY:
Any person or entity found in violation of any provision of this chapter shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. Each violation of this chapter or day
such violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 2536, 3-26-2019)
CHAPTER 14: CANNABIS ORGANIZATIONS
Section
4-14-1: License Required; Fee
4-14-2: Requirements
4-14-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
It shall be unlawful to establish or operate a cannabis organization in the
city without first having secured a license therefor in accordance with the
provisions of Article I of this Chapter. The license fee for a cannabis
organization shall be $2,500 annually. The license fee shall be non-refundable
and shall not be prorated.
(Ord. 2557, 1-28-2020)
4-14-2: REQUIREMENTS:
Each cannabis organization shall be required to obtain and maintain its proper
licensure through the State of Illinois to operate and shall otherwise comply
with all applicable state and local laws.
(Ord. 2557, 1-28-2020)
TITLE 5: HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
Chapter
GENERAL HEALTH AND SANITATION REGULATIONS   1

   NUISANCES RELATING TO ANIMALS   3A
   NUISANCES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY   3B

CHAPTER 1: GENERAL HEALTH AND SANITATION REGULATIONS
Section
5-1-1: Expectorating In Public
5-1-2: Water Pollution
5-1-3: Stagnant Pools Of Water
5-1-4: Unlawful Burials
5-1-1: EXPECTORATING IN PUBLIC:
   It shall be unlawful to spit or expectorate on any public ways or property
or any place frequented by the public or where the public is invited.
(1980 Code § 29-61)
5-1-2: WATER POLLUTION:
It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person, firm or corporation to
obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the City.
(1980 Code § 29-52)
5-1-3: STAGNANT POOLS OF WATER:
Any stagnant pool of water in the City is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It
shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit any such
nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his or its control.
(1980 Code § 29-53)
5-1-4: UNLAWFUL BURIALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to establish a
cemetery within the City or to bury any person within the City limits or within
a mile thereof, except in an established cemetery.
(1980 Code § 29-55)
CHAPTER 2: ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL
Section
5-2-1: Environmental Impact Reports Required
5-2-2: Environmental Assessments
5-2-3: Environmental Impact Report Procedures
5-2-1: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT REPORTS REQUIRED:
   A.   Public Projects: The City Council shall cause to be prepared an
environmental impact report on any project that it intends to carry out which
may have a significant effect on the environment, and it shall cause said
report to be filed with the Plan Commission for its consideration and report
thereon to the City Council. Such projects include:
      1.   Acquisition of property by the City; and
      2.   Construction to be performed by the City or let to contractors
pursuant to the applicable bidding and purchasing statutes and ordinances (see
title 3, chapter 2 of this Code).
(1980 Code § 26-1)
   B.   Private Projects: With respect to new private projects which may have a
significant effect on the environment of the City, the City Plan Commission
shall have jurisdiction to investigate said projects, to hold hearings thereon,
to make findings of fact thereon and to report its conclusions in writing to
the City Council. For the purpose of holding hearings, the commission shall
have the power to adopt and publish all reasonable rules and regulations for
the conduct of the hearings.
(1980 Code § 26-2)
5-2-2: ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS:
   A.   Considerations: When an environmental impact report may be required,
there shall be considered in its making an environmental assessment of whether
or not the action or activity under consideration involves:
      1.   A large-scale alteration of existing environmental components
including, but not limited to, air, water, and configuration, plant or animal
food chains and habitats.
      2.   Disruption of existing neighborhoods or communities.
      3.   An impact to a measurable degree upon rare or endangered plant or
animal species.
      4.   Substantial alteration of the physical, chemical, or biological
properties of the air, water or land in a manner contrary to the promotion of
the health, safety or welfare of a substantial number of persons, or to the
balance of an ecological resource.
      5.   Reasonable probability of irrevocable harm to the aesthetic
amenities of an area or resource.
      6.   A substantial change in existing uses of an area or resource.
      7.   A disruption or alteration of the appearance or surroundings of a
historical or archaeological site.
      8.   The growth-inducing impact of the proposed action.
      9.   The boundaries of the area which may be significantly affected by
the proposed action.
(1980 Code § 26-3)
   B.   Notice Of Hearing: Public notices of hearings on environmental
assessments shall consist of the words “Notice of Hearing on Environmental
Assessments to Determine Whether an Environmental Impact Report Shall Be
Required” and shall set forth the location of the property, the nature of the
proposed activity and the time and place for hearing.
(1980 Code § 26-4)
   C.   Hearing Held: Within twenty (20) but not less than ten (10) days before
making its final environmental assessment on any one particular project, the
Plan Commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon, and notice
thereof shall be given once by publication in a local newspaper of general
circulation in the City at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing.
(1980 Code § 26-5)
   D.   Appeals:
      1.   Right To Appeal: Any person or persons, individually or jointly, may
appeal the decision of the Plan Commission in the environmental assessment to
the City Council. The decision of the Plan Commission as made in the
environmental assessment report shall be final eight (8) days from and
including the day of filing it with the City Clerk, unless, prior to the
expiration thereof, a written appeal is filed with the City Clerk setting forth
the grounds of appeal.
(1980 Code § 26-6)
      2.   Hearing: Within not less than ten (10) days nor more than forty (40)
days following the filing of an appeal as authorized by subsection D1 of this
section, the City Council shall hold a public hearing on the matter, public
notice of which shall be given in the same manner as required to be given by
the Plan Commission in subsections B and C of this section. In the event that
more than one notice of appeal is filed, the time provision of this subsection
D2 shall commence to run from the date of filing of the first such notice.
(1980 Code § 26-7)
      3.   Records To Council: Upon filing of such an appeal to the City
Council as herein provided, the Plan Commission shall forthwith transmit to the
City Clerk for the use of the City Council the Plan Commission record in the
matter.
(1980 Code § 26-8)
      4.   Council Decision: Within ten (10) days following the hearing on the
appeal from the decision of the Plan Commission on an environmental assessment,
the City Council shall announce its decision, in writing, and cause the same to
be filed with the City Clerk. Upon receipt of such filing, the City Clerk shall
give written notice of such decision to the appellant or appellants, as the
case may be, at the address shown on the appeal to the City Council.
(1980 Code § 26-9)
5-2-3: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT REPORT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Contents: Any environmental impact report required pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter shall include a detailed statement setting forth the
following:
      1.   The environmental impact of the proposed action.
      2.   Any adverse environmental effects which cannot be avoided if the
proposal is implemented.
      3.   Mitigation measures proposed to minimize the impact.
      4.   Alternatives to the proposed action.
      5.   The relationship between local short-term uses of man’s environment
and the maintenance and enhancement of long-term productivity.
      6.   Any irreversible environmental changes which would be involved in
the proposed action should it be implemented.
      7.   The growth-inducing impact of the proposed action.
      8.   The boundaries of the area which may be significantly affected by
the proposed action.
(1980 Code § 26-10)
   B.   Notice Of Report:
      1.   In any case in which an environmental impact report is required,
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the City shall, within ten (10)
days after completion of the environmental assessment, cause to be published,
at least one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, a notice
that such a report is in the process of preparation by the City.
(1980 Code § 26-11)
      2.   The notice required under subsection B1 of this section shall
consist of the words, “Notice of Preparation of Environmental Impact Report”
and shall contain:
         a.   A general description of the proposed action or project.
         b.   The location thereof.
         c.   A brief statement that written comments on such action or project
from members of the public will be considered and must be addressed to the Plan
Commission and received by it ten (10) days after publication of the notice.
(1980 Code § 26-12)
   C.   Public Input: The Plan Commission shall incorporate by reference or
narrative summary in an environmental impact report written comments from the
public received pursuant to and in accordance with the notice in subsection B2
of this section and shall consider such comments received from the public in
the preparation of the environmental impact report, and the Plan Commission and
the City Council shall consider such comments in rendering a decision on any
action or project for which the report is made.
(1980 Code § 26-13)
   D.   Time For Completion Of Report: The environmental impact report shall be
completed and filed with the Plan Commission within sixty (60) days after
publication as required by subsection B1 of this section.
(1980 Code § 26-14)
CHAPTER 3: NUISANCES
Section
5-3-1: Public Nuisances Enumerated
5-3-2: Other Nuisances Enumerated
5-3-3: Nuisances Unlawful; Abatement
5-3-4: Abatement Procedures
5-3-5: Penalties
5-3-1: PUBLIC NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance:
   A.   Common Law Nuisances: To commit any offense which is a nuisance
according to the common law or which is made such by the Statutes of the State
of Illinois.
   B.   Disposal Of Offensive Substances: To cause or suffer the carcass of any
animal or any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected or deposited or
to remain any place, to the prejudice of others.
   C.   Deposits On Premises Of Another: To dump, deposit or place any garbage,
rubbish, trash or refuse upon any real estate owned by another without the
consent of the owner or person in possession of such real property.
   D.   Offensive Conditions And Premises:
      1.   To throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter or the
carcass of any dead animal in any watercourse, lake, pond, spring, well or
common sewer, street or public highway.
      2.   To suffer or permit any structure, building or premises under one’s
control to become infested with rats, mice, rodents or other vermin or snakes.
      3.   To suffer or permit any premises used as a residence, leased for
sleeping quarters, or used for the sale or dispensing of food products to
become infested with cockroaches, bed bugs, or any other insect which might or
would create a health hazard.
      4.   For any owner or occupant, or the agent of any owner or occupant, of
any premises within the City to permit the premises to become or remain
unsanitary or a fire menace by allowing any offensive or unsafe or combustible
material to grow, accumulate or otherwise occupy and remain upon the premises.
      5.   To maintain an unsightly yard in any residential area where junked,
wrecked, disabled or abandoned motor vehicles, trucks, equipment, machinery or
other materials are allowed to accumulate.
   E.   Water Pollution: To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water
of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of
others.
   F.   Obstructing Waterways: To obstruct or impede, without legal authority,
the passage of any navigable river or waters.
   G.   Obstructing Public Ways And Places:
      1.   To obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets,
alleys, commons, landing places, and ways to burying places.
      2.   To loiter, stand or idle about, to sit or lie down in, or to
congregate in or about any street, sidewalk, or public place or way in such a
manner that other members of the general public desiring to pass through and
make use of said street, sidewalk, or public place or way are unable to do so,
it being the declared policy of the City that all members of the public have an
equal right of access to and use of the streets, sidewalks, and public places
or ways of the City.
      3.   To interfere with or obstruct any gutter, conduit, sewer or outlet
for water or the natural drainage of any public or private property.
   H.   Prohibited Deposits On Public Ways: To deposit in any street or public
way without the prior authority of the City any earth, stone, gravel, rock,
cement, or other like material which is not removed within twenty four (24)
hours of its deposit, or to spill, drop, scatter or deposit upon the paved
portion of any street any earth, stone, gravel, rock, cement, broken glass,
glass bottles, garbage, fertilizer, manure, refuse, boards, nails, merchandise,
petroleum products, acids, chemicals, or other like materials in sufficient
quantities so as to constitute and be a risk, hazard or danger to the public
using such street, unless the person causing the spill, dropping, scattering,
or depositing promptly removes said material from the street.
   I.   Merchandise On Public Ways: To make use of the streets or sidewalks for
the display or sale of merchandise or goods, without first having secured the
permit or authority of the Corporate Authorities for such display or sale.
   J.   Noxious Odors: To erect, continue or use any building or other place
for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture, which, by occasioning
noxious exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous
to the health of individuals, or of the public.
   K.   Construction Hazards: For any builder, contractor, owner, contract
vendor, contract purchaser, or other person, or their agent or agents, whether
in the building of a new house or structure of other kind or in the remodeling
or repair of a house or other building or structure, to conduct said building,
repair or remodeling operations in such a manner that the operations create a
definite hazard to the life or safety of members of the general public lawfully
in the vicinity of said operations or endanger the property of adjoining
owners.
   L.   Land Fills: In the filling of any lot or site, whether the fill be blow
sand or some other type of fill, to fail promptly to cover and secure said fill
so that it will not be blown by the winds upon the lands of adjoining property
owners.
   M.   Fire Hazards: To cause or suffer any grass, leaves, corn cobs,
underbrush or other combustible matter to be collected, deposited or remain on
any premises in such quantities so as to create a fire hazard, or to throw,
deposit or burn any of the above named materials upon any paved portion of any
street.
   N.   Unlawful Advertising: To advertise wares or occupations by painting
notices of the same on or affixing them to fences or other private property, or
on rocks or other natural objects, without the consent of the owner, or if in
the highway or other public place, without permission of the proper
authorities.
   O.   Wells For Oil, Gas Or Salt Water:
      1.   To permit any well drilled for oil, gas, saltwater disposal or any
other purposes in connection with the production of oil and gas, to remain
unplugged, after such well is no longer used for the purpose for which it was
drilled.
      2.   To construct or operate any saltwater pit or oil field refuse pit,
commonly called a “burn out pit”, so that salt water, brine or oil field refuse
or other waste liquids may escape therefrom in any manner except by the
evaporation of such salt water or brine or by the burning of such oil field
waste or refuse.
      3.   To permit concrete bases, discarded machinery and materials to
remain around any oil or gas well, or to fail to fill any holes, cellars, slush
pits and other excavations made in connection with any such well or to restore
the surface of the lands surrounding any such well to its condition before the
drilling of any such well, upon abandonment of any such oil or gas well.
      4.   To permit any salt water, oil, gas or other wastes from any well
drilled for oil, gas, or exploratory purposes to escape to the surface, or into
a mine or coal seam, or into any underground fresh water supply, or from one
underground stratum to another.
   P.   Gunpowder And Explosives:
      1.   To carry on the business of manufacturing gunpowder, nitroglycerine,
or other highly explosive substances, or mixing or grinding the materials
therefor, in any building within one hundred ten (110) yards of any building
erected at the time such business may be commenced.
      2.   To establish powder magazines at a point different from that
appointed according to law by the Corporate Authorities of the City or within
two hundred seventy five (275) yards of any occupied dwelling house.
   Q.   Real Estate Harassment: To harass, intimidate or threaten any person
who is about to sell or lease or has sold or leased a residence or other real
property or is about to buy or lease or has bought or leased a residence or
other real property, when the harassment, intimidation or threat relates to a
person's attempt to sell, buy or lease a residence, or other real property, or
refers to a person's sale, purchase or lease of a residence or other real
property.
   R.   Use Of Property For Immoral, Indecent Uses: To make, engage in, permit,
allow, or contribute to a condition or use of property which greatly offends
the public morals or decency.
   S.   Trains Blocking Crossings:
      1.   For any railroad company repeatedly to obstruct with its trains,
engines, equipment or cars, or for any railroad company repeatedly to obstruct
with trains, engines, equipment or railroad cars under its control, public
travel at any railroad highway grade crossing within the City for a period of
time in excess of that permitted by State Statute, or for any lessee of
railroad equipment or for any official, officer, engineer, conductor, employee
or agent of any railroad company, through the use of trains, engines, equipment
or railroad cars under his or its control, to obstruct repeatedly, for a period
of time in excess of that permitted by State Statute, public travel at any
railroad highway grade crossing in the City.
      2.   For any railroad company or any of its officials, officers,
engineers, conductors, employees or agents, when notified that a train under
his or its control is blocking all railroad highway grade crossings in the City
on the railroad tracks then being used by the train and when further notified
that an emergency exists wherein an ambulance or other emergency vehicle, a
fire truck or other firefighting equipment, or a police car needs to cross the
tracks immediately, to fail or refuse to make a break in the train and permit
the crossing immediately. The City defines this conduct as a nuisance, being
mindful of the fact that the Iroquois Memorial Hospital, which serves a
substantial portion of Iroquois County, is situated in the City of Watseka,
that State Highway Route No. 1 and U.S. Highway Route No. 24 intersect within
the City of Watseka, that it is commonplace for motor vehicle traffic to be
backed up in the City from one-half (½) mile to one mile in distance on each
side of railroad tracks because the railroad crossings are obstructed by trains
or railroad cars, that on said occasions, all railroad crossings on the
railroad track have been blocked and obstructed, making it impossible for an
ambulance, emergency vehicle, fire truck or police vehicle promptly to pass
from one side of the tracks in the City to the other to attend emergencies,
that on various occasions railroad employees have failed or refused to
cooperate when such an emergency has existed, and that irreparable injury,
mischief and damage has and will occur on account of said obstructions.
(1980 Code § 17-6)
5-3-2: OTHER NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
   A.   Business Nuisances: No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted
or operated as to amount to a nuisance in fact.
(1980 Code § 17-1)
   B.   Deposit Of Garbage, Refuse And Animal Carcasses: REFUSE is defined as
any waste, rubbish, garbage, trash, or any material of any kind that has been
discarded, rejected, cast aside, or thrown away as worthless, except body
wastes. GARBAGE is defined as all animal and vegetable waste, such as, but not
limited to, waste material and refuse from kitchens, residences, grocery
stores, butcher shops, restaurants, cafes, hotels, motels, rooming houses,
boarding houses, and all other deleterious substances.
(1980 Code § 17-3)
   C.   Harboring Rats:
      1.   The storing or placing of ashes, garbage, refuse, old bricks,
concrete, branches, brush, or trash, or the storing or placing of any materials
which may harbor rats, at any place in the City, is hereby declared to be a
nuisance.
      2.   The maintenance in the City of any premises, house, building or
structure in such a condition that in fact it has become infested with rats is
hereby declared to be nuisance. When any such condition exists as is herein
declared to be nuisance, a notice to abate said nuisance may be given on behalf
of the City by the Chief of Police or Building Official to the owners of and
all persons in possession of the premises on which the nuisance exists.
      3.   If the nuisance is not abated within fifteen (15) days after the
giving of notice, the City, upon court approval, may abate the nuisance, and
the cost and expense of abating the nuisance shall be filed as a lien against
the premises in accordance with section
11-20-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
(1980 Code § 17-18)
   D.   Landfills: The placing or disposal of garbage or refuse of any kind,
waste materials, debris, tin cans, trash, junk, wastepaper, discarded
appliances or other discarded items in any landfill within the corporate limits
of the City or outside of and within one-half (½) mile of the corporate limits
of the City is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a hazard to public health
and safety, and the same is hereby prohibited.
(1980 Code § 17-19)
   E.   Privies:
      1.   Whoever shall erect or maintain any privy within one hundred feet
(100') of any line of a City sanitary sewer shall be deemed guilty of
maintaining a nuisance.
(1980 Code § 17-7)
      2.   All wooden privies now standing upon any ground or hereafter to be
erected within the fire limits of the City are hereby declared to be public
nuisances, and the same are ordered to be removed and abated. In the event of
the failure of the owners of such premises within the fire limits to abate and
remove the privies and fill up any vault or vaults on which the privies were
located, within thirty (30) days after receipt of notice from the City to do
so, then it shall be the duty of the Director of Public Works to take charge of
the abatement of the nuisance, the removal of the privies and the careful
filling up of any vaults without endangering the public health of the
inhabitants of the City. The costs of such abatement shall be charged to the
property owner.
(1980 Code § 17-8)
   F.   Open Sewage: It shall be a nuisance and unlawful for any person to
maintain, permit, cause, create, or contribute to, in any way, an open drain,
sewer, or cesspool, and it shall also be unlawful and a nuisance for any person
on any premises under his control to permit, create, cause or contribute to any
unsightly, nauseous, or unhealthful condition by failing promptly to dispose of
any such sewage or refuse, both within the limits of the City and at any point
within one-half (½) mile of the City limits.
(1980 Code § 17-9)
   G.   Obstructing Public Ways: All obstructions to streets, alleys, crossings
and sidewalks of the City and all excavations in or under the same, which are
by ordinance prohibited or which may be made without the permission or
authority of the Corporate Authorities, are hereby declared to be nuisances.
(1980 Code § 17-10)
   H.   Dangerous Billboards: Any billboard or signboard, which is dangerous
because of insecure construction or fastening or which is a fire hazard and in
fact a nuisance, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated as such.
(1980 Code § 17-11)
   I.   Sirens, Etc.: It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to
carry or use upon any vehicle, other than Police or Fire Department vehicles or
emergency vehicles, any gong, siren or whistle similar to that used on
ambulances or vehicles of the Police and Fire Departments.
(1980 Code § 17-21)
   J.   Dust: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation within
the City limits of the City to use its property, or permit the same to be used,
in such a manner as to create, allow, or permit excessive dust from any act or
omission of the owner or its invitees on such property.
(1980 Code § 17-25)
   K.   Discharging Guns And Combustible Materials: No discharging of guns or
fireworks is allowed at any time. The provisions of this subsection do not
apply to a police officer or other peace officer discharging a gun while in the
discharge of his official duties.
(1980 Code § 17-20)
5-3-3: NUISANCES UNLAWFUL; ABATEMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit or maintain
the existence of any nuisance on any property under his, her or its control.
(1980 Code § 17-2)
5-3-4: ABATEMENT PROCEDURE
   A.   Duty To Abate: It is hereby made the duty, jointly and severally, of
every person creating or causing any nuisance, and of every owner of property,
and of every person in possession or control of any premises, upon which any
nuisance may be found or maintained, to immediately abate the same.
(1980 Code § 17-12)
   B.   Abatement By City: If any person, after being served with a forty eight
(48) hour notice, shall not, within the time specified, abate the nuisance, the
nuisance shall be abated by the officers of the City; and an accurate account
of the expense shall be made, and suit shall forthwith be brought against the
person or persons to recover the expense of abatement. In abating a nuisance,
the City may seek a court action in order to abate the nuisance, or it may take
such other action as may be authorized by ordinance or may be necessary under
the circumstances.
(1980 Code § 17-13)
5-3-5: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this
chapter, including articles A, B and C, shall, upon conviction, be fined as set
forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
   B.   In addition to the penalties provided in subsection A of this section,
the City may seek the abatement of any nuisance by a suit or action in court
for an injunction or other appropriate remedy.
(1980 Code § 17-90; amd. 2019 Code)
ARTICLE A: NUISANCES RELATING TO ANIMALS
Section
5-3A-1: Responsibility Of Owner
5-3A-2: Number Of Dogs And Cats
5-3A-3: Domestic Animals At Large
5-3A-4: Noisy Animals
5-3A-5: Dogs Disturbing The Peace
5-3A-6: Dog And Cat Excreta
5-3A-7: Animal Houses
5-3A-8: Failure To Provide Proper Care And Treatment
5-3A-1: RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER:
It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any owner or harborer to fail to
exercise proper care and control of his animals to prevent them from becoming a
public nuisance. Excessive, continuous or untimely barking, molesting
passersby, chasing vehicles, habitually attacking persons or other domestic
animals, trespassing upon school grounds, or trespassing upon private property
in such manner as to damage property, shall be deemed nuisances.
(1980 Code § 17-83)
5-3A-2: NUMBER OF DOGS AND CATS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit the
keeping of more dogs or cats than are permitted in this section within the
corporate limits of the City, as this poses health, safety and public welfare
risks and is therefore deemed a public nuisance.
   B.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section, it shall be
unlawful to keep, own or harbor more than four (4) dogs or four (4) cats over
the age of five (5) months, or more than one litter of puppies and one litter
of kittens per year on any property consisting of two (2) contiguous acres or
less.
   C.   This section shall not apply to the following:
      1.   A licensed and inspected dog dealer or kennel operator, veterinary
clinic or animal hospital when operated by a veterinarian licensed under the
Illinois Veterinary Medicine and Surgical Practice Act of 2004 (225 ILCS 115/
1 et seq.), cat dealer or cattery operator, pet shop, animal control facility
or animal shelter as defined in 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 605/2. Nor shall
this chapter apply to an owner of a dog obedience training facility or to the
property where an animal show is being conducted where animals are not kept for
more than two (2) continuous days.
      2.   Individuals or households engaged in the business of pet shop
operator, dog dealer, kennel operator, daycare operator, dog breeder, cat
breeder, operator of a guard dog service, an animal control facility or animal
shelter, as defined by the Animal Welfare Act (225 ILCS 605/1 et seq.) The City
may request verified financial reports from a certified accountant or tax
professional providing sufficient information and detail to establish that
individuals or members of the household are engaged in the professions outlined
above. The City may request proof of a current license issued by the Illinois
Department of Agriculture pursuant to the Animal Welfare Act (225 ILCS 605/3).
   D.   Inability to produce appropriate financial records or a State license
will be considered prima facie evidence of a violation of this section.
(Ord. 2344, 6-28-2011)
5-3A-3: DOMESTIC ANIMALS AT LARGE:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
HARBORER: Any person who provides food or shelter for any domesticated animal,
who keeps an animal, or who has an animal in his care or custody, or who
knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him.
OWNER: Any person having right of property in any animal, who keeps an animal,
who has an animal in his care or custody, or who knowingly permits an animal to
remain on or about any premises occupied by him.
   B.   Responsibility Of Owner Or Harborer: It shall be unlawful and a
nuisance for the owner or harborer of any dog, cat or other domestic animal to
cause or permit such animal to perform, create or engage in any nuisance. When
any such animal is involved in any activity which is herein defined as an
animal nuisance, or which otherwise shall be a nuisance, its owner or harborer
shall be subject to prosecution therefor.
   C.   Nuisance Created: An animal nuisance is created when an animal owner or
harborer permits his animal to run uncontrolled upon the public streets and
ways or upon the properties of others without first having obtained the consent
of the one in possession of the property.
(Ord. 2354, 9-27-2011)
5-3A-4: NOISY ANIMALS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a nuisance to harbor or keep any animals or
poultry which disturb the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night.
(1980 Code § 17-80)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, harbor, possess or
maintain any dog, which dog, by long or continued barking, howling or other
noises, shall disturb the peace and quiet of any person, family or
neighborhood. Any such disturbance is hereby declared to be a public nuisance.
(1980 Code § 17-23)
5-3A-5: DOGS DISTURBING THE PEACE:
No person owning or harboring any dog shall suffer or permit such dog to
disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood by barking, making other loud
or unusual noises, or by running through or across yards, cultivated gardens or
fields of persons other than the owner or harborer of the dog. Such prohibited
activity shall constitute a nuisance, for which the owner or harborer shall be
responsible for the abatement thereof.
(1980 Code § 17-81)
5-3A-6: DOG AND CAT EXCRETA:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and unlawful for any owner, keeper or
walker of any dog or cat to permit his or her dog or cat to discharge such
animal’s excreta upon any public or private property, other than the property
of the owner or keeper of any such dog or cat, within the City, if such owner,
keeper or walker does not immediately thereafter remove and clean up the
animal’s excreta from the public or private property and dispose of it on his
own property.
(1980 Code § 17-4)
5-3A-7: ANIMAL HOUSES:
No poultry is allowed in the City.
(1980 Code § 17-84)
5-3A-8: FAILURE TO PROVIDE PROPER CARE AND TREATMENT:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any owner or harborer to fail
to provide animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper
shelter and protection from the weather, veterinary care when needed to prevent
suffering, and humane care and treatment.
   B.   It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any owner or other person to
beat, cruelly ill-treat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise abuse any
animal, or cause or permit any dogfight, cockfight, bullfight or other combat
between animals or between animals and humans.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any owner to crop a dog’s ears except when a
licensed veterinarian issues a signed certificate that the operation is
necessary for the dog’s health or comfort, and in no event shall any person
except a licensed veterinarian perform such an operation.
(1980 Code § 17-83)
ARTICLE B: NUISANCES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY
Section
5-3B-1: Definition
5-3B-2: Exterior Storage Of Nonoperating Vehicles
5-3B-3: Duty To Maintain Property
5-3B-4: Enforcement
5-3B-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this article, the term NUISANCE is defined to mean any
condition or use of any premises or of building exteriors which is detrimental
to the property of others or which causes or tends to cause substantial
diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which the
premises is located. This includes, but is not limited to, the keeping or the
depositing on, or the scattering over, the premises of any of the following:
   A.   Lumber, junk, trash, or debris.
   B.   Abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment, such as
automobiles, motor vehicles, farm machinery, furniture, stoves, refrigerators,
freezers, cans, or containers.
(1980 Code § 17-40)
5-3B-2: EXTERIOR STORAGE OF NONOPERATING VEHICLES:
No person in charge of or in control of any premises, whether as owner, lessee,
tenant, occupant or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, wrecked,
junked, discarded or otherwise nonoperating motor vehicle to remain on such
property longer than ten (10) days; and no person shall leave any such vehicle
on any property within the City for a longer time than ten (10) days; except,
that this section shall not apply with regard to any vehicle in an enclosed
building. This article shall further not apply with regard to any vehicle on
the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place, other than in
a residential district, and operated in a lawful manner, when the keeping or
maintenance of such vehicle is necessary to the operation of the business
enterprise; or with regard to a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or
depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the City or any other
public agency or entity.
(Ord. 2058, 5-20-2002)
5-3B-3: DUTY TO MAINTAIN PROPERTY:
No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any premises shall
maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, nor shall any such person keep or
maintain the premises in a manner causing substantial diminution of the value
of the other property in the neighborhood in which the premises is located.
(1980 Code § 17-41)
5-3B-4: ENFORCEMENT:
Enforcement of this article may be accomplished by the City in any manner
authorized by law, and in addition, any person who, by reason of another's
violation of any provision of this article, suffers special damage to himself
different from that suffered by other property owners throughout the City
generally, may bring an action to enjoin or otherwise abate an existing
violation.
(1980 Code § 17-43)
ARTICLE C: STORAGE OF UNSHELTERED PERSONALTY
Section
5-3C-1: Nuisance Declared
5-3C-2: Abatement Procedures
5-3C-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
The unsheltered storage of old, unused, stripped, junked, and other automobiles
not in good and safe operating condition, and of any other vehicles, machinery,
implements, and/or equipment and personal property of any kind which is no
longer safely usable for the purposes for which it was manufactured, which
hereinafter are collectively described as “said personalty”, for a period of
thirty (30) days or more, except in licensed junkyards, within the corporate
limits of the City, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and dangerous to the
public safety.
(1980 Code § 17-50)
5-3C-2: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Abatement By Owners And Tenants: The owner, owners, tenants, lessees
and/or occupants of any lot within the corporate limits of the City upon which
such storage is made, and also the owner, owners, and/or lessees of said
personalty involved in such storage, all of whom are hereinafter referred to
collectively as “owners”, shall jointly and severally abate the nuisance by the
prompt removal of said personalty into completely enclosed buildings authorized
to be used for such storage purposes, if within the corporate limits of the
City, or otherwise to remove it to a location without the corporate limits.
(1980 Code § 17-51)
   B.   Failure To Abate: If owners or persons in possession allow the nuisance
to exist or fail to abate the nuisance, they, and each of them, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which the nuisance is permitted to exist.
(1980 Code § 17-52; amd. 2019 Code)
   C.   Abatement By City; Costs: Whenever the owners or persons in possession
fail to abate the nuisance, the City shall remove said personalty to a location
of its selection. The expenses therefor are to be billed to the owners or
persons in possession, jointly and severally, the bill to be recoverable in a
suit at law.
   D.   Sale Of Property; Liability For Costs: When said personalty has been
removed and placed in storage by the City, as provided herein, said personalty
shall be sold by the City after the lapse of such time as is provided by law.
If the proceeds of the sale are insufficient to pay the costs of abatement, the
owners and persons in possession shall be liable to the City for the balance of
the costs, jointly and severally, to be recoverable in a suit at law. If the
proceeds are in excess of costs, the balance shall be paid to the owners or
deposited in the City Treasury for their use.
(1980 Code § 17-53)
CHAPTER 4: GARBAGE AND REFUSE
Section
5-4-1: Definitions
5-4-2: Scavenger Services
5-4-3: Collection Fees
5-4-4: Other Scavenger Services Required
5-4-5: Yard Waste Burning
5-4-6: Penalty
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
EXCLUDED WASTE: Excluded waste is any and all hazardous waste, special waste,
yard waste, bulk items (carpeting, furniture, appliances, etc.) and/or
construction debris.
GARBAGE AND REFUSE: Any combustible or noncombustible household waste, trash or
unwanted materials including, but not limited to, ashes, cans, cartons, metal
ware, glass, paper, boxes, crockery, bottles, wood, litter, and other forms of
