CHAPTER 1: POLICE DEPARTMENT
Section
6-1-1: Definition Of Member
6-1-2: Department Created
6-1-3: Department Personnel
6-1-4: Chief Of Police
6-1-5: Departmental Positions: Deputy Chief Of Police: Corporal
6-1-6: Powers And Duties Of Department
6-1-7: Rules And Regulations
6-1-8: Auxiliary Police
6-1-9: Police Pension Fund
6-1-1: DEFINITION OF MEMBER:
When used in this chapter, the term MEMBER means any person who is a member of
the Police Department, regardless of rank, and is regularly employed and,
except where exempted hereunder, has been appointed by the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners.
(2019 Code)
6-1-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a Police Department, an executive department of the
City.
(2019 Code)
6-1-3: DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL:
The classified service ranks and maximum number of full-time police officers in
each rank is established as follows: one (1) Chief of Police; one (1) captain;
one (1) lieutenant; three (3) sergeants; and five (5) patrol officers. The
number of personnel above are the maximum and not the minimum number required
to be employed. If a person leaves the services of the Police Department or is
promoted, a vacancy shall not exist in any rank, and no employee shall be hired
or promoted until such time as the City Council authorizes the vacancy to be
filled.
(2019 Code; amd. Ord. 2639, 3-22-2022)
6-1-4: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the office of
Chief of Police, who shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and
consent of the City Council.
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the Police
Department, shall be the keeper of the City Jail, and shall have custody of all
persons incarcerated therein.
      2.   The Chief of Police shall keep such records and make such reports
concerning the activities of the Police Department as may be required by
statute, ordinance, or at the request of the Mayor or City Council.
      3.   The Chief of Police shall be responsible for the performance of the
Police Department of all its functions, and all persons who are members of the
department shall serve subject to the orders of the Chief of Police.
      4.   The Chief of Police shall, with the consent of the City of Council,
prescribe the property uniform and badge for all members of the Police
Department, and shall make suitable regulations under which they shall be
required to wear an appropriate uniform and badge, by which they shall be known
and designated at all times.
(2019 Code)
6-1-5: DEPARTMENTAL POSITIONS: DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE: CORPORAL:
   A.   Deputy Chief of Police: There is hereby established the position of
Deputy Chief of the Police Department. The Deputy Chief is an exempt rank
immediately below that of the Chief of Police. The Deputy Chief shall be
appointed by the Chief of Police, subject to the approval of the City Council,
from any full-time member of the Police Department holding the rank of sergeant
or above. The Deputy Chief shall serve at the discretion of the Chief of Police
and may be suspended or removed from the position at the discretion of the
Chief of Police, subject to the approval of the City Council. The Deputy Chief
shall be considered on furlough from the rank held prior to the appointment and
will revert to his prior rank upon resignation or discharge as Deputy Chief.
   The Deputy Chief shall be second in command of the Police Department and
shall have the duties and responsibilities as prescribed by the Chief of
Police. In the absence of the Chief of Police, the Deputy Chief shall be
charged with the general oversight of the activities of the Police Department
and shall be the direct supervisor over the captain, lieutenant, sergeants, and
other members.
   B.   Corporal: There is hereby established the position of Corporal. The
Corporal shall be appointed by the Chief of Police from the rank of patrol
officer, subject to the approval of the City Council. The Corporal will serve
at the discretion of the Chief of Police and may be suspended or removed from
the position at the discretion of the Chief of Police. A Corporal shall be the
ranking officer in the absence of a sergeant or other supervisory officer.
(Ord. 2639, 3-22-2022)
6-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   The several members of the Police Department shall have all powers as
may be authorized by law, or which are incidental thereto, including the power
of arrest.
   B.   All members of the Police Department shall devote their time to the
discharge of their duties, according to the provisions of this Code and the
rules and regulations as the Chief of Police, City Council, and Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners may adopt and prescribe.
   C.   It shall be the duty of each member of the Police Department to
preserve order, preserve peace and quiet, and enforce the law.
   D.   It shall be the duty of every member of the Police Department to report
to the Chief of Police at such times and places as he may require, and at all
times obey the orders and instructions of the Chief of Police.
(2019 Code)
6-1-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   The City Council shall provide by ordinance for the general rules of
conduct of the Police Department.
   B.   The Chief of Police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations
for the conduct and guidance of the members of the Police Department as he
shall deem advisable, and such rules, when approved with the consent of the
City Council, shall be binding on such members. The respective rank and grade
of the members, as to superiority within the Police Department, may be
prescribed by regulation.
   C.   Rules and regulations prescribed by the Chief of Police shall yield in
favor of those prescribed by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. The
rules and regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall yield
to those prescribed by the City Council.
(2019 Code)
6-1-8: AUXILIARY POLICE:
   A.   Position Created: There is hereby established within the Police
Department the position of auxiliary police officer.
   B.   Appointment: Auxiliary police officers shall be appointed by the
Auxiliary Police Director, with the approval of the Chief of Police.
   C.   Not Regular Police: Auxiliary police officers shall not be members of
the Police Department. Auxiliary police officers shall not supplement members
of the regular Police Department in the performance of their assigned and
normal duties, except as otherwise provided in herein.
   D.   Supervision: Auxiliary police officers shall at all times during the
performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the
Chief of Police.
   E.   Residency: Auxiliary police officers need not be residents of the City.
   F.   Fingerprints: Before the appointment of an auxiliary police officer,
the person's fingerprints shall be taken, and no person shall be appointed as
an auxiliary police officer if that person has been convicted of a felony or
other crime involving moral turpitude.
   G.   Training: Auxiliary police officers, before entering upon any of their
duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other
police procedures appropriate for the exercise of the powers conferred upon
them. The training and course of study shall be determined and provided by the
City Council. Before being permitted to carry a firearm, however, an auxiliary
police officer must have the same course of training as required of peace
officers under section 2 of the Peace Officer and Probation Officer Firearm
Training Act (50 ILCS 710/2).
   H.   Duties:
      1.   Auxiliary police officers shall only be assigned to perform the
following duties: a) to aid or direct traffic within the City; b) to aid in
control of natural or manmade disasters; and c) to aid in case of civil
disorder as directed by the Chief of Police.
      2.   When it is impractical for members of the regular Police Department
to perform those normal and regular police duties, however, the Chief of Police
may assign auxiliary police officers to perform those normal and regular police
duties.
   I.   Firearms: Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms, except
with the permission of the Chief of Police and while in uniform and in the
performance of their duties. Auxiliary police officers, when on duty, shall
also be conservators of the peace and shall have the powers specified in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-15-25.
   J.   Identification: Identification symbols worn by auxiliary police
officers shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the
Police Department.
   K.   Uniform And Equipment Allowances; Compensation: Auxiliary police
officers shall receive such uniform and equipment allowance and compensation
for services performed as may from time to time be determined by the City
Council.
(2019 Code; amd. Ord. 2639, 3-22-2022)
6-1-9: POLICE PENSION FUND:
   A.   Fund Created: There shall be a Police Pension Fund established in the
City as provided by law.
(1980 Code § 8-1)
   B.   Board Of Trustees Of Fund: The Police Pension Fund shall be
administered by a Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees of said fund shall
consist of five (5) members, of which two (2) trustees shall be appointed by
the Mayor, two (2) trustees shall be elected by members of the Police
Department, and one trustee shall be elected by the beneficiaries of the
Pension Fund. The election shall be held on the second Monday in April, and the
term of each member shall be for two (2) years; except, that on the initial
appointment and election of trustees, where more than one trustee is to be
appointed or elected, one shall be appointed or elected for a one-year term and
one shall be appointed or elected for a two-year term. The Pension Board shall
meet at least quarterly, and shall hold such additional meetings as shall be
called by the President of the Pension Board.
(Ord. 2424, 9-23-2014)
   C.   Contributions To Fund: There shall be deposited in the Pension Fund the
sums required by law, which for the present includes 9.91% of the salary per
month deducted from the salary of each member of the police force, and the
proceeds of an annual tax to be levied upon all the taxable property in the
City at the rate one dollar ($1.00) on all such taxable property, which annual
tax shall produce an amount which, when added to the deductions from the
salaries or wages of the police officers and the receipts available from all
other sources, will equal a sum sufficient to meet the annual requirements of
the Pension Fund. If the Pension Funds on hand equal or exceed the reserve
required by law, no annual tax need be levied.
(1980 Code § 8-3)
   D.   Extension Of Benefits Of Fund: All members of the City Police
Department, who are appointed or appointable by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners, shall be entitled to the benefits of the Police Pension Fund
under the following conditions:
      1.   Those members who, under statutory provisions, appear not to be
entitled to the benefits of said fund shall, nevertheless, by this section,
have and receive the same pension benefits and make the same pension
contributions as the other members of the police force receive and make, who,
under statute, are entitled to the benefits of the Police Pension Fund.
      2.   It is the intention of this section to waive the age requirements of
the statute as to those police officers who, under the statute and on account
of age, would not be entitled to the benefits of the Police Pension Fund.
      3.   The benefits of the police officers covered by this Code shall be
governed by the Statutes of the State of Illinois, excepting, however, those
statutory provisions which deny pension benefits on account of the age of the
police officer when employed.
      4.   As to those police officers now employed who appear not to be
entitled to the benefits of the Police Pension Fund, no contributions shall be
required of them on their services rendered prior to the date of the adoption
of this Code. The first contribution to be required of them shall be for the
first pay period accruing after the date of the adoption of this Code.
      5.   The police officers whose pension coverage is provided by this Code,
shall have, however, the option and privilege to pay into the Police Pension
Fund, within three (3) years from the date hereof, contributions, without
interest, on one or more years past service, so as to provide such pension
coverage as they may wish at the time of their retirement.
(1980 Code § 8-4)
CHAPTER 2: BURGLAR, FIRE AND PROTECTIVE ALARM SYSTEMS
Section
6-2-1: Operation Of Systems
6-2-2: False Alarms
6-2-3: Enforcement
6-2-1: OPERATION OF SYSTEMS:
The City Council shall decide all questions arising as to the use and operation
of the burglar, fire, and protective alarm systems, through the City-owned
electric control board.
(1980 Code § 6-69)
6-2-2: FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   Generally: In connection with the automatic fire alarm service
installed, the owner and/or lessee of the fire alarm system shall reimburse the
City for any expense incurred by the City by reason of the Watseka Fire
Department responding to a “false fire alarm” which shall have originated in or
shall have been caused by the fire alarm system. A “false fire alarm” is one
that is caused by a mechanical defect or improper operation of the system
installed by the owner and/or lessee or by the fault of the personnel of the
owner and/or lessee in connection with the system where no fire exists. The fee
for any such false alarm shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00).
   B.   Nonemergency Activation: Any person who intentionally activates any
alarm when no need for emergency response exists or to test an alarm without
first advising the 911 Communications Center shall be deemed to have violated
this article. Persons who intentionally activate an alarm under conditions set
forth in this subsection shall not use the defense that the intentional
activation was one of the allowable four (4) false alarms as set forth in
subsection E of this section.
   C.   Failure/Refusal To Respond To Premises:
      1.   A responsible party or his designee will be allowed twenty (20)
minutes to respond to the location of the alarm from the time they receive
notification from the 911 Communications Center. Failure to respond within
twenty (20) minutes will be regarded as a refusal to respond. Any failure or
refusal to respond shall be deemed a violation of this article.
      2.   If a responsible party or his designee fails or refuses to respond
to the location of the alarm within the time allowed by subsection B1 of this
section, the responsible party shall not hold the City, Police Department, Fire
Department, or any of their agents responsible for the security of the
premises, and any emergency personnel at the premises will be returned to duty.
The premises will not be responded to again until the alarm at the premises has
been reset and/or the building has been secured.
   D.   Notice Of False Alarms: The Chief of Police shall notify the
responsible party, in writing, of each occurrence of a false alarm. The notice
may include, but not necessarily be limited to: the date of the false alarm;
the number of the false alarm for the year; the nature of the false alarm if
ascertainable, such as human error or system malfunction; a statement that the
responsible party must take corrective action to ensure that a false alarm
based upon the same circumstances does not recur; and the amount of the false
alarm service charge, if any, incurred by the responsible party for the
response to the false alarm.
   E.   Failure To Take Corrective Action: The failure of the responsible party
to take corrective action as directed by the false alarm notice shall be a
violation of this article.
(1980 Code § 6-65) (Ord. 2423, 7-22-2014)
Cross-reference:
   See also sections
6-3-11 and
7-6-3 A of this Code
6-2-3: ENFORCEMENT:
The Chief of Police is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this
article to the end that the burglar, fire, and protective alarm systems may be
unified and operated through one control board.
(1980 Code § 6-68)
CHAPTER 3: FIRE DEPARTMENT
Section
6-3-1: Department Created; Composition And Appointment
6-3-2: Fire Chief
6-3-3: Assistant Fire Chief
6-3-4: Functions, Powers And Duties Of Department
6-3-5: Mandatory Retirement Age
6-3-6: Rules And Regulations
6-3-7: Fire Protection Outside City Limits
6-3-8: Spectators Near Or At Fires
6-3-9: Authority To Destroy Structures At Fires
6-3-10: Entering Firehouses Restricted
6-3-11: False Alarms
6-3-12: Penalty
6-3-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; COMPOSITION AND APPOINTMENT:
   A.   There is hereby created the Fire Department of the City whose
membership shall consist of volunteer/paid-on-call firefighters.
(1980 Code § 10-1)
   B.   The personnel of the City Fire Department shall consist of a Fire Chief
and not more than thirty five (35) other members, who shall be appointed by the
Mayor on the advice of the Public Safety Committee and by the consent and
approval of the City Council, at the beginning of each fiscal year, provided
that any vacancy may be filled at any time by a like appointment. Appointees
shall serve for the current fiscal year and until their successors are
appointed. A retirement age of sixty five (65) years is hereby established for
the members of the Fire Department, and no person who has attained his or her
65th birthday shall be eligible for membership in said Department.
(1980 Code § 10-19) (Ord. 2549, 10-22-2019)
   C.   The power to appoint the nonfull-time members of the Fire Department is
vested in the Mayor, with the advice and the consent of the Alderpersons.
Pursuant to its home rule powers, the City exempts itself from the provisions
of 65 ILCS 5/10-3-2.
(Ord. 2517, 8-28-2018)
6-3-2: FIRE CHIEF:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the office of Fire
Chief, an executive office of the City. The Fire Chief shall be appointed by
the Mayor, by and with the consent of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 10-2)
   B.   Oath And Bond: The Fire Chief shall qualify by taking the oath of
office and by furnishing a bond for one thousand dollars ($1,000.00),
conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties as herein set out.
(1980 Code § 10-20)
   C.   Duties:
      1.   Generally: The Fire Chief shall be Chief of the Fire Department, and
shall be responsible for the care of the apparatus belonging thereto, and the
performance of the duties by the members of the department. He shall keep such
records and make such reports as may be required by law and by the City
Council, regarding the activities of the department.
(1980 Code § 10-3)
      2.   Smoke Alarm Inspections: In addition to other duties herein
specified, the Fire Chief or his designee shall be responsible for the
inspection of smoke alarms in the City. Any person wishing a smoke alarm
inspection to be made by the Fire Chief shall pay to the City Collector a fee
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) prior to the inspection and issuance of the
report.
(1980 Code § 10-27)
6-3-3: ASSISTANT FIRE CHIEF:
   A.   In the absence of the Fire Chief, it shall be the duty of the Assistant
Fire Chief to take charge of the work of the department, and he shall have and
exercise the duties and powers of the Fire Chief.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the Assistant Fire Chief, if in his power, to
attend all fires within the City.
(1980 Code § 10-6)
6-3-4: FUNCTIONS, POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   It shall be the function of the Fire Department, and the duty of
members thereof, to prevent and extinguish any accidental or destructive fire
occurring in the City and to enforce all ordinances relating to fire hazards.
(1980 Code § 10-4)
   B.   It shall be the duty of all officers of the Fire Department and all
police officers of the City to see that the provisions of this chapter are
enforced and to arrest on view any person who shall be found violating any of
the provisions of this chapter or who shall hinder, resist, or refuse to obey
any such officer in the discharge of his duty, and to that end, all such
officers are hereby vested with the usual power and authority of police
officers.
(1980 Code § 10-21)
   C.   The Fire Chief and members of the Fire Department shall have the power
to arrest any person at or near the scene of an accident or destructive fire
for interference with the Fire Department in the performance of its duties, or
for the commission of any crime or ordinance violation in connection therewith.
(1980 Code § 10-17)
6-3-5: MANDATORY RETIREMENT AGE:
A retirement age of sixty five (65) years is hereby established for the members
of the Fire Department, and no person who has attained his sixty fifth birthday
shall be eligible for membership in the department.
(1980 Code § 10-19)
6-3-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Chief of the Fire Department may make or prescribe such rules and
regulations for the conduct and guidance of the members of the department as he
may deem desirable, and such rules, when approved by the City Council, shall be
binding on such members. He shall also have the power to designate what
firefighter or person shall have the command of the Fire Department during the
temporary absence of both the Fire Chief and Assistant Fire Chief.
(1980 Code § 10-18)
6-3-7: FIRE PROTECTION OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
   A.   Nothing in this Code shall obligate the City or its Fire Department to
furnish fire protection to any property outside the corporate limits of the
City, except as to such properties as the City, by valid contract, is bound to
furnish fire protection, and the Fire Department, in its discretion, may give
or refuse to give fire protection outside the corporate limits of the City,
unless, by valid contract, the City is bound to furnish fire protection. For
each fire attended by the Fire Department outside the corporate limits of the
City, there shall be a charge of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which shall
pay for the first hour or fraction thereof of service, and an additional charge
of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each hour or fraction of an hour over and
above the first hour of service required in attending the fire, all of which
charge shall be payable by the owner and/or lessee of the premises on which the
fire occurred or by the person requesting the service or by any person
receiving a benefit from the service, and all of which charges shall be payable
immediately to the City at the Office of the City Collector.
   B.   The Fire Department may enter into mutual assistance agreements with
the fire departments of other nearby cities and municipalities and fire
protection districts; provided, that the agreements are first approved by the
City Council.
(1980 Code § 10-23)
   C.   The City shall furnish firefighting equipment and personnel for use
outside its boundaries, as provided in any mutual fire aid program agreed to as
provided herein, to any municipality or fire protection district that has
agreed to conform to the program and has assumed the obligations imposed upon
it thereby.
(1980 Code § 10-24)
6-3-8: SPECTATORS NEAR OR AT FIRES:
   A.   Obedience To Department Orders:
      1.   It shall be the duty of all spectators at fires to obey all the
orders of the members of the Fire Department on duty there, with respect to
keeping away from the scene of the fire or the handling of or interference with
the apparatus of the department.
(1980 Code § 10-5)
      2.   Every person who shall be present at any fire or emergency shall be
subject and obedient to the orders of the Fire Chief, Assistant Fire Chief, or
any command officer in extinguishing the fire and the removal and protection of
property; provided, that no person not a member of the Fire Department shall be
bound to obey any of the officers, unless the officers shall bear their
respective badges of office or their official character shall be known to him,
and the officer shall have the power to arrest any person or persons so
refusing to obey such lawful orders.
(1980 Code § 10-13)
   B.   Cordoned Area: The Fire Chief, Assistant Fire Chief, or any member in
command may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any fire, within which no
person excepting those who reside therein, firefighters and police officers,
and those admitted by order of any officer of the Fire Department, shall be
permitted to come.
(1980 Code § 10-7)
   C.   Obstructing Department; Damaging Equipment; Driving Over Hose: Any
person who shall wilfully resist, obstruct, or hinder or interfere with any
member of the Fire Department in the performance of his duty connected with the
Fire Department, or shall wilfully or negligently or in any manner injure,
break or deface any engine, hose, truck, cart, or other fire apparatus
belonging to the City, or belonging to any other fire department, or shall
wilfully or negligently drive any mode of conveyance across or upon any fire
hose, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars
($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(1980 Code § 10-9; amd. 2019 Code)
   D.   Following Fire Apparatus: No person or persons driving any automobile,
truck, motorcycle, or motor vehicle of any kind shall follow within five
hundred feet (500') of any fire engine, fire truck, cart or other fire
apparatus while said engine, truck, cart or apparatus is proceeding to a fire,
and any person or persons violating the provisions of this subsection shall,
upon conviction, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(1980 Code § 10-10)
6-3-9: AUTHORITY TO DESTROY STRUCTURES AT FIRES:
The Fire Chief, or in his absence the officer in command at any fire or in case
of the absence of such officers, the Mayor, or any two (2) members of the City
Council, may direct the members of the Fire Department to cut down and remove
any building, erection or fence for the purpose of checking the progress of any
fire; and the Fire Chief, or other officer in command, shall have the power to
blow up or cause to be blown up, with powder or otherwise, any building or
erection during the progress of any fire for the purpose of extinguishing or
checking the same.
(1980 Code § 10-12)
6-3-10: ENTERING FIREHOUSES RESTRICTED
It shall be and hereby is declared unlawful for any person or persons, unless
invited by Fire Department personnel, to enter the Fire Department house or any
place where the equipment and apparatus of the Fire Department is stored, at
any time, except on business pertaining to the Fire Department or other City
business without consent of the City Council.
(1980 Code § 10-22)
6-3-11: FALSE ALARMS:
Any person who shall intentionally give or make a false alarm of fire shall,
upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
(1980 Code § 10-8; amd. 2019 Code)
Cross-reference:
   See also sections
6-2-2 and
7-6-3 A of this Code
6-3-12: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, any person violating any of the
provisions of this chapter, or failing to comply with the same, where no other
penalty is provided, shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(1980 Code § 10-25)
ARTICLE A: RAPID ENTRY SYSTEM
Section
6-3A-1: Definitions
6-3A-2: Application Of Provisions; Exemptions
6-3A-3: Means Of Accessibility To Secured Systems And Premises
6-3A-4: Construction Sites
6-3A-5: Key Box Contents
6-3A-6: Alert Decals
6-3A-7: Penalties
6-3A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
FIRE DEPARTMENT: The normal fire protection area, both incorporated and
unincorporated, covered by the Watseka Fire Department.
FIRE OFFICIAL: The Fire Chief or his designee.
KEY BOX: A UL “Listed” box, size and style, approved by the Fire Official that
meets the requirements and uses the same security key code adopted by the Fire
Department.
RESPONSIBLE PARTY: The person(s) charged with the responsibility for the
occupancy, building or business owner.
SECURITY CAP: A Fire Department connection (FDC) plug and cap approved for use
in the City of Watseka by the Fire Official utilizing two and one-half inch
(21/2") National Standard thread pattern.
SECURITY PADLOCK: A padlock approved by the Fire Official that utilizes the
approved key code utilized by the Fire Department.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
6-3A-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Application Of Provisions; Costs: All newly constructed buildings, not
yet occupied, or buildings currently under construction, and all buildings or
businesses applying for a certificate of occupancy and/or building permits will
be required to comply with this article. The cost of purchasing and installing
the required equipment, along with any cost associated with implementation of
the program at a specific property, will be borne by the responsible party.
   B.   Exemptions From Provisions: This article shall not apply to owner-
occupied single- and two-family dwellings. Owners of single- and two-family
dwellings are encouraged to participate voluntarily utilizing a residential
security box.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
6-3A-3: MEANS OF ACCESSIBILITY TO SECURED SYSTEMS AND PREMISES:
   A.   Mandatory Key Boxes:
      1.   Fire Suppression And Standpipe: When a new or remodeled building
within the Fire District is protected by an automatic fire suppression and/or
standpipe system, it shall be equipped with a key box, installed at a location
approved by the Fire Official.
      2.   Automatic Alarm Systems: When a new or remodeled building is
protected by an automatic alarm system and/or access to or within a building,
or an area within that building, is unduly difficult because of secured
openings, and where immediate access is necessary for lifesaving or
firefighting purposes, it shall be equipped with a key box, to be installed at
a location approved by the Fire Official.
   B.   Hazardous Materials Storage Cabinets: In occupancies storing or
dispensing hazardous materials, a hazardous materials cabinet may be required.
This cabinet will serve to store materials safety data sheets and other
information as required.
   C.   Key Switch For Automatic Gates: When a property is accessed through a
gate or cross arm that impedes ingress through required fire lanes by means of
a key or swipe card, it shall be equipped with a key switch to be installed at
a location approved by the Fire Official.
   D.   Accessible Security Padlocks: When a property is protected by a locked
fence or gate and where immediate access to the property is necessary for
lifesaving and firefighting purposes, it shall be equipped with a security
padlock to be installed at a location approved by the Fire Official. It shall
then be the responsibility of the responsible party to see that the fence or
gate is secured properly so that the security padlock is accessible.
   E.   Security Caps To Exposed Fire Department Connections: When a building
is protected by an automatic sprinkler and/or standpipe system and the Fire
Department connection is exposed to vandalism, the Fire Official may require
that a security cap be installed.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
6-3A-4: CONSTRUCTION SITES:
   A.   When a construction site is to be secured by a locked fence or gate,
that site will fall under subsection
6-3A-3D of this article during the duration of construction or until said fence
or gate is removed.
   B.   If needed, at the discretion of the Fire Chief, a security padlock will
be obtained by placing a security deposit with the City Clerk in an amount set
to cover replacement of the security padlock should it be lost or damaged. Once
the deposit has been made, the Fire Official will come to the construction site
and explain the use of the security padlock. It shall then be the
responsibility of the construction company to see that the fence or gate is
secured properly so that the security padlock is accessible.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
6-3A-5: KEY BOX CONTENTS:
The key boxes shall contain, but not be limited to, the following items as
designated by the Fire Official:
   A.   Labeled keys to locked points of egress, whether in the interior or
exterior of the buildings.
   B.   Labeled keys to the locked mechanical rooms.
   C.   Labeled keys to any fence or secured areas not covered in subsection
6-3A-3C or D or section
6-3A-4 of this article.
   D.   Labeled keys to any other areas that may be required by the Fire
Official.
   E.   A card containing the emergency contact people and phone numbers for
each occupancy.
   F.   Floor plans of the rooms within the building may also be required,
showing locations of shutoffs.
   G.   Hazardous materials safety data sheets as required.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
6-3A-6: ALERT DECALS:
Alert decals, approved by the Fire Official, to alert fire companies of the
presence of security features covered by this article will be displayed on any
outside doors or windows as designated by the Fire Official.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
6-3A-7: PENALTIES:
Any violation of the provisions of this article is punishable by a fine not to
exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Continued noncompliance may
result in revocation of the certificate of occupancy by the Building Official.
(Ord. 2389, 12-18-2012)
CHAPTER 4: FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
Section
6-4-1: Accumulation Of Combustible Materials
6-4-2: Open Burning
6-4-3: Fires Near Buildings, On Public Ways
6-4-4: Fireworks
6-4-5: Explosives
6-4-6: Life Safety Code
6-4-7: Smoke And Carbon Monoxide Detector Inspections
6-4-8: Emergency Response And Recovery Fees
6-4-1: ACCUMULATION OF COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit or
allow the accumulation of combustible or inflammable materials on any premises
within the fire limits of the City in such quantities so as to create a
dangerous fire hazard. Upon complaint made to him, the City Fire Chief shall
inspect any such premises, and if such a dangerous fire hazard is found to
exist, shall order its removal within twenty four (24) hours time. Refusal to
permit said inspection or failure to comply with said order shall, upon
conviction, subject the offender to a fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(1980 Code § 10-16)
   B.   1.   It shall be unlawful to permit or store any combustible refuse in
such a way as to create a fire hazard or to store or throw away any refuse of
any kind in an alley, street or public way in the City.
      2.   Accumulations of wastepaper, hay, grass, straw, weeds, litter or
combustible or flammable waste or rubbish of any kind shall not be permitted to
remain upon any roof or in any court, yard, vacant lot or open space, or upon
any public street, sidewalk, easement or alley abutting thereon. All weeds,
grass, vines or other growth, when the same endangers property or is liable to
catch on fire, shall be cut down and removed by the owner or occupant of the
property, including all weeds, grass, vines or other growth growing in or upon
any public street, sidewalk, easement or alley abutting said property.
(1980 Code § 53-39)
      3.   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of
this subsection shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifteen
dollars ($15.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day a
violation continues or is permitted to continue shall constitute a separate
offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
(1980 Code § 53-56; amd. 2019 Code)
6-4-2: OPEN BURNING:
   A.   Prohibited Burning; Burning Landscape Waste:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to burn or attempt to burn on any premises in
the City any wastepaper, boxes, cartons, brush, leaves, or other waste or
inflammable materials, unless: Landscape waste (exclusive of any other waste)
is burned on Saturday and/or Sunday of the months of March and November of each
year during daylight hours and/or the first weekend of each month of all months
other than March and November of each year during daylight hours, and burning
is constantly attended by an adult person over the age of eighteen (18) years,
with the means to expeditiously and appropriately extinguish such fire.
      2.   Landscape waste may be burned by City employees at the City
landscape waste area at times when the wind and other conditions are
appropriate for such burning.
   B.   Recreational Fires: Recreational fires shall be allowed only upon a
written permit issued by the City for a specific date.
   C.   Location And Conditions Of Fires:
      1.   All outdoor fires allowed hereinabove must be contained upon private
property, and all such permitted burning is strictly prohibited upon public
streets, gutters, sidewalks, berms, or approaches, and further, no fires
permitted hereinabove nor smoke therefrom shall obstruct the vision of
pedestrians and/or motor vehicle operators upon the sidewalks and/or public
roadways.
      2.   No person shall permit outdoor fires at such time when the Police
Chief or the Fire Chief determines conditions are unsafe for outdoor burning.
   D.   Nuisance Fires:
      1.   Notwithstanding anything herein provided, any outdoor fires may be
declared a nuisance if the smoke, sparks, heat, or ash therefrom unreasonably
interferes with the rights of adjoining or adjacent property owners to
peacefully enjoy the occupation of their real estate.
      2.   In the event a nuisance is declared, the first such instance of a
nuisance by a particular offender shall invoke issuance of a warning by a City
official to such offender; the second nuisance made by a particular offender
shall invoke an immediate order to cease and desist the burning in progress;
the third instance of a nuisance by a particular offender shall cause the City
to revoke said offenders privilege to engage in permitted burning under this
section at any time in the future.
   E.   Penalty: Any unpermitted burning within the City shall be a violation
of City ordinance punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) per occurrence.
(Ord. 2093, 10-20-2003)
6-4-3: FIRES NEAR BUILDINGS, ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. It shall be unlawful to build or light any bonfire so close to any building
or other structure as to endanger such building or structure or on any public
street or sidewalk pavement.
(1980 Code § 53-27)
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifteen dollars
($15.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day a violation
continues or is permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and
shall be punishable as such hereunder.
(1980 Code § 53-56; amd. 2019 Code)
6-4-4: FIREWORKS:
   A.   Definitions: The following words, terms, and phrases, as used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein, unless the context
clearly indicates otherwise:
1.3G FIREWORKS: Those fireworks used for professional outdoor displays and
classified as fireworks UN0333, UN0334, or UN0335 by the United States
Department of Transportation under 49 CFR 172.101.
CONSUMER FIREWORKS: Those fireworks that must comply with the construction,
chemical composition, and labeling regulations of the U.S. Consumer Products
Safety Commission, as set forth in 16 CFR Parts 1500 and 1507, and classified
as fireworks UN0336 or UN0337 by the United States Department of Transportation
under 49 CFR 172.101. CONSUMER FIREWORKS shall not include snake or glow worm
pellets; smoke devices; trick noisemakers known as “party poppers”, “booby
traps”, “snappers”, “trick matches”, “cigarette loads”, and “auto burglar
alarms”; sparklers; toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which
paper or plastic caps containing twenty-five hundredths (0.25) grain or less of
explosive compound is used, provided they are so constructed that the hand
cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy
pistol paper or plastic caps that contain less than twenty hundredths (0.20)
grain of explosive mixture, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all
times.
CONSUMER FIREWORKS DISPLAY OR CONSUMER DISPLAY: The detonation, ignition, or
deflagration of consumer fireworks to produce a visual or audible effect.
DISPLAY FIREWORKS: 1.3G or special effects fireworks or as further defined in
the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act (225 ILCS 227/1 et seq.)
FLAME EFFECT: The detonation, ignition, or deflagration of flammable gases,
liquids, or special materials to produce a thermal, physical, visual, or
audible effect before the public, invitees, or licensees, regardless of whether
admission is charged, in accordance with the National Fire Protection
Association 160 guidelines, and as may be further defined in the Pyrotechnic
Distributor and Operator Licensing Act.
PERSON: An individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, company,
consortium, joint venture, commercial entity, state, municipality, or political
subdivision of a state or any agency, department, or instrumentality of the
United States and any officer, agent, or employee of these entities.
PYROTECHNIC DISPLAY: The detonation, ignition, or deflagration of display
fireworks or flame effects to produce visual or audible effects of an
exhibitional nature before the public, invitees, or licensees, regardless of
whether admission is charged, and as may be further defined in the Pyrotechnic
Distributor and Operator Licensing Act.
SPECIAL EFFECTS FIREWORKS: Pyrotechnic devices used for special effects by
professionals in the performing arts in conjunction with theatrical, musical,
or other productions that are similar to consumer fireworks in chemical
compositions and construction, but are not intended for consumer use and are
not labeled as such or identified as “intended for indoor use”. SPECIAL EFFECTS
FIREWORKS are classified as fireworks UN0431 or UN0432 by the United States
Department of Transportation under 49 CFR 172.101.
   B.   Prohibitions: Excepting pyrotechnic and consumer displays permitted by
the City (see subsection
5-4-2K of this Code for permitted dates), no person, firm, co-partnership, or
corporation shall knowingly possess, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at
retail, or use or explode any display fireworks, flame effects, or consumer
fireworks within the corporate limits of the City.
   C.   Penalty: Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. Each act or product in violation of this
section shall constitute a separate and different offense.
   D.   Administrative Adjudication: Citations issued for violating this
section shall be administered through title 1, chapter 4, article A of this
Code.
(Ord. 2508, 6-26-2018)
6-4-5: EXPLOSIVES:
   A.   Dynamite: It shall be unlawful to keep or store any dynamite in the
City in excess of five (5) pounds on any one premises or in any one building.
(1980 Code § 23-62)
   B.   Nitroglycerine (TNT): It shall be unlawful to keep or store any
nitroglycerine or the explosive commonly known as TNT in the City in any
quantities, excepting for medical or laboratory purposes, and for such purposes
no more than one-fourth (1/4) ounce shall be stored in any one building or
premises.
(1980 Code § 23-63)
   C.   Gunpowder: It shall be unlawful to keep or store any black powder or
gunpowder or guncotton in excess of five (5) pounds on any one premises in the
City.
(1980 Code § 23-64)
   D.   Rules Of The State Fire Chief: All explosives must be kept, stored and
sold in accordance with State law and in accordance with the rules enforced by
the State Fire Chief with regard to the same, subject to the conditions of this
section.
(1980 Code § 23-65)
   E.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than fifteen dollars ($15.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation thereof.
(1980 Code § 23-190; amd. 2019 Code)
6-4-6: LIFE SAFETY CODE:
   A.   Life Safety Code Adopted: NFPA 101, Life Safety Code, as published by
the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA), 2021 edition, is hereby
adopted as the Life Safety Code of the City of Watseka. Any amendments to the
Life Safety Code after April 15, 2021 , shall be effective in the City thirty
(30) days after promulgation by the NFP A. Said Life Safety Code is made a part
hereof as if fully set out in this section.
(Ord. 2628, 11-23-2021)
6-4-7: SMOKE AND CARBON MONOXIDE DETECTOR INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Inspections Required: No sale, lease, sublease or other transfer of
possessory rights (including installment contracts) in and to any residential
dwelling unit including, but not limited to, single-family residences, and any
living unit of a multi-family dwelling building (townhomes, duplexes,
apartments, condominiums) or mixed-use building, shall be finalized or closed
unless the owner, seller, lessor or other individual having possessory rights
therein provides to the purchaser, tenant or potential occupant a valid and
current (specific to the date of finalization or closing) certificate of
compliance from the Watseka Fire Department certifying compliance with the
Smoke Detector Act ( 425 ILCS 60/1, et seq.), the Carbon Monoxide Alarm
Detector Act (430 ILCS 135/1, et seq.), and the smoke detector and carbon
monoxide detector provisions of the Life Safety Code of the City of Watseka for
the dwelling unit.
   B.   Validity: Certificates of compliance shall be valid for a period of
thirty (30) days after issuance.
   C.   Applications: Requests for certificates of compliance shall be made to
the Watseka Fire Department and said application shall be accompanied by a non-
refundable forty dollars ($40.00) inspection fee. A non-refundable forty
dollars ($40.00) fee will be charged to and paid by the requestor each time a
subsequent request for a certificate of compliance is made due to the requestor
having failed to appear or provide appropriate access for an inspection or a
reinspection is necessitated due to the dwelling unit's non-compliance with
applicable laws.
   D.   Penalty: Any person that sells, purchases, leases, subleases or
transfers or takes ownership or possessory rights, or in any way facilitates
the finalization or closing of such transaction, in and to any residential
dwelling unit without obtaining or verifying that a valid and current
certificate of compliance from the Watseka Fire Department has been issued and
is in effect therefor shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1 ,000.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2628, 11-23-2021)
6-4-8: EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND RECOVERY FEES:
The City hereby establishes the cost mitigation rates for the deployment of
certain emergency services by the Fire Department of the City for services
provided and/or rendered to residents and non-residents including the provision
of personnel, supplies and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle incidents
and other emergency incidents as set forth herein, which are based on the
actual costs of the services and those costs that are usual, customary and
reasonable.
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions
apply:
      AMBULANCE SERVICES: EMS response/pre-hospital care (involving usage of
supplies and/or medication) and/or transportation to the nearest hospital of
the sick, injured, wounded, incapacitated, or helpless at the time of dispatch.
Ambulance service shall only be provided to non-residents in circumstances
governed by a contract, mutual-aid or extreme life-saving necessity.
      FIRE SERVICES: Basic scene safety, investigation and fire/hazard control.
      FIRE INVESTIGATION SERVICES (FIRE INVESTIGATION TEAM): Scene safety,
investigation, source identification, K-9/Arson Dog Unit, identification
equipment, mobile detection equipment, fire/hazard control and fire report. The
claim begins when the fire investigator or investigation team responds to the
incident and is billed for logged time only.
      HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENTS: The following:
         Level 1: Basic Response: This level is the provision of basic response
services including engine response, first responder assignment, perimeter
establishment, evacuations, set-up and command.
         Level 2: Intermediate Response: This level includes provision of Level
1 services as well as hazmat certified team and appropriate equipment, level A
or B suit donning, breathing air, detection equipment and set-up and removal of
decontamination center as necessary.
         Level 3: Advanced Response: This level includes provisions of Levels 1
and 2 services as well as robot deployment, recovery and identification of
material, disposal and environmental cleanup. This level also includes any
disposal rates for contaminated equipment and material used at scene.
      LIFT ASSISTANCE: Assistance moving an individual from one position to
another and there being no attendant physical injury requiring transportation
to the hospital.
      MOTOR VEHICLE INCIDENT: The following:
         Level 1: This level is the provision of hazardous materials
assessment, scene stabilization and basic response services.
         Level 2: This level includes provision of Level 1 services, as well as
clean up and material used for hazardous fluid clean-up and disposal. Billing
at this level will occur if the Fire Department of the City must clean up any
gasoline or other automotive fluids that are spilled as a result of the
accident or incident.
         Level 3: This level relates to the extinguishment of a car fire,
provision of scene safety, fire suppression, breathing air, rescue tools, hand
tools, hose, tip use, foam, exposure protection, and clean-up of gasoline or
other automotive fluids that are spilled as a result of the accident or
incident.
         Level 4: This level includes provisions of Levels 1 and 2 services, as
well as the use of extrication tools (heavy rescue tools, ropes, airbags,
cribbing, etc.). Billing at this level will occur if the Fire Department of the
City is required to free or remove anyone from the vehicle(s) using any powered
equipment. Billing at this level will not occur if the person to be extricated
is unconscious or unable to move and the Fire Department is able to open a door
to the vehicle to access and safely remove the person.
         Level 5: This level includes provisions of Levels 1, 2 and 4 services
as well as aeromedical response coordination (multi-engine company response,
mutual aid, and helicopter). Billing will occur at this level any time a
helicopter is utilized to transport the patient(s).
         Level 6: Itemized Response: In the case of an unusual incident, the
Fire Department of the City may bill each incident as an independent incident
with actual costs and/or customary mitigation rates using itemized rates deemed
usual, customary and reasonable. Such incidents will be billed using itemized
amounts for apparatus and personnel, plus products and equipment used.
      NONRESIDENT: Any person not residing within the corporate limits of the
City who requires emergency services of any type, whether knowingly or
unknowingly, by the Watseka Fire Department.
      SPECIAL/BACK COUNTRY RESPONSE: Itemized Response: Each incident will be
billed in accordance with actual costs and/or customary mitigation rates using
itemized rates deemed usual, customary and reasonable, subject to the minimum
amounts set forth above. Such incidents will be billed using itemized amounts
for each apparatus and each trained rescue person per hour, plus rescue
products and equipment used.
      WATER INCIDENTS:
         Level 1: Basic Response: This level is the provision of basic response
services including engine response, first responder assignment, perimeter
establishment, evacuations, first responder set-up and command, scene safety
and investigation (including possible patient contact and hazard control).
         Level 2: Intermediate Response: This level is the provision of Level 1
services as well as clean-up and material used (sorbents), minor hazardous
clean-up and disposal. Billing will occur at this level if the Fire Department
of the City must clean up small amounts of gasoline or other fluids that are
spilled as a result of the incident.
         Level 3: Advanced Response: This level is the provisions of Levels 1
and 2 services as well as D.A.R.T. activation, donning breathing apparatus,
detection equipment, set up and removal of decontamination center, recovery and
identification of material, and disposal and environment clean up. This level
also includes any disposal rates of contaminated equipment and material used at
scene.
         Level 4: Itemized Response: In the case of an unusual incident, the
Fire Department of the City may bill each incident as an independent incident
with actual costs and/or customary mitigation rates using itemized rates deemed
usual, customary and reasonable. Such incidents will be billed using itemized
amounts for apparatus and personnel, plus products and equipment used.
   B.   Fees Established: Any person or entity (resident or nonresident) who
utilizes or is serviced with the emergency services of the Fire Department of
the City shall be responsible for the costs of such services according to the
following mitigation rates. Unless otherwise provided, the hourly rates set
forth below are the minimum response cost in that they will be charged whether
or not services are rendered for the entire hour:
Service
