   RELOCATION OF VEHICLES   10A
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT   11
   ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF STANDING, PARKING AND VEHICLE COMPLIANCE
VIOLATIONS   11A
SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES   12
CHAPTER 1: TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, MARKINGS AND DEVICES
Section
8-1-1: Obedience To Traffic-Control Devices
8-1-2: Unauthorized Signs, Signals, Markings And Devices
8-1-3: Interference With Signs Or Signals
8-1-4: Barricades
8-1-1: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES:
Each driver of any type of a vehicle, whether motorized or not, and, where it
applies, motorcycle, moped, and bicycle operators, shall obey all signs and
signals directing traffic, giving information about special speed zones,
hazardous conditions, road work and any other special directions.
(1980 Code § 46-8)
8-1-2: UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS, MARKINGS AND DEVICES:
No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any
unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is in
imitation of or resembles an official traffic- control device or railroad sign
or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic; nor shall any
person place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any other sign
which hides from view or interferes with the movement of traffic or
effectiveness of any traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal; and
no person shall place or maintain, nor shall any public authority permit upon
any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial
advertising. Any such unauthorized device is hereby declared to be a nuisance
and may be removed by any police officer.
(1980 Code § 46-15)
8-1-3: INTERFERENCE WITH SIGNS OR SIGNALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, move or interfere with
any official traffic sign or signal.
(1980 Code § 46-16)
8-1-4: BARRICADES:
The driver of any vehicle shall use extreme caution in approaching any
barricade or similar warning device. Red and white barricades warn drivers of
the termination of a road, street or highway, other than construction or
maintenance areas. Such barricades are striped, and the colors are
reflectorized red and reflectorized white. Some of the meanings attached to
such barricades indicate the following:
   A.   The roadway ends in a dead-end or cul-de-sac with no outlet;
   B.   A ramp or lane is closed for operational purposes; or
   C.   The permanent or semipermanent closure or termination of a roadway.
(1980 Code § 46-10)
CHAPTER 2: DRIVING RULES
Section
8-2-1: State Rules Of The Road Adopted
8-2-2: Traffic Not To Be Obstructed
8-2-3: Through Streets; One-Way Streets And Alleys; Stop Streets
8-2-4: Driver Signals
8-2-5: Emerging From Alleys, Buildings, Private Roads Or Driveways
8-2-6: Use Of Spotlights
8-2-7: Use Of Off-Road Vehicles On Private Property
8-2-8: Snowmobiles Prohibited
8-2-1: STATE RULES OF THE ROAD ADOPTED:
Except as herein specifically provided differently, all drivers of motor
vehicles shall in all respects comply with the provisions of chapter eleven,
entitled “Rules of the Road”, of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-100
et seq.) Said provisions are hereby incorporated by reference into this Code,
and a violation of any of these provisions within the City shall be deemed a
Municipal offense.
(1980 Code § 46-137)
8-2-2: TRAFFIC NOT TO BE OBSTRUCTED:
No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon any street in such a
manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon.
(1980 Code § 46-185)
8-2-3: THROUGH STREETS; ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS; STOP STREETS:
   A.   Through Streets: The streets and parts of streets of the City
designated by ordinance as through streets (see section
8-5-1 of this title) are hereby declared to be through streets. The driver of a
vehicle shall stop at the entrance to a through street and shall yield the
right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection or which are
approaching so close on a through street as to constitute an immediate hazard,
unless directed otherwise by a traffic officer or a traffic-control signal.
(1980 Code § 46-93)
   B.   One-Way Streets And Alleys: It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle
on any street or alley designated as a one-way street or alley by ordinance
(see section
8-5-4 of this title) in any direction other than that so designated.
(1980 Code § 46-94)
   C.   Stop Streets (see section
8-5-2 of this title for specific stop streets): The driver of a vehicle shall
stop in obedience to a stop sign at an intersection where a stop sign is
erected at one or more entrances thereto, and shall proceed cautiously yielding
to the vehicles not so obliged to stop which are within the intersection or
approaching so close as to constitute an immediate hazard, unless traffic at
such intersection is controlled by a police officer on duty, in which event,
there shall be compliance with the directions of the police officer.
(1980 Code § 46-95)
8-2-4: DRIVER SIGNALS:
No driver of a vehicle shall suddenly start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn
without first giving a suitable signal in such a manner as to apprize others
who might be affected by his action.
(1980 Code § 46-275)
8-2-5: EMERGING FROM ALLEYS, BUILDINGS, PRIVATE ROADS OR DRIVEWAYS:
The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, building, private road or
driveway shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving into the sidewalk
area extending across such alley, building, entrance, road or driveway or in
the event there is no sidewalk area, shall stop at the point nearest to the
street to be entered where the driver has a view of approaching traffic
thereon, and shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian as may be necessary
to avoid collision, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right-of-way
to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. The Public Works Director is hereby
authorized and directed to place stop signs on such alleys, buildings, private
roads or driveways as may be designated by the Public Works Committee as having
sufficient volume of traffic as to require the placement of a traffic-control
device.
(1980 Code § 46-100.1)
8-2-6: USE OF SPOTLIGHTS:
The use of a spotlight within the City limits is hereby prohibited upon all
vehicles, except those being used by members of the police force of the City or
the Sheriff or his deputies while in the discharge of their duties.
(1980 Code § 46-268)
8-2-7: USE OF OFF-ROAD VEHICLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate any off-road vehicle, motorized go-
cart, three-wheeled vehicle, or four-wheeled vehicle (other than a properly
titled, licensed, and certificated motor vehicle as defined in the Illinois
Vehicle Code as now in force or as from time to time hereafter amended) on
private property, other than for the purpose of ingress and egress to such
property, within the City limits.
(1980 Code § 17-24)
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction, be fined as set forth in section
8-11-5 of this title. Each day a violation is committed or permitted to
continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such
hereunder. In addition to the penalty provided in this subsection, the City may
seek the abatement of any nuisance by a suit or action in Court for an
injunction or other appropriate remedy.
(1980 Code § 17-90; amd. 2019 Code)
8-2-8: SNOWMOBILES PROHIBITED:
No person shall ride in or on, or use or control the operation of a snowmobile
in any manner within the City limits. Any person, firm or corporation violating
this section shall be fined as set forth in section
8-11-5 of this title.
(Ord. 2224, 3-13-2007)
CHAPTER 3: TRUCK TRAFFIC
Section
8-3-1: Application Of Provisions; Exemptions
8-3-2: General Regulations
8-3-3: Pavement And Weather Conditions Causing Restrictions
8-3-4: Trucks Over Ten Tons
8-3-5: Enforcement
8-3-6: Penalty
8-3-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS; EXEMPTIONS:
All trucks within the City shall be operated only over and along the
established truck routes (see section
8-5-7 of this title) and on the other designated streets over which truck
travel is permitted. This chapter shall not prohibit:
   A.   Operation On Street Of Destination: The operation of trucks upon any
street where necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point,
provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching
the intersection nearest the destination point.
   B.   Emergency Vehicles: The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street
in the City.
   C.   Street Repair And Maintenance: The operation of trucks owned or
operated by the City, public utilities, any contractor or material man, while
engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street
improvements, or street utilities within the City.
   D.   Detoured Trucks: The operation of trucks upon any officially
established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon
the street for which such detour is established.
(1980 Code § 45-132)
8-3-2: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
   A.   Outside Origin:
      1.   One Inside Destination Point: All trucks entering the City for a
destination point in the City shall proceed only over an established truck
route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which
such traffic is permitted nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the
destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the
shortest permissible route.
      2.   Multiple Inside Destination Points: All trucks entering the City for
multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes
and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such
traffic is permitted nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the
first destination point, a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination
points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic
is permitted. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck shall
return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route.
   B.   Inside Origin:
      1.   Outside Destination Point: All trucks on a trip originating in the
City and traveling in the City for a destination point outside the City shall
proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is
permitted to a truck route as herein established.
      2.   Inside Destination Points: All trucks on a trip originating in the
City and traveling in the City for destination points in the City shall proceed
only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted.
(1980 Code § 45-134)
8-3-3: PAVEMENT AND WEATHER CONDITIONS CAUSING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   When any of the streets of the City, surfaced with blacktop or
bituminous materials, shall, in the opinion of the Public Works Committee and
because of weather or water conditions or any other condition affecting the
traffic-carrying capacity of the street surface, be in imminent danger of
substantial damage or destruction of the surface or pavement by truck traffic,
the Public Works Committee shall have the power to restrict or prohibit the use
of any said street or portion thereof during the emergency.
   B.   The committee, in the event of such emergency, shall post and place on
the street or streets or portions thereof signs with lettering thereon at least
three inches (3") high, which shall either prohibit or restrict truck traffic
on the street or streets, as the case may require. Any person or corporation
who shall, in violation of such signs, travel upon any street of the City,
shall be fined and set forth in sections
1-4-1 of this Code and 8-11-5 of this title.
(1980 Code § 45-135)
8-3-4: TRUCKS OVER TEN TONS:
   A.   Compliance With Provisions; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any
person, firm or corporation to transport, haul or convey any load, weight or
burden upon any wagon, automobile, truck or other wheeled vehicle over, upon or
along any pavement other than concrete laid and maintained upon any street,
avenue or alley in the City, when the weight of such load or burden, including
the weight of such wheeled vehicle, shall exceed ten (10) tons, unless the
person shall comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(1980 Code § 45-130)
   B.   Permit Required: Any person, firm or corporation, desiring to
transport, haul or convey any load, weight or burden exceeding ten (10) tons
upon any wagon, automobile, truck or other wheeled vehicle over, upon or along
any pavement, other than concrete or other than those streets named in section
8-5-7 of this title, shall first make application for a permit therefor to the
Public Works Director stating the nature, character and weight of such wagon,
automobile, truck or other wheeled vehicle, also naming in the application the
paved streets, avenues or alleys over which it is proposed to transport or haul
the same, and agreeing to be responsible for and pay to the City all damages
that may occur to any such paved street, avenue or alley by reason of the
transportation or hauling of such load, weight or burden over or upon the same,
and if, in the opinion of the Public Works Director, no permanent injury is
likely to occur by reason of the transportation or hauling of such load, weight
or burden over or along the paved streets, avenues or alleys named in the
application, he may grant a permit therefor.
(1980 Code § 45-131)
8-3-5: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Maps: The City Clerk shall keep and maintain accurate maps depicting
all truck routes, and the maps shall be kept on file in the Office of the City
Clerk and shall be available to the public.
   B.   Signs Posted: The Chief of Police shall cause all truck routes to be
clearly signposted.
   C.   Weigh-In: The Chief of Police shall have the authority to require any
person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle not proceeding over a
truck route or street over which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any
public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining
whether there has been compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. 2519, 9-25-2018)
8-3-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter, for
which no specific penalty has been provided, shall be fined as set forth in
section
8-11-5 of this title.
(1980 Code § 45-140)
CHAPTER 4: PARKING REGULATIONS
Section
8-4-1: Method Of Parking
8-4-2: Stopping, Standing Or Parking Prohibited In Specified Places
8-4-3: General Parking Restrictions
8-4-4: Parking On Highways
8-4-5: Parking During Snow Removal
8-4-6: Parking For Persons With Disabilities
8-4-7: Municipal Parking Lots
8-4-8: Loading And Unloading Zones
8-4-9: Signs Posted
8-4-10: Tampering With Motor Vehicle Prohibited
8-4-1: METHOD OF PARKING:
   A.   Parallel Parking:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided in this section, every vehicle stopped
or parked upon a two-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked with the right-
hand wheels parallel to and within twelve inches (12") of the right-hand curb
or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder.
      2.   Except when otherwise provided by ordinance, every vehicle stopped
or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked parallel to the
curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of authorized traffic movement,
with its right-hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the right-hand curb or
as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder, or with
its left-hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the left-hand curb or as
close as practicable to the left edge of the left-hand shoulder.
   B.   Angle Parking: The City may permit angle parking on any roadway;
except, that angle parking shall not be permitted on any Federal-aid or State
highway unless the Department of Transportation has determined that the roadway
is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the
free movement of traffic.
(1980 Code § 46-129)
   C.   Parallel And Angle Parking:
      1.   No vehicle shall be parked with the left of such vehicle next to the
curb or other edge of the pavement, except on one-way streets, and it shall be
unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel with the
curb or other edge of the pavement, and with the right wheels of the vehicle
within twelve inches (12") of the regularly established curb or other edge of
the pavement line; except, that upon those streets that have been marked for
angular parking, vehicles shall be parked at an angle to the curb or other edge
of the pavement as indicated by such marks.
(1980 Code § 46-111)
      2.   When stalls are marked on streets for diagonal parking, diagonal
parking is permitted on the following portions of streets, namely: That part of
Second, Third and Fourth Streets lying between Oak Street and Cherry Street.
Except where the berm of the street (that portion of a street between the
traveled portion of the street and the sidewalk) has been improved by the City
or someone else with the City's permission for diagonal parking, the parking of
vehicles in the streets of the rest of the City shall be by parallel parking.
(1980 Code § 46-133)
   D.   Parking Within Stalls; No Parking Zones:
      1.   When parking stalls have been marked on streets, it shall be
unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to park any vehicle in or on any
of said streets, except within the parking lanes or stalls as herein provided
and wherein parking is not designated as prohibited.
      2.   No person shall park any vehicle within the spaces designated and
marked on said streets as no parking spaces in front of fire hydrants, theaters
and hotel entrances, or in the stall immediately south of the City Hall which
is hereby reserved for the police cars and the car of the Mayor.
(1980 Code § 46-115)
8-4-2: STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
   A.   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic-
control device, no person shall:
      1.   Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
         a.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street.
         b.   On a sidewalk.
         c.   Within an intersection.
         d.   On a crosswalk.
         e.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings.
         f.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
         g.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel.
         h.   On any railroad tracks.
         i.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
         j.   On any controlled-access highway.
         k.   In the area between roadways on a divided highway, including
crossovers.
         l.   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
         m.   At any place where the standing of a vehicle reduces the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
         n.   On the west side of North 5th Street between Hickory Street and
Elm Street.
      2.   Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily
to pick up or discharge passengers:
         a.   In front of a public or private driveway.
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
         c.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
         d.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of
the roadway.
         e.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly sign posted).
         f.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
      3.   Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or
passengers:
         a.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing.
         b.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   B.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any
such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful.
(1980 Code § 46-110; amd. Ord. 2680, 3-28-2023)
8-4-3: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   No Parking Areas: No person shall park or permit to stand any vehicle
in any areas in the City designated and marked as a “No Parking” area.
(1980 Code § 46-122)
   B.   In Front Of Certain Buildings: No person shall be permitted to park in
front of any public meeting place for a space of ten feet (10') on either side
of the main entrance thereto, when a public meeting or entertainment is being
held, except for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers, which must be
accomplished with all convenient speed.
(1980 Code § 46-24)
   C.   Berm Parking: No vehicle shall be parked on the berm, being that
portion of the-right-of way between the paved portion of the street and the
sidewalk, or if there is no sidewalk, being the unpaved portion of the right-
of-way.
(Ord. 2260, 3-25-2008)
   D.   Obstructing Driveway Entrances: No person shall park or permit any
vehicle to stand in such manner as to obstruct the entrance to any public or
private driveway or any street or alley in the City.
(1980 Code § 46-122)
   E.   Alleys: No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner
or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet (10') of the
width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person
shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to
block the driveway entrance to any abutting property.
(1980 Code § 46-113)
   F.   Double Parking: No person shall park or leave any motor vehicle so that
the same shall stand outside of any authorized or plainly marked off parking
space provided on the streets or highways of the City; nor shall any person
permit any motor vehicle to stand upon the traveled portion of any street in
the City.
(1980 Code § 46-117)
   G.   Cab Stands And Bus Stands: No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab
shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cab stand; and no
vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus
loading zone.
(1980 Code § 46-118)
   H.   Vehicles For Sale: It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, stand,
or park any motor vehicle, boat, recreational vehicle, equipment or trailer on
any street, highway, Municipal or other government-owned parking lot, alley, or
easement, for the purpose of displaying such motor vehicle, boat, recreational
vehicle, or trailer for sale.
(Ord. 2322, 6-22-2010)
   I.   Private Property: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any
private property without the consent of the owner of the property.
(1980 Code § 46-120)
8-4-4: PARKING ON HIGHWAYS:
The City, with respect to highways under its jurisdiction, may place signs
prohibiting, limiting, or restricting the stopping, standing or parking of
vehicles on any highway where, in its opinion, such stopping, standing or
parking is dangerous to those using the highway or where the stopping, standing
or parking of vehicles would unduly interfere with the free movement of traffic
thereon. No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in violation of the
restrictions indicated by such devices.
(1980 Code § 46-129)
8-4-5: PARKING DURING SNOW REMOVAL:
   A.   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to park or to leave standing any
vehicle on any public street in the City at any time within twelve (12) hours
after a snowfall of three inches (3") or more has occurred, unless the snow has
first been plowed or removed from said streets.
(1980 Code § 46-124)
   B.   Towing Vehicles; Notice Provisions; Costs:
      1.   The Police Department and all members thereof assigned to traffic
duty are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed
away by a commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked
on any public street in violation of subsection A of this section.
      2.   Cars so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe
place and shall be restored to the owner or operator of such car or vehicle
upon payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00), plus all storage, towing and
other charges incurred by the City.
      3.   If the identity and address of the owner of any such towed vehicle
is readily accessible, the Chief of Police shall send or cause to be sent by
U.S. mail, postage prepaid, a notice in writing to such person informing him of
the location of said vehicle and the procedure to be followed in order to
reclaim said vehicle. If such identity and address is not available, then a
notice containing the same information as required in the mailed notice shall
be published three (3) times in a newspaper printed and published or of general
circulation in the City. Said notice, whether mailed or published, shall also
state that the owner or bailee of said vehicle has the right to contest the
action of the Police Department by filing with the City Clerk, or in the
absence from the City of said Clerk, with the City Collector, his written
notice of his contest, stating the reason or reasons of his contest. Said
notice of contest must be filed within two (2) weeks after the mailing or first
publication of the notice by the Chief of Police. Within two (2) weeks after
the filing of the notice of contest, the City Council, after due notice to the
contestant, shall hear the objections of the contestant and testimony thereon
and within two (2) weeks after the close of said hearing make its decision
thereon. All proceedings thereafter shall be conducted in accordance with the
Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.)
(1980 Code § 46-125)
8-4-6: PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
   A.   1.   It is unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any
vehicle in a stall or space designed for persons with disabilities if,
immediately adjacent to and visible from such stall or space, there is posted a
sign known as the international wheelchair symbol consisting of a profile view
of a stylized wheelchair with occupant in white on a blue background, unless
the driver of the car has a disability.
      2.   As used in this subsection A1, “disability” means either having a
physical condition requiring the use of a wheelchair, artificial limb, crutch,
cane or walker, or having a physical disease making it difficult or impossible
to walk more than twenty five feet (25') without shortness of breath or danger
of impairment of health. A certificate by a person licensed to practice the
healing arts in this State shall be acceptable by the City as evidence under
this subsection B1.
(1980 Code § 46-123; amd. 2019 Code)
      3.   The provisions of subsection A1 of this section shall apply to all
off-street parking facilities owned or operated by the City or by any privately
owned or operated parking lot.
      4.   Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this
subsection B1 shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(1980 Code § 46-123)
   B.   It shall be unlawful and prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is
not bearing registration plates issued to a person with a disability, a veteran
with a disability, or which is not bearing such devices as City authorities
have authorized as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a person
with a disability or a veteran with a disability, in any parking place
specifically reserved, by the posting of an official sign, for motor vehicles
bearing such registration plates, unless in fact said vehicle is operated by a
person with a disability or a veteran with a disability.
(1980 Code § 46-132; amd. 2019 Code)
8-4-7: MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS:
   A.   Parking Lots Established:
      1.   Parking Lot No. 1: There is hereby established a Municipal parking
lot at the corner of Oak Street and Third Street within the City, which said
parking lot shall be described and designated as “Parking Lot No. 1”. All other
Municipal parking lots acquired and maintained by the City for the parking of
vehicles shall be numbered consecutively in the order in which such lot, or
lots, are acquired.
(1980 Code § 46-87)
   B.   Supervision: The Municipal parking lots now or hereafter acquired or
established by the City shall be under the supervision of the Chief of Police.
   C.   Use:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any Municipal parking
lot in violation of any ordinance; or to park contrary to the rules established
by the City Council for the use of such parking lot; or in any place or manner
other than that designated by the custodian thereof.
      2.   No commercial or freight-carrying vehicle or trailer shall be parked
in a City parking lot.
(1980 Code § 46-89)
   D.   Hours: It shall be unlawful to park any car in any parking lot for a
period more than twelve (12) hours in any one day.
(1980 Code § 46-90)
   E.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of
this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(1980 Code § 46-91)
8-4-8: LOADING AND UNLOADING ZONES:
   A.   During the times specified herein, it shall be unlawful for the driver
of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a longer time than is necessary
to load or unload passengers, not to exceed three (3) minutes, and for the
driver to stand any freight carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than
is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30)
minutes, at any of the following places:
      1.   In any public alley, during any hour of the day or night.
      2.   At any place not to exceed twenty five feet (25') along the curb
before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time.
      3.   At any place not to exceed twenty five feet (25') along the curb
before the entrance to a public building between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except Sunday.
      4.   Directly in front on the entrance to any theater at any time the
theater is open for business.
(1980 Code § 46-114)
   B.   Draying and hauling vehicles, while loading or unloading, shall not
stop or park so as to obstruct traffic and shall park near the entrance of any
public building only for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers or
freight.
(1980 Code § 46-23)
8-4-9: SIGNS POSTED:
The Public Works Committee shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where
parking is limited or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions.
(1980 Code § 46-121)
8-4-10: TAMPERING WITH MOTOR VEHICLE PROHIBITED:
No person other than a police officer shall move a vehicle into any such
prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful, or start or
cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change or move
the lever, brake, starting device, gears or other mechanism of a standing motor
vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or
driver thereof, or attempt so to do.
(1980 Code § 46-116)
ARTICLE A: UNATTENDED MOTOR VEHICLES
Section
8-4A-1: Leaving Vehicle Unattended
8-4A-2: Action By Police
8-4A-3: Presumption
8-4A-4: Parking Ticket
8-4A-1: LEAVING VEHICLE UNATTENDED:
   Except for a law enforcement officer or an operator of an authorized
emergency vehicle performing his official duties, no person driving or in
charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first
stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key from the ignition,
effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any perceptible
grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway. An
unattended motor vehicle shall not include an unattended locked motor vehicle
with the engine running after being started by a remote starter system.
(625 ILCS 5/11-1401) (1980 Code § 46-80)
8-4A-2: ACTION BY POLICE:
Whenever any police officer shall find a motor vehicle standing unattended with
the ignition key in the vehicle, in violation of this article, the police
officer is authorized to remove the key from the vehicle and to deliver the key
to the police officer in charge of the Police Station.
(1980 Code § 46-81)
8-4A-3: PRESUMPTION:
The registered owner of a vehicle found in violation of this article shall be
held prima facie responsible for any such violation.
(1980 Code § 46-82)
8-4A-4: PARKING TICKET:
A police officer, upon removing the ignition key from the unattended vehicle,
shall write a parking violation ticket or summons and leave it on the
windshield of the vehicle. On the ticket or summons shall be stated the name
and address of the police station where the key will be held and at which the
motorist may reclaim the key upon his proof of his right of possession to the
key and the vehicle. If one other than the owner, whether a bailee or
otherwise, appears to have the right of possession to the key and vehicle, then
a separate ticket or summons may be issued to that person. If no one appears to
claim the key and vehicle within twenty four (24) hours after the removal of
the key, then a notice in writing to the registered owner of the vehicle shall
be sent by certified mail, return receipt, stating that the Police Department
holds the ignition key to the vehicle, and further stating that the vehicle
will be treated as an abandoned vehicle unless reclaimed within seven (7) days
of the date of the notice. Upon the expiration of the seven (7) day period,
without the reclaiming of the key and vehicle, the procedure with reference to
abandoned vehicles shall be followed (see chapter 10 of this title).
(1980 Code § 46-83)
ARTICLE B: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY
Section
8-4B-1: Authority To Remove Or Tow Vehicles
8-4B-2: Prima Facie Proof
8-4B-3: Leased Vehicles
8-4B-1: AUTHORITY TO REMOVE OR TOW VEHICLES:
The Police Department, and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty, are
hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a
commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in any
place where the parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks
the use of a fire hydrant, obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any
emergency vehicle, or is illegally parked in violation of any of sections
8-4-2,
8-4-3F, and
8-4-6A and B of this chapter and
8-5-6-1 and
8-5-6-2 of this title. All proceedings thereafter shall be conducted in
accordance with the Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.)
(1980 Code § 46-135)
8-4B-2: PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in
whose name the vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such
violation and subject to the penalty for such violation.
(1980 Code § 46-135.1)
8-4B-3: LEASED VEHICLES:
   A.   Any person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to law and
who leases such vehicle to others, after receiving a written notice of a
violation of this chapter shall, upon request, provide the City police with a
written statement of the name and address of the lessee at the time of such
offense and the identifying number upon the registration plates and
registration sticker or stickers of the vehicle.
(1980 Code § 46-135.2)
   B.   No person who is the lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease
agreement shall be liable for the violation of any parking or standing
regulation of this chapter during the period of the lease; provided, that upon
the request of the City police received within one hundred twenty (120) days
after the violation occurred, the lessor provides, within sixty (60) days after
such release, the name and address of the lessee. The driver's license number
of a lessee may subsequently be requested by the City police if needed for the
enforcement of this chapter.
(1980 Code § 46-135.3)

8-5-4: DIRECTION OF TRAFFIC ON SPECIFIC STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   One-Way Alleys: The following alleys are hereby made alleys for one-way
traffic. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to drive or
operate any vehicle of any kind in, along, or upon the following alleys except
in the direction indicated:
      The alley located in Blocks Seventeen, Eighteen, Nineteen and Twenty in
the Town of South Middleport, now a part of the City, in a westerly direction.
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to stop or park any
vehicle in the alley herein described, except for the purpose of unloading
goods, wares, or merchandise consigned to any of the premises adjoining the
alley, in which case, the vehicle shall not be parked for any length of time
other than that which is reasonably necessary to unload said goods, wares, or
merchandise.
      The alley located in Block 27 in the Town of South Middleport, now a part
of the City, and the alley located in Block 12 in Stanley's Addition to the
City, in a westerly direction.
(1980 Code § 46-103)
   B.   Two-Way Alleys: The following alleys are hereby made alleys for two-way
traffic:
(2019 Code)
      The alleys between and bounded by North Fifth Street, North Second
Street, Walnut Street and Oak Street, in both easterly and westerly directions.
(Ord. 2090, 7-21-2003)

8-5-6: PARKING:
8-5-6-1: PARKING PROHIBITED; TIME LIMIT PARKING:
It shall be unlawful at any time to park any vehicle on certain City streets
and portions of streets at the times as specified as follows:
Brianna Drive, east or west side, from its intersection with U.S. Route 24/
Illinois Route 1, also known as Walnut Street, to Cemetery Road, any time.
Fairman Avenue, north side, from its intersection with Belmont Avenue west to a
point 175 feet west of its intersection with Fifth Street, any time.
Mulberry Street, from a point 195 feet west of MOPAC northbound main track to a
point 150 feet east of MOPAC main track, any time.
Mulberry Street, south side, between the hours of 8:00 A.M. and 4:30 P.M., from
its intersection with Second Street to its intersection with Third Street.
North Street, from a point 175 feet west of the centerline of MOPAC northbound
main track to a point 160 feet east of the centerline of MOPAC northbound main
track, any time.
Oak Street, north side, between its intersection with Eighth Street and its
intersection with Tenth Street, any time.
Park Street, from a point 430 feet west of the centerline of MOPAC northbound
main track to a point 330 feet easterly, measured on the centerline of Park
Street, east of MOPAC northbound main track, any time.
Porter Avenue, south side, between the hours of 7:00 A.M. and 4:30 P.M., on
days when school is in session, from its intersection with Faith Street to its
intersection with Ninth Street, but that portion of Porter Avenue shall be a
school unloading zone in which vehicles may stop temporarily to load and unload
passengers only with the driver remaining in the vehicle.
Sheridan Street, north side, from the intersection of Second Street to the
intersection of Sixth Street.
U.S. Route 24 and Illinois Route 1, also known as Walnut Street, both sides,
from 5th Street easterly ±1.86 miles (±9820 feet) to the east corporate limits
of Watseka, located at the east junction of U.S. Route 24 and Illinois Route 1,
any time
U.S. Route 24 and Illinois Route 1, that part that lies east of the half
section line of Section 33, Township 25 North, Range 12 West of the Second
Principal Meridian, and is within the corporate limits, any time.
Walnut Street between Fifth Street and Eighth Street, any time.
South Second Street, west side, either on the street or in the paved portion
immediately west thereof for a distance of 90 feet north from the centerline of
West Cherry Street.
Third Street, west side, from Mulberry Street to its intersection with
Washington Street, any time.
North Third Street, any motor vehicle or motor vehicle combination, west side,
from its intersection with the alleyway between Hickory Street and North
Street, any time.
Fifth Street, east side, from the intersection of Ash Street to the
intersection of Elm Street, any time.
Fifth Street, east side, from Hamilton Street to Lincoln Avenue, any time.
Fifth Street, west side, parallel parking only, from Hamilton Street to Lincoln
Avenue, any time.
Fifth Street, either side, from Lincoln Avenue to Mulberry Street, any time.
Ninth Street, west side, from its intersection with Locust Street south to its
intersection with Lincoln Avenue, any time.
Tenth Street, west side, between its intersection with Mulberry Street and its
intersection with Locust Street, any time.
(1980 Code § 46-128; amd. Ord. 1984, 11-15-2000; Ord. 2005, 5-14-2001; Ord.
2131, 11-15-2004; Ord. 2185, 6-19-2006; Ord. 2453, 1-26-2016)
8-5-6-2: ORDINANCE 1169 ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Ordinance No. 1169, adopted July 19, 1971, and being an ordinance regulating
parking on F.A. Route 9 (Illinois Route 1 and U.S. Route 24) Section 20-R,
along Lafayette, Jefferson and Walnut Streets extending north, east and west of
the intersection of Illinois Route 1 and U.S. Route 24 in the City, is
incorporated herein by reference. Said ordinance provides:
That in order to promote the health, safety, and welfare of its citizens,
parking will be prohibited on the pavement or shoulders of Illinois Route 1 and
U.S. Route 24 within the corporate limits of the City of Watseka, from
approximately 678.79 feet west; 485.11 feet north; and 731.21 feet east of the
intersection of U.S. Route 24 and Illinois Route 1 in the City of Watseka,
Iroquois County, Illinois.
(1980 Code § 46-127)
8-5-6-3: PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
The City hereby designates suitable and sufficient space as required by its
ordinances and applicable State and Federal law for the following parking
spaces for persons with disabilities:
   1 space at 500 North Fourth Street.
(Ord. 2033, 12-19-2001; Ord. 2145, 5-16-2005; Ord. 2146, 5-16-2005)
8-5-7: RESTRICTED WEIGHT STREETS; TRUCK ROUTES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to transport,
haul, or convey any load weight or burden upon any wagon, automobile, truck, or
any other road vehicle over or around designated restricted streets in the City
when the weight of such load or burden, including the weight of such wheeled
vehicles, shall exceed six (6) tons. The streets or specified portions involved
shall be designated as restricted weight streets, as follows:
      That portion of Oak Street from a point 166 feet east of its intersection
with Eighth Street, thence east through the remaining course of the street.
      Ninth Street between its intersection with Walnut Street to the
intersection of Oak Street.
(1980 Code § 45-142)
   B.   Truck Routes: There are hereby designated the following truck routes
within the corporate limits of the City:
      Brianna Drive.
      Elm Street from Brianna Drive to the eastern boundary of the corporate
limits.
      Ernest Grove Parkway.
      Fleming Street.
      Illinois Route 1.
      U.S. Route 24.
      Veterans Parkway.
      Second Street from West Oak Street to the southern boundary of the
corporate limits of the City.
(Ord. 2519, 9-25-2018)
8-5-8: BICYCLES, MOTORCYCLES AND TOY VEHICLES PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to ride or drive any bicycle or
motorcycle or ride or use skateboards or roller skates on the sidewalks within
the area bounded and described as follows:
   West to east from the Union Pacific Railroad to Sixth Street.
   North to south from the alley between Oak Street and Ash Street to the alley
between Locust Street and Mulberry Street.
(Ord. 2328, 8-14-2010)

8-7-3H3 of this title

Iroquois County Community Unit School District No. 9 for controlling traffic
