   B.   Waiver: Except for those violations referenced in subsection E of this
section, a person may waive a hearing by paying the fine amount specified in
step 1 on or before the hearing date identified on the violation notice.
   C.   Nonappearance: As a courtesy to an individual who files a timely
“Request for Hearing - Nonappearance”, the fine amount shall be frozen at the
amount specified in step 1 until five (5) days after a notice of determination
has been mailed to the violator.
   D.   Uniformity: The fines and penalties herein set forth shall be uniformly
applied to each violation of any Code provision regulating, restricting, or
prohibiting the standing or parking of motor vehicles, the use or condition of
vehicular equipment, and the requirement for display of a Municipal vehicle
sticker presently in effect or hereafter adopted.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
   E.   Violations Regarding Persons With Disabilities: Notwithstanding
subsections A through D of this section, any person found to be in violation of
subsection
8-4-7B2 of this title or 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes section 5/11-1301.3(a)
shall be subject to a fine of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) if a sign
is displayed indicating that the fine imposed shall be three hundred fifty
dollars ($350.00) for violation. If a sign is not displayed indicating that the
fine is three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00), the fine shall be as posted or,
if no fine is posted, the fine shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
Any person found to be in violation of the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1301.3(a-1) or similar provision of this Code shall be fined six
hundred dollars ($600.00) for the first offense and one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for a second or subsequent offense.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-7: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS:
An administrative hearing shall be held to adjudicate vehicular regulation
violations on their merits in accordance with the following provisions:
   A.   Time, Date And Location: The time, date, and location of any
administrative hearing shall be as set forth on a violation notice.
   B.   Waiver: Certain violation notices may be issued that allow the
recipient to pay a fine prior to, and thus obviating the need for, a hearing.
If the recipient fails to pay the required fine within the allotted time, the
violation notice will be processed through the administrative adjudication
system.
   C.   Tape Recording: Administrative hearings shall be tape recorded.
   D.   Hearing Rights: Persons appearing to contest an alleged violation may
be represented by counsel of their own choice at their own expense. Any written
notarized statement of facts timely submitted by a person filing a “Request for
Hearing-Nonappearance” shall be given the same weight as in-person testimony.
   E.   Nonappearance Of Nonresidents: Individuals that are served with a
violation notice that are not residents of the City may contest the merits
thereof without personally appearing at an administrative hearing. The person
cited shall complete and sign the “Request for Hearing - Nonappearance” section
of the violation notice acknowledging that his/her personal appearance is
waived, and file the same with the Traffic Compliance Officer no later than ten
(10) days after the date of issuance of the violation notice, along with a
notarized statement of facts specifying the grounds for challenging the
violation notice. The Hearing Officer’s decision shall be served by first class
mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the address set forth in the statement of
facts. Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice is placed
in the United States mail.
   F.   Evidentiary Standard: The formal and technical rules of evidence do not
apply. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted if it is of the type
commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their
affairs. City police reports, inspection reports and records of the State and
other governmental agencies shall be admissible in evidence.
   G.   Determinations: Hearings shall result in a determination of liability
or nonliability after consideration of the facts and/or testimony. The Hearing
Officer shall, upon a determination of liability, assess fines and penalties in
accordance with this article. A determination shall constitute a final
determination for purposes of judicial review.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-8: ADDITIONAL NOTICES:
The following additional notices shall be sent by first class mail, postage
prepaid, at the times and in the manner hereinafter prescribed:
   A.   Second Notice: Upon failure of the registered owner or lessee to appear
at the administrative hearing indicated on the violation notice, the Traffic
Compliance Administrator shall send or cause to be sent a second notice
containing the following information:
      1.   The date, time, and place of the violation (date of issuance);
      2.   The particular vehicular regulation violated;
      3.   Vehicle make and State registration number;
      4.   The fine and any penalty which may be assessed for late payment;
      5.   The date, time, and place of the administrative hearing at which the
alleged violation may be contested on its merits;
      6.   A statement that failure to either pay the fine and any applicable
penalty or failure to appear at the hearing on its merits on the date, time,
and place specified will result in a determination of liability for the
violation in the amount of the fine or penalty indicated; and
      7.   A statement that upon the occurrence of a final determination of
liability for the failure, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust,
available administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or
penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the City.
   B.   Notice Of Final Determination: A notice of final determination of
liability shall be sent following a determination of liability and the
conclusion of judicial review. The notice shall include the following
information:
      1.   A statement that the unpaid fine or penalty is a debt due and owed
to the City; and
      2.   A warning that a failure to pay any fine or penalty due and owing
the City may result in the filing of a petition in the Circuit Court of the
21st Judicial Circuit, Iroquois County, to have any unpaid fine or penalty
rendered as a judgment or may result in the suspension of the person’s driver’s
license or the immobilization or towing of vehicles for failure to pay fines or
penalties for ten (10) or more violations.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-9: FINAL DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY; PETITION TO SET ASIDE:
   A.   Final Determination Of Liability: A final determination of liability
shall occur upon the failure to pay the fine or penalty after the Hearing
Officer's determination of liability and the exhaustion of or failure to
exhaust administrative review, or where a person fails to appear at a hearing
to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified, the Hearing
Officer's determination shall become final upon the denial of a timely petition
to set aside a determination, or upon the expiration of the period for filing
the petition without a filing having been made.
   B.   Petition To Set Aside:
      1.   Time And Manner Of Filing: A petition to set aside a determination
of liability must be filed or mailed to the Traffic Compliance Administrator
within ten (10) days of the Hearing Officer's determination of liability.
      2.   Grounds: The grounds for granting a petition to set aside a
determination of liability are limited to:
         a.   The person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the date
the violation occurred;
         b.   The person has paid the fine or penalty for the violation in
question; or
         c.   Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a
hearing.
      3.   Review And Decision: Upon receipt of a timely petition to set aside
a determination of liability, the Traffic Compliance Administrator shall review
the petition to determine if sufficient cause has been shown to set aside the
determination of liability. If cause has been shown, the Traffic Compliance
Administrator shall forward to the petitioner a new hearing date on which the
petitioner must appear to present his/her case on the underlying violation. The
Traffic Compliance Administrator shall notify the petitioner of his/her
decision to grant a hearing or deny the petition within fourteen (14) days of
his/her receipt of the petition.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-10: VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION PROGRAM:
   A.   Grounds For Immobilization: Any motor vehicle whose registered owner
has been determined to be liable for ten (10) or more vehicular regulation
violations, for which the fines or penalties remain unpaid, may be immobilized
or impounded if:
      1.   The Traffic Compliance Administrator has determined that a person is
liable for ten (10) or more vehicular regulation violations, the fines or
penalties for which remain unpaid.
      2.   The person determined to be liable for ten (10) or more vehicular
regulation violations is the registered owner of a motor vehicle located within
the City’s geographical boundaries.
      3.   a. A notice of impending vehicle immobilization/impoundment, and
right to challenge the validity of said notice by disproving liability for the
unpaid final determination of liability has been sent to the registered owner
of the motor vehicle containing the following information:
            (1)   A final determination has been made on ten (10) or more
vehicular regulation violations, the fines and penalties of which remain
unpaid.
            (2)   A listing of the vehicular regulation violations for which
the person has been determined to be liable, which shall include for each
violation:
               (A)   The vehicular regulation violation notice number;
               (B)   Date of issuance; and
               (C)   Total amount of fines and penalties assessed.
            (3)   Any motor vehicle(s) owned by the person and located within
the City is subject to immobilization and/or impoundment if the fines and
penalties are not paid within fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice.
         b.   The registered owner may contest the validity of the notice by
fully completing, signing, and filing the request for hearing portion of the
notice with the Traffic Compliance Administrator within, but not later than,
fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice. The request for hearing shall be
deemed filed upon receipt by the Traffic Compliance Administrator.
      4.   The motor vehicle(s) of the registered owner to whom notice is sent
has failed to make payment of the fines or penalties as specified in the
notice, and no timely request for hearing has been filed with the Traffic
Compliance Administrator to contest the validity of the notice.
   B.   Administrative Hearing:
      1.   Upon the receipt of the request for hearing to contest the validity
of the notice of impending immobilization or impoundment, the Traffic
Compliance Administrator shall schedule an administrative hearing to contest
the validity of said notice by disproving liability for the unpaid final
determinations of parking, standing, or compliance violation liability listed
on the notice on the next available hearing date, but in no case shall the
hearing be scheduled later than sixty (60) days after the request for hearing
is filed. The Traffic Compliance Administrator shall serve notice of the
hearing date on the registered owner by first class mail, postage prepaid.
Service of the notice shall be complete on the date it is placed in the United
States mail.
      2.   A registered owner of the vehicle(s) immobilized or impounded under
this section shall have the right to an administrative hearing to be held at
the next regularly scheduled administrative court date without the requirement
of payment of outstanding fines and penalties for which final determination has
been made, as follows:
         a.   The Traffic Compliance Administrator shall serve a post-
immobilization and post- impoundment notice upon the registered owner of a
vehicle immobilized or towed and impounded under this section, which notice
shall advise the registered owner of the vehicle of the right to a hearing to
challenge the validity of the immobilization or impoundment and which shall
contain the following information:
            (1)   Date of immobilization or impoundment;
            (2)   Location of vehicle;
            (3)   That the vehicle was immobilized or towed for nonpayment of
fines or penalties assessed for the violation of ten (10) or more violations of
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation(s) for which the
registered owner has been determined liable and notified of impending
immobilization or impoundment;
            (4)   The date that the notice of impending immobilization or
impoundment was issued; and
            (5)   That the registered owner may contest the validity of the
immobilization or impoundment by completing and signing the request for hearing
portion of the notice and filing the request for hearing with the Traffic
Compliance Administrator within, but not later than, fourteen (14) days of the
date of the notice. Said request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the
Traffic Compliance Administrator.
         b.   Upon the receipt of the request for hearing to contest the
validity of the immobilization or impoundment, the Traffic Compliance
Administrator shall schedule an administrative hearing to contest the validity
of the immobilization or impoundment on the next available hearing date or
sooner if scheduled by the Traffic Compliance Administrator for good cause
shown, but in no case shall the hearing be scheduled later than sixty (60) days
after the request for hearing is filed, as follows:
            (1)   The Traffic Compliance Administrator shall serve notice of
the hearing date upon the registered owner by first class mail, postage
prepaid; and
            (2)   Service of the notice shall be complete on the date it is
placed in the United States mail.
         c.   An order entered after the hearing to contest the validity of the
immobilization or impoundment is a final administrative decision within the
meaning of 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., incorporated herein
by reference.
   C.   Release Of Immobilized Or Impounded Vehicle: A vehicle immobilized or
impounded pursuant to this section shall be released to the registered owner
thereof, or his or her agent, upon payment of the fines and penalties due and
owing the Municipality as specified in the notice sent in accordance with
subsection A3 of this section, and upon payment of a fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) for the installation and removal of an immobilization device, if any,
and upon payment of towing charges and accrued daily impound charges, if any,
or upon order of the Hearing Officer following the hearing contesting the
validity of the impoundment.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-11: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
Review of final determinations issued by the Hearing Officer shall be subject
to the provisions of the Administrative Review Law as is set forth in 735
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. The City shall have the right to
appeal a determination, regardless of whether the violation notice in question
was formally prosecuted with the presence of an attorney representing the City.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-12: DEBT TO CITY:
Any fine or penalty, or part thereof, assessed following a final determination
of liability that remains unpaid shall be a debt due and owing the City and, as
such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. Payment in full of
any fine or penalty resulting from a violation under this article shall
constitute a final disposition of that violation.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-13: JUDGMENTS:
   A.   The Traffic Compliance Administrator shall, following the expiration of
the period within which administrative and judicial review may be sought for a
determination of vehicular regulation violation liability take all necessary
actions, execute all required documents and appoint or retain any individual or
agency deemed appropriate to obtain a judgment against and collect monies from
the person(s) who has been assessed fines or penalties which remain unpaid, and
have become a debt due and owing the City.
   B.   The Traffic Compliance Administrator is authorized to file a complaint
in the Circuit Court praying for the entry of a judgment against the person for
whom a final determination of vehicular regulation violation liability has been
made. The complaint filed by the Traffic Compliance Administrator or individual
or agency on behalf of the City, seeking entry of a judgment against an
individual for unpaid fines and/or penalties pursuant to a final determination
of vehicular regulation violation liability, shall have attached to it:
      1.   A certified copy of determination of vehicular violation liability;
and
      2.   A certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the final
determination of vehicular regulation violation liability was issued in
accordance with this Code. Nothing shall prevent the City from consolidating
multiple final determinations of vehicular regulation violation liability in an
action in the Circuit Court against an individual. The summons and a copy of
the complaint may be served upon the person against whom a judgment is sought
under the provisions of this Code by any method provided under State Statute;
or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided the total amount of
fines and penalties for final determination of vehicular regulation violation
liability does not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
      3.   The Traffic Compliance Administrator is authorized to pursue all
available remedies authorized by the law to collect monetary judgments.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
8-11A-14: ADDITIONAL MEANS OF ENFORCEMENT:
The City reserves the right to employ all other means and methods available
under the law to enforce this Code, including direct application to the courts.
(Ord. 2487, 10-24-2017)
CHAPTER 12: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES

8-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words or phrases used in this Article shall be defined as herein
provided unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
AGGRAVATED ASSAULT: Any violation as defined in §12-2 of the Illinois Criminal
Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/12-2), as amended from time to time.
AGGRAVATED BATTERY: Any violation as defined in §12-3.05 of the Illinois
Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/12-3.05), as amended from time to time.
ARSON: Any violation as defined in the following sections of the Illinois
Criminal Code of 2012, as amended from time to time: “Arson” (720 ILCS 5/20-1);
or “Aggravated Arson” (720 ILCS 5/20-1.1).
BURGLARY: Any violation as defined in the following sections of the Illinois
Criminal Code of 2012, as amended from time to time: “Burglary” (720 ILCS 5/19-
1); or “Residential Burglary” (720 ILCS 5/19-3).
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES VIOLATION: Except as otherwise authorized by law
including, but not limited to, the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act or the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot program Act, a violation of one or
more of the following statutes of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act or the
Illinois Cannabis Control Act: “Manufacture or Delivery of a Controlled
Substance” (720 ILCS 570/401); “Controlled Substance Trafficking” (720 ILCS
570/401.1); “Possession of a Controlled Substance” (720 ILCS 570/402);
“Possession of More than 10 Grams of Any Substance Containing Cannabis” (720
ILCS 550/4); “Manufacture or Delivery of Cannabis” (720 ILCS 550/5); “Cannabis
Trafficking” (720 ILCS 550/5.1); “Delivery of Cannabis on School Grounds” (720
ILCS 550/5.2); or “Unauthorized Production or Possession of Cannabis Sativa
Plant” (720 ILCS 550/8).
DRAG RACING: A violation as defined in §11-506 of the Illinois Vehicle Code
(625 ILCS 5/1 1-506), as amended from time to time.
DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE: Any violation as defined in §11-501 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-501), as amended from time to time.
DRIVING WHILE LICENSE, PERMIT OR PRIVILEGE TO OPERATE A MOTOR VEHICLE IS
SUSPENDED OR REVOKED: Any violation as defined in § 6-303 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code (625  ILCS 5/6-303), as amended from time to time, except for
suspensions resulting solely from violations of vehicle emission requirements.
DRIVING WITHOUT A VALID DRIVERS LICENSE: A violation of § 6-101 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/6-101), as amended from time to time, where the
driver’s license or driving privileges have never been obtained, or previously
have been obtained and have been expired for not less than six (6) months.
FLEEING AND ELUDING A PEACE OFFICER: Any violation as defined in § 11-204 of
the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-204), as amended from time to time.
HEARING OFFICER: A licensed attorney who is not an officer or employee of the
City.
INDECENT SOLICITATION OF A CHILD: Any violation as defined in § 11-6 of the
Illinois Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/11-6), as amended from time to time.
INSURANCE VIOLATION: A violation of one or more of the following statutes of
the Illinois Vehicle Code, as amended: “Required Liability Insurance Policy”
(625 ILCS 5/7-601); or “Insurance Card” (625 ILCS 5/7-602).
MOB ACTION: Any violation as defined in § 25-1 of the Illinois Criminal Code of
2012 (720 ILCS 5/25-1), as amended from time to time.
OWNER:  The record titleholder to a motor vehicle.
POSSESSION OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: Except as otherwise authorized by law
including, but not limited to, the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act or the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, any violation as
defined in § 3.5 of the Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act (720 ILCS 600/
3.5), as amended from time to time.
POSSESSION OF EXPLOSIVES OR EXPLOSIVE OR INCENDIARY DEVICES: Any violation as
defined in § 20-2 of the Illinois Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/20-2), as
amended from time to time.
PROSTITUTION VIOLATION: A violation of one or more of the following statutes of
the Illinois Criminal Code of 2012, as amended: “Prostitution” (720 ILCS 5/11-
14); “Solicitation of a Sexual Act” (720 ILCS 5/11-14.1); or “Patronizing a
Minor Engaged in Prostitution” (720 ILCS 5/11-18.1).
RETAIL THEFT: Any violation as defined in §16-25 of the Illinois Criminal Code
of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/16-25), as amended from time to time.
ROBBERY: A violation of one or more of the following statutes of the Illinois
Criminal Code of 2012, as amended: “Robbery” (720 ILCS 5/18-1); or “Armed
Robbery” (720 ILCS 5/18-2).
VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle.
WEAPONS VIOLATION: A violation of one or more of the following statutes of the
Illinois Criminal’‘Code of 2012, as amended: “Unlawful Use of Weapons” (720
ILCS 5/24-1); “Unlawful Possession of Firearms and Firearm Ammunition” (720
ILCS 5/24-3.1); or, “Unlawful Sale or Delivery of Firearms on the Premises of
any School” (720 ILCS 5/24-3.3).
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-2: VIOLATION:
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be used in conjunction or association
with any of the following offenses:
   A.   Aggravated Assault;
   B.   Aggravated Battery;
   C.   Any Arson;
   D.   Any Burglary;
   E.   Any Controlled Substance Violation;
   F.   Drag Racing;
   G.    Driving Under the Influence;
   H.   Driving While License, Permit or Privilege to Operate a Motor Vehicle
is Suspended or Revoked;
   I.   Driving without a Valid Driver’s License;
   J.   Fleeing and Eluding a Peace Officer;
   K.   Indecent Solicitation of a Child;
   L.   Mob Action;
   M.   Possession of Drug Paraphernalia;
   N.   Possession of Explosives or Explosive or Incendiary Devices;
   O.   Any Prostitution Violation;
   P.   Retail Theft;
   Q.   Any Insurance Violation;
   R.   Any Robbery; and,
   S.   Any Weapons Violation.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-3: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES:
Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle has been
used in violation of Section
8-12-2, he shall cause the seizure and impoundment of the vehicle to a facility
controlled by the City or its agents. No vehicle shall be seized and impounded
under this section unless the police officer determines that such action is
necessary and reasonable under the circumstances including, but not limited to,
community caretaking functions. If the vehicle is capable of being removed from
the scene by an individual who is present on the scene (not otherwise to be
taken into custody), and who has permission from the owner of the vehicle to
drive the vehicle, and the individual is otherwise capable of lawfully
operating a motor vehicle in the State of Illinois, the police officer shall
allow that individual to remove the vehicle without the same being subject to
seizure and impoundment. Similarly, if the vehicle is parked legally, and/or
will not present a hazard to the public safety or otherwise jeopardize the
efficient movement of vehicular traffic at its location, the officer shall
permit the vehicle to remain at its location without being seized and impounded
pursuant to this subsection. Nothing herein shall be interpreted to prevent a
police officer from seizing and impounding a vehicle when necessary for
investigative purposes or when otherwise authorized pursuant to some other
lawful purpose.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-4: BOND:
Any vehicle seized and impounded under Section
8-12-3 shall be held as bond to secure the personal appearance of the owner at
the administrative hearing. If a cash bond in the amount of Five Hundred
Dollars ($500.00) is posted with the City, the impounded vehicle will be
released to the owner, upon the payment by the owner of the towing and storage
costs. If a penalty is imposed for a violation of this Section
8-12-2, the cash bond will be forfeited to the City to satisfy such penalty;
provided, in the event that a violation of Section
8-12-2 is not proven, the bond will be returned to the owner. Any form of bond
posted pursuant to this section will be held by the City until the hearing
officer issues a decision, or, if there is a judicial review, until a reviewing
court issues a final decision. No bond shall be required to be posted in the
event a vehicle is not seized and impounded.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-5: PRELIMINARY HEARING ON IMPOUNDMENT:
Whenever a vehicle is seized and impounded, the police officer shall notify the
person identifying himself or herself as the owner of the vehicle, or any
person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged
violation, of the vehicle owner’s right to request a preliminary hearing within
twelve (12) hours of the seizure. If the owner of a vehicle seized under the
provisions of this section timely requests a preliminary hearing, the Watch
Commander or any supervising officer must conduct a preliminary hearing within
twenty-four (24) hours after the request for the preliminary hearing is
received by the ‘City; provided that if the date for the hearing falls on a
Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the preliminary hearing will be held on the
next business day following the Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. No
preliminary hearing shall be required or granted to an owner whose vehicle was
not seized and impounded. For purposes of this section, the following shall
apply:
   A.   All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to he
heard at the preliminary hearing.
   B.   The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and hearsay
testimony will be allowed, and will be admissible.
   C.   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the Watch Commander or
supervising officer determines that there was probable cause to believe that
the vehicle was being used in violation of Section
8-12-2, and further determines that the seizure and impoundment of the vehicle
was proper under Section
8-12-3, he shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle unless the
owner of the vehicle posts a cash bond with the City in the amount of Five
Hundred Dollars ($500.00). Posting of the bond shall not relieve the owner from
paying any applicable towing and storage costs associated with the seizure and
impoundment of the vehicle.
   D.   If the Watch Commander or supervising officer determines that there was
no probable cause to believe that the vehicle was used in violation of Section
8-12-2, or otherwise determines that the vehicle should not have been seized
and impounded pursuant to Section
8-12-3, the motor vehicle will be returned to the owner of record without the
posting of the bond and without the costs associated with the seizure and
impoundment of the vehicle. A determination that the vehicle should not have
been seized and impounded pursuant to Section
8-12-3 has no bearing nor will relieve an owner of responsibility for violating
Section
8-12-2.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-6: FINAL HEARING:
   A.   Notice of Hearing. Any owner issued a citation for a violation of
Section
8-12-2 shall have the right to request a hearing to challenge the citation and/
or seizure and impoundment. Notice shall be given to the owner of record of the
ability to request a hearing. Such notice shall be mailed by certified mail,
return receipt requested, to the owner of record, as shown on the records of
the Illinois Secretary of State. Notice by certified mail need not be given
when the owner of the vehicle has been personally served with notice, in
written form, of his ability to apply for a hearing. If the owner of the
vehicle requests a hearing, the City shall, within ten (10) business days after
such request, notify the owner of the date, time and location of a hearing.
Notice of the date, time and location of the hearing shall be sent via regular
mail.
   B.   Requesting a Hearing. Any person cited for a violation of Section
8-12-2 may apply for a hearing to contest whether the person driving the
vehicle was in violation of Section
8-12-2 at the time the citation was issued and/or whether the seizure and
impoundment of the vehicle was proper under the circumstances. The application
for a hearing shall be made no later than five (5) days after notice has been
given either personally or by certified mail, whichever is applicable in the
given circumstance. The application to request a hearing shall be provided by
the City at the time notice is given. The bond will be forfeited in the event a
hearing is not requested as provided for in this chapter.
   C.   Hearing. For purposes of this section, the following shall apply to the
owners hearing:
      1.   Unless continued by order of the hearing officer, the hearing shall
be held within forty five (45) days the citation was issued.
      2.   All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the final hearing.
      3.   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer
determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used in
violation of Section
8-12-2, and otherwise determines that the seizure and impoundment of the
vehicle was proper pursuant to Section
8-12-3, the hearing officer shall order the continued impoundment of the
vehicle until the owner of the vehicle pays to the City a penalty in the amount
of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00), plus the towing arid storage costs. In the
event the vehicle was not impounded, an order shall be entered wherein the
owner of record shall be liable to the City in the amount of Five Hundred
Dollars ($500.00).
      4.   If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing
officer shall enter an order of default in favor of the City, which order shall
require the payment to the City of a penalty of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00).
      5.   If the hearing officer determines that the vehicle was not used as
hereinabove provided in violation of Section
8-12-2, the motor vehicle will be returned to the owner of record of the
vehicle without any penalty or other costs, or, if a cash bond had previously
been posted, the cash bond shall be returned.
      6.   If the hearing officer determines that the vehicle was used in
violation of Section
8-12-2, but determines that the vehicle was not properly subject to seizure and
impoundment under Section
8-12-3, the hearing officer shall enter a judgment against the owner in the
amount of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) and release the seized vehicle without
towing and storage costs and/or order the reimbursement of towing and storage
costs if the vehicle was previously released.
      7.   The ticket issued shall constitute prima facie evidence that the
offense stated was committed.
      8.   Any penalty assessed shall be a debt due and owing the City.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-7: UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
   A.   Any motor vehicle that is not claimed within thirty (30) days after the
expiration of the time in which the owner of record may seek judicial review of
the action of the City under this section, or the time at which a final
judgment is rendered in favor of the City, or the time at which a final
administrative decision is rendered against an owner of record who is in
default, may be disposed of as an abandoned or unclaimed vehicle, as otherwise,
provided by law.
   B.   If the penalty and towing and storage costs are not paid within eighty
(80) days after a penalty is imposed, the vehicle shall be deemed to be
abandoned and may be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the
disposition of abandoned or unclaimed vehicles, unless a petition for judicial
review is filed with a court of proper jurisdiction. Where a petition for
judicial review of the hearing officer’s determination is filed and pending in
a court of proper jurisdiction, the vehicle shall not be deemed to be abandoned
and shall lot be sold. If the petition for judicial review is resolved in favor
of the City, the vehicle shall be deemed abandoned and may be disposed of by
the City if the penalty and towing and storage costs are not paid within thirty
(30) days after the date of the Court’s order.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-8: LIABILITY FOR PENALTY AND COSTS:
   A.   The owner of record of a motor vehicle used in violation of Section 46-
296 shall be liable to the City for a penalty of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00)
in addition to any fees for the towing and storage of the motor vehicle.
   B.   Fees for towing and storage are established by the towing company,
except where the motor vehicle is stored on City property, in which case the
storage cost will be established by the Mayor or the Chief of Police.
   C.   A vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall remain impounded
until the earlier of the following occurs:
      1.   The penalty is paid to the City, and all towing and storage costs
are paid to the towing company and/or City, as may be applicable; and
      2.   A bond in amount equal to the liability of the owner as herein
provided in subsection A. above is posted with the City and all applicable
towing and storage costs are paid to the towing company; and
      3.   The vehicle is deemed abandoned, in which case the vehicle shall be
deposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of abandoned or
unclaimed vehicles.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
8-12-9: POSSESSORY RIGHTS OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLES:
Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner, lien holder, or any
other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a motor vehicle
impounded under this article until the penalty and all towing and storage costs
applicable have been paid in full. Notwithstanding the above, in the event a
lienholder has commenced foreclosure proceedings, pays the applicable towing
and storage costs, and executes and agreement with the City to refund to the
City the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale up to Five Hundred Dollars
($500.00), less any amounts necessary to pay any lienholders of record having
priority over the City’s claim. The lienholder shall submit the following
documents to the City as evidence that it has commenced foreclosure
proceedings: (1) a certificate of title showing the lienholder as having first
priority; (2) the motor vehicle installment agreement; (3) a notarized
affidavit detailing the default of the owner/purchaser and any steps taken by
lienholder to give notice or an opportunity to owner/purchaser in accordance
with its contract; and (4) identification of any contract provisions granting
the lienholder right of possession.
(Ord. 2580, 7-28-2020)
TITLE 9: PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter
GENERAL REGULATIONS FOR STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS   1

   SIDEWALK CAFES   2A

CITY PARKS   6

CHAPTER 1: GENERAL REGULATIONS FOR STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
Section
9-1-1: Supervision
9-1-2: Street And Sidewalk Construction Comply With Specifications
9-1-3: Injury To Pavements
9-1-4: Maintenance And Repairs
9-1-5: Openings And Stairways
9-1-6: Obstructions And Encroachments
9-1-7: Deposits On Public Ways
9-1-8: Private Uses
9-1-9: Barbed Wire And Electric Fences
9-1-10: Barricades And Lights
9-1-11: Utility Poles And Wires
9-1-12: Removing Earth From Street
9-1-13: Playing Games In Public Ways
9-1-14: Penalties
9-1-1: SUPERVISION:
All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways in the City shall
be under the supervision of the Public Works Committee. It shall have
supervision over all work thereon, and shall have power to enforce all
ordinance provisions relating to such public places, and is hereby authorized
to enforce such ordinances.
(1980 Code § 45-1)
9-1-2: STREET AND SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION COMPLY WITH SPECIFICATIONS:
All street and sidewalk pavements shall be made in conformity with the
specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the City Council.
(1980 Code § 45-4)
Cross-reference:
   See section
12-3-4 of this Code for permit requirements
9-1-3: INJURY TO PAVEMENTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon
or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded
by a warning sign or barricade, or knowingly to injure any soft newly laid
pavement.
(1980 Code § 45-5)
   B.   It shall be unlawful to injure any sidewalk, street or alley pavements.
(1980 Code § 45-13)
9-1-4: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS:
   A.   All public street, alley and sidewalk pavements shall be kept in good
repair. Such repair work, whether done by the City or by the abutting owner,
shall be under the supervision of the Public Works Committee.
(1980 Code § 45-6)
   B.   It shall be the duty of every City officer or employee, on becoming
cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction
thereof, to report the same to the Public Works Director as soon as possible.
(1980 Code § 45-7)
9-1-5: OPENINGS AND STAIRWAYS:
It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any
public street, sidewalk or alley without a permit from the City Council. All
such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover
or a railing, subject to the approval of the Public Works Committee.
(1980 Code § 45-27)
9-1-6: OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause,
create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other
public way, except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the
Public Works Committee.
(1980 Code § 45-8)
   B.   It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure
which encroaches upon any public street or property.
(1980 Code § 45-12)
   C.   No person shall make, or cause to be made, any enclosure, fence,
bridge, arched way or building of any kind extending upon, over or across any
street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within the City.
(1980 Code § 45-16)
   D.   It shall be unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or
alley.
(1980 Code § 45-20)
9-1-7: DEPOSITS ON PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Generally:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to throw or deposit any glass, nails or other
similar articles or any debris on any street, alley or sidewalk or other public
place in the City.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dump or
deposit, or cause to be dumped or deposited, any grass, leaves, branches, or
any other things in the roadway or gutter of any public street in the City.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person mowing lawns to cause grass
clippings, leaves, or other debris to be thrown into a street or gutter and
left there.
(1980 Code § 45-24)
   B.   Deposits On Streets:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street any material which may
be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass, or
other articles which may do injury to any person, animal or property.
      2.   Coal or other materials may be deposited in streets preparatory to
delivery or use; provided such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the
roadway at the point to less than eighteen feet (18'); and provided, that such
material or coal, other than material to be used in actual building
construction, shall not be permitted to remain on such street for more than
three (3) hours. Any material or coal shall be guarded by lights, if the same
remains upon any street at nighttime.
(1980 Code § 45-14)
   C.   Deposits On Sidewalks: It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public
sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any
waste material, or any glass or other articles which might cause injury to
persons, animals or property.
(1980 Code § 45-15)
9-1-8: PRIVATE USES:
   A.   Display Of Merchandise; Making Advertisements On Pavements: It shall be
unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use any street, sidewalk or
other public place as space for the display or sale of goods or merchandise; or
to write or mark any signs or advertisements on any such pavements.
(1980 Code § 45-11)
   B.   Gas Pumps: It shall be unlawful to erect any gasoline pump or tank in
any public street, alley or sidewalk.
(1980 Code § 45-25)
9-1-9: BARBED WIRE AND ELECTRIC FENCES:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any fence composed in whole or in
part of barbed wire, spikes, or with any similar device, or any wire charged
with electric current sufficient to cause shock, within seven feet (7') of the
ground level.
(1980 Code § 45-17)
9-1-10: BARRICADES AND LIGHTS:
   A.   Required:
      1.   Any person, firm or corporation laying or repairing any pavement on
a street, sidewalk or other public place, or making any excavation in any such
place, shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or
vehicle by reason of the work; and such barricades shall be protected by lights
at nighttime.
      2.   Any defects in the pavement shall be barricaded to prevent any
injury; and any person, firm or corporation properly maintaining any opening or
excavation in any such place shall guard the opening or excavation while the
same remains open by proper barricades and lights.
(1980 Code § 45-9)
   B.   Disturbing Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere
with any barricade or light lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement
or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk.
(1980 Code § 45-10)
9-1-11: UTILITY POLES AND WIRES:
   A.   Poles:
      1.   No person or corporation shall set or cause to be set any telegraph,
telephone, electric light or other poles upon any street or alley within the
City, or string or hang any wire along or across any street or alley, unless
authorized so to do by the Public Works Committee. All guy wires shall be
equipped with guards from the ground level to a distance of eight feet (8')
above the ground level.
(1980 Code § 45-21)
      2.   All electric light, telegraph, cable TV, and telephone poles now in
any street of the City, or which shall hereafter be placed on any alley, or
street, shall be located and placed within the curb lines on the sidewalk side
thereof, which are now or may hereafter be established; and poles shall be
placed as near as may be in a line in the streets.
(1980 Code § 45-22)
   B.   Wires:
      1.   All wires suspended from the poles shall be at least thirty feet
(30') high above the level of the street grades, unless a different height is
required or permitted by the State or Illinois Commerce Commission, and the
poles shall be neatly smoothed and in a fit condition to be painted.
      2.   All high tension wires shall, so far as practicable, be kept upon
opposite sides of the streets from telephone and telegraph wires.
(1980 Code § 45-23)
      3.   In all new additions or subdivisions, all telephone, telegraph,
cable TV and electric light or power lines shall be constructed and maintained
in alleys or easements at the rear of the lot and in underground conduits.
(1980 Code § 45-21)
9-1-12: REMOVING EARTH FROM STREET:
It shall be unlawful, for any private purpose, for any person or corporation to
dig, remove or carry away any earth, gravel or sod from any street, avenue or
alley without first having secured the permission of the Public Works
Committee.
(1980 Code § 45-18)
9-1-13: PLAYING GAMES IN PUBLIC WAYS:
It shall be unlawful to play any games upon any street, alley or sidewalk,
where such games cause unnecessary noise or interfere with traffic or
pedestrians.
(1980 Code § 45-26)
9-1-14: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall, upon conviction, be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Each day a violation is committed or permitted to continue
shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
In addition to the penalty provided in this section, the City may seek the
abatement of any nuisance by a suit or action in court for an injunction or
other appropriate remedy.
(1980 Code § 45-141; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2: SIDEWALKS
Section
9-2-1: City Powers
9-2-2: Construction Regulations
9-2-3: Maintenance And Repairs
9-2-4: Obstructing Sidewalks
9-2-5: Displaying Merchandise
9-2-6: Openings And Steps
9-2-7: Expectorating Prohibited
9-2-8: Penalty
9-2-1: CITY POWERS:
The Public Works Committee may regulate or designate the location of any
sidewalk paving, and may require the reconstruction of any sidewalk paving
which is not made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(1980 Code § 45-107)
9-2-2: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Original Construction: It shall be the duty and obligation of the
abutting property owner or owners to construct, at their own cost, the original
sidewalk paving in front of any private property adjacent to any street. To
this end, the Corporate Authorities may take the appropriate proceedings under
the powers granted to the City by the Statutes of the State of Illinois to
impose upon the abutting property owner or owners a special tax to cover the
cost of the construction of the sidewalk paving, when the abutting owner or
owners refuse to construct the paving.
(1980 Code § 45-106)
   B.   Specifications:
      1.   All sidewalks shall be of cement or concrete construction. Before
any grouting shall be placed within the forms for any proposed sidewalk, the
subgrade of the walk shall be brought to an elevation at all points four and
one-fourth inches (41/4") below the elevation of the top surface of the
finished walk; and before any grouting or any materials to be used in the
construction of the walk shall be placed on the subgrade, the subgrade shall be
inspected, approved and accepted by the Public Works Committee.
      2.   Hereafter, the centerline of the top or wearing surface of all
cement or concrete sidewalks constructed in the City for public travel shall be
one-half inch (½") higher than the outer edges thereof.
(1980 Code § 45-108)
   C.   Crossing Driveways: Where sidewalks cross a driveway, the sidewalks
shall be constructed of concrete not less than eight inches (8") in thickness.
(1980 Code § 45-109)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
13-5-6 of this Code; see section
12-3-4 of this Code for permit requirements
9-2-3: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS:
   A.   Maintenance:
      1.   Persons owning, occupying or in control of any premises shall keep
the sidewalks and alleys adjacent thereto free of litter.
      2.   In residential areas, owners or occupants shall sweep or rinse off
the sidewalks abutting their premises as often as may be required to keep the
walk and street reasonably free from dirt, paper, and waste.
      3.   All owners or persons controlling premises in the Central Business
District of the City shall, at least once each twenty four (24) hours, except
when the business is closed, sweep the sidewalks in front of their premises
down to the curb, and gather up and remove all loose paper and refuse.
(1980 Code § 45-121)
   B.   Repairs: Any abutting property owner desiring a repair or replacement
of a sidewalk in front of his premises may furnish the materials for said
repair or replacement, and the City may furnish the labor for said repair or
replacement. Any owner, desiring such repair or replacement shall make
application therefor to the Public Works Committee. This subsection shall not
obligate the City to make repairs under this subsection if funds are not
available for that purpose.
(1980 Code § 45-110)
9-2-4: OBSTRUCTING SIDEWALKS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, either by the
assemblage of persons on sidewalks or by the placing of objects on or across
sidewalks, to obstruct the sidewalk so as to prevent the free passage of
pedestrians thereon.
(1980 Code § 45-124)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to pile any
goods, sidewalk signs, boxes, or other like material or things upon any
sidewalk within the corporate limits of the City to a point farther from the
edge of the sidewalk adjacent to the lot or building than three feet (3').
(1980 Code § 45-114)
9-2-5: DISPLAYING MERCHANDISE:
   A.   Prohibited On Certain Streets: It is unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to sell or display any goods, wares, merchandise or stock in trade
for sale, or any boxes, baskets, or other like materials upon the sidewalks
provided for the use of pedestrians on either side of Walnut Street between the
east and west intersection of Routes 1 and 24, or upon the sidewalks on either
side of Second Street, Third Street and Fourth Street within one block of
Walnut Street, all within the City.
(Ord. 2417, 6-24-2014)
   B.   Newsracks And Real Estate Flyer Racks Exempt; Regulations: It shall be
unlawful to exhibit or offer to sell, at or from any newspaper stand or real
estate flyer rack on any public street or other public place, anything other
than newspapers and regularly published magazines or real estate flyers or to
place on any public street or other public place at or near any such stand, or
use in connection with such stand, any rack, chair, box or other article not
located wholly within the stand. Any newsrack or real estate flyer rack which,
in whole or in part, rests upon, in or over any public property shall comply
with the following standards:
      1.   Location And Manner Of Installation:
         a.   No box shall be less than one and one-half feet (11/2') from the
back of the curb edge of the roadway.
         b.   No newsrack or real estate flyer rack shall be permitted to rest
upon, in or over any public property, when such installation, use or
maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property, or when such site or
location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation impedes the
flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic including any legally marked or stopped
vehicle, the ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or
interferes with the use of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants,
mailboxes, parking meters, traffic-control devices, or other objects permitted
at or near said location.
         c.   No newsrack or real estate flyer rack shall be chained, bolted,
or otherwise attached to any tree, utility pole, light pole, parking meter,
traffic-control post, street sign post, or other fixture located on public
property except to other newsracks or real estate flyer racks.
         d.   Newsracks or real estate flyer racks may be placed next to each
other; provided, that no group of newsracks or real estate flyer racks shall
extend for a distance of more than eight feet (8') along a curb, and a space of
not less than three feet (3') shall separate each group of newsracks or real
estate flyer racks.
         e.   No newsracks or real estate flyer racks shall be placed,
installed, used or maintained:
            (1)   Within three feet (3') of any marked crosswalk.
            (2)   Within twelve feet (12') of the curb return of any unmarked
crosswalk.
            (3)   Within five feet (5') of any fire hydrant, fire call box,
police call box, or other emergency facility.
            (4)   Within fifteen feet (15') of any intersection, driveway,
alley or street from the point where the curb line meets an imaginary line
which constitutes an extension of the boundary of the driveway, alley or street
at its narrowest point.
            (5)   At any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of
pedestrians is reduced to less than three feet (3').
            (6)   Within three feet (3') of or on any public area improved with
lawn, flowers, shrubs, trees or other landscaping.
(Ord. 2304, 10-13-2009)
            (7)   On or interfering with any access ramp for persons with
disabilities.
(Ord. 2304, 10-13-2009; amd. 2019 Code)
            (8)   On or within any median within any public right-of-way.
            (9)   Within two hundred fifty feet (250') of any other newsrack on
the same side of the street in the same block containing the same issue or
edition of the same publication or periodical.
      2.   Size: No newsrack or real estate flyer rack shall exceed the
following:
         a.   Four feet (4') in height.
         b.   Twenty four inches (24") in width.
         c.   Twenty inches (20") in thickness.
(Ord. 2304, 10-13-2009)
9-2-6: OPENINGS AND STEPS:
   A.   Permit Required: No cellar way, window, or other opening, and no steps,
shall be built or maintained upon any street, alley, or sidewalk without having
first obtained a permit therefor from the Public Works Committee.
(1980 Code § 45-122)
   B.   Safety Precautions: All cellar ways, window openings, or steps upon any
street, alley, or sidewalk shall be securely protected by a substantial iron
guard, or railing, or covering.
(1980 Code § 45-123)
9-2-7: EXPECTORATING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared a nuisance for any person within
the corporate limits of the City to spit or expectorate on any sidewalk, depot
platform or in any public building or entrance thereto in any stairway or
hallway thereof.
(1980 Code § 45-113)
9-2-8: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 45-129)
ARTICLE A: SIDEWALK CAFES
Section
9-2A-1: Purpose
9-2A-2: Application For License
9-2A-3: Term Of License
9-2A-4: License Fee
9-2A-5: Conditions For Operation
9-2A-6: Penalty
9-2A-7: Administrative Adjudication
9-2A-1: PURPOSE:
Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, a sidewalk café business
license shall authorize the retail sale and/or consumption of food and beverage
(but excluding alcoholic beverages) in a sidewalk café adjacent to a permanent
structure otherwise being a licensed business premises.
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
9-2A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person applying for a sidewalk café business license shall submit to the
City Clerk the following information:
   A.   Approved Permit: An approved sidewalk café permit issued by the
Building Official;
      1.   An applicant for a sidewalk café permit shall submit the following
information to the Building Official with its request for a sidewalk café
permit:
         a.   The name of the individual, partnership, corporation, or
association applying for the permit;
         b.   The residence and phone number of the applicant or partners or,
if a corporation or association, the residences and phone numbers of the
principal officers;
         c.   The name of the business and the location for which the permit is
requested;
         d.   A nonrefundable permit application processing fee in the amount
of fifty dollars ($50.00);
         e.   A refundable, assuming the permit is not granted, permit fee of
fifty dollars ($50.00), plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of sidewalk
space used; and
         f.   A scaled site plan of the proposed sidewalk café, including the
location of the licensed premises, location of access points to the sidewalk
café, locations of tables and seating, locations of fences, and the location of
the curb cut and adjacent street or roadway. Measurements of the size of the
sidewalk café, its proximity to the licensed premises, and proximity to any
adjacent roadway shall be shown on the site plan.
      2.   The Building Official's decision to grant or deny the sidewalk café
permit shall be governed by the following standards:
         a.   The sidewalk café shall be operated on a sidewalk adjacent to the
business premises, and no part thereof shall protrude past the building lines
of the licensed premises;
         b.   No sidewalk café shall be located next to another premises
licensed for a sidewalk café;
         c.   No sidewalk café shall be located adjacent to a designated bus
stop;
         d.   No sidewalk café shall be located within fifteen feet (15') of
any street corner, or twenty five feet (25') of a street corner if the
intersection is not controlled by a traffic-control device at each direction of
travel, as measured from the intersection of the curb line;
         e.   The sidewalk on which the sidewalk café is to be located must
have a minimum width of twelve feet (12');
         f.   No sidewalk café shall reduce the paved pedestrianway to less
than five feet (5');
         g.   The sidewalk café, with the exception of the entranceway thereto
which shall be no larger than six feet (6') in width, shall be separated from
the sidewalk and pedestrian traffic by a wrought iron fence or other approved
divider of at least three feet (3') but no greater than four feet (4') in
height on all sides;
         h.   The sidewalk café shall be situated on the sidewalk nearest the
licensed premises, and shall leave that portion of the sidewalk closest to the
street unobstructed; and
         i.   Tables and seats proposed should be heavy enough to withstand
significant wind gusts.
   B.   Bond: A bond issued by an insurance company authorized to do business
in the State of Illinois in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
with the City's name as obligee, conditioned for the faithful performance of
the provisions of this Code.
   C.   Liability Insurance:
      1.   Proof of commercial public liability insurance in the amount of
three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per person, five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence, and twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) in property damage, and the City shall be named an additional
insured on a primary and noncontributory basis with respect to claims.
      2.   The applicant shall also provide a waiver of subrogation on the
liability policy in favor of the City.
      3.   Liability coverage should be written by a carrier licensed to do
business in Illinois and have an AM Best's rating of A-VII or better. Coverages
shall be written on an occurrence basis. Claims- made coverage is not
acceptable.
      4.   The applicant shall, upon the request of the City, furnish said
insurance policy or certificates evidencing coverage, which policy or
certificates shall provide that the insurance coverage shall not be reduced,
canceled, or allowed to expire without at least thirty (30) days’ written
notice to City.
      5.   Failure to provide evidence of insurance in no way will be deemed a
waiver of the insurance requirements.
   D.   License Fee: The annual sidewalk café business license fee.
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
9-2A-3: TERM OF LICENSE:
A sidewalk café business license shall only be valid from May-October of the
calendar year.
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
9-2A-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual license fee for a sidewalk café business license shall be seventy
five dollars ($75.00).
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
9-2A-5: CONDITIONS FOR OPERATION:
   A.   Sidewalk cafes shall be closed no later than nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.,
Sunday through Thursday, and no later than eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., Friday
and Saturday.
   B.   No live entertainment or amplified sound or music shall be permitted in
a sidewalk café.
   C.   No smoking shall be permitted in or within five feet (5') of a sidewalk
café.
   D.   The sale, delivery, or consumption of alcoholic liquor in a sidewalk
café is prohibited in the absence of a Class S liquor license.
   E.   Any sidewalk café being operated on the side of the building located on
a corner lot shall be accessible from a side door of the licensed premises
only.
   F.   Licensees shall be responsible for the cleanliness of the sidewalk
within fifty feet (50') of the approved location.
   G.   Licensees shall stack tables and chairs together and secure them with a
lock at the end of each day’s operation.
   H.   Licensees shall sweep and remove any garbage or debris from the
sidewalk café at the end of each day's operation and shall also hose the area
of the sidewalk upon which the sidewalk café is located.
   I.   Sweeping or placement of garbage, debris, or other materials into the
street, storm sewers or any adjacent paved pedestrianway is prohibited.
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
9-2A-6: PENALTY:
Any person found to be in violation of this article shall be fined not less
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for each offense. For purposes of this chapter, each violation or
day a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
9-2A-7: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
Citations issued for violating this article may be administered through title
1, chapter 4, article A of this Code.
(Ord. 2513, 7-24-2018)
CHAPTER 3: DRIVEWAYS
Section
9-3-1: Construction Regulations
9-3-2: Driveway Crossings; Presence Of Utility Appurtenances
9-3-3: Maintenance And Repairs
9-3-4: Penalty
9-3-1: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Bond Required: The contractor or person proposing to construct a
driveway shall file with the City Clerk, on a form furnished by the City and
approved by the City Attorney, a penal bond in the sum of two thousand dollars
($2,000.00) with good and sufficient surety thereon, conditioned that the
makers shall save harmless, defend and indemnify the City against or on account
of accidents, damages or claims arising out of or during the construction of
any driveway laid by the contractor. All such bonds shall be continuing until
terminated by notice in writing given thirty (30) days in advance, but only
after the completion of the proposed work.
   B.   Supervision: All such work shall be done under the jurisdiction of the
Public Works Director and in accordance with the ordinances of the City; and
shall be inspected upon completion by the Director.
   C.   Specifications: All plans and specifications must conform to the
following minimum requirements:
      1.   Driveways for other than residential or dwelling house use shall be
constructed of Portland cement concrete at least eight inches (8") in
thickness. Concrete shall be as specified by ordinance for sidewalks and in
accordance with sketches on file in the office of the City Engineer at all
times.
      2.   Driveways for residential or dwelling house use shall be constructed
in a manner and of a material equal at least to that existing for the paving in
the public street adjacent thereto; except, that where concrete pavement exists
in the public street and bituminous surface is desired for the driveway, such
surface shall be permitted, provided it shall have a minimum depth of two
inches (2") without any loose material on top and a base of water-bound macadam
at least six inches (6") thick; and provided, that a Portland cement concrete
apron not less than three feet (3') in width be constructed between the
existing concrete pavement and the proposed bituminous driveway surfaces.
      3.   Where a driveway of any kind of material is constructed across the
sidewalk space, it shall conform to the sidewalk grade as established by the
City Engineer.
      4.   a.   Where a driveway of any kind of material is constructed across
an existing sidewalk, said sidewalk shall be removed and replaced with Portland
cement concrete for the full width of the driveway and for a distance of at
least twelve inches (12") on both sides of the driveway. This portion shall be
not less than six inches (6") in thickness or the thickness of the driveway,
whichever is greater, and constructed in accordance with sketches on file in
the offices of the City.
         b.   Driveways across sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete or of
such other materials as may be approved by the City Council.
      5.   Macadam, gravel, cinder and other types of driveways, where
permitted herein, shall be not less than eight inches (8") thick, compacted
depth.
      6.   Where paving in the public street is of concrete and a concrete
driveway is constructed, a one inch (1") bituminous pre-molded expansion joint
with load transmission unit shall be placed approximately three feet (3') from
the edge of the concrete paving and normal to the centerline of the driveway.
      7.   The width of the driveways for other than residential or dwelling
house shall not exceed thirty-six feet (36') at the outer or street edge of the
sidewalk. Where two (2) or more adjoining driveways are provided for the same
property, a safety island of not less than ten feet (10') at the outer or
street side of the sidewalk shall be provided. Not more than two (2) such
driveways shall be allowed to any one owner for any one piece of property on
any one street for each one hundred feet (100') of continuous frontage thereof.
      8.   The width of the driveways for residential or dwelling house shall
be not less than nine feet (9') nor more than thirty feet (30') at the outer or
street edge of the sidewalk.
      9.   The width of the driveway opening at the curb line shall not exceed
the width of the driveway at the outer or street edge of the sidewalk, plus:
         a.   Ten feet (10') for residential or dwelling house properties
consisting of individual flares on each side not to exceed five feet (5'); or
         b.   Twenty feet (20') for properties other than residential or
dwelling houses consisting of individual flares on each side not to exceed ten
feet (10'). Flares shall be constructed and designed for a gradual and
consistent expanse from the outer or street edge of the sidewalk to the curb
line.
      10.   All driveways shall be so graded between the gutter and the
sidewalk that it will not be necessary to change the established grade of
either and will not elevate or depress any portion of either unless the
sidewalk cross-slope exceeds two (2%) percent. If the sidewalk cross-slope
exceeds two (2%) percent, the sidewalk shall be removed and reinstalled for the
full width of the driveway and a minimum of five (5') feet on each side of the
driveway with a maximum cross-slope of two (2%) percent. No part of the
driveway shall extend beyond the curb line in such a manner as to change the
grade of the gutter or obstruct the free flow of water in the gutter. Where
elevations or depressions are necessary in the parkway strip between the curb
and walk, the parkway shall be graded on both sides of the driveway to a
distance sufficient to create a gradual ascent or descent. At no time shall the
gradient exceed one foot (1') vertical to ten feet (10') horizontal.
      11.   Combined curb and gutter and separate curbing shall be entirely
removed for the full width of the driveway opening at the curb line. If an
existing joint in the curb is within five feet (5') of the end of the driveway
opening, remove the existing curbing to the joint, otherwise cut the combined
curb and gutter or separate curbing, making a neat edge truly at right angles
to the edge of the pavement and truly ve1tical. Integral curbing, which is that
type placed with the pavement and molded as an integral part of it, must be
removed for the full depth from the top of the curb to the bottom of the
pavement. The edge must be cut as above described. No combined curb and gutter,
straight curb or integral curb shall be removed within five feet (5') of a
public crosswalk.
(1980 Code §§ 45-81, 45-83, and 45-84; amd. 2019 Code; Ord. 2630, 11-23-2021;
Ord. 2691, 10-24-2023)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
13-5-8 of this Code; see section
12-3-4 of this Code for permit requirements
9-3-2: DRIVEWAY CROSSINGS; PRESENCE OF UTILITY APPURTENANCES:
   A.   Where driveways cross open ditches in the parkways, culverts shall be
installed. Said culverts shall be of such size and shall be constructed of such
material as determined by the Public Works Committee, depending on the
conditions existing. In no instance shall the size of opening be less than that
obtained by a twelve inch (12") diameter pipe. The length of culvert shall be
determined by the following method: For ditch depth of two feet (2') or less,
the culvert shall extend not less than five feet (5') beyond both edges of the
driveway where it crosses the ditch. For each additional foot depth of ditch,
add two feet (2') to the above figure; except, that no culvert shall be less
than twenty feet (20') long; and except, that where headwalls are constructed
at the ends of the culvert, the length shall be as determined by the Public
Works Committee.
   B.   Where existing meter pits are in the area of a proposed driveway, the
existing cast iron top shall be removed and turned in to the Water Department.
A heavier cover shall be furnished and set by the Water Department, and the
additional cost thereof shall be paid by the contractor.
   C.   Where an existing catch basin is in the area of the proposed driveway,
the tops shall be removed and replaced with a manhole top with perforated lid.
Said top shall be set by the Public Works Department, and the additional cost
thereof shall be paid by the contractor.
(1980 Code § 45-83)
9-3-3: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS:
   A.   All driveways constructed or reconstructed over, across or upon any
public street or public parkway in the City shall be kept and maintained at all
times in accordance with the provisions hereof by the persons so constructing,
reconstructing or using the same as an adjunct or appurtenance to lands or
properties immediately adjacent thereto.
(1980 Code § 45-83)
   B.   It shall be the duty of every person maintaining a driveway to keep the
same in good repair where it crosses the sidewalk and free from obstruction and
openings.
(1980 Code § 45-85)
9-3-4: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code § 45-90)
CHAPTER 4: CONSTRUCTION OF FACILITIES IN THE PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY
Section
9-4-1: Purpose; Scope; Interpretation
9-4-2: Definitions
9-4-3: Registration Required; Annual Recurring Rate For Wireless Provides
9-4-4: Permit Requirements
9-4-5: Insurance; Indemnity; Security
9-4-6: Collocation Of Small Wireless Facilities
9-4-7: Change Of Ownership, Identity Or Legal Status
9-4-8: General Construction Standards
9-4-9: Traffic Control
9-4-10: Location Of Facilities
9-4-11: Construction Methods And Materials
9-4-12: Vegetation Control
9-4-13: Removal, Relocation Or Modifications Of Facilities
9-4-14: Cleanup And Restoration
9-4-15: Maintenance And Repairs
9-4-16: Variances
9-4-17: Penalties
9-4-1: PURPOSE; SCOPE; INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and
procedures for constructing facilities in the rights-of-way within the City so
as to:
      1.   Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys,
parkways and other public ways and places;
      2.   Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other
conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic;
      3.   Prevent interference with the facilities and operations of the
City’s utilities and of other utilities lawfully located in rights-of-way or
public property;
      4.   Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees,
from the installation of facilities;
      5.   Protect against increased stormwater runoff due to structures and
materials that increase impermeable surfaces;
      6.   Preserve the character of the neighborhoods in which facilities are
installed;
      7.   Preserve open space, particularly the tree-lined parkways that
characterize the City's residential neighborhoods;
      8.   Prevent visual blight from the proliferation of facilities in the
rights-of-way; and
      9.   Assure the continued safe use and enjoyment of private properties
adjacent to utility facilities locations.
   B.   Scope: This chapter applies to all facilities on, over, above, along,
upon, under, across, or within the rights-of-way within the City, unless
otherwise exempted pursuant to a franchise, license, or similar agreement.
   C.   Franchises, Licenses Or Similar Agreements:
      1.   The City may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license,
or similar agreement for the privilege of locating their facilities on, over,
above, along, upon, under, across, or within a right-of- way. Utilities or
wireless providers that are not required by law to enter into such an agreement
may request that the City enter into such an agreement.
      2.   In the event that a utility other than a telecommunications provider
has a franchise, license, or similar agreement with the City, such franchise,
license, or similar agreement shall govern and control during its term.
      3.   In the event of any conflict with, or inconsistency between, the
provisions of this chapter and the provisions of any franchise, license, or
similar agreement between the City and any telecommunications provider, the
provisions of such franchise, license, or similar agreement shall govern and
control during the term.
      4.   Existing agreements between the City and wireless providers that
relate to the collocation of small wireless facilities in the right-of-way,
including the collocation of small wireless facilities on City utility poles,
that are in effect on June 1, 2018, remain in effect for all small wireless
facilities collocated on the City's utility poles pursuant to applications
submitted to the City before June 1, 2018, subject to applicable termination
provisions contained therein. Agreements entered into after June 1, 2018, shall
comply with this chapter. A wireless provider that has an existing agreement
with the City on the effective date of the Small Wireless Facilities Deployment
Act, P.A. 100-0585, may accept the rates, fees and terms that the City has
currently adopted for the collocation of small wireless facilities or the
installation of new utility poles for the collocation of small wireless
facilities that are the subject of an application submitted two (2) or more
years after the effective date of the act by notifying the City that it opts to
accept such rates, fees and terms. The existing agreement remains in effect,
subject to applicable termination provisions, for the small wireless facilities
the wireless provider has collocated on the City's utility poles pursuant to
applications submitted to the City before the wireless provider provides such
notice and exercises its option under this subsection C4.
   D.   Sound Engineering Judgment: The City shall use sound engineering
judgment when administering this chapter, and may vary the standards,
conditions, and requirements provided herein when appropriate under the
circumstances.
(Ord. 2516, 7-24-2018)
9-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the
words and terms listed below shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section. Any term not defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed
to it in 92 Illinois Administrative Code section 530.30.
AASHTO: The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials.
ANSI: The American National Standards Institute.
ASTM: The American Society for Testing and Materials.
ANTENNA: Communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic
radio frequency signals used in the provision of wireless services.
APPLICABLE CODES: The International Building, Fire, Electrical, Plumbing or
Mechanical Code, adopted by a recognized national code organization, or local
amendments to those Codes, including the National Electric Safety Code.
APPLICANT: A person applying for a permit under this chapter.
BACKFILL: The methods or materials for replacing excavated material in a trench
or pit.
BORE OR BORING: To excavate an underground cylindrical cavity for the insertion
of a pipe or electrical conductor.
CABLE OPERATOR: Shall be given the meaning ascribed in 47 USC 522(5).
CABLE SERVICE: Shall be given the meaning ascribed in 47 USC 522(6).
CABLE SYSTEM: Shall be given the meaning ascribed in 47 USC 522(7).
CARRIER PIPE: Any pipe enclosing a liquid, gas or slurry to be transported.
CASING: A structural protective enclosure for transmittal devices such as:
carrier pipes, electrical conductors, and fiber optic devices.
CITY: The City of Watseka.
CLEAR ZONE: The total roadside border area, starting at the edge of the
pavement, available for safe use by errant vehicles. This area may consist of a
shoulder, a recoverable slope, a nonrecoverable slope, and a clear runout area.
The desired width is dependent upon the traffic volumes and speeds, and on the
roadside geometry. Distances are specified in the AASHTO Roadside Design Guide.
COATING: The protective wrapping or mastic cover applied to buried pipe for
protection against external corrosion.
CODE: The City of Watseka City Code.
COLLOCATE OR COLLOCATION: To install, mount, maintain, modify, operate or
replace wireless facilities on or adjacent to a wireless support structure or
utility pole.
COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE: “Cable service”, as defined in 47 USC 522(6), as
amended; “information service”, as defined in 47 USC 153(24), as amended;
"mobile service", as defined in 47 USC 153(53), as amended; or wireless service
other than mobile service.
COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE PROVIDER: A “cable operator”, as defined in 47 USC 522
(5), as amended; a “provider of information service”, as defined in 47 USC 153
(24), as amended; or a wireless provider.
CONDUCTOR: Any wire carrying electrical current.
CONDUIT: A casing or encasement for wires or cables.
CONSTRUCTION OR CONSTRUCT: The installation, repair, maintenance, placement,
alteration, enlargement, demolition, modification, or abandonment in place, of
facilities.
COVER: The depth of earth or backfill over buried utility pipe or conductor.
CROSSING FACILITY: A facility that crosses one or more right-of-way lines of a
right-of-way.
DISRUPT THE RIGHT-OF-WAY: Any work that obstructs the right-of-way or causes a
material adverse effect on the use of the right-of-way for its intended use.
