10-3M-2: RECOVERY OF COSTS INCURRED:
   A.   Generally: Any person or user violating any of the provisions of this
chapter, or who causes damage to or impairs the POTW is liable to the City for
all expenses, costs, losses and damages caused directly or indirectly by such
violation. The City may invoice the costs and expenses, including, but not
limited to, sampling and analyses associated with the investigation, costs and
expenses of mitigating impact to the POTW, costs and expenses of preparing the
administrative enforcement actions such as notices and orders; investigative
and/or correction actions, and review of response(s) from the user. The City
shall invoice the user for the costs and expenses incurred by the City for any
and all cleaning, repair, replacement or other investigative and/or corrective
action(s) as a response to the violation. Any user that does not pay to the
City all such assessed costs and expenses shall constitute a violation of this
chapter enforceable under the provisions of article L of this chapter.
   B.   Food Service Establishments (FSEs):
      1.   Grease Disposal Mitigation Fee:
         a.   An FSE that operates without a grease interceptor may be required
to pay an annual grease disposal mitigation fee to equitably cover the costs of
increased maintenance of the POTW as a result of the FSE's inability to
adequately remove FOG from its wastewater discharge. This subsection B1a shall
not be interpreted to allow the new construction of an FSE, or existing FSE
undergoing remodeling, to operate without an approved grease interceptor.
         b.   The grease disposal mitigation fee is be based on the estimated
annual increased cost of maintaining the sewer system for inspection and
removal of FOG and other viscous or solidifying agents attributable to the FSE
resulting from the lack of a grease interceptor or in the case a grease
interceptor or alternate grease control device exists but has been determined
to be inadequate.
      2.   Sewer System Overflows; Public Nuisance; Abatement And Cleanup
Costs: Notwithstanding the waiver of grease interceptor installation for
existing FSE established in section
10-3D-5 of this chapter, an FSE found to have contributed to a sewer blockage,
sewer system overflow (SSO) or any public sewer interference resulting from the
discharge of wastewater or waste containing FOG may be subject to costs and
expenses incurred by the City. SSOs cause threats and injuries to public
health, safety, and welfare of life and property and are hereby declared public
nuisances. Building sewer failures and SSOs caused by FSE alone or collectively
are the responsibility of the private property owner or FSE, and the individual
(s) as a responsible officer or owner of the FSE. If the City must act
immediately to contain and clean up an SSO caused by blockage of a building
sewer or public sewer, or at the request of the property owner or operator of
the FSE, or because of the failure of the property owner or FSE to abate the
condition causing immediate threat of injury to the health, safety, welfare, or
property of the public, the City's costs and expenses of such abatement shall
be entirely borne by the property owner or operator of the FSE, and the
individual(s) as a responsible officer or owner of the FSE(s), and shall
constitute a debt to the City and become due and payable upon the City's
request for reimbursement of such costs and expenses.
   C.   Lien Provisions:
      1.   Notice Of Lien:
         a.   If any person refuses to remedy a violation of the provisions of
this section and said violation is remedied by the City, a notice of lien for
the cost and expenses incurred shall be recorded in the following manner: The
City, or the person performing the service by authority of the City, may file
notice of lien in the Office of the County Recorder of Deeds.
         b.   The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting
forth:
            (1)   A description of the real estate involved sufficient for
identification;
            (2)   An amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred
or payable for the service; and
            (3)   The date or dates when the expense was incurred.
         c.   The notice of lien shall be filed within sixty (60) days after
the cost and expense is incurred.
      2.   Release Of Lien: If payment of the cost and expense is made after
notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the City, and the
release filed in the same manner as the notice of lien.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3M-3: ADMINISTRATIVE FINES:
   A.   When the Pretreatment Coordinator finds that a user has violated, or
continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual or general
wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
pretreatment standard or requirement, the Coordinator may fine such user in an
amount not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Such fines shall be
assessed on a per violation, per day basis. In the case of monthly or other
long-term average discharge limits, fines shall be assessed for each day during
the period of violation.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Unpaid charges, fines, and penalties shall, after fifteen (15) calendar
days, be assessed an additional penalty of ten percent (10%) of the unpaid
balance. If the charges for such services are not paid within forty five (45)
days after the rendition of the bill for such services, such services shall be
discontinued without further notice and shall not be reinstated until all
claims are settled. A one hundred dollar ($100.00) disconnect and reconnect fee
shall be applied to the unpaid balance. A lien against the user’s property
shall be sought for unpaid charges, fines and penalties.
   C.   Users desiring reconsideration of such fines must file a written
request for the Coordinator to reconsider the fine along with full payment of
the fine amount within thirty (30) calendar days of being notified of the fine.
Where a request has merit, the Coordinator may convene a hearing on the matter.
In the event the user’s appeal is successful, the payment, together with any
interest accruing thereto, shall be returned to the user.
   D.   Issuance of an administrative fine shall not be a bar against, or a
prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3M-4: INJUNCTIVE RELIEF:
When the Coordinator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate,
any provision of this chapter, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued
hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the City Attorney
may petition the Circuit Court of Iroquois County for the issuance of a
temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels
the specific performance of the wastewater discharge permit, order, or other
requirement imposed by this chapter on activities of the user. The Coordinator
may also seek such environmental remediation. A petition for injunctive relief
shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action
against a user.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3M-5: CIVIL PENALTIES:
   A.   A user who has violated or continues to violate any provision of this
chapter, an individual or general wastewater discharge permit, or order issued
hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall be liable to
the City for a maximum civil penalty of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
violation, per day. In the case of a monthly or other long-term average
discharge limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of the
violation.
   B.   The Coordinator may recover costs, including, but not limited to,
filing fees, witness fees, attorney fees, court costs, and other expenses
associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring
expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred by the City.
   C.   In determining the amount of fines and/or civil liability, the court or
judicial administrator shall take into account all relevant circumstances,
including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the
magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through
the user's violation, corrective actions by the user, the compliance history of
the user, and any other factor as justice requires.
   D.   Issuing a notice of local ordinance violation or the filing of a suit
for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking
any other action against a user.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3M-6: REMEDIES NONEXCLUSIVE:
The remedies provided in this article are not exclusive. The Coordinator may
take any or all or any combination of these actions against a noncompliant
user. Enforcement of pretreatment violations will generally be in accordance
with the City’s enforcement response plan. However, the Coordinator may take
other action against any user when the circumstances warrant. Further, the
Coordinator is empowered to take more than one enforcement action against any
noncompliant user.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
ARTICLE N: SUPPLEMENTAL ENFORCEMENT ACTION
Section
10-3N-1: Performance Bond Required
10-3N-2: Liability Insurance Required
10-3N-3: Failure To Pay For Outstanding Fees And Penalties
10-3N-4: Water Supply Severance; Recommencement Of Service
10-3N-5: Public Nuisance Declared
10-3N-6: Contractor Violations
10-3N-1: PERFORMANCE BOND REQUIRED:
The Pretreatment Coordinator may decline to issue or reissue an individual or
general wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with
any provision of this chapter, a previous individual or general wastewater
discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard
or requirement, unless such user first files a satisfactory bond, payable to
the City, in a sum not to exceed a value determined by the Coordinator to be
necessary to achieve consistent compliance.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3N-2: LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
The Coordinator may decline to issue or reissue an individual or general
wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with any
provision of this chapter, a previous individual or general wastewater
discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard
or requirement, unless the user first submits proof that it has obtained
financial assurances sufficient to restore or repair damage to the POTW caused
by the user's discharge of wastewater.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3N-3: FAILURE TO PAY FOR OUTSTANDING FEES AND PENALTIES:
The Coordinator may decline to issue or reissue an individual or general
wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to pay any outstanding
fees, fines or penalties incurred as a result of any provision of this chapter,
a previous individual or general wastewater discharge permit, or order issued
hereunder.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3N-4: WATER SUPPLY SEVERANCE; RECOMMENCEMENT OF SERVICE:
Whenever a user has violated or continues to violate any provision of this
chapter, an individual or general wastewater discharge permit, or order issued
hereunder, or any pretreatment standard or requirement, water service to the
user may be severed. Water service will recommence, at the user’s expense, only
after the user has satisfactorily demonstrated its ability to comply with the
violation(s) giving rise to the termination of the service.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3N-5: PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED:
A violation of any provision of this chapter, an individual or general
wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
pretreatment standard or requirement, is hereby declared a public nuisance and
shall be corrected or abated as directed by the Coordinator. Any person(s)
creating a public nuisance shall be subject to the provisions governing such
nuisances, including reimbursing the City for any costs incurred in removing,
abating, or remedying the nuisance.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3N-6: CONTRACTOR VIOLATIONS:
Users which have not achieved compliance with applicable pretreatment standards
and requirements are hereby declared to be nonresponsible users and therefore
are not eligible to receive a contractual award for the sale of goods or
services to the City. Existing contracts for the sale of goods or services to
the City held by a user found to be in significant noncompliance with
pretreatment standards or requirements may be terminated at the discretion of
the Coordinator.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
ARTICLE O: AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES TO DISCHARGE VIOLATIONS
Section
10-3O-1: Upsets
10-3O-2: Prohibited Discharge Standards
10-3O-3: Bypasses
10-3O-1: UPSETS:
   A.   For the purposes of this section, UPSET means an exceptional incident
in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical
pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the
user. An "upset" does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by
operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate
treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper
operation.
   B.   An UPSET shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action brought
for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards if the requirements
of subsection C of this section are met.
   C.   A user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset shall
demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs, or other
relevant evidence that:
      1.   An upset occurred and the user can identify the cause(s) of the
upset;
      2.   The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and
workerlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance
procedures; and
      3.   The user has submitted the following information to the Pretreatment
Coordinator within twenty four (24) hours of becoming aware of the upset (if
this information is provided orally, a written report must be provided within
five (5) workdays):
         a.   A description of the indirect discharge and cause of
noncompliance;
         b.   The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times or,
if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to
continue; and
         c.   Steps being taken and/or planned to reduce, eliminate, and
prevent recurrence of the noncompliance.
   D.   In any enforcement proceeding, the user seeking to establish the
occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof.
   E.   Users will have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any
claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with
categorical pretreatment standards.
   F.   Users shall control production of all discharges to the extent
necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon
reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is
restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement
applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power
of the treatment facility is reduced, lost, or fails.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3O-2: PROHIBITED DISCHARGE STANDARDS:
A user shall have an affirmative defense to an enforcement action brought
against it for noncompliance with the general prohibitions in subsections
10-3F-2A1 and A2 of this chapter or the specific prohibitions in subsection
10-3F-2A3 of this chapter if it can prove that it did not know, or have reason
to know, that its discharge, alone or in conjunction with discharges from other
sources, would cause pass through or interference or that either:
   A.   A local limit exists for each pollutant discharged and the user was in
compliance with each limit directly prior to and during the pass through or
interference; or
   B.   No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change substantially
in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when the City was
regularly in compliance with its NPDES permit, and in the case of interference,
was in compliance with applicable biosolids use or disposal requirements.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3O-3: BYPASSES:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
   BYPASS: The intentional diversion of wastewater from any portion of a user's
treatment facility.
SEVERE PROPERTY DAMAGE: Substantial physical damage to property, damage to the
treatment facilities which causes them to become inoperable, or substantial and
permanent loss of natural resources which can reasonably be expected to occur
in the absence of a bypass. SEVERE PROPERTY DAMAGE does not mean economic loss
caused by delays in production.
   B.   Bypasses Permitted: A user may allow any bypass to occur which does not
cause pretreatment standards or requirements to be violated, but only if it
also is for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses
are not subject to the provisions of subsections C and D of this section.
   C.   Notice Of Bypass:
      1.   Anticipated: If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it
shall submit prior notice to the Coordinator at least ten (10) workdays before
the date of the bypass, if possible.
      2.   Unanticipated: A user shall submit oral notice to the Coordinator of
an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable pretreatment standards within
twenty four (24) hours from the time it becomes aware of the bypass. A written
submission shall also be provided within five (5) workdays of the time the user
becomes aware of the bypass. The written submission shall contain a description
of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates
and times, and, if the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it
is expected to continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and
prevent reoccurrence of the bypass. The Coordinator may waive the written
report on a case-by-case basis if the oral report has been received within
twenty four (24) hours.
   D.   City Actions:
      1.   Bypass is prohibited, and the Coordinator may take an enforcement
action against a user for a bypass, unless:
         a.   The bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal
injury, or severe property damage;
         b.   There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the
use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or
maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not
satisfied if adequate backup equipment should have been installed, in the
exercise of reasonable engineering judgment, to prevent a bypass which occurred
during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance; and
         c.   The user submitted notices as required under subsection C of this
section.
      2.   The Coordinator may approve an anticipated bypass after considering
its adverse effects, if the Coordinator determines that it will meet the three
(3) conditions listed in subsection D1 of this section.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
ARTICLE P: USER AND SURCHARGE INDUSTRIAL WASTE COST RECOVERY
Section
10-3P-1: User And Surcharge Rates
10-3P-2: Bills For Service; Payments
10-3P-3: Disposition Of Revenues
10-3P-4: Accounting
10-3P-5: Notice Of Rates
10-3P-6: Access To Records
10-3P-7: Responsibilities Of City Employees
10-3P-8: Penalty
10-3P-1: USER AND SURCHARGE RATES:
   A.   There has heretofore been and continues to be a minimum charge and
basic user rate for the use and service supplied by the wastewater works of the
City. Such rate shall apply as established and scheduled from time to time by
the Corporate Authorities of the City.
   B.   The user rate is set forth in the section
10-2-2 of this title (see also subsections
10-4-2B and 10-4-3B of this title). The City may issue default rates for
defined classes of users. The basic user rate shall be based on water usage as
recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters for wastes having a 5-day, twenty
degree Celsius (20°C) BOD of two hundred one milligrams per liter (201 mg/L)
and an SS concentration of two hundred thirty nine milligrams per liter (239
mg/L) (see also subsections
10-2-1C and 10-4A-1C1 of this title).
   C.   For users that cannot be defined in a default class, the surcharge rate
is based on the following three (3) components: volume discharged, surcharged
BOD, and surcharged TSS. The Pretreatment Coordinator may choose to not bill
users for surchargeable discharges if the Coordinator estimates that issuing
the surcharge would be cost prohibitive or have minimal benefit.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-2: BILLS FOR SERVICE; PAYMENTS:
   A.   Monthly Payments; Liability Of User: The rates or charges for service
under this article shall be payable monthly. The user of the service shall be
liable to pay for the service to such premises, and the service is furnished to
the premises by the City only upon the condition that the user of the service
is liable therefor to the City.
   B.   Rendition Of Bills; Due Date: Bills for sewer service shall be sent out
by the City on the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the
service is billed. All sewer bills are due and payable fifteen (15) calendar
days after issuance.
   C.   Delinquent Payments:
      1.   An invoice not paid by the due date and which has an outstanding
balance of at least the minimum shown on the invoice shall have a late fee
assessed of ten percent (10%) of the outstanding balance.
      2.   If the charges for the services under this chapter with a balance of
any balance after 30 days are not paid within ninety (90) calendar days after
the issuance of the bill for such services, the City may proceed with
termination of such services shall be discontinued without further notice and
shall not be reinstated until all claims are settled.
   D.   Collection Agencies May Collect; City Fee: In addition to any other
method of collection as herein provided or as provided by laws, the City may
turn delinquent users over to collection agencies. Any user being turned over
to such an agency for collection shall first be sent a notice of the City
intent to do so. Any outstanding water invoices will also be added to the sewer
use charges being turned over to the collection agency. The City may impose a
collection agent turnover fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) on any customer
so turned over to such an agency, If so, the notice must state to the customer
the amount of such fee.
   E.   Lien Provisions:
      1.   Statement Of Lien Claim; Notice Requirements:
         a.   Whenever a bill for a sewer service having any balance remains
unpaid for thirty (30) calendar days for monthly service after it has been
issued, the City Collector shall file with the Recorder of Deeds of Iroquois
County, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal
description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill and a notice
that the City claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges
subsequent to the period covered by the bill.
         b.   If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises
and the City Secretary has notice of this condition, a notice shall be mailed
to the owner of the premises, if known to the Secretary, whenever such bill
remains unpaid for one hundred five (105) calendar days after it has been
issued.
         c.   The failure of the City Secretary to record such lien or to mail
such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect
the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned in subsection E2
of this section.
      2.   Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to lien for unpaid charges
under this chapter shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds
of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting the costs, as
is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by
bill in equity in the name of the City. The City Attorney is hereby authorized
and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the City of Watseka
in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against the property for
which the bill has remained unpaid one hundred five (105) calendar days in the
case of a quarterly bill after it has been issued.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-3: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
   A.   All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the POTW shall be
deposited in the sewerage account of the Sewerage Fund. All such revenues and
monies shall be held by the City Treasurer separate and apart from his private
funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the City, and all of said
sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the City Financial
Clerk not more than ten (10) workdays after receipt of the same, or at such
more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the Chair of
the Finance, Legal, Audit and Insurance Committee and City Council.
   B.   The City Financial Clerk shall receive all such revenues from the
sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of
such system as the same may be delivered to him or her and deposit the same in
the account of the fund designated as the “Sewerage Fund of the City of
Watseka”. Said Financial Clerk shall administer such fund in every respect in
the manner provided by statute in the Illinois Municipal Code, effective July
1, 1961, as amended.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-4: ACCOUNTING:
   A.   The City Financial Clerk shall establish a proper system of accounts
and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the Sewerage Fund, and at
regular intervals, the Financial Clerk shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewerage system.
   B.   In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit
report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater
facilities, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service
charges under the waste cost recovery system and capital amounts required to be
recovered under the industrial cost recovery system meet these regulations. In
this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall
include the following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for
the current fiscal year;
      2.   Billing data to show total number of gallons billed;
      3.   Number of users connected to the system;
      4.   Number of nonmetered users; and
      5.   A list of users discharging nonresidential wastes and volume and
strength of waste discharged.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-5: NOTICE OF RATES:
A copy of this chapter, properly certified by the City Financial Clerk, shall
be recorded in the Office of Recorder of Deeds of Iroquois County and shall be
deemed notice to all users of the sewerage system of the contents of this
chapter, including the charges of the system by the City on their properties.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-6: ACCESS TO RECORDS:
The IEPA or its authorized representative shall have access to any books,
documents, papers and records of the City which are applicable to the City
system of user charges or industrial cost recovery, for the purpose of making
audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance
with the terms of the special and general conditions to any State grant or
loan.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-7: RESPONSIBILITIES OF CITY EMPLOYEES:
The City Secretary shall maintain the necessary records for determination of
the user share of the cost and shall provide the billing and collection
services as required by this article, and the City Financial Clerk shall be
responsible for the investment and expenditure of all monies collected for
industrial cost recovery in accordance with this article.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013)
10-3P-8: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provisions of this article, for
each offense, shall be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(Ord. 2408, 11-26-2013; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 4: COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM RATES AND CHARGES
Section
10-4-1:    System Continued
10-4-2: Water And Sewer Rates For Commercial Users
10-4-3: Water And Sewer Rates For Residential Users
10-4-4:    Infrastructure Maintenance Fee
10-4-5:    Filling Private Swimming Pools
10-4-6:    Water Or Sewer Service Outside Corporate Limits
10-4-7:    Bills For Service; Delinquencies
10-4-8:    Discontinuance Of Service For Nonpayment
10-4-9:    Refusal Of Service When There Are Delinquent Charges
10-4-10: Lien Provisions
10-4-11: Disposition Of Revenues
10-4-12: Accounting
10-4-1:   SYSTEM CONTINUED:
The combined waterworks and sewerage system, created by ordinance 824, adopted
and passed March 8, 1948, is hereby continued by this chapter and is
incorporated in this chapter by reference.
(1980 Code § 35-1)
10-4-2:   WATER AND SEWER RATES FOR COMMERCIAL USERS:
The rates and charges to commercial users for the use of and for the service
supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be determined by
water meter readings as follows:
   A.   Water Service:
      1.   From May 1, 2024 through April 30, 2025:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00)
per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for commercial users shall
be forty dollars ($40.00) per month for four thousand (4,000) gallons.
      2.   From May 1, 2025 through April 30, 2026:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of ten dollars and
thirty-five cents ($10.35) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for commercial users shall
be forty-one dollars and forty cents ($41.40) per month for four thousand
(4,000) gallons.
      3.   From May 1, 2026 through April 30, 2027:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of ten dollars and
seventy-one cents ($10.71) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for commercial users shall
be forty-two dollars and eighty-four cents ($42.84) per month for four thousand
(4,000) gallons.
      4.   From May 1, 2027 through April 30, 2028:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of eleven dollars and
nine cents ($11.09) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for commercial users shall
be forty-four dollars and thirty-six cents ($44.36) per month for four thousand
(4,000) gallons.
      5.   From May 1, 2028 through April 30, 2029:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of eleven dollars and
forty-seven cents ($11.47) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for commercial users shall
be forty-five dollars and eighty-eight cents ($45.88) per month for four
thousand (4,000) gallons.
   B.   Sewer Service:
      1.   From May 1, 2024 through April 30, 2025:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of twelve dollars and
sixteen cents ($12.16) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for commercial users shall
be forty-eight dollars and sixty-four cents ($48.64) per month for four
thousand (4,000) gallons.
      2.   From May 1, 2025 through April 30, 2026:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of twelve dollars and
fifty-nine cents ($12.59) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for commercial users shall
be fifty dollars and thirty-six cents ($50.36) per month for four thousand
(4,000) gallons.
      3.   From May 1, 2026 through April 30, 2027:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of thirteen dollars and
three cents ($13.03) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for commercial users shall
be fifty-two dollars and twelve cents ($52.12) per month for four thousand
(4,000) gallons.
      4.   From May 1, 2027 through April 30, 2028:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of thirteen dollars and
forty-eight cents ($13.48) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for commercial users shall
be fifty-three dollars and ninety-two cents ($53.92) per month for four
thousand (4,000) gallons.
      5.   From May 1, 2028 through April 30, 2029:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of thirteen dollars and
ninety-six cents ($13.96) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for commercial users shall
be fifty-five dollars and eighty-four cents ($55.84) per month for four
thousand (4,000) gallons.
      6.   The rate of sewer service for commercial users that shall have their
own source of water in whole or in part shall be a minimum charge set forth
above, as applicable, except where more than four thousand (4,000) gallons of
water or effluent is discharged into the sewer system per month, the charge for
sewer service only shall be based upon the same gallonage charge as other users
of the sewer service shall pay. Sewer service to users for water-cooled air-
conditioning units and water-cooled condensers, who shall have their own source
of water in whole or in part, shall be the minimum charge set forth above.
(Ord. 2485, 9-26-2017; amd. Ord. 2498A, 2-5-2018; Ord 2532, 2-26-2019; Ord.
2548, 10-24-2019; Ord. 2707, 2-27-2024)
10-4-3:   WATER AND SEWER RATES FOR RESIDENTIAL USERS:
The rates and charges to residential users for the use of and for the service
supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be determined by
water meter readings as follows:
   A.   Water Service:
      1.   From May 1, 2024 through April 30, 2025:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00)
per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for residential users shall
be twenty dollars ($20.00) per month for two thousand (2,000) gallons.
      2.   From May 1, 2025 through April 30, 2026:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of ten dollars and
thirty-five cents ($10.35) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for residential users shall
be twenty dollars and seventy cents ($20.70) per month for two thousand (2,000)
gallons.
      3.   From May 1, 2026 through April 30, 2027:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of ten dollars and
seventy-one cents ($10.71) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for residential users shall
be twenty-one dollars and forty-two cents ($21.42) per month for two thousand
(2,000) gallons.
      4.   From May 1, 2027 through April 30, 2028:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of eleven dollars and
nine cents ($11.09) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for residential users shall
be twenty-two dollars and eighteen cents ($22.18) per month for two thousand
(2,000) gallons.
      5.   From May 1, 2028 through April 30, 2029:
         a.   For all quantities of water at the rate of eleven dollars and
forty-seven cents ($11.47) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for water service for residential users shall
be twenty-two dollars and ninety-four cents ($22.94) per month for two thousand
(2,000) gallons.
   B.   Sewer Service:
      1.   From May 1, 2024 through April 30, 2025:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of twelve dollars and
sixteen cents ($12.16) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for residential users shall
be twenty-four dollars and thirty-two cents ($24.32) per month for two thousand
(2,000) gallons.
      2.   From May 1, 2025 through April 30, 2026:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of twelve dollars and
fifty-nine cents ($12.59) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for residential users shall
be twenty-five dollars and eighteen cents ($25.18) per month for two thousand
(2,000) gallons.
      3.   From May 1, 2026 through April 30, 2027:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of thirteen dollars and
three cents ($13.03) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for residential users shall
be twenty-six dollars and six cents ($26.06) per month for two thousand (2,000)
gallons.
      4.   From May 1, 2027 through April 30, 2028:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of thirteen dollars and
forty-eight cents ($13.48) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for residential users shall
be twenty-six dollars and ninety-six cents ($26.96) per month for two thousand
(2,000) gallons.
      5.   From May 1, 2028 through April 30, 2029:
         a.   For all quantities of sewer at the rate of thirteen dollars and
ninety-six cents ($13.96) per one thousand (1,000) gallons per month.
         b.   The minimum charge for sewer service for residential users shall
be twenty-seven dollars and ninety-two cents ($27.92) per month for two
thousand (2,000) gallons.
      6.   The rate of sewer service for residential users that shall have
their own source of water in whole or in part shall be a minimum charge set
forth above, as applicable, except where more than two thousand (2,000) gallons
of water or effluent is discharged into the sewer system per month, the charge
for sewer service only shall be based upon the same gallonage charge as other
users of the sewer service shall pay. Sewer service to users for water-cooled
air-conditioning units and water-cooled condensers, who shall have their own
source of water in whole or in part, shall be the minimum charge set forth
above.
(Ord. 2485, 9-26-2017; amd. 2019 Code; Ord 2532, 2-26-2019; Ord. 2548, 10-24-
2019; Ord. 2707, 2-27-2024)
10-4-4:   INFRASTRUCTURE MAINTENANCE FEE:
An infrastructure maintenance fee of five dollars ($5.00) per month shall be
paid by all commercial, industrial, and residential water users, commencing
January 1, 2019, to provide funds for the maintenance, extension, improvement,
and reconstruction of the water supply, water storage, water treatment works,
water infrastructure, and other water improvements.
(Ord. 2527, 12-18-2018)
10-4-5:   FILLING PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS:
   A.   All persons seeking to fill a private swimming pool from a City fire
hydrant shall:
      1.   Contact City Hall to obtain permission and to coordinate obtaining
the water from a fire hydrant with the assistance of a representative of the
City.
      2.   Pay a service fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) to the City of
Watseka, Illinois.
      3.   Pay ten dollars ($10.00) per thousand gallons or part thereof for
all such water obtained.
   B.   Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation
thereof.
(Ord. 2465, 9-27-2016)
10-4-6:   WATER OR SEWER SERVICE OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS:
   A.   No service shall be supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage
system outside the corporate limits of the City, unless each user thereof
outside the corporate limits pays double the rates and charges set forth in
this chapter for users of the services within the corporate limits of the City.
   B.   No new users outside the corporate limits shall be accepted and no
further extensions of service shall be made outside of the corporate limits,
unless the same shall have been approved by the City Council.
(1980 Code § 35-5)
10-4-7:   BILLS FOR SERVICE; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Types Of Payments; Liability For Service: Rates and charges for service
shall be payable monthly, bi-monthly or quarterly as the City Council shall
direct. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the
service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service on such
premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the City, only upon
the condition that the owner of the premises and occupant and user of the
service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the City.
   B.   Rendition Of Bills; Due Date: All bills for service shall be rendered
as of the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is
billed, and shall be payable not later than the close of business on the
fifteenth day of the same month.
   C.   Late Payment Penalties: A penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be added
to all residential billings and a penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be added
to all commercial billings not paid within fifteen (15) days of the date of
billing. An additional penalty of three percent (3%) for residential and one
and one-half percent (11/2%) for commercial billings shall be added to the
cumulative total of such billings for each billing period where such billings
remain unpaid for more than one billing period. When the tenth day of any month
shall be Sunday or a legal holiday, then such bills for service shall be
payable on the next succeeding secular day without any additional penalty.
(1980 Code § 35-6)
10-4-8:   DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE FOR NONPAYMENT:
   A.   The supply may be shut off from any premises for which the water bill,
water tap charge, sewer bill, sewer tap charge, or other water charges or sewer
charges remain unpaid for thirty (30) days after the bill or charge is rendered
or mailed. When shut off, the water supply shall not again be turned on, except
upon the payment of the usual fee for disconnecting service and upon payment of
the usual fee for turning on water (see subsection
10-3M-3B of this title for sewer disconnect and reconnect fee), and upon
payment of all delinquent charges in full. When any service is disconnected
under this section, the procedure outlined in the form on file in the Office of
the City Clerk must be followed.
(1980 Code § 35-7)
   B.   No water supply or sewer service of any user shall be disconnected,
discontinued or shut off by the City until at least thirty (30) days have
elapsed since the billing for supply or service and said service remains
partially or wholly unpaid and until the City Collector has first given a ten
(10) day notice, either by mail or by personal service, to the user of the
intent of the City to discontinue said water service or sewer service, or both,
which notice is on file in the Office of the City Clerk.
(Ord. 2338, 3-22-2011; amd. 2019 Code)
10-4-9:   REFUSAL OF SERVICE WHEN THERE ARE DELINQUENT CHARGES:
Anyone moving from one premises to another premises in the City, owing
delinquent water and/or sewer charges to the City, shall not be entitled to
receive water or sewer service of the City until all the delinquent charges of
the user are paid in full.
(1980 Code § 35-9)
10-4-10:   LIEN PROVISIONS:
Rates and charges for services furnished pursuant to any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be a lien upon the premises, as provided by statute.
   A.   Whenever a bill for service remains unpaid sixty (60) days after it has
been rendered, the City Attorney may file with the Recorder of Deeds of
Iroquois County, Illinois, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall
contain the legal description for the premises served, the amount of the unpaid
bill, and a notice that the City claims a lien for this amount as well as for
all charges for water and sewer services furnished subsequent to the period
covered by the bill.
   B.   If the user or consumer whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the
premises, and the City Collector has notice of this, then notice shall be
mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address be known to the City
Collector, whenever such bills or charges remain unpaid for a period of sixty
(60) days after it has been rendered.
   C.   The failure of the City Collector to record such a lien claim or to
mail such notice, or the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not
affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water or sewer bills as
mentioned in subsection D of this section.
   D.   Upon the filing of the lien, there shall accrue to the City a
delinquency charge in the amount of one hundred seventy five dollars ($175.00),
to cover the costs and expenses of the City in preparing and filing the lien,
which said charge, together with the recording fee, shall be added to the
charges due from the user and/or owner for services furnished the premises on
which the lien is recorded, and shall become a part of the amount for which a
lien is claimed.
(Ord. 2350, 8-23-2011)
   E.   Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges or bills shall be sold
for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to
pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of
statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by suit filed in the name of the
City. The City Attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such
proceedings, in the name of the City, in any court having jurisdiction over
such matters, against any property for which any of the charges or bills has
remained unpaid for sixty (60) days after it has been rendered.
(1980 Code § 35-11)
10-4-11:   DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
   A.   Funds To Collector And Treasurer: All revenues and monies derived from
the operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be held by
the Collector separate and apart from all other funds of the City, and all of
said sums, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the City
Treasurer within ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at such more
frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the City Council.
(1980 Code § 35-12)
   B.   Waterworks And Sewerage Fund: The City Treasurer shall receive all such
revenues from the combined waterworks and sewerage system and all other funds
and monies incident to the operation of such system as the same may be
delivered to him and deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the
“Waterworks and Sewerage Fund” of the City, and the Treasurer shall administer
the fund in every respect in the manner provided in division 139 of article 11
of the Illinois Municipal Code and all other laws thereunto enabling or
amendatory.
(1980 Code § 35-13)
10-4-12:   ACCOUNTING:
The City Collector shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep
proper books, records and accounts in which complete and current entries shall
be made of all transactions relative to the combined waterworks and sewerage
system, and at regular annual intervals, he shall cause to be made an audit by
an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the combined waterworks and sewerage system.
(1980 Code § 35-14)
ARTICLE A: DETERMINATION OF WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES
Section
10-4A-1: Basis For Wastewater Service Charges
10-4A-2: Measurement Of Flow
10-4A-3: Rates And Charges Established
10-4A-4: Computation Of Certain Charges
10-4A-5: Dispute Appeals
10-4A-6: Review And Revision Of Wastewater Service Charge
10-4A-7: Notice Of Rates
10-4A-8: Payment Of Bills
10-4A-9:Disposition Of Revenues
10-4A-10: Accounting
10-4A-11: Access To Records
10-4A-12: Penalty
10-4A-1:   BASIS FOR WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES:
The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the
wastewater facilities of the City shall consist of a basic user charge for
operation and maintenance plus replacement, applicable surcharges and local
capital cost charge composed of a debt service charge and a capital improvement
charge.
   A.   Debt Service Charge: The debt service charge is computed by
apportioning the annual debt service on a cost per one thousand (1,000) gallons
basis.
   B.   Capital Improvement Charge: The capital improvement charge is levied on
all users to provide for capital improvements, extensions or reconstruction of
the sewage treatment works. The capital improvement is computed by apportioning
the annual amount to be accrued as a cost per one thousand (1,000) gallons or
as a fixed charge per month.
   C.   Basic User Charge:
      1.   The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by
water meters and/or sewage meters for wastes having the following normal
domestic concentrations (see also subsections
10-2-1C and
10-3P-1B of this title):
         a.   A five (5) day, twenty degree centigrade (20°) biochemical oxygen
demand (BOD) of two hundred one milligrams per liter (201 mg/L)
         b.   A suspended solids (SS) content of two hundred thirty nine
milligrams per liter (239 mg/L).
      2.   It shall consist of operation and maintenance replacement and shall
be computed as follows:
         a.   Estimate wastewater volume, pounds of SS and pounds of BOD to be
treated.
         b.   Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and
maintain the wastewater facilities including a replacement fund for the year,
for all works categories.
         c.   Proportion the estimated operation, maintenance, and replacement
(OM&R) costs to each user class by volume, suspended solids and BOD.
         d.   Proportion the estimated OM&R costs to wastewater facility
categories by volume, suspended solids and BOD.
         e.   Compute costs per one thousand (1,000) gallons for normal sewage
strength.
         f.   Compute surcharge costs per pound per one thousand (1,000)
gallons in excess of normal sewage strength for BOD and SS.
   D.   Surcharge: A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed
the normal domestic concentrations of BOD (201 mg/L) and SS (239 mg/L). The
surcharge will be based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or
sewage meters for all wastes which exceed the two hundred one milligrams per
liter (201 mg/L) and two hundred thirty nine milligrams per liter (239 mg/L)
concentration for BOD and SS respectively. Subsection
10-4A-4A of this article specifies the procedure to compute a surcharge.
(1980 Code page 216 art. I § 1)
10-4A-2:   MEASUREMENT OF FLOW:
The volume of flow used for computing basic user charges and surcharges shall
be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of one
thousand (1,000) gallons.
   A.   If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any
part, or all, of his water from sources other than the public waterworks
system, all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person
shall install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by
the City for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these
other sources.
   B.   Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by
the City if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water
consumption records.
   C.   Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be
installed, owned, and maintained by the person. Following approval and
installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is canceled,
without the consent of the City.
(1980 Code page 217 art. I § 2)
10-4A-6   RATES AND CHARGES ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Local Capital Cost Charge:
      1.   A debt service charge of sixty five cents ($0.65) per one thousand
(1,000) gallons to each user of the wastewater facility of the City is hereby
established.
      2.   A capital improvement charge will be levied on all users as a charge
of ninety cents ($0.90) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, to provide funds for
extension, improvement of reconstruction of the sewage treatment works and
other sewer improvements.
(1980 Code page 217 art. I § 3)
   B.   Basic User Rate:
      1.   There shall be and there is hereby established a minimum charge and
a basic user rate for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater
facilities of the City of two dollars forty cents ($2.40) per one thousand
(1,000) gallons' usage per month. The basic user rate is calculated upon
charges of debt service of sixty five cents ($0.65) per one thousand (1,000)
gallons, capital improvement charge of ninety cents ($0.90) per one thousand
(1,000) gallons, and eighty five cents ($0.85) for operation, maintenance and
replacement for a total of two dollars forty cents ($2.40) per one thousand
(1,000) gallons.
      2.   a.    All nonmetered residential users of the wastewater facilities
shall pay a minimum flat rate charge of seven dollars fifty cents ($7.50) per
month. The flat rate charge will allow a maximum of two thousand (2,000)
gallons per month.
         b.   In the event use of the wastewater facilities is determined by
the City to be in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month, the City
may require such flat rate user to install metering devices on the water supply
or sewer main to measure the amount of service supplied.
      3.   Metered residential users of the wastewater system shall also be
subject to a flat rate minimum charge in the amount of four dollars eighty
cents ($4.80) per month where the usage does not exceed two thousand (2,000)
gallons per month.
      4.   All nonmetered commercial users of the wastewater facilities shall
pay a minimum flat rate charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month. The flat
rate charge will allow a maximum of four thousand (4,000) gallons per month. In
the event the use of the wastewater facilities is determined by the City to be
in excess of four thousand (4,000) gallons per month, the City may require such
flat rate user to install metering devices on the water supply or a sewer main
to measure the amount of service supplied.
      5.   Commercial and institutional users of the wastewater system shall
also be subject to a minimum monthly fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) where the
metered usage does not exceed four thousand (4,000) gallons per month.
(1980 Code page 217 art. I § 4)
   C.   Surcharge Rates: The rates of surcharges for BOD5 and SS shall be as
follows:
      1.   Per pound of BOD: Fifteen cents ($0.15).
      2.   Per pound of SS: Fourteen cents ($0.14). (1980 Code page 218 art. I
§ 5)
10-4A-4:   COMPUTATION OF CERTAIN CHARGES:
   A.   Surcharge: The concentration of wastes used for computing surcharges
shall be established by waste sampling. Waste sampling shall be performed as
often as may be deemed necessary by the City and shall be binding as a basis
for surcharges.
(1980 Code page 218 art. I § 6)
   B.   Residential Wastewater Service Charge: The wastewater service charge
for residents shall be computed by the following formula:
   CW = CC + CD + CM + (VU-X)CU + CS
   Where:
    CW   =   Amount of service charge ($) per billing period.
   CD   =   Debt service charge (subsection
10-4A-3A1 of this article).
   CC   =   Capital improvement charge (subsection
10-4A-3A2 of this article).
   CM   =   Minimum charge for operation, maintenance, and replacement.
   VU   =   Wastewater volume for the billing period.
   X   =   Allowable consumption in gallons for the minimum charge (subsection
10-4A-3B of this article).
   CU   =   Basic user rate for operation, maintenance and replacement
(subsection 10-4A-3B of this article).
   CS   =   Amount of surcharge (subsections
10-4A-3C and
10-4A-4A).
(1980 Code page 218 art. I § 7)
10-4A-5:   DISPUTE APPEALS:
The method for computation of rates and service charge established for user
charges in sections
10-4A-3 and
10-4A-4 of this article shall be made available to a user within ten (10) days
of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over the method used
or in the computations thereof shall be remedied by the City within thirty (30)
days after notification of a formal written appeal outlining the discrepancies
(1980 Code page 219 art. I § 11)
10-4A-6:   REVIEW AND REVISION OF WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGE:
The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be reviewed not less often
than annually by certified public accountants for the City in their annual
audit report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to
reflect a change in local capital costs or a change in operation and
maintenance costs including replacement costs.
(1980 Code page 217 ¶ 2)
10-4A-7:   NOTICE OF RATES:
The users of wastewater treatment services will be notified annually, in
conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate of that portion of the user
charges which is attributable to the wastewater treatment operation,
maintenance and replacement.
(1980 Code page 217 ¶ 3)
10-4A-8:   PAYMENT OF BILLS:
The rates or charges shall be payable monthly for residential users and monthly
for industrial and commercial users.
(1980 Code page 219 art. I § 8)
10-4A-9:   DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall
be deposited in the sewerage account of the Sewerage Fund. All such revenues
and monies shall be held by the City Treasurer separate and apart from his
private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the City, and all
of said sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the City
Treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at such
more frequent intervals as may, from time to time, be directed by the Mayor and
City Council. The City Treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the
sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of
such system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in the
account of the fund designated as the “Sewerage Fund of the City”. The
Treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by
statute of the “Revised Cities and Villages Act”, effective January, 1942 (65
ILCS).
(1980 Code page 219 art. III § 1)
10-4A-10:   ACCOUNTING:
   A.   The City Treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and
shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and
at regular annual intervals, he shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewerage system.
   B.   In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit
report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater
facilities, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service
charges under the waste cost recovery system and capital amounts required to be
recovered under the industrial cost recovery system do in fact meet these
regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit
report shall include the following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for
the current fiscal year.
      2.   Billing data to show the total number of gallons billed per fiscal
year.
      3.   Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
      4.   Number of users connected to the system.
      5.   Number of nonmetered users.
      6.   A list of users discharging nondomestic and industrial wastes and
volume of waste discharged.
(1980 Code page 220 art. III § 2)
10-4A-11:   ACCESS TO RECORDS:
The IEPA or its authorized representative shall have access to any books,
documents, papers and records of the City which are applicable to the City
system of user charges or industrial cost recovery for the purpose of making
audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance
with the terms of the special and general conditions to any State grant or any
Federal regulations and conditions of the Federal grant.
(1980 Code page 219 art. I § 9)
10-4A-12:   PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall
be fined as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
(1980 Code page 219 art. I § 12)

CHAPTER 1: GENERAL BUILDING REGULATIONS
Section
11-1-1: Building Official
11-1-2: Building Permits
11-1-3: Building Operations
11-1-4: Soil Fills
11-1-5: Building Appearance
11-1-6: Enforcement
11-1-7: Penalties
11-1-1: BUILDING OFFICIAL:
Whenever the term “Building Official” is used in this title, it shall relate to
and mean the same person who, under title 12 of this Code, “Zoning”, is
appointed as Building Official.
(1980 Code § 39-7)
11-1-2: BUILDING PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to construct or alter any
building or structure in the City where the cost of such construction or
alteration exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or where the effect of such
alteration is to enlarge the capacity or affect the bearing walls of any
building or the roof thereof without first having secured a permit therefor.
   B.   Application For Permit: Application for such permit shall be made to
the Building Official and shall be accompanied by plans and specifications in
duplicate showing the work to be done. Such plans shall be verified by the
signature of either an owner of the premises, a duly authorized agent of an
owner or the architect or contractor in charge of operations.
   C.   Examination Of Application; Approval Of Plans: The Building Official
shall examine the application, plans and specifications to determine whether
the proposed construction will comply with all ordinance provisions relating
thereto. Upon approval, one set of the plans shall be returned to the
applicant, with a permit, and the other shall be retained by the Building
Official. No permit shall be issued, except after approval of the plans and
payment of the fee herein provided.
   D.   Permit Fees: Fees for permits for building construction shall be as
follows:
 
                                                                                Greater of the fee amount listed on the “City of Watseka Building Permit Fee -
Commercial and Industrial Construction:                                         Non Residential” schedule maintained in the office of the Building Official
                                                                                corresponding to the value of the work to be undertaken or $50.00.
Residential Construction (new or additions):                                    Greater of 0.25 per square foot or $50.00
   Residential utility construction (including, but not limited to, garages,
decks, patios, utility sheds and carports, and other structures not adding      Greater of 0.15 per square foot or $50.00
living space to the residence)
Roofing                                                                         $50.00
 
   There shall be a minimum fee for all permits in the amount of fifteen
dollars ($15.00), and said fee shall be payable at the Office of the City
Collector.
   E.   Expiration And Extension Of Permits: Building permits shall expire on
the day of expiration set forth therein. Thirty (30) day extensions of such
building permits shall be allowed upon written request and payment of the sum
of fifty dollars ($50.00) per month for each such thirty (30) day request.
   F.   Variations: It shall be unlawful to vary materially from the approved
plans and specifications deposited with and approved by the Building Official,
unless amended plans and specifications showing such proposed alterations or
variations are first filed with and approved by the Building Official.
(1980 Code §§ 39-1 through 39-5; amd. Ord. 2081, 2-17-2003; Ord. 2307, 10-27-
2009; Ord. 2568, 4-28-2020; Ord. 2634, 4-26-2022)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
12-3-2 of this Code
11-1-3: BUILDING OPERATIONS:
   A.   Use Of Streets:
      1.   The use of streets for the storage of materials in the process of
construction or alteration of a building may be granted where the same will not
unduly interfere with traffic and will not reduce the usable width of the
roadway to less than eighteen feet (18').
      2.   No portion of the street, other than that directly abutting on the
premises on which work is being done, shall be used, except with the consent of
the owner or occupant of the premises abutting on such portion.
      3.   Any person seeking to make such use of the street shall file an
application for a permit therefor with the City Clerk, together with a bond
with sureties to be approved by the Clerk, to indemnify the City for any loss
or damage which may be incurred thereby by reason of such use and occupation.
(1980 Code § 39-75)
   B.   Sidewalks: No sidewalk shall be obstructed in the course of building,
construction or alteration without a special permit from the City Clerk; and
whenever the removal of a sidewalk is required in such work, a special permit
from the Clerk shall be obtained.
(1980 Code § 39-77)
   C.   Safeguards: It shall be the duty of the person or corporation doing any
construction, altering or wrecking work in the City to do the same with proper
care for the safety of persons and property. Warnings, barricades and lights
shall be maintained wherever necessary for the protection of pedestrians or
traffic; and temporary roofs over sidewalks shall be constructed wherever there
is danger from falling articles or materials to pedestrians.
(1980 Code § 39-80)
   D.   Night Operations: No construction or altering operations shall be
carried on at nighttime if the same are accompanied by loud noises.
(1980 Code § 39-76)
11-1-4: SOIL FILLS:
   A.   Permit Requirements:
      1.   Permit Required: A separate fill permit is necessary for each
location where fill is to be deposited, and no fill may be deposited within the
City without a valid permit for the site upon which fill is deposited.
      2.   Application For Permit: Applications for soil fill permits for
material to be deposited within the City limits may be applied for in writing
at the Watseka City Hall upon such forms as the Building Inspector may require
from time to time.
      3.   Term Of Permit: Fill permits shall be valid for a period of one year
after issuance.
      4.   Revocation Of Permit: Revocation of permits may occur at anytime the
Building Inspector finds a violation of the requirements of the fill or the
terms and conditions of the permit.
   B.   Contents And Quality Of Fill: All fill used within the City shall meet
or exceed the minimum requirements for fill content and quality as set forth in
the Federal Emergency Management Agency specifications and Environmental
Protection Agency rules and regulations for fill as set forth in The Flood
Plain Manual and other publications.
   C.   Time Limit For Leveling Fill: All fill transported to sites within the
City must be leveled within sixty (60) days of the fill being deposited upon
the location.
(Ord. 2139, 2-22-2005)
   D.   Penalty: Any person, firm, corporation or other entity who violates the
provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as set
forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Each day a violation of this section continues shall
constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such.
(Ord. 2139, 2-22-2005; amd. 2019 Code)
11-1-5: BUILDING APPEARANCE:
In the B-2 Central Business Zoning District, building appearance for new
construction and/or building renovations/rehabilitations shall conform to the
following requirements:
   A.   Form and Proportion: Massing and configuration (i.e., height, width,
and roofline) shall conform, as near as possible, to that of other buildings on
the same block. When a new building is proposed to be wider than the historic
twenty (20') to thirty (30') feet in width, the facade shall be visually
subdivided into proportional bays, and similar in scale to adjacent buildings.
Horizontal alignments and vertical spacing elements shall be similar to other
buildings on the same block.
   B.   Roof Forms: Rooflines shall be similar to adjacent buildings. Gable
roof shapes are acceptable if parapet walls hide the end wall and water
drainage is contained on the property. When feasible, the original roof shape
of a building shall be maintained or restored.
   C.   Windows: The window openings above the first floor shall appear as
“punched” openings within a solid wall. Proportions shall be similar to the
window openings of other buildings on the same block. New and existing
storefronts shall include the basic features of a historical storefront. A
bulkhead shall be provided separating the upper stories from the first floor.
The first floor shall have an 80%-20% glass to other material ratio. Door
openings directly onto the public sidewalk shall include/maintain a recessed
entry.
   D.   Materials: Building materials for exposed surfaces shall include brick,
stone, split-face concrete block, or an architecturally detailed exterior
insulation finish system (i.e., Dryvit). Permitted detailing materials include
cast and molded metals, wood, fiberglass replications, gypsum detailing,
structural glass when replicating a storefront design, and Dryvit. Wood, vinyl,
aluminum siding, wood asphalt, fiberglass shingles, structural ribbed panels,
corrugated metal panels, plywood sheathing, plastic or fiberglass sheathing,
reflective or moderate to high-grade tinted should be avoided, and shall not
otherwise be permitted for visible surfaces unless otherwise approved by the
Building Official taking into account conformity with other buildings on the
same block.
   E.   Architectural Details: When renovating/rehabilitating buildings, the
removal or alteration of historic architectural features should be avoided.
Recreated features shall relate to the building’s period of construction,
scale, proportions and use of materials. Existing elements not original to the
building that are historically or architecturally insignificant to the building
should be removed and replaced. Historically or architecturally significant
elements or details should remain visible. Existing brick shall be retained
wherever possible. To the extent new brick is required, the new brick shall
match the original brick and mortar for color and texture, and the width of
repointed joints should match the original.
(Ord. 2591, 10-27-2020)
11-1-6: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the Building Official and any lawfully appointed
deputies to enforce the provisions of this title. The Building Official is
hereby empowered to make such inspections as may be necessary to see to the
enforcement of these provisions, and to make any tests or examinations of
materials or methods to be used, for the purpose of seeing if they comply with
the requirements of this title.
(1980 Code § 39-6)
11-1-7: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this title shall,
upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, together
with costs of proceedings for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(1980 Code § 39-8; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2: BUILDING CODE
Section
11-2-1: Code Adopted
11-2-2: Amendments To Code
11-2-1: CODE ADOPTED:
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the Office of the
City Clerk at the Watseka City Hall, 201 Brianna Drive, Watseka, Illinois
60970, being marked and designated as the International Building Code, 2006
edition, as published by the International Code Council, including all of the
appendices thereto, is hereby adopted as the Building Code of the City for
regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property,
buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and
facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that
structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the
condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and
the demolition of such structures as herein provided; providing for the
issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the
regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Building Code
on file in the Office of the City Clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and
made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions,
insertions, deletions and changes prescribed in section
11-2-2 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2209, 10-16-2006)

(Ord. 2209, 10-16-2006)

CHAPTER 4: USE OF SOLAR ENERGY
Section
