11-4-1: COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS:
Any building hereafter constructed or remodeled wherein the use of solar energy
is incorporated in said construction or remodeling shall be built or remodeled
in accordance with the standards as are set forth in “Solar Dwelling Design
Concepts”, published May 1976 by the Office of Policy Development and Research
of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, and all
subsequent published amendments thereof.
(1980 Code § 39-125)
CHAPTER 5: FIRE LIMITS
Section
11-5-1: Boundaries
11-5-2: Repairs
11-5-3: Penalties
11-5-1: BOUNDARIES:
That portion of the City within the following described boundaries is hereby
designated and established as the fire limits of the City:
Commencing at the West end of Oak Street, thence East along the center line of
Oak Street to the center line of Fifth Street, thence South along the center
line of Fifth Street to the center line of Cherry Street, thence West along the
center line of Cherry Street to the center line of First Street as originally
platted, (now the L & N Railroad and formerly the Missouri Pacific and Union
Pacific Railroad), thence North along the center line of said First Street to a
place where the center line of Oak Street as extended would be intersected,
thence East to the place of the beginning.
(1980 Code § 39-10)
11-5-2: REPAIRS:
It shall be unlawful to repair any existing frame building within the fire
limits after the same shall be damaged by any cause in an amount exceeding
fifty percent (50%) of its value; provided, that in such event, the building
may be completely rebuilt with fireproof materials.
(1980 Code § 39-12)
11-5-3: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, together with costs of proceedings
for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(1980 Code § 39-15; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 6: PLUMBING REGULATIONS
Section
11-6-1: Plumbing Inspector
11-6-2: State Plumbing Code
11-6-1: PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
The plumbing inspector for the City is a position that is hired out as needed.
The inspector shall be a licensed plumber.
(1980 Code § 41-1; amd. 2019 Code)
11-6-2: STATE PLUMBING CODE:
All plumbing in the City must comply with the Illinois Plumbing Code.
CHAPTER 7: ELECTRICAL CODE AND REGULATIONS
Section
11-7-1: Definition
11-7-2: Compliance Required; Exceptions
11-7-3: Permit Requirements
11-7-4: Certificate Of Approval
11-7-5: Penalty
11-7-1: DEFINITION:
The term ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT, as used in this chapter, means the definition of
such equipment as set forth in the National Electrical Code, as published by
the National Fire Protection Association, and as from time to time hereafter
amended. It does not include apparatus, conductors, or other equipment
installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are
under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission, for use in their
operation as public utilities.
(Ord. 2320, 6-22-2010)
11-7-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   All electrical wiring, apparatus, equipment, or appliances for
furnishing light, heat, or power shall be in strict conformity with approved
methods and practices for safety to life and property and in accordance with
the National Electrical Code, as published by the National Fire Protection
Association, and as from time to time hereafter amended.
(Ord. 2320, 6-22-2010)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to repair or
install any electrical wiring or electrical equipment within the City, unless
the repairs or installations are made in strict compliance with the provisions
of this chapter. This subsection shall not apply to repairs or installations
made on: 1) radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and
signals; or 2) apparatus conductors or other equipment installed for or by
public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction
of the Illinois Commerce Commission for use in their operation as public
utilities.
(1980 Code § 40-41)
   C.   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the installation of
new merchandise or equipment, electrically operated, or to any such equipment
which is used and has been repaired by a duly licensed electrical contractor,
where nothing more is required for the installation of the equipment other than
to plug it into already existing electrical conduits or sockets.
(1980 Code § 40-44)
11-7-3: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to install or alter any
electrical equipment or wiring subject to registration under Title 4, Chapter
13 of this Code without having first secured a permit therefor.
   B.   Application For Permit; Issuance: Applications for permits shall be
made in writing to the City Clerk and shall be referred by him to the
Electrical Inspector. Each application shall contain the name of the owner of
the premises to be served, the name of the contractor doing the work and the
nature of the work to be done. Where the work consists of new or extensive
repairs or alterations, plans and specifications of the work shall accompany
the application. Upon approval of the application by the Electrical Inspector,
the permit shall be issued by the City Clerk.
   C.   Permit Fee: Where any electrical equipment or wiring is installed or
altered in connection with the erection of a new building or in connection with
the alteration or repair of a building, for which a permit and a fee are
required under the Building Code or the zoning ordinance, no additional fee
shall be required for the permit to be issued hereunder. For all other
electrical permits, the fee for the permit shall be two percent (2%) of the
cost of the repairs or installation to be made, but in no event less than fifty
dollars ($50.00).
   D.   Service Providers: No electrical service provider shall make an
electrical connection to a property (be it newly constructed or altered) unless
an electrical permit has been issued by the Electrical Inspector for the work
and the electrical service provider's requirements for the supply of electric
service has been satisfied.
(1980 Code §§ 40-42 and 40-43) (Ord. 2526, 11-23-2021)
11-7-4: CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
   A.   The Electrical Inspector shall issue a certificate of approval after
each inspection in which the wiring or apparatus is found to be in compliance
with the terms of this chapter and all amendments hereto.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to use or to turn on electrical power into any
wires or apparatus hereafter installed for which a certificate has not been
issued because the permit was not secured for the installation or because the
work was not completed according to the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   No electrical service provider shall make initiate or restore
electrical service to a property (be it newly constructed or altered) unless a
certificate of approval has been issued by the Electrical Inspector. The
electrical service provider shall not consider a connection to be a final
connection until and unless a certificate of approval has been issued.
(1980 Code § 40-45) (Ord. 2526, 11-23-2021)
11-7-5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(1980 Code § 40-50; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 8: FENCES
Section
11-8-1: Definitions
11-8-2: Permit Requirements; Exemptions
11-8-3: Variations From Plans
11-8-4: Height Of Fences Generally
11-8-5: Location And Height Of Certain Fences
11-8-6: Penalty
11-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
Words used in this chapter shall be defined and have the following meanings:
LOT LINE, FRONT: The line dividing a lot from a street. On a corner lot, only
one street line shall be considered as a front; provided, that where the length
of a shorter line is less than eighty percent (80%) of the length of a longer
line, the shorter street shall be considered as the front.
SETBACK LINE: The line established by the minimum yard requirements of the
standard use requirements for the zoning district and use applicable to a
particular lot.
SITE LINE: Where more than one side of a lot faces a street, the setback line
on those parts of the lot facing the street must equal the front yard setback
line for that district.
(1980 Code § 39A-6)
11-8-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to construct, erect, or emplace
any fence within the corporate limits of the City without first having secured
a permit therefor.
   B.   Application For Permit:
      1.   Application for a fence permit shall be made to the Building
Official and shall be accompanied by plans and specifications showing the work
to be done. Such plans shall be verified by the signature of either an owner of
the premises, a duly authorized agent or contractor in charge of the
operations.
      2.   Applicants for fence permits shall evidence the lot lines next to
the street to the Building Official to determine the appropriate setback. The
Building Official shall also determine if the type of fence and other
information provided by the application is in accordance with the ordinances of
the City prior to the issuance of a permit, but the Building Official, in
issuing the permit, shall not be empowered or responsible for determining lot
lines of private owners with adjoining private lots.
   C.   Permit Fee: The fee for fence permits shall be in the amount of fifty
dollars ($50.00), and payment of the fee shall accompany the application for
the permit.
   D.   Exemptions: Fences less than two feet (2') in height are exempt from
any requirement under this chapter to obtain a fence permit or to pay a fee for
the same but are otherwise subject to all of the other provisions of this
chapter.
(1980 Code §§ 39A-2, 39A-3, and 39A-4; amd. Ord. 2377, 8-28-2012; Ord. 2634, 4-
26-2022)
11-8-3: VARIATIONS FROM PLANS:
It shall be unlawful to vary materially from the approved plans and
specifications filed with and approved by the Building Official unless amended
plans and specifications showing such proposed alterations or variations are
first filed with and approved by the Building Official.
(1980 Code § 39A-5)
11-8-4: HEIGHT OF FENCES GENERALLY:
   A.   No fence exceeding the height of the four and one-half feet (41/2')
shall be permitted in or on any portion of a residential lot having frontage
upon a street.
   B.   No fence within the City limits shall exceed six and one-half feet (61/
2') on any residential lot.
(Ord. 2144, 4-18-2005)
11-8-5: LOCATION AND HEIGHT OF CERTAIN FENCES:
   A.   Stockade Fences: No stockade-type fence shall be permitted in or on the
front portion of a lot nearer to the street than a line to be determined by the
greatest distance of the following:
      1.   The setback line for that district and use; or
      2.   The front portion of any structure upon the lot.
   B.   Corner Lot Fences:
      1.   For corner lots, no stockade-type fence, nor any other type fence
exceeding four and one-half feet (41/2') in height, shall be constructed,
erected or emplaced closer to the street than the setback line or the actual
building, whichever is greater. Where no building exists on the lot, no such
fence shall be constructed, erected or emplaced nearer to the street than the
applicable setback line for the most restrictive use of the applicable
district.
(Ord. 2144, 4-18-2005)
      2.   Fences on all corner lots shall be restricted to four and one-half
feet (41/2') in height on all exterior lot lines of said lots, being lot lines
that front on streets, and fences on corner lots shall have a ten foot (10')
setback line on all such lot lines that front on streets. No such fences shall
be erected upon easements and/or rights-of-way.
(Ord. 2266, 6-10-2008)
   C.   Prohibited On Easements And Rights-Of-Way: Fences on all lots shall not
be erected upon easements and/or rights-of-way.
(Ord. 2377, 8-28-2012)
11-8-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, corporation or entity who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects
or refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions
of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day a violation
occurs or continues.
(1980 Code § 39A-8)
CHAPTER 9: PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS
Section
11-9-1: Definition
11-9-2: Compliance With Provisions
11-9-3: Permit Requirements
11-9-4: Location
11-9-5: Method Of Disinfection
11-9-6: Fencing And Gates
11-9-7: Electrical Requirements
11-9-8: Nuisance Conditions Prohibited
11-9-9: Maintenance Required; Inspections
11-9-10: Penalty
11-9-1: DEFINITION:
A SWIMMING POOL, within the meaning of this section, shall be any depression in
the ground, either temporary or permanent, or a container of water, either
temporary or permanent, and either above or below the ground, in which water of
more than twenty four inches (24") in depth is contained and which is used
primarily for the purpose of bathing and swimming.
(1980 Code § 39-201)
11-9-2: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install, or enlarge any
privately owned or operated swimming pool, not enclosed in a permanent building
in the City, except in accordance with the regulations of this chapter.
(1980 Code § 39-200)
11-9-3: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install, enlarge, or alter
any private swimming pool unless a building permit and performance bond have
first been obtained from the Building Official. The permit fee shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00). Application shall be on forms provided by the Building
Official and shall be accompanied by plans drawn to scale showing the
following:
   A.   Pool dimensions and volume of water in gallons.
   B.   Location and type of waste disposal system.
   C.   Location of pool on lot, distance from lot lines, and distance from
structure.
   D.   Fencing and landscape plan, or a combination thereof.
(1980 Code § 39-202; amd. Ord. 2634, 4-26-2022)
11-9-4: LOCATION:
No pool shall be located erected, constructed or maintained closer to any side
or rear lot line than allowed by the zoning ordinance for permitted accessory
building uses.
(1980 Code § 39-203)
11-9-5: METHOD OF DISINFECTION:
Gaseous chlorination system shall not be made use of as a disinfection method
for pool waters. The Building Official shall recommend a proper disinfectant.
(1980 Code § 39-203)
11-9-6: FENCING AND GATES:
   A.   Pools within the scope of this chapter or not enclosed within a
permanent building shall be completely enclosed by a fence of sufficient
strength to prevent access to the pool and shall be not less than four feet
(4') in height, so constructed as not to have voids, holes or openings larger
than four inches (4") in one dimension. Gates or doors shall be equipped with a
self-closing and self- latching device for keeping the gate or door securely
closed at all times when not in actual use.
   B.   Aboveground pools with self-provided fencing to prevent unguarded entry
will be allowed without separate additional fencing, provided the self-provided
fencing is of the minimum height and design as heretofore specified.
Aboveground pools with a height of more than four (4) feet shall be permanent
without fencing provided that the means of access to such pool may be secured
by lifting or removing stairs or ladders or means of entry are equipped with
self-closing and self-latching devices.
   C.   Location or fencing required shall be subject to all other applicable
ordinances.
   D.   The wall of the house or building faced to a pool may be incorporated
as a portion of the fence.
(1980 Code § 39-204) (Ord. 1859, 3-24-1997)
11-9-7: ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Compliance With State And City Laws: All electrical installations
provided, installed, and used in conjunction with a private swimming pool shall
be in conformance with State laws and City ordinances regulating electric
installations (See chapter 7 of this title).
   B.   Overhead Lighting: If overhead floodlights or other artificial lights
are used to illuminate the pool at night, such lights shall be shielded to
direct light only on the pool.
(1980 Code § 39-205)
11-9-8: NUISANCE CONDITIONS PROHIBITED:
No pool shall be so operated or maintained as to create a nuisance, a hazard,
an eyesore, or otherwise to result in a substantial adverse effect on
neighboring properties, or to be in any other way detrimental to public health,
safety, and welfare.
(1980 Code § 39-206)
11-9-9: MAINTENANCE REQUIRED; INSPECTIONS:
A swimming pool or swimming pools shall be maintained in a sanitary manner. The
Building Official or Code Enforcement Official may inspect or cause to be
inspected each private swimming pool maintained in the City.
(1980 Code § 39-207)
11-9-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(1980 Code § 39-208)
CHAPTER 10: MOVING BUILDINGS
Section
11-10-1: Permit Requirements
11-10-2: Bond Requirements
11-10-3: Procedures For Moving Buildings
11-10-4: Penalty
11-10-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person, firm or corporation shall move any building
on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the
City without having obtained a permit therefor from the City.
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for such permits shall be made in
writing to the City Clerk and shall state thereon the proposed route and number
of days it is intended that the building should occupy any portion of any
street, alley, sidewalk or other public place.
(1980 Code § 23-145)
   C.   Approval Of Route; Permit Fee: Upon the approval of the intended route
by the Public Works Committee, the applicant and permittee shall pay to the
City Clerk a fee which fee shall entitle the applicant and permittee to use the
public streets, alleys and ways of the City on the route approved by the Public
Works Committee for a period of one day for the purpose of moving the building
for which the permit is granted hereunder. If it shall require the permittee
more than one day in which to move said building, he shall pay to the City
Clerk for each day or fraction thereof over and above the first day used to
move said building.
(1980 Code § 23-146)
   D.   Issuance Of Permit: Upon the compliance with the provisions of this
chapter and the payment of the fees herein provided, the City Clerk shall sign
and issue a permit to the applicant for the moving of the building on the
intended route.
(1980 Code § 23-147)
11-10-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Every person, firm or corporation applying for a permit under this chapter
shall submit with his application a cash bond or a bond with a lawful corporate
surety or a personal bond signed by two (2) or more responsible freeholders of
the City, conditioned on his compliance with all the provisions of this
chapter, and agreeing to pay and hold the City harmless from any claim which
may be made against it by reason of the occupation of any street, sidewalk,
alley or other public place by the building or structure moved, and agreeing to
reimburse and pay the City for all damages which may be caused to its streets,
alleys or other public ways by virtue of the moving of the building or
structure in question. The amount of the bond shall be at least twenty five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00) and it shall be approved by the City Clerk.
(1980 Code § 23-148)
11-10-3: PROCEDURES FOR MOVING BUILDINGS:
   A.   Lights And Warning Devices: The person, firm or corporation moving any
building or structure through the streets or other public ways of the City
shall keep warning signs and lanterns or lights during all hours on the
building or structure so as to guard against any person or vehicle colliding
therewith. The permittee shall also set out such flares and erect such
barricades and take any and all other steps which shall be necessary to warn
the public and protect it from colliding with the building or structure.
(1980 Code § 23-149)
   B.   Utility Wires Or Cables: Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere
with the wires or cables of a public utility in moving a building, the terms of
any existing special or franchise ordinance governing this subject matter shall
apply.
(1980 Code § 23-150)
   C.   Trimming Trees: The permittee shall trim, at his own expense, all trees
required to be trimmed for the purpose of moving the building or structure, but
no trees shall be trimmed by the permittee until the Public Works Committee has
approved the proposed trimming to be done thereby.
(1980 Code § 23-151)
11-10-4: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(1980 Code § 23-152)
CHAPTER 11: DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS
Section
11-11-1: Permit Required; Qualifications; Restrictions
11-11-2: Permit Fee
11-11-3: Application For Permit
11-11-4: Issuance Or Denial Of Permit
11-11-5: Permit Nontransferable
11-11-6: Permit Expiration
11-11-7: Asbestos Remediation
11-11-8: Insurance Requirements
11-11-9: Project Commencement; Site Preparation and Security
11-11-10: Dust Control
11-11-11: Traffic Control
11-11-12: Location and Protection of Utilities
11-11-13: Authorized Fill
11-11-14: Unsuitable Materials; Contamination
11-11-15: Site Maintenance
11-11-16: Foundation Walls and Slabs
11-11-17: Grading and Seeding
11-11-18: Acts Prohibited
11-11-19: Penalty
11-11-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; QUALIFICATIONS; RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to for any person or entity to engage in demolition
activities with respect to any building or structure without a demolition
permit. Only bona-fide and licensed wrecking or excavating companies shall be
eligible for a demolition permit to engage in demolition activities affecting
non-residential buildings or structures or any buildings or structures located
outside of a residential zoning district.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-2: PERMIT FEE:
The fee for a demolition permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), which shall be
payable at the time of application and shall be non-refundable.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
An application for a demolition permit, signed and verified by the owner (the
"permittee") of the property on which the building or structures to be
demolished are located, or the owner's agent, shall be filed with the Building
Official and shall include the following information:
   A.   The street address of the building or structure to be demolished.
   B.   A plan for demolition and a schedule of time to complete the demolition
activities.
   C.   The name and address of the contractor to perform the demolition work,
including a copy of the contractor's license, as applicable.
   D.   Evidence the permittee has satisfied the insurance requirements of this
chapter.
   E.   The name and address of the landfill at that the permittee will use to
dispose of Unsuitable Materials, as defined herein.
   F.   If the building or structure is infested with rodents or insects, the
applicant shall supply documentation that such infestation has been eliminated.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-4: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT:
The Building Official shall review the demolition permit application and shall
issue a demolition permit within five (5) days after receipt provided all
information and documentation required to be included has been supplied, the
information evidences that the demolition project will be completed in
compliance with this chapter in all aspects, and the application fee has been
paid. Any denial of a demolition permit shall be issued in writing with the
basis for such denial stated. Any denial of a demolition permit is appealable
to the City Council provided the permittee files his appeal, which shall
include a copy of the Building Officials written denial, within thirty (30)
days following the dated date of the denial letter.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-5: PERMIT NONTRANSFERABLE:
Once issued, a demolition permit is not transferable to any other person or
property.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-6: PERMIT EXPIRATION:
A demolition permit will be valid for sixty (60) days but shall be subject to
thirty (30) day extensions for good cause shown.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-7: ASBESTOS REMEDIATION:
The permittee shall comply with applicable laws (including Iroquois County),
and the regulations and rules of the IEPA and IDPH governing the inspection,
remediation, and disposal of asbestos encountered during demolition activities.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-8: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
The permittee shall obtain and shall at all times maintain insurance in a form
approved by the City evidencing that permittee has a policy of comprehensive
general liability insurance naming "City of Watseka, its officers, employees
and each of their respective successors and assigns as their interests may
appear," the owners of any utilities traversing the property, and adjoining
property owners as additional insured parties, insuring permittee's demolition
activities upon, in or about the property against claims or bodily injury or
death or property damage or loss with a combined single limit of not less than
Three Hundred Thousand Dollars ($300,000). The policy shall stipulate that the
insurance afforded to the additional insureds shall apply as primary insurance
and that those commercial general liability insurance policies carried by the
additional insureds shall be non-contributory with respect to any losses or
claims. Such insurance policy shall be with a company licensed in the State of
Illinois, and such policy shall provide that it is not subject to cancellation
or reduction in coverage except after thirty (30) days' prior written notice to
the additional insureds. The permittee shall submit certificates evidencing the
existence and amount of the insurance policy when submitting its application.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-9: PROJECT COMMENCEMENT; SITE PREPARATION AND SECURITY:
   A.   Subject to the below requirements for site preparation and security,
demolition activities may commence upon the issuance of a demolition permit and
shall continue in a diligent manner without interruption or delay through
completion.
   B.   No demolition activities shall be commenced until the permittee
furnishes and erects a six (6') foot chain link security fence around the
perimeter of the project site. Such fence shall be maintained by the permittee
on the project site until completion.
   C.   No demolition activities shall be commenced until the permittee
provides proper and adequate shoring to protect and brace pavements, sidewalks,
adjacent buildings, fences and other structures not subject to demolition, so
as to prevent any settlement, collapse or other damage to these structures.
Such shoring shall remain in place until existing elements to remain can
properly be supported by fill or other acceptable measures.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-10: DUST CONTROL:
The permittee shall control the dust and air-borne dirt generated by the
demolition activities. The implementation of dust control procedures shall be
required if wind and dry soil conditions reduce visibility on adjacent property
or the right-of-way. Concerns for health and safety to the public using
adjacent facilities will be grounds for the implementation of a dust control
plan. The permittee and the Building Official shall review the nature and
extent of dust generating activities and cooperate to develop specific types of
control techniques appropriated for the situation. Sample techniques that may
warrant consideration include such measures as:
   A.   Minimization of the track out of soil to nearby public areas; and
   B.   Use of "wet saws" when cutting materials.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-11: TRAFFIC CONTROL:
To the extent required by the Building Official, the permittee shall provide
traffic control in accordance with applicable sections of the Illinois
Department of Transportation, Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction and applicable guidelines contained in the Illinois Manual on
Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways. The permittee shall
obtain, erect, maintain, and remove all signs, barricades, flagmen and other
traffic control devices as may be necessary for the purpose of warning or
guiding traffic. Placement and maintenance of all traffic control devices shall
be in accordance with the applicable parts of Article 107.14 of the Standard
Specifications and the Illinois Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for
Streets and Highways. The permittee shall be solely responsible for ensuring
that all traffic control devices are installed and maintained in accordance
with applicable state standards.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-12: LOCATION AND PROTECTION OF UTILITIES:
The permittee shall inspect each location, identify the existence and location
of all utilities, contact the owners thereof for notification of vertical/
horizontal separations, comply with all other safety requirements required by
the owners of such utilities, and observe such requirements as necessary at all
times. The permittee shall notify J.U.L.I.E. (811) at least forty-eight (48)
hours prior to any excavation to verify locations of all utilities. Existing
public utilities, such as water mains, sewers, gas lines, streetlights,
telephone lines, electric power lines, cable television, etc., shall be
protected against damage by the permittee. The permittee shall disconnect and
cap the water service connection at the curb stop or meter pit. The permittee
shall disconnect, bring above-grade and cap the sanitary service connection at
the property line. The water and sewer service connections shall be inspected
by the Public Works Director prior to backfilling. The permittee must maintain
all utility services which may traverse the project site serving adjacent
properties, and any such damage to said utilities shall be repaired at once at
the permittee's expense, so that no adjacent property is without such services.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-13: AUTHORIZED FILL:
Concrete foundation walls and slabs, and bricks, shall be broken into pieces no
larger than three (3') square feet and left in place for use as fill. All other
fill shall consist of compacted aggregate material. The top twelve (12") inches
of each demolition site shall be filled with topsoil and graded to provide
positive drainage. Only clean demolished brick and concrete material shall be
used as fill. All material used as fill shall be accounted for by the permittee
in applicable quantities.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-14: UNSUITABLE MATERIALS; CONTAMINATION:
   A.   All materials not used or suitable for fill (the "Unsuitable
Materials") shall be hauled away, as it accumulates, by the permittee, and
disposed of at facilities qualified to accept the same, depending on the
nature, under applicable law. Unsuitable Materials shall be transported and
disposed of at facilities that can legally accept new construction, excavation,
and demolition materials for the purpose of re-use, recycling, composting or
disposal. Only Building Official-approved facilities shall be used by the
permittee to dispose of Unsuitable Materials. The permittee shall supply to the
Building Official load tickets and landfill receipts from qualified facilities
evidencing proper disposal of Unsuitable Materials. The disposition of all
Unsuitable Materials shall be accounted for by the permittee in applicable
quantities.
   B.   If encountered, the removal and proper disposal of hazardous
substances, hazardous materials and contaminated soil, water, and or
underground storage tanks (UST) shall be performed meeting all requirements of
the IEPA and the Office of the State Fire Marshal. The City shall be
immediately notified if such conditions are encountered.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-15: SITE MAINTENANCE:
The permittee shall maintain the project site in a clean condition, and free of
accumulation of debris. Unsuitable Materials shall not be stored at the project
site at in excess of two (2) working days.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
 11-11-16: FOUNDATION WALLS AND SLABS:
All foundation walls and slabs of building or structures demolished shall be
demolished and removed from the project site unless used as fill. No filling
activities shall be commenced until foundation walls and slabs are inspected by
the City to ensure broken for proper drainage.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-17: GRADING AND SEEDING:
The project site shall be graded to its pre-work elevation and seeded no later
than ten (10) days following the completion of demolition and fill activities.
The permittee shall seed and straw the project site, or have a hydro-seed
product installed, before final inspection. Only dormant seeding shall be
permitted through the months of October and March.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-18: ACTS PROHIBITED:
A permittee shall not:
   A.   Conduct demolition activities before sunrise or after sunset;
   B.   Use explosives as a means to demolish buildings or structures;
   C.   Burn, or cause to be burned, at any time, any materials;
   D.   Initiate demolition work prior to pumping out and disposing of water
that may have accumulated in the building or structure; or
   E.   Illegally dispose of or dump materials.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
11-11-19: PENALTY:
Any person or entity violating any of the provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2657, 8-23-2022)
CHAPTER 12: NUMBERING LOTS AND STRUCTURES
Section
11-12-1: Numbering Plan
11-12-2: Duty To Number
11-12-3: Assignment Of Numbers
11-12-4: Street Number Chart
11-12-1: NUMBERING PLAN:
All lots, buildings and structures in the City shall be numbered in accordance
with the following plan:
The base line for streets running north and south shall be Walnut Street, and
numbers lying north and south thereof shall be designated as North, or South,
as the case may be, provided that, where Walnut Street meets or intersects with
Fleming Street, the base line for streets running north and south shall be
Fleming Street from that point on west and Walnut Street from that point on
east shall be used as the base line. The base line for streets running East and
West shall be Third Street, and all numbers lying East or West of this line
shall be designated East or West, as the case may be. Numbering shall begin
with the base lines with the number one hundred (100), shall be consecutive,
and one unit may be allowed for each twenty five feet (25') of frontage. The
numbering on each block shall begin with one hundred (100) or a multiple
thereof. Odd numbers shall be on the south and west sides of the streets. Even
numbers shall be on the north and east sides of the streets.
(1980 Code § 39-141)
11-12-2: DUTY TO NUMBER:
It shall be the duty of the owner and occupant of every building in the City to
have placed thereon, in a place readily visible from the street, the street
number of the building. The figures of each street number shall be at least
three inches (3") in height. Any person, firm or corporation, having a duty to
number a building in accordance with this chapter and having failed to do so
after having received a notice to do so from the Building Official for each day
on which the failure to number the building continues.
(1980 Code § 39-142)
11-12-3: ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS:
It shall be the duty of the Building Official to assign or have assigned to
each and every building, store or residence its proper number. The Building
Official may also renumber or change any existing numbers, upon notice to the
owner or occupant of the building, so as to make the numbers conform to this
chapter.
(1980 Code § 39-143)
11-12-4: STREET NUMBER CHART:
The Building Official shall keep a chart showing the proper street number of
every lot, building and structure in the City, which chart shall be open to
inspection by anyone interested.
(1980 Code § 39-144)
TITLE 12: ZONING
Chapter
